headline: RARA AVIS FINDS A NICHE IN WORLD OF COMIC BOOKS
abstract: The balloons are familiar, as are the comic-book faces from which they issue. But the words inside the balloons are startlingly different.   ''Aspice, usitatum automatum temporis emi!'' one says. Another exclaims, ''Nil quidem! Vetus enim televisificum instrumentum inerat.'' In the English version these balloons say, ''Look! I've bought a second-hand time machine,'' and ''No! There was only this old television set which is still here.''

headline: PERSONAL FINANCE; CHECKING OUT RETIREMENT PLAN OPTIONS
abstract: IF you are a corporate employee, retirement plan options that shelter earned income from Federal income taxes may be more available than you realize. They bear an alphabet-soup array of names and have different rules, with some serving particular needs better than o thers.  One such program is the Qualified Voluntary Employee Contribution Plan, or QVEC. Obtainable only through an employer on a voluntary basis, these plans let employees deduct up to $2,000 of earnings from Federal income taxes, with the money invested and compounded taxfree. When authorized by the plan, proceeds may be withdrawn before the employee reaches age 59 1/2 or incurs a disability, but in that case they may be subject to a tax penalty of 10 percent of the amount received.

headline: Japan Cartel Extension
abstract: The Japanese Government's Fair Trade Commission said today that it had approved a three-month extension of the antirecession cartel of 12 Japanese petrochemical companies to regulate ethylene production because of low domestic demand. The producers in the cartel may run their operations at 55.9 percent of capacity and produce 845,000 tons in the three months ending in June, down 9.2 percent from the same 1982 period, it said. Under the previous cartel agreement the companies cut ethylene production to 1.56 million tons in the five and a half months ended Thursday.

headline: Choices Asked On Fed Chief
abstract: The Reagan Administration has been asking the chief executive officers of the nation's largest banks to recommend individuals who might succeed Paul A. Volcker as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. Mr. Volcker's term as chairman expires in August.   According to banking sources, Walter B. Wriston, chairman of Citicorp, recommended G.A. Costanzo, who retired in 1981 as Citicorp's vice chairman.

headline: Money Supply Up $7 Billion; Sharp Jump Causes Rise In Bond Rates
abstract: The Federal Reserve yesterday reported a $7 billion increase in the nation's money supply for the week ended May 11, far above the $4 billion rise that many analysts had predicted.   Treasury bond prices fell sharply and yields rose in response to the late afternoon announcement of the rise in M-1, the measure of currency and checking deposits readily available for spending. The new price drops brought the total bond decline over the last two weeks to about five points, or $50 for each $1,000 issue. Three-month Treasury bill rates rose yesterday by more than two-tenths of a percentage point.

headline: Data Bank; May 8, 1983
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: AMERICAN EXPRESS EXPANDS SYSTEM OF TELLER MACHINES
abstract: In an effort to capture a larger share of the credit card market, American Express is expanding its automatic teller machine service to more regions of the country, as well as to nonbanking locations. In the process, it is drawing criticism from bankers, who say American Express is encroaching on their territory.   The Express Cash system, first offered to all American Express members last summer, allows card holders to draw, for a $1 fee per transaction, up to $500 a week from 24-hour cash machines at 704 banks around the country. An additional 504 machines are to be added to the system in the near future. Of these, 289 will be installed at Publix Super Markets in Florida in an agreement reached with Sun Banks of Florida.

headline: CLUES TO TRUE POWER OF ANDROPOV ARE EXPECTED AT MOSCOW MEETINGS
abstract: Two meetings of the Soviet leadership here next week are expected to throw light on key questions that have arisen about the health of Yuri V. Andropov and his hold on power in the seven months since he became leader of the Communist Party.   Recently, he has not acted so forcefully nor looked so vigorous as he did in his first weeks in power. There are growing doubts among Western diplomats and analysts about whether he has the physical strength or political clout to move any more people of his choice into positions of power than he already has, and whether he can break the bureaucratic inertia responsible for the sluggish state of the country's economy.   Unless other events intervene, the party's Central Committee will meet for its regular summer session, a session that might authorize new appointments to the bodies exercising control - the Politburo and the Secretariat.   The Central Committee session will be followed on Thursday by a meeting of the Supreme Soviet, the country's nominal Parliament, which has the power to fill the post of chief of state, vacant since Leonid I. Brezhnev died in November.

headline: TRANSAMERICA UP
abstract: The RCA Corporation said yesterday that its first-quarter profits declined 46.6 percent from the 1982 quarter, when results were inflated by nonrecurring gains. Excluding those gains, the company's first-quarter profit would have risen 47.5 percent, the company said.    ''Earnings were better than anticipated a few months ago and RCA's business environment appears to be gradually strengthening,'' RCA's chairman, Thornton F. Bradshaw, said in a prepared statement.

headline: Cluett Plans Sale
abstract: Cluett, Peabody & Company, a New York-based apparel concern, said it would sell Boyd's, the last of its specialty store group, and said it had begun discussions with a group of investors interested in the eight Boyd's stores. Cluett said it would provide a reserve of six cents a share in the second quarter to cover combined costs of the disposal, the recent withdrawal from its Young Quinlan store in Minneapolis and the discontinuance of its Retail Stores division. The company said the operations did not project a near-term potential for reaching target levels of return on investment.

headline: ISRAELIS REACT WITH CALM TO HUSSEIN DECISION
abstract: Israeli officials reacted with calm and nonchalance today to the news that King Hussein had abandoned his talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization and would not enter negotiations with Israel on the future of the occupied West Bank.   No formal statement was issued by the Israeli Government. But officials familiar with the thinking of Prime Minister Menachem Begin and other Cabinet members said they had never expected the Jordanian leader to come into talks and were therefore not at all surprised by the announcement. They said they believed the King's failure to move had effectively killed President Reagan's Middle East peace plan.

headline: Squibb Files Suit
abstract: The Squibb Corporation has sued Diagnostic Medical Instruments Inc. and seven of its employees on charges of misappropriating trade secrets. All of the employees worked for Squibb's subsidiary, Instruments for Cardiac Research Inc., before joining Diagnostic Medical. The action, filed in United States District Court in Syracuse, seeks an injunction against shipping certain cardiac monitoring systems made by Diagnostic Research, and unspecified damages.

headline: Prospects
abstract: Talk of Two Tax Bills   From the House Ways and Means Committee comes talk of two tax bills this year. One is an expected move to cap the third year of the President's individual tax cut, which is effective July 1. The Democratic leadership in the House, pushing the fairness issue, wants to deny a further break for the wealthy.   The second bill, which would come later, would be needed to raise the additional revenue required by the fiscal 1984 budget resolution - that is, if the House and Senate can reach agreement during conference committee negotiations on the resolution that begin this week.

headline: Dow Advances 4.16, to 1,117.65
abstract: Stock market prices closed slightly higher yesterday, with some of the retailing issues making the best gains.  The Dow Jones industrial average, which moved in a narrow price range throughout the session, ended up 4.16 points, at 1,117.65. In the previous four trading days, the key average tumbled almost 30 points mainly because of concern that interest rates would rise.

headline: THE ADVANTAGES OF GOING PRIVATE
abstract: Going public is almost always a bonanza for the owners of young, growing companies. The founders sell some of their shares to the public and put cash in the bank. But financial strategy is coming full circle. Now, taking companies private is becoming lucrative and popular as well.   More and increasingly larger companies are buying back their shares and becoming closely held again, mainly through daring financial deals known as leveraged buyouts.   The latest case is Norton Simon Inc. A group led by its chairman and chief executive, David J. Mahoney, last week proposed a $1.65 billion deal to take the consumer products company private. Then last night, Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, an investment firm that specializes in assembling leveraged buyouts, made a higher offer for a competing group.

headline: Advertising; Packaging Aid for Olympics
abstract: PROCTER & GAMBLE and Woman's Day magazine have joined together for a monster, long-playing couponing effort that is intended to sell products for Procter and jazz up the image of Woman's Day while at the same time trying to raise $10 million for the United States Olympic Team.   It is what is being called a ''charity overlay'' in marketing circles. Last month the National Easter Seal Society, working with 12 manufacturing companies, thought it was asking a lot, shooting for $1.5 million. In 1981 General Foods only sought $1 million for Muscular Dystrophy.

headline: Quanex Refinancing
abstract: The Quanex Corporation, which makes steel products, said yesterday it had signed an interim refinancing agreement with its lenders covering $170.8 million of debt.

headline: Realty Credit Ads Challenged
abstract: Home builders and real estate agents in 16 metropolitan areas have increased their ''deplorably low'' 13 percent compliance rate with credit advertising laws to more than 84 percent under a Federal Trade Commission project that is being expanded nationwide, James C. Miller 3d, the agency's chairman, said today.   He added at a news conference that the six-month pilot project involved reviewing all newspaper display ads in the 16 major housing markets and sending more than 1,500 letters to advertisers pointing out where their ads did not comply with the law.

headline: PROFILE OF COMPUTER BUYERS
abstract: Who owns what type of home computers? Public opinion polls differ on specifics but are beginning to provide a profile. Following are a few of the polls' findings:   - Between 3 percent and 5 percent of the nation's households have computers. That would translate into between 2.4 million and 4 million computers in American homes.

headline: THE MARKET'S LITTLE WINNERS
abstract: When the stock market began climbing last August like an inspired mountain goat, Carol A. Ruth didn't rush right out and buy something. In fact, she waited until April before making her choices.   ''Three weeks ago I bought 100 shares of Chrysler at 20,'' said Miss Ruth, the senior vice president of a Manhattan public relations firm. ''It's about 26 now, which isn't a lot, but I think it's terrific.'' She laughed in describing her $600 profit, adding, ''I'm excited.''

headline: Superior Oil Unit To Study All Bids
abstract: The Superior Oil Company said that, though there are no offers for the company at present, its board had adopted a resolution calling for the creation of a special committee of outside directors to review any possible offer for 45 percent or more of the company's stock.   The resolution conforms to a much-contested recommendation by a shareholder, Willametta Keck Day, daughter of the founder of the Houston oil company. Mrs. Day and her brother, Howard B. Keck, clashed over the resolution and Mrs. Day sued the company and its directors, including her brother, who strongly supported an antitakeover position.

headline: The Talk of St.-Denis
abstract: DENIS, Reunion - John Boot, a figure created by Evelyn Waugh in his novel ''Scoop,'' once cabled his editors from a far-flung place to announce that nothing much was happening. He then went on to chronicle unrest, upheaval and the outbreak of bubonic plague.   In this place, surrounded by ocean and steeped in Frenchness, only the first part of the message would apply: nothing much, at present at least, is happening here. Moreover, the people who live on the island of Reunion - a distant department of the French Republic -seem to want to keep it that way.

headline: ** Company Reports ** GIFFORD-HILL & CO (N)
STAKE IN FLEXI-VAN RAISED BY MURDOCK
abstract: David H. Murdock disclosed yesterday that he and the four companies he controls had sharply increased their stake in the Flexi-Van Corporation.   In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Murdock group said it had purchased more than 300,000 shares of Flexi-Van common stock last Thursday and Friday, increasing their stake to 2.7 million shares, or 41.6 percent, of the 6.1 million common shares outstanding.

headline: FLOODS AND DROUGHT SWEEP ACROSS SOUTH AMERICA
abstract: Widespread floods and a major drought in South America have left hundreds of people dead and hundreds of thousands sick and homeless over the last eight months.   The floods, the highest and most persistent ever recorded in some parts, have been fed by continuing rains since November, causing what officials say is billions of dollars of damage in Peru, Ecuador, Bolivia, Argentina, Brazil and Paraguay.   An eight-month-old drought that international relief officials say may be related to the same weather pattern has gripped the Andean mountain plateaus straddling Peru and Bolivia. Several hundred thousand peasants are threatened with malnutrition and starvation, the officials said.

headline: 2 California Bonds Repriced Upward
abstract: The prices of two term bonds, part of the $447 million bond issue for the M-S-R Public Power Agency of California, were increased yesterday by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company because of heavy demand.

headline: Stake in Eastern
abstract: Eastern Airlines pilots probably will get less than a reported 21 percent stake in the airline in exchange for wage and work rule concessions, an offical of the Airline Pilots Association said. August Gorse, chairman of the Master Executive Council of Eastern's Pilots Association, said the figure, which stemmed from a taped message to union members from Richard Heckenberger, chairman of an Eastern Pilot's Council in New York, was ''purely speculative.''

headline: WOOLWORTH HAS PROFIT IN QUARTER
abstract: The F.W. Woolworth Company said yesterday that it earned $1 million, or 1 cent a share, in the fiscal first quarter ended April 30. In the corresponding period of 1982, the company had a loss of $16 million.   Revenues advanced 4.6 percent, to $1.13 billion, from $1.08 billion.  Woolworth, one of the first of the nation's major retail chains to report results for the quarter, said the 1982 loss was after two special items. One was a $5 million after-tax gain from the repurchase of certain debentures and the other was an after-tax loss of $11 million from discontinued operations.

headline: HYATT CHIEF QUITS CONTINENTAL AMID BRANIFF TALKS
abstract: Jay A. Pritzker, chairman of the Hyatt Corporation, has resigned from the board of Continental Air Lines, the carrier said today. The move, apparently to avoid a conflict of interest, came as Mr. Pritzker offered a ''revised and improved'' proposal to revive Braniff International, according Irma Jensen, a Braniff representative.   Mr. Pritzker's original proposal to revive Braniff was first announced a week ago. It called for a $10 million Hyatt investment, in exchange for 80 percent of Braniff common stock and the right to operate 30 Braniff planes on some of the airline's former routes.

headline: BEWARE THE WELL-INTENTIONED
abstract: SHOULD the United States and other Western nations pursue a policy o f disinvestment in South Africa? The answer depends on who you ask. A merican liberals, and other well-meaning people, from the safety a nd comfort of their high-rise apartments, say yes. Their reasoning i s that disinvestment will weaken the South African economy and f orce the Government to change its position on apartheid. I am sure d isinvestors sleep better after taking a moral stance against trade w ith the devil.   But if you ask South African blacks, the supposed beneficiaries of disinvestment, you get a different answer. Chief Gatsha Buthelezi, leader of the Zulus, says no. The chief has told me, ''Americans have got the whole issue exactly upside down. It is morally imperative that American firms remain active here.'' The chief's sentiments are shared by Lucy Mvubelo, general secretary of South Africa's largest union; David Thebehali, Mayor of Soweto, and many others.

headline: COSTS UP BY 1.1% IN NEW YORK AREA
abstract: Increases in the costs of shelter, airline fares and gasoline helped push up the Consumer Price Index for the New York-northeastern New Jersey area by 1.1 percent in April, the Labor Department reported yesterday. It was the sharpest rise since last October.   Prices in the area rose more last month than they did nationally for household furnishings, restaurant meals, cigarettes and apparel.  But the cost of groceries held steady after rising sharply in March.

headline: 60 DEAD, WITH TOLL OF 200 FEARED; The Associated Press
abstract: Much of the southwestern mountain city of Popayan was devastated today by an earthquake that killed at least 60 people and injured 500. But with the Roman Catholic cathedral and other buildings in ruins, it was estimated that the death toll would reach at least 200.   The earthquake struck at 8:15 A.M., sending roofs of houses flying through the air, toppling buildings and shrouding the city of 135,000 people with a cloud of dust.   It was estimated that 50 to 100 people were worshiping in the Spanish colonial-style cathedral when it collapsed. The police reported during the day that 25 bodies had been recovered from the rubble, but that the search there had not yet been completed. They said 35 bodies had been recovered from houses and some hotels.

headline: The U.N. Today; May 11, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Disarmament Commission - 10:30 A.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Economic Committee - 10:30 A.M.  and 3 P.M.   Social Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Unicef Executive Board - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Commission on Transnational Cor- porations - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Newspapers and TV Expand Ad Revenues
abstract: Newspapers and television both showed advertising revenue increases in this year's first quarter.

headline: CONSUMER MEASURES ENACTED
abstract: After years of lobbying, the State Legislature has passed a bill designed to limit the time banks take to clear checks. The bill, one of a series of measures dealing with consumer issues, was signed into law this week by Governor Cuomo.   Banks will have to clear customers' checks within a set time under a new law, which most legislators said was one of their constituents' top priorities. Currently, it can take up to 13 days for banks to clear a check.

headline: JOBS FOR ITALIAN WOMEN: ROCKING THE POLITICAL BOAT
abstract: For Ludina Barzini, the elections that will decide Italy's new Parliament on June 26 and 27 are a case of ''the same old faces, the same old party politics.'' For Luciana Castellina they may be the most important in decades, not because they will produce a change, but because they may be the beginning of change.   From such differing perceptions, both women have decided to put their names on the lists from which more than 44 million Italians will pick the next Parliament.   Not all candidates, if elected, choose to serve. Potentially votecatching names are often put on party tickets even if their owners intend to cede their places to the next person down the list if the proportional-representation system won them election.

headline: New Law Lets Military Bar Turkish Candidates
abstract: Turkey's ruling generals have amended the new election bill so that they have a right to veto candidates put up by political parties in the general elections scheduled for November.

headline: Firebombings in Ulster
abstract: Firebombs destroyed or damaged 25 post office vans today in the town of Armagh, the police said.

headline: DOZENS ARE SWEPT TO SEA BY WAVE AFTER QUAKE HITS NORTHERN JAPAN
abstract: A major earthquake struck northern Japan this morning, causing a huge sea wave that swept dozens of people, including elementary schoolchildren, into the Sea of Japan.   Unconfirmed reports said as many as 50 people had been washed away, but most were believed to have been rescued. The death of one child was confirmed and an unspecified number of other people were reported missing.

headline: McGraw-Hill's Changes For 'Market Segments'
abstract: A major restructuring involving seven executives was announced last week by John G. Wrede, president of the McGraw-Hill Publications Company. Although James R. Pierce of Business Week really was not involved, he did get promoted to senior vice president publisher, a title that also went to four of the seven men.

headline: BRAZILIAN CONDEMNS LIBERALIZATION FOES
abstract: The riots over unemployment that convulsed Sao Paulo, Brazil's largest city, last week were denounced tonight by President Joao Baptista Figueiredo as the work of enemies of the country's political liberalization.   ''The violence that the country has just witnessed is a fight against the process'' of liberalization that Brazil has undertaken, he said in a national radio and television broadcast.   Brazil has restored elections, reduced censorship, ended the imprisonment of political dissidents and declared an amnesty for thousands of citizens exiled or stripped of their civil rights by the ruling military. 'I Will Not Tolerate'   ''Though I am willing to hear and examine grievances that are raised,'' Mr. Figueiredo, a retired army general, said, ''I will not tolerate that they under any pretext be transformed into acts of violence or disturbances of the public order.''

headline: 3 SOVIET DIPLOMATS ARE OUSTED BY U.S. IN ESPIONAGE CASE
abstract: The Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday announced the expulsion of three Soviet diplomats as spies. One was a military attache at the Soviet Embassy who was reportedly caught in the act of retrieving what he thought were stolen American military secrets from the base of a tree in rural Maryland.   The attache was identified as Lieut. Col. Yevgeny N. Barmyantsev, a 39-year-old Soviet military intelligence officer. He was ordered expelled along with two other Soviet diplomats suspected of seeking American military secrets in separate incidents of what Federal officials characterized as attempted espionage - one in the halls of Congress, the other in suburban New York.

headline: AT DATA GENERAL, A SUBDUED 'SOUL'
abstract: brash management, brash salesmen, brash advertising, brash pricing, brash commissions.  Its salesmen brushed aside the traditional selling courtesy as well as the industry dress code of gray suits, dark ties and white shirts. To them, selling minicomputers was ''pumping iron'' in their often electric blue polyester knits.  The formula worked. From the start, Data General exploded with sales and profit gains of around 40 percent a year and within a decade it had became the third-biggest minicomputer maker. The founders all became millionaires many times over, and the company's round-the-clock, in-house competition to produce a new high-powered minicomputer was glorified in Tracy Kidder's best-selling book, ''The Soul of a New Machine.''

headline: SOVIET BUILDING FISHERY PORT ON NICARAGUA'S PACIFIC COAST
abstract: This tiny, forgotten Pacific harbor, once a key point on the gold rush route from New York to San Francisco, is about to get a new life as a port of call for Soviet fishing boats.   In about three months a 7,000-ton Soviet drydock and a 60-foot-long floating pier will be anchored in the bay here to service Russian tuna vessels, according to Nicaraguan officials.   Under an agreement signed a year ago in Moscow, the Nicaraguans are making available to the Soviet Union its second center of this kind on the Pacific coast of Latin America. The site has the advantage of being more centrally situated in areas fished by the Soviet fleet than the port of Paita that it now uses in northern Peru. The Soviet Union will pay Nicaragua $200,000 a year as a rental fee, the officials said.

headline: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 29, 1983; Markets
abstract: The stock market experienced its biggest decline in nearly two months as concern over rising interest rates continued to spread among investors. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 20.24 points, to 1,209.23. The decline was broadly based, with declines outnumbering advances by more than 4 to 1. (Page D1.)   Bond prices edged higher, eliminating about half of Monday's losses. (D14.) The dollar was mixed in foreign currency trading, while gold prices fell $1.25 an ounce, to $414, in New York. (D16.) Futures prices for frozen pork bellies declined sharply. (D16.)

headline: Advertising; Consultant Is Going to Laurence
abstract: ALTHOUGH he had not planned it that way, Thomas K. Myers, one-time president of Norman, Craig & Kummel, is heading back into agency work, leaving behind the lucrative and loose field of management consulting.   At 50 years of age, he is being lured back by the title of vice chairman at Laurence, Charles & Free, the all-but-unknown company that resulted from the late 1981 merger of two well-known agencies, Daniel & Charles and F. William Free & Company.   He will serve on the four-man executive committee with Charles Goldschmidt, 61, chairman and chief executive; Bill Free, 53 and chairman of the executive committee, and Laurence D. Dunst, the 42-year-old president. Mr. Myers will be the only member of the committee with a background strictly in marketing and account management. Mr. Free came up as an art director, and his two partners as copywriters.

headline: Interpace Officers In Bid for Company
abstract: The Interpace Corporation, a construction materials company based in Parsippany, N.J., said yesterday that the First Boston Corporation had conveyed an offer from a new company wishing to acquire Interpace for nearly $132 million.   The group offered $30 for each of Interpace's 4 million common shares and $118.125 for each of its 5 percent convertible preferred, of which there are 99,000.   The newly formed company's management would consist of some Interpace officers, including William R. Hartman, its chairman and chief executive officer, and John F. Maypole, president and chief operating officer.

headline: Israeli Consults in U.S.  On Lebanon Pullback
abstract: David Kimche, director general of the Israeli Foreign Ministry, began consultations here today on plans for redeployment and partial withdrawal of Israeli forces in Lebanon.   According to Israeli officials, Mr. Kimche gave no timetable for such moves, which would be intended to reduce Israeli losses to terrorism.

headline: ** Company Reports ** ATLAN-TOL INDUSTRIES (O)
abstract: Qtr to Jan 31 1983 1982 Sales 2,524,000 2,636,000 Net inc 164,000 182,000 Share earns .18 .21 Yr sales 10,183,000 9,527,000 Net inc 59,000 b356,000 Share earns .01 .42 b-Including income of $9,000 fromdiscontinued operations.

headline: JARUZELSKI SYAS POLISH PARTY IS STRONGER THAN A YEAR AGO
abstract: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski defended his stewardship of Poland's Communist Party today against criticism from within his ranks and from Moscow.   ''The party is now better prepared to carry out its tasks and much stronger than a year ago,'' the Jaruzelski regime told the party's Central Committee at its long-delayed 12th full meeting.   The report from the governing Politburo obliquely conceded, however, that the party was still having trouble winning the support of, among others, workers, peasants, intellectuals and young people.

headline: GERMAN PUBLISHER SUING HIS REPORTER OVER THE HITLER HOAX
abstract: The publisher of Stern, the West German magazine that bought bogus Hitler diaries for $3.3 million, filed fraud charges today against the reporter who said he had discovered them.   The publisher also suggested that the reporter, who apparently has disappeared, kept some of the money.  Henri Nannen, the Stern publisher, took the action in a Hamburg court against Gerd Heidemann, 51 years old, a journalist whom the magazine lauded two weeks ago as a ''bloodhound'' responsible for the biggest scoop in postwar history. Stern has already published some of the bogus material.

headline: Japan High-Risk Loans
abstract: The outstanding balance of high-risk loans by 16 leading Japanese banks to 25 borrower countries stood at 5,327.70 billion yen, or about $21.3 million, on March 31, banking sources said today. The amount represented 24.3 percent of the outstanding balance of their overseas lending, an estimated 21,912.40 billion yen.

headline: FIRM'S TIES TO FEDDERS DISCLOSED
abstract: The former law firm of John M. Fedders, who is now the enforcement chief for the Securities and Exchange Commission, is paying his legal fees in connection with his involvement in a bribery case against the Southland Corporation, according to a financial disclosure statement filed this week.   The statement did not specify the amount. But a source familiar with the matter, who asked not to be identified, said that during 1982 and 1983, the law firm, Arnold & Porter of Washington, had paid out more than $50,000 in legal fees and out-of-pocket expenses for Mr. Fedders.

headline: HOUSE REPUBLICANS LOSE IN NICARAGUA DEBATE
abstract: The House Foreign Affairs Committee today rejected two Republican attempts to dilute a proposed ban on covert aid to Nicaraguan rebels, and Democrats failed in efforts to negotiate a compromise with Administration officials.   The committee rejected, in a 21-12 vote along party lines, a Republican amendment that would have banned covert aid to the rebels only after Nicaragua stopped aiding rebels in El Salvador and other neighboring countries. The committee then rejected, 18-13, another Republican amendment that would have ended covert aid when Nicaragua began to negotiate with opposition forces and halted what the amendment called violations of human and political rights.   The votes reflected growing concern in Congress over covert activities in Central America and the committee's resentment of what some members think is the inflexibility of the Administration.  Democrats said they would make a final effort to arrive at some accommodation with the White House.

headline: WITH FLOWERS AND 'V'S,' A POLISH ANNIVERSARY PASSES QUIETLY
abstract: An official wreath-laying ceremony was held here today at the stark monument where supporters of the outlawed Solidarity union used to gather on this special day.   Today was the 27th anniversary of the rioting here in 1956 in which some 70 people taking part in a protest over living conditions were shot dead. It was also the first occasion since the visit of Pope John Paul II to mark an anniversary of clashes between the people and their rulers, and the authorities wanted no incidents.   Riot policemen were massed to prevent any outburst. But at noon, the authorities also apparently made an effort to assert unity with the people.

headline: Ex-Aide to Shultz Is Dean at Chicago
abstract: John P. Gould Jr., a former special assistant and consultant on economic affairs to George P. Shultz, was named dean of the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business yesterday, succeeding Richard Rosett. An active proponent of the Chicago approach to business education, Mr. Gould is expected to encourage the school's theoretical style while placing increasing emphasis on its link to business realities.   ''I hope to have the opportunity to do the kinds of things that will keep the school in the innovative frontier,'' the 44-year-old professor said.

headline: Brae Plans Sale
abstract: Brae Corporation of San Francisco said it had agreed to sell for about $120 million a portfolio of 7,100 leased signs of its 85 percent owned American Sign and Indicator unit.

headline: Oil Concerns Offer Bearing Sea Bids
abstract: Oil companies offered $427.3 million for Federal oil and gas leases on 97 tracts in the Bering Sea.

headline: Hill & Knowlton Hires Ex-Gov. Edward King
abstract: Former Gov. Edward J. King of Massachusetts, who failed to win the Democratic primary last year in his re-election bid, has become a senior consultant for Hill & Knowlton Inc., the big New York public relations firm that is part of the JWT Group.   Mr. King, 58, who will work out of the firm's Boston office, made the traditional enthusiastic comment, calling the job ''an exciting opportunity to help build our economy, particularly our growth industries.''

headline: HONG KONG TO PUT ELECTRONIC TOLL TAKERS IN STREETS
abstract: After grappling unsuccessfully for years with the problem of traffic chaos, the Government of this crowded British colony has decided to make motorists pay for driving on its most congested roads.   Officials call the plan electronic road pricing, and it will affect Hong Kong's 230,000 private motorists.  Secretary of Transport Alan Scott announced last week that the Government had earmarked $5.8 million for a 21-month pilot program.  If it proves successful, a more extensive system, expected to cost about $50 million, could be operational by 1987.

headline: CUBA OFFERS TALKS ON RETURN OF 'UNDESIRABLES'
abstract: Cuba has informed the United States that it is willing to discuss the return of some of the Cubans who came to this country illegally in 1980, but only as part of overall negotiations on ''normalization of migration'' between the two countries, Administration officials said today.   The officials said that Cuba, in a formal note delivered June 17, in effect spurned an official request from Washington last month that it take back unconditionally a few thousand ''undesirables'' from the 125,000 Cubans who came to this country in a boatlift from the Cuban port of Mariel in 1980. These were primarily Cubans who are now in American prisons or mental institutions.   The American note, sent May 24, said that until Cuba agreed to their return the United States would continue to refuse immigration visas in Havana to Cubans who did not have close relatives who were American citizens.

headline: Advertising
abstract: ADVERTISING agency people can watch TV commercials with an enthusiasm that is hard to believe. And if it is the work of their own shops, they can maintain the enthusiasm through constant repeats.   But few exhibit as much ecstasy over their own work as did Richard Rich, the 52-year-old copywriter, showing his latest work yesterday.  He is the same Rich who in the mid-1960's lent his name to the newborn Wells, Rich, Greene, where it remains without him even to this day.

headline: A G.M.A.C. SHELF FILING OF $1.25 BILLION IN NOTES
abstract: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation filed a shelf registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering $1.25 billion in medium-term notes yesterday.   The notes are due from nine months to five years from date of issue and are offered on a continuing basis by the company directly to investors.   Currently, the offered rates are 8.75 percent for the nine-month to one-year term note; 9 percent from one year to 18 months; 9.5 percent from 18 months to two years; 9.75 pecent from two to three years; 10 percent from three to four years and 10.25 percent from four to five years.

headline: People
abstract: * Randall Emond, Jeffrey Fischgrund, Jane Fuller, Martha Holmes, James Kieff and Yolan Toro elected senior vice presidents at Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn Inc.

headline: CUBA DISPUTES REAGAN ON DRUGS
abstract: Cuba's official Communist Party newspaper, Granma, harshly criticized President Reagan today and denied charges he made last week that there was ''strong evidence'' of Cuban involvement in the illicit drug trade that flows through Miami.   The President, in a speech to Cuban expatriates in Miami on Friday, demanded an accounting from the Havana Government on whether this was ''officially sanctioned.''

headline: Sun Banks Merger
abstract: Sun Banks of Florida Inc. said it had signed a preliminary agreement to acquire Sun City Center Bank for cash or stock, subject to state and regulatory agency approvals. Under the agreement Sun City holders will receive between 1.8 and 2.2 shares of Sun common, or $44 cash for each Sun City share.

headline: SUBURBAN CONDOMINIUM BUILDERS VS. NEW STATE TAX
abstract: New York State's capital gains tax is endangering the financial stability of low-rise condominium developments and may prevent hundreds of buyers across the state from quickly moving into their homes, according to developers and spokesmen for the building industry.   Although the tax took effect only this spring, the Cuomo administration has already received many complaints from developers.  A delegation from the New York State Association of Builders met yesterday with officials of the State Tax Department to discuss possible changes in administering the law.   John Dugan, general counsel of the department, said it had been working closely with industry leaders. ''We know they have problems with it, and we want to see how we can make it easier for them to comply,'' he said. The department has set up an advisory panel on the law.

headline: Market Place; Maryland Cup: Merger Bait
abstract: EVERY time someone buys a Coke in a disposable cup at McDonald's, the cash register rings in the Owings Mills, Md., headquarters of the Maryland Cup Corporation.   With its 10,000 employees and 35 factories (including one in Britain and another in the Netherlands) Maryland Cup, operating under the Sweetheart label, is the world's largest manufacturer of disposable paper and plastic food containers. It also lays claim to being the world's largest producer of ice cream cones and drinking straws.   No wonder, then, that it has had at least three takeover bids in the last four years. It was approached by Kraft Inc. in 1979, by the Fort Howard Paper Company in 1981 and only last month by an unidentified buyer thought to be from abroad.

headline: Market Place; Power of Analysts Seen As the Dow Dawdles
abstract: THE stock market last week demonstrated the positive power of analyst recommendations while the Dow Jones industrial average simply dawdled. The Dow slipped 3.10 points, closing at 1,213.04.   Daily volume on the New York Stock Exchange contracted to an average of 83 million shares from nearly 90 million the previous week, when the Dow average gained more than 26 points.   On Friday, Newton D. Zinder of E.F. Hutton & Company forecast the possibility of ''a subdued rally rather than the start of a large new advance'' unless the market develops some favorable momentum, particularly in trading volume. Otherwise, he believes the Dow is likely to bump into trouble above the 1,220 level, where an advance has been turned back three times since late April.

headline: Market Place; Penn Central Buyback Plan
abstract: ON Monday, the Penn Central Corporation extended an offer to an estimated 55,000 of its 65,000 shareholders. The company wants to purchase the common stock of those owning fewer than 100 shares.   The Penn Central offer is the latest example of an increasingly popular process known as the corporate buyback. The concept is that both sides can benefit. The company saves money it would normally spend in serving odd-lot owners and they, in turn, get cash for their stock without paying brokerage commissions or other fees.

headline: Michigan Issue To Yield 7.75%
abstract: Blyth Eastman Paine Webber tentatively priced a $55 million Michigan higher education student loan revenue bond issue at par to yield 7.75 percent.   All of the bonds mature June 1, 1986. They were originally scheduled to be priced last week, but because of the rise in yields and market instability, they were put on a day-to-day pricing schedule.

headline: A WILSON FOODS PACT IS REACHED
abstract: The Wilson Foods Corporation, which took the unusual step of filing for bankruptcy to reduce labor costs, said yesterday it had reached a tentative wage agreement with striking meatpackers. The agreement would end a 20-day walkout against the nation's largest processor of fresh pork.   Both the striking union and Wilson said the accord included wage reductions. But Wilson declined to say whether the cuts were sufficient to bring it out of Chapter 11 proceedings under the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

headline: SEOUL ENDS DISSIDENT'S DETENTION
abstract: The Government decided today to end the detention of a former opposition leader who has been on hunger strike for 13 days demanding the establishment of democratic rule and other changes.   But the opposition leader, Kim Young Sam, told reporters in his hospital room that he would continue his fast because the Government of President Chun Doo Hwan had not met his demands.

headline: Rainier Merger
abstract: The Rainier Bancorporation of Seattle said it became the first out-of-state bank holding company to acquire an Alaska bank, with the purchase of Peoples Bank and Trust here.

headline: Economic Scene; Seattle Looks For Its Future
abstract: THIS beautiful city is stretching and yawning in the bright spring sunshine - and starting to wake up from the deep recession. In front of the Pike Place Market on the waterfront, a crowd gathers to watch a young woman prancing and kicking up her heels in an improvised dance that goes on and on - sunshine and springtime are especially exhilarating to Seattle, used to melancholy skies and too much rain.   A decade ago, in the midst of the ''Boeing bust,'' when 100,000 people lost their jobs and about a quarter of them moved away from this area, a freeway billboard asked, ''Will the last person to leave Seattle please turn out the lights?''   This time, despite an unemployment rate that hangs on at 12 percent, nobody wants to leave Seattle. They like this city of parks and hills, with Puget Sound on one side and Lake Washington on the other; they like its easy and colorful and untouristy waterfront.  And they do not see much better job prospects elsewhere.

headline: CAMBODIANS TELL OF HORROR
abstract: It is still impossible to say how many civilians died this month at O Smach, a Cambodian refugee and guerrilla camp that was shelled and overrun by Vietnamese troops. It is also not known with certainty how they died.

headline: 16 Killed at Ugandan Funeral
abstract: A Ugandan special forces policeman went berserk and shot and killed 16 people at the funeral of a colleague before committing suicide, the police said today.

headline: TUESDAY, JUNE 14, 1983; Markets
abstract: Stock prices rose sharply as investors reacted to favorable economic news. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 24.44 points, to 1,220.55, the biggest one-day gain since Feb. 24, when it climbed 24.47 points. Analysts cited Friday's report that the basic money supply had risen less than expected. (Page D1.)   Government securities prices rose and rates fell. (D7.) The dollar was mixed, while gold prices rose $6.25 an ounce in New York, to $413.25. (D12.) Prices of interest rate futures rose. (D12.)

headline: ** Company Reports ** AEROFLEX LABORATORIES INC (A)
The U.N. Today; May 10, 1983; SECURITY COUNCIL
abstract: Meets on complaints by Nicaragua at 3 P.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Meets at 3 P.M.   General Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Disarmament Commission - 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   First (Economic) Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Second (Social) Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Unicef Executive Board Meeting - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Commission on Transnational Cor- porations, Special Session - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: CHIEF RESIGNS POST AT APPLIED DIGITAL
abstract: Robert A. Degan, president and chief executive of Applied Digital Data Systems, was named yesterday to become president of another high-technology company, the Data Switch Corporation, of Wilton, Conn. Applied Digital Data based, in Hauppauge, L.I., has been a subsidiary of the NCR Corporation since 1980.

headline: South Africa Bans Protests Over Hangings
abstract: A judge issued a 48-hour ban beginning today on protests over the hanging of three black nationalist guerrillas.   The ban outlawed a large gathering planned for Sunday in Lenasia, an Indian township south of here, where members of the executed men's families had planned to speak.

headline: Barclays Bank To Retrench
abstract: Barclays, one of Britain's big four commercial banks, will phase out 150 branch offices over the next two years to streamline operations and cut costs, a spokesman said today.

headline: ** Company Reports ** BANK SECURITIES INC (O)
abstract: Qtr to March 31 1983 1982 Net loss 168,000 b559,000 Per share .17 b-Net income.

headline: OIL LEASING IN A FAMILIAR PITCH
abstract: As the slump in energy markets has deepened in the past couple of years, the nation's leading oil companies have reduced spending for exploration and production. But on Wednesday, they are expected to put frugality aside for a day and bid furiously at a Federal auction of oil and gas leases in the Gulf of Mexico.   The sale, to be held here, will be the first in the Gulf under the Interior Department's accelerated leasing program, which is intended to reduce the nation's reliance on foreign oil by making more acreage available for drilling in Unites States waters.   Oil industry executives say the auction, focused on the central Gulf, promises to be the most important lease sale in the United States this year and could be the biggest ever in terms of tracts leased.

headline: Market Place; Bleak Outlook For Oil Drillers
abstract: OFFSHORE drilling companies won top honors among 96 groups monitored by Standard & Poor's by advancing 6.7 percent in the week ended May 25. But Arthur L. Smith of Oppenheimer & Company regards this rebound as ''a trading rally'' and recommends that investors with holdings in the eight offshore drillers followed by his firm either reduce or eliminate their stock positions.   The catalyst for the recent price gains, he said, was investor anticipation regarding lease sales by the Federal Government giving energy companies the right to explore for oil and natural gas in the Gulf of Mexico. On May 25, 78 companies bid a record $3.47 billion for exploration rights covering 39.8 million acres in the Gulf.

headline: MONEY FUND RATES AT BANKS DECLINE
abstract: The interest rates on money market deposit accounts offered by banks declined slightly this week in New York and throughout the nation, the Bank Rate Monitor said yesterday.   The average money market rate paid by 50 large institutions in the five largest United States markets was 8.34 percent yesterday, down from 8.38 percent the previous week.

headline: 7 SUMMIT LEADERS PRESS THE RUSSIANS ON NUCLEAR TALKS
abstract: The leaders of the seven nations at the economic summit meeting called on the Soviet Union tonight to negotiate constructively on reducing nuclear weapons and warned that any attempt to divide the West would fail.   The statement came after daylong discussions on its wording, taking up unexpected portions of the leaders' agenda, and leaving an impression of divisions at a conference intended to express economic solidarity and converging views.   But the statement, which was endorsed by France and Japan even though they are not members of the military wing of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, had the mark of a success for the Reagan Administration, which pressed for a firm definition of the Western security stance at the conference. French Objections Raised   French officials said they had initially raised objections to issuing a statement on arms control before a statement on the main work of the conference, economic matters, was made. They also said they did not wish to be committed to positions endorsed by the NATO allies but not specifically by France.

headline: Tenneco Restricts 'Old Gas' Buying
abstract: Tenneco Inc. said it had told its natural gas suppliers that it would no longer accept gas that is from wells drilled before 1977 and that costs more than 110 percent of the price of No.2 heating oil.   Tenneco's price lid for this ''old gas'' is part of a policy to cut the weighted averaged cost of natural gas to between $2.69 and $2.79 per thousand cubic feet from the $3.09 that the company had forecast for the first quarter.   The new policy affects about 10 percent of Tenneco's supplies for its Tenneco Gas Pipeline Company subsidiary, which has been buffeted by declining natural gas sales in its 21-state service area.

headline: Zurich Official Says 3 Swindled Iranian Envoy
abstract: Three Swiss nationals swindled an Iranian envoy out of $43.4 million by promising him 50 American-built tanks that were never delivered, the Zurich prosecutor said today.

headline: Turkey Decrees Laws Curbing Role of Unions
abstract: Turkey's ruling military announced new laws today that forbid unions from engaging in political activity, make them put their money in state-controlled banks and limit strikes to 60 days.

headline: G.M. Faces Recall
abstract: Howard Kehrl, the General Motors Corporation vice chairman, said that the possible recall of 5.3 million 1978-1980 model midsize A-cars, could cost the company $125 million. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is considering ordering a recall for fear the axles might fall off.

headline: Salomon Brothers Sets CATS Issue
abstract: Solomon Brothers said yesterday that it had begun offering a new series of Certificates of Accrual on Treasury Securities, or CATS, with a total par value of $2.2 billion.

headline: Nepal Premier Won't Resign
abstract: Prime Minister Surya Bahadur Thapa rejected opposition demands today that he resign or face the first no-confidence vote since a new system of government was introduced in Nepal 23 years ago. Demands in Parliament for Mr. Thapa's resignation came after recent opposition rallies in which the Government was charged with corruption, inefficiency and failure to handle last year's drought.

headline: BID TO CURB LENDING OVERSEAS
abstract: As a quid pro quo for higher American contributions to the International Monetary Fund, rules governing international lending by American banks would be tightened under a proposal that bank regulators will submit to Congress Friday.   One restriction would bar banks from using the substantial fees they receive for rescheduling loans to developing countries to enhance their current income, officials said.   The Federal Reserve Board, the Comptroller of the Currency and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation prepared the recommendations in response to a request by legislators now considering American participation in a $40 billion increase in resources of the I.M.F.   The tightening of conditions governing international bank lending must take place if Congress is to approve an $8.4 billion increase in the American contribution, many legislators and Administration officials believe.

headline: BIG RISES BY MACY'S, FEDERATED
abstract: R.H. Macy & Company and Federated Department Stores Inc., continuing the trend of improved earnings among the nation's leading retail chains, yesterday announced sharply higher results for their latest fiscal quarters.   Macy's reported an 85.5 percent rise in earnings, while Federated had a 47.8 percent gain. Earlier this week, the K Mart Corporation, the Allied Stores Corporation and the May Department Stores Company reported sharp increases in earnings. The J.C. Penney Company and the Dayton-Hudson Corporation announced modest advances.

headline: COURT AVOIDS BRANIFF BANKRUPTCY RULING
abstract: The Supreme Court refused today to hear a challenge by American Airlines to a Federal bankruptcy court's jurisdiction over the reorganization of the bankrupt Braniff International Corporation.   The Court turned down American's petition without comment, persisting in its refusal to enter the continuing debate over the current and future status of Federal bankruptcy jurisdiction.   Within the last few months, the Court has turned down similar challenges by the International Harvester Company, the Alabama Furniture Company, and by a group of companies that are co-defendants with the Manville Corporation in thousands of asbestos-related lawsuits.

headline: NEUTRALS PROTEST MADRID STALEMATE
abstract: A group of countries that consider themselves neutral or nonaligned today protested the lack of progress at the Madrid talks on East-West relations in Europe. Malta openly questioned the point of continuing the meeting, which is in its third year, delegates said.   The smaller countries at the 35-nation conference called a special session of the talks today to voice their concern.  Eight of the nine neutral or nonaligned countries had proposed ending the conference today. The proposal was in a compromise final document that they submitted in March in hope of winning the required consensus of all participating nations.

headline: FIRST SINCE 1981
abstract: Dome Petroleum Ltd. reported today that it returned to profitability in the first quarter; it was the troubled Canadian energy company's first profit since the fourth quarter of 1981.   Citing reductions in interest charges, greater efficiency and higher Canadian oil and natural gas prices, Dome reported net income of $7.2 million (Canadian currency), or 2 cents a share, compared with a loss of $21.6 million in the corresponding three months in 1982.   At current exchange rates, Dome's net income was about $5.8 million in United States currency.  The report also showed that long-term debt had been reduced to $6.35 billion (Canadian currency), from $6.5 billion at the end of the year.

headline: Fraser Vote Keeps Harrods
abstract: After months of feuding, Britain's House of Fraser P.L.C. announced today that it had thwarted, temporarily at least, an attempt by its largest shareholder, Lonrho Ltd., the mining conglomerate, to spin off the renowned store, Harrods of Knightsbridge, from the rest of the giant retailer.   In a poll last Friday, Fraser's shareholders cast 65.6 million votes in favor of supporting the board and keeping Harrods within the group.

headline: Hartford Insurance In Piper Jaffray Pact
abstract: Piper Jaffray Inc., a regional securities firm with offices in the Middle West, Northwest and Mountain states, and the Hartford Insurance Group said yesterday that they had entered into a long-term agreement under which Piper Jaffray would market life insurance products for Hartford and the insurer would acquire about 25 percent of Piper Jaffray.   Hartford, a subsidiary of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, said that it had recently agreed to acquire, for $95 a share, about 271,000 shares of Piper Jaffray stock from the company, its management, its employee stock ownership trust and a major unidentified shareholder.

headline: Western Nations Hopeful Of Accord in Madrid
abstract: Western nations said today that a proposal by neutral countries at the conference on East-West relations in Europe could help break a 30-month deadlock in efforts to reach an agreement with the Soviet bloc.   The proposal calls for separate 35-nation conferences on disarmament, military confidence-building measures and scientific cooperation.

headline: State Fund May Buy Seafirst
abstract: The Washington State Investment Board will decide Monday whether to invest state employee pension funds in a bid to buy the troubled Seafirst Corporation.   The actual bid will come within two weeks if a study by the board's investment committee determines Seafirst is a good pension fund risk, said John Hitchman, the fund board's executive director.

headline: Warsaw Newspaper Warns Catholic Church
abstract: The editor of a Warsaw newspaper warned the Roman Catholic Church today against applying double standards in its actions.   The church has asked for an amnesty for martial-law offenders to mark the visit of Pope John Paul II next month.

headline: Shoe Duties Removed
abstract: Special duties imposed to hold down United States imports of shoes from India, Spain and Brazil were lifted Tuesday by the International Trade Commission. The decision in favor of India revoked duties of 15 percent imposed in 1979; the commission also voted in favor of imports of ''non rubber footwear'' from Brazil and Spain, where the duties, which range up to 14.3 percent for Brazil and 2.5 percent to 3.5 percent for Spain, go back to 1974.

headline: U.S. LOOKS AT ANTITRUST ISSUE IN OIL COMPANIES' SAUDI LINKS
abstract: The Justice Department is looking into possible antitrust violations in the relationship of four major American oil companies that jointly pump and buy most of the oil produced by Saudi Arabia.   Specifically, according to a senior department official who asked that he not be identified, the antitrust division has internally raised questions about a meeting in early January in which top officials of the companies met in Geneva with the Saudi oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani. The subject was the slumping world oil market, which had led to sharp declines in crude oil prices.   Top executives of the four companies reportedly put pressure on Sheik Yamani to lower Saudi crude prices from what they considered an artificially high level. The Justice Department is presumably concerned that the meeting was part of an effort to fix prices.

headline: LEBANON HOLDING 4 IN EMBASSY ATTACK
abstract: Lebanon's Foreign Minister, Elie Salem, confirmed today that the Lebanese police had arrested four men in connection with Monday's bombing of the American Embassy in Beirut.   Mr. Salem added, however, that it was still far too soon to ''accuse anybody'' of the destruction of the embassy, in which at least 40 people were confirmed to have been killed and at least 25 others were presumed to be buried under the rubble.   The Foreign Minister said in an interview with NBC News that the Lebanese Government had ''arrested four individuals'' and ''they are being investigated.''   Mr. Salem added that he could not discuss any details of the search being mounted by the Lebanese police, who have set up additional checkpoints on streets around West Beirut.

headline: Patents; Solar-Run Chiming Sundial
abstract: WASHINGTON ACHIMING sundial, which is solar-powered and celebrates the passage of each hour with a musical note, was patented this week by Edwin F.  Shelley, who is director of the Center for Energy Policy and Research at the New York Institute of Technology in Old Westbury, L.I. He received patent 4,387,999 for the electronic apparatus.  Two concentric hemispheres have slits that line up the sun's rays once each hour, illuminate a photoelectric cell and trigger the chime generator.  A watch company, which is considering it for manufacture, has expressed interest in the chiming sundial as a decorative timepiece for gardens and for rooms with south-facing windows.

headline: Fedders Hearing Set
abstract: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, chairman of a Congressional subcommittee that oversees the Securities and Exchange Commission, announced today that he would hold hearings next Tuesday on the involvement of John M. Fedders with the Southland Corporation. Mr. Fedders, head of the S.E.C.'s enforcement division, is the subject of a Federal grand jury investigation into his role in an purported bribery scheme involving Southland and a top company executive. Before joining the commission, Mr. Fedders served as an outside counsel to Southland.

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: American and other Western intelligence analysts have concluded that the most dangerous element in any possible military confrontation between Syrian and Israeli forces in Lebanon is what they see as the Palestine Liberation Organization's desire to prove to itself and to Israel that it must be recognized as a key player in the Middle East. Such an effort by the P.L.O. is believed to be behind its increasing attacks on Israeli patrols and the firing of two mortar shells at United States Marine positions near Beirut International Airport on Monday.   The Syrian Army, while not directly involved in any of the incidents, protects the P.L.O. Most of the 10,000 to 12,000 organized Palestinian troops and guerrillas are behind Syrian lines in eastern and northern Lebanon.   To engage the Palestinians, Israeli forces would inevitably come up against Syrian positions unless the Israeli Air Force destroyed Palestinian encampments.

headline: RARA AVIS FINDS A NICHE IN WORLD OF COMIC BOOKS
abstract: The balloons are familiar, as are the comic-book faces from which they issue. But the words inside the balloons are startlingly different.   ''Aspice, usitatum automatum temporis emi!'' one says. Another exclaims, ''Nil quidem! Vetus enim televisificum instrumentum inerat.'' In the English version these balloons say, ''Look! I've bought a second-hand time machine,'' and ''No! There was only this old television set which is still here.''

headline: PERSONAL FINANCE; CHECKING OUT RETIREMENT PLAN OPTIONS
abstract: IF you are a corporate employee, retirement plan options that shelter earned income from Federal income taxes may be more available than you realize. They bear an alphabet-soup array of names and have different rules, with some serving particular needs better than o thers.  One such program is the Qualified Voluntary Employee Contribution Plan, or QVEC. Obtainable only through an employer on a voluntary basis, these plans let employees deduct up to $2,000 of earnings from Federal income taxes, with the money invested and compounded taxfree. When authorized by the plan, proceeds may be withdrawn before the employee reaches age 59 1/2 or incurs a disability, but in that case they may be subject to a tax penalty of 10 percent of the amount received.

headline: Japan Cartel Extension
abstract: The Japanese Government's Fair Trade Commission said today that it had approved a three-month extension of the antirecession cartel of 12 Japanese petrochemical companies to regulate ethylene production because of low domestic demand. The producers in the cartel may run their operations at 55.9 percent of capacity and produce 845,000 tons in the three months ending in June, down 9.2 percent from the same 1982 period, it said. Under the previous cartel agreement the companies cut ethylene production to 1.56 million tons in the five and a half months ended Thursday.

headline: Choices Asked On Fed Chief
abstract: The Reagan Administration has been asking the chief executive officers of the nation's largest banks to recommend individuals who might succeed Paul A. Volcker as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. Mr. Volcker's term as chairman expires in August.   According to banking sources, Walter B. Wriston, chairman of Citicorp, recommended G.A. Costanzo, who retired in 1981 as Citicorp's vice chairman.

headline: Money Supply Up $7 Billion; Sharp Jump Causes Rise In Bond Rates
abstract: The Federal Reserve yesterday reported a $7 billion increase in the nation's money supply for the week ended May 11, far above the $4 billion rise that many analysts had predicted.   Treasury bond prices fell sharply and yields rose in response to the late afternoon announcement of the rise in M-1, the measure of currency and checking deposits readily available for spending. The new price drops brought the total bond decline over the last two weeks to about five points, or $50 for each $1,000 issue. Three-month Treasury bill rates rose yesterday by more than two-tenths of a percentage point.

headline: Data Bank; May 8, 1983
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: AMERICAN EXPRESS EXPANDS SYSTEM OF TELLER MACHINES
abstract: In an effort to capture a larger share of the credit card market, American Express is expanding its automatic teller machine service to more regions of the country, as well as to nonbanking locations. In the process, it is drawing criticism from bankers, who say American Express is encroaching on their territory.   The Express Cash system, first offered to all American Express members last summer, allows card holders to draw, for a $1 fee per transaction, up to $500 a week from 24-hour cash machines at 704 banks around the country. An additional 504 machines are to be added to the system in the near future. Of these, 289 will be installed at Publix Super Markets in Florida in an agreement reached with Sun Banks of Florida.

headline: CLUES TO TRUE POWER OF ANDROPOV ARE EXPECTED AT MOSCOW MEETINGS
abstract: Two meetings of the Soviet leadership here next week are expected to throw light on key questions that have arisen about the health of Yuri V. Andropov and his hold on power in the seven months since he became leader of the Communist Party.   Recently, he has not acted so forcefully nor looked so vigorous as he did in his first weeks in power. There are growing doubts among Western diplomats and analysts about whether he has the physical strength or political clout to move any more people of his choice into positions of power than he already has, and whether he can break the bureaucratic inertia responsible for the sluggish state of the country's economy.   Unless other events intervene, the party's Central Committee will meet for its regular summer session, a session that might authorize new appointments to the bodies exercising control - the Politburo and the Secretariat.   The Central Committee session will be followed on Thursday by a meeting of the Supreme Soviet, the country's nominal Parliament, which has the power to fill the post of chief of state, vacant since Leonid I. Brezhnev died in November.

headline: TRANSAMERICA UP
abstract: The RCA Corporation said yesterday that its first-quarter profits declined 46.6 percent from the 1982 quarter, when results were inflated by nonrecurring gains. Excluding those gains, the company's first-quarter profit would have risen 47.5 percent, the company said.    ''Earnings were better than anticipated a few months ago and RCA's business environment appears to be gradually strengthening,'' RCA's chairman, Thornton F. Bradshaw, said in a prepared statement.

headline: Cluett Plans Sale
abstract: Cluett, Peabody & Company, a New York-based apparel concern, said it would sell Boyd's, the last of its specialty store group, and said it had begun discussions with a group of investors interested in the eight Boyd's stores. Cluett said it would provide a reserve of six cents a share in the second quarter to cover combined costs of the disposal, the recent withdrawal from its Young Quinlan store in Minneapolis and the discontinuance of its Retail Stores division. The company said the operations did not project a near-term potential for reaching target levels of return on investment.

headline: Slater Hanft Martin Gets Muzak Business
abstract: The Muzak subsidiary of the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company, which likes to identify itself as the world's largest supplier of environmental music, has named Slater Hanft Martin Inc. as its new agency.

headline: Import Ruling On Cement
abstract: The Commerce Department issued a preliminary ruling today that Japanese and Australian cement is selling in the United States at less than fair value.

headline: 167 PERUVIAN REBELS AND PEASANTS SAID TO DIE IN A WEEK OF FIGHTING
abstract: The military said today that 167 rebels and peasants and 2 police officers were killed in a week of fighting in central Peru, and President Fernando Belaunde Terry suggested that he might send a special antiguerrilla squad into the battle zone.   The report on the most violent week in the three-year-old guerrilla war raised the official death toll from two months of fighting to 560. More than 1,000 people have been reported killed since Mr.  Belaunde Terry sent soldiers into guerrilla areas at the end of December.

headline: MONEY SUPPLY UP $5.6 BILLION
abstract: The Federal Reserve yesterday announced a large, but widely expected, increase in the nation's basic money supply for the week to June 8.   The $5.6 billion increase, to a total of $514.1 billion, put the level of M-1, which is intended to measure money readily available for spending, even further above the Fed's target than it has been for weeks. But analysts remained divided as to whether the Fed had already begun to combat the rapid growth by raising short-term interest rates.   ''I don't think that there has been any shift in Fed policy,'' said Robert Schwartz, a financial economist at Merrill Lynch Government Securities. He acknowledged, however, that there were many who expected a tightening move by the Fed in coming weeks.

headline: CANNON'S BOX-OFFICE RESPECT
abstract: At a time when the major film studios have been retrenching, the Cannon Group, a company controlled by two Israeli cousins, has grown into one of the biggest and most successful independent movie producers.   This year, Cannon, based in an office on Sunset Boulevard, overlooking the storied junction of Hollywood and Vine, has achieved commercial - if not critical - acclaim with ''10 to Midnight,'' starring Charles Bronson, and ''The Last American Virgin.'' Most of its films do not even make it to American theaters. Cannon's forte is low-budget, American-style films for overseas markets. And those films have financed the company's pheneomenal growth.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: PATENTS; Device Collects Samples Of Airborne Pollutants
abstract: A sample collector for atmospheric pollutants has been developed at the Environmental Protection Agency's laboratory in Research Triangle Park, N.C. John P. Bell of the laboratory staff got Patent 4,381,681 for the device, which accumulates particles that may be hazardous.

headline: Breton Farmers Storm Prison After Arrest of Two Militants
abstract: About 1,500 farmers, angered by the arrest of two young farm union militants and falling farm prices, attacked a prison in this Breton town on Friday, the police said today.

headline: DELAY INDICATED IN REAGAN'S PLAN FOR SALVADOR AID
abstract: The Reagan Administration, worried about rising opposition to a $60 million military aid request for El Salvador, is seeking to delay consideration of the measure until it can muster enough votes on Capitol Hill.   Administration officials said the delay was prompted in large part by indications that the request would be rejected in a key House appropriations subcommittee.   Pentagon and State Department officials said last month that El Salvador faced a ''crisis'' and could run out of military supplies in 30 days unless the United States provided the additional $60 million in aid immediately.   The $60 million request is part of an emergency $110 military aid program sought by President Reagan. Mr. Reagan seeks the $60 million by persuading the Appropriations Committees to re-direct funds now marked for other nations. The remainder would come from a supplemental appropriation, which would be debated and voted upon by both the House and Senate.

headline: ** Company Reports ** FIRST KENTUCKY NATIONAL CORP (O) Qtr to March 31 1983 1982
7 LEADING NATIONS PLAN CURRENCY 'COORDINATION'
abstract: Finance ministers of the seven leading industrial countries said today that they were willing to undertake ''coordinated'' intervention in foreign exchange markets to try to prevent excessive gyrations of currency values.   But Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said that the statement should not be taken as an indication of a policy change by the United States, which favors intervention only in disorderly markets.   The statement was issued after a meeting of the finance representatives of the United States, Britain, France, West Germany, Italy, Japan and Canada, held today to prepare for the economic summit conference in Williamsburg, Va., on Memorial Day weekend.   Mr. Regan told newsmen that the United States understood ''coordination'' to mean only that other governments should be informed of what the United States was doing.

headline: Regan Fights Bank Plan
abstract: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said Friday that he opposes moves in Congress to temporarily ban nonbanking companies from establishing or buying banks and thrift institutions. Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, has asked Congress to slow the blending of banking and other types of businesses.

headline: Gasoline Up 9¦ in 8 Weeks
abstract: Gasoline prices have climbed 9 cents a gallon in the last eight weeks, spurred on by the new Federal gasoline tax, but they remain 13 cents below the peak reached two years ago, the American Automobile Association reported today.   The automobile club reported an average price of $1.26 a gallon, 8.8 cents higher than a previous survey taken just before the 5-centa-gallon Federal gasoline tax rise went into effect on April 1.

headline: 'NO DISAGREEMENT' IN GONZALEZ-REAGAN TALKS
abstract: President Reagan and Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez of Spain discussed the situation in Central America at length today and were reported in agreement on broad goals of peace, democracy and justice for the region.   Although Mr. Gonzalez, on a recent trip to the area, had criticized United States policy, a senior State Department official told reporters after the talks that there had been ''no fundamental disagreement'' between the two leaders over Central America.   Mr. Reagan, in opening the discussion on Central America, said that the United States had ''historic ties'' to the region and that the Administration wanted to promote ''three principal goals - peace, democracy and justice,'' the official said.   Mr. Gonzalez ''said he had no disagreement with these goals and there was, I think, no fundamental disagreement in the discussion about Central America,'' the official said.

headline: Money Fund Assets Drop
abstract: Asset levels of money market mutual funds declined $412 million last week, to $169.7 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.   The drop was the 27th consecutive decline for the funds.

headline: Nigerian Debt Plan
abstract: Twenty-four banks have accepted an offer to consolidate Nigeria's short-term debt into a three-year facility, a spokesman for Barclays Bank International said today.

headline: Pennsylvania Bank Borrowings
abstract: The First Pennsylvania Corporation said it had prepaid some $150 million on borrowings that were part of a 1980 rescue loan from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and a group of banks that was intended to prevent the collapse of First Pennsylvania Bank.

headline: JAPAN TRAINING GLOBAL EXPERTS
abstract: This rural town, more than 100 miles northwest of cosmopolitan Tokyo, seems an unlikely place for corporate Japan to teach worldly executives how to function in an international arena that has become increasingly hostile to Japan's economic advance. But that is why the International University of Japan opened here in April.   ''In the future, Japan will need more international men,'' said Ko Tashiro, secretary general of the two-year postgraduate school.  ''This university is to educate such people.''

headline: U.S. CHALLENGED ON ASSURANCE THAT ITS RECOVERY AIDS WORLD
abstract: Leaders at the economic summit meeting challenged today President Reagan's assurances that economic recovery in the United States was enough to bring prosperity to the rest of the world.   They insisted, instead, that their economies would remain in the doldrums unless American interest rates were brought lower and the Federal budget deficit was reduced even more than President Reagan has proposed, reporters were told at several briefings led by aides of the leaders.   ''There is a note in the American attitude that everything will work itself out,'' said a European Economic Community official, in one of the briefings. ''The Europeans fear that things will not look after themselves and that more will have to be done.''

headline: HOME COMPUTERS STEAL SHOW
abstract: The Consumer Electronics Show this year is almost all fun but not all games. Last year the show was almost all games but not as much fun.   This show, which opened here today, is more fun because the exhibitors, who make everything from hi-fi to home computers, are heading for a strong sales year, helped by the general improvement in the economy and by a drying up of excess inventories that had caused prices to plummet in such product categories as television sets and video-cassette recorders.   ''Even some of our weaker product categories are showing signs of life,'' said William E. Boss, an official of RCA Electronics and of the Electronic Industries Association, the trade group that sponsors the show.

headline: DMG Stake Sold
abstract: DMG Inc., a real estate developer and mortgage-financing concern, said Equity Group Holdings, a private concern, had recently acquired 1.39 million shares, or 19 percent, of its common stock, for an undisclosed price. Equity Group purchased the shares from an affiliate of the Pacific Holding Corporation and in market transactions, it said. DMG also said that Donald E. Benson, president of the MEI Corporation, a Milwaukee soft-drink bottler, had resigned as chairman of DMG after MEI sold its stake in the company.

headline: Macmillan Bloedel Net
abstract: Macmillan Bloedel, a diversified paper products company, yesterday reported net income of $2.4 million in the latest quarter, compared with a net loss of $10.4 million a year earlier. But excluding special gains of $25.4 million on the sale of office buildings and a 50 percent interest in Island Paper Mills, the company had an operating loss in the latest period of $23 million. Sales in the quarter dropped 12.4 percent, to $442 million, from $504.5 million.

headline: POLAND LETS PARTY WEEKLY REBUT SOVIET ATTACK ON MILITARY REGIME
abstract: The Polish Government of Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski has cleared for publication on Thursday a defense of his military rule against criticism from the Soviet Union and from hard-liners within his own Communist Party.   The defense, in the Polish party weekly Polityka, the first copies of which arrived from the printer today, is in response to criticism published last Friday in the Soviet foreign affairs weekly Novoye Vremya. The Soviet attack was directed at Polityka and, by implication, at its former editor, Deputy Prime Minister Mieczyslaw Rakowski, a Jaruzelski aide, but it was viewed by diplomats and Polish political experts as a general warning to General Jaruzelski that his policies were incurring disfavor in Moscow.   Polityka represents what is known as the pragmatic wing of the party around Mr. Rakowski and its response to Novoye Vremya includes a series of thrusts at Polish hard-liners.

headline: IN GANDHI'S FOOTSTEPS, POLITICIAN TREKS 2,700 MILES
