abstract: Under a blistering summer sun, an opposition party leader trekked into the capital this weekend, ending a 2,700-mile walk across India that he called both an act of ''self-education and an effort to reach people at their level instead of preaching from New Delhi.''   The politician, Chandra Shekhar, head of the Janata Party, concluded the grueling six-month walk Saturday at the marble memorial to Mohandas K. Gandhi, who demonstrated the political power of long walks in 1930 by marching 200 miles to the sea to defy a British tax on salt.   At the memorial, before a tumultuous crowd of about 10,000, Mr.  Shekhar pledged to restore ''moral values'' to national life.  ''We have to approach people in the style of Mahatma Gandhi - on their level - to listen to them, not just talk at them,'' he said during the walk.

headline: COMPANIES' DIVIDEND TAX PLANS
abstract: While many banks say that withholding 10 percent from customers' interest payments will cause them a plethora of problems, most companies expect only minimal adjustments in withholding taxes from stockholders' dividends.   New legislation requires the deduction of 10 percent from interest and dividend payments made to depositors and stockholders by banks, corporations and other financial institutions beginning July 1. While opponents have mounted efforts to repeal the law in Congress, resolution of those efforts could take several months. The Senate, which put off debate on the subject on Friday, is scheduled to take up the issue today. But President Reagan has promised to veto a repeal measure.

headline: Home Loan Banks In Bond Offering
abstract: A $500 million bond offering was announced yesterday by the Federal Home Loan Banks.

headline: A.M.C. Public Offering Raises $58.75 Million
abstract: The American Motors Corporation said its public offering of 10 million common shares was sold out early today for a total of about $58,750,000, just hours after being placed on the market on the New York Stock Exchange.   A.M.C. doubled the size of its planned public offering to 10 million shares on Monday after it became clear there was a strong demand for the company's stock, according to Jerry L. Sloan, A.M.C.'s vice president for public relations. The stock sold for $5.875 a share, Monday's closing price on the exchange.

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: United States intelligence analysts say that in the course of Secretary of State George P. Shultz's talks in the Middle East, Israel is likely to press for a revival of a 1981 memorandum of strategic understanding. The memorandum, which was suspended by Washington three weeks after it was signed, calls for extensive Israeli cooperation in the deployment of American forces in the Middle East to counter Soviet military threats to the region.   The danger, the analysts say, is that renewed discussion of such a formal military alliance between Israel and the United States would complicate Mr. Shultz's efforts by deepening the suspicions of moderate Arabs over Washington's long-term policies in the region.   The memorandum was signed on Nov. 30, 1981, but was suspended by the United States the next month to express its displeasure over the Israeli annexation of the Golan Heights.

headline: BRITISH LOBBY SENATE ON EXPORT ACT
abstract: The British Government, in an unusual lobbying effort, has called on the Senate to strike a provision of an East-West trade bill that extends the reach of American laws to foreign countries.   A letter from Sir Oliver Wright, the British Ambassador, was sent to all members of the Senate Banking Committee two days ago as they were drawing up legislation to renew the Export Administration Act of 1979. Legislative aides said they could not recall a foreign lobbying effort of Congress timed for the day of a legislative drafting session.

headline: Teheran Zoo Gets U.S. Meat
abstract: Animals at the Teheran zoo have received a seven-year supply of food -frozen meat from storerooms at the captured United States Embassy, the national press agency said today.

headline: SALVADOR REBELS SAID TO OVERRUN COMMUNICATIONS BASE ATOP PEAK
abstract: Leftist guerrillas overran a military communications base in the northern province of Morazan today, according to a military source.   The base, at the top of the 5,000-foot Cacahuatique volcano, serves as a relay station for the eastern part of the country. An officer at the high command said the station was ''important, but not critical.''

headline: Judge Allows GTE Deal
abstract: Setting aside the objections of a competitor, a Federal judge today authorized the GTE Corporation to consummate its purchase of the long-distance telephone and satellite subsidiaries of the Southern Pacific Company.   United States District Judge Harold H. Greene said in a written order that he was satisfied that GTE would close the deal in such a fashion that it would not jeopardize his authority to review a related antitrust settlement.

headline: CHINESE JET IS HIJACKED TO SOUTH KOREA
abstract: Two crew members of a Chinese domestic airliner were shot in midair Thursday and their plane, with 105 people aboard, was hijacked to South Korea, Government officials said.   The plane landed at an American Army base northeast of Seoul and then, for seven hours, the hijackers held 92 passengers and five crew members hostage in an apparent demand for political asylum.   During the siege, the two wounded crew members - a navigator and a radio operator - were removed from the aircraft on stretchers.  According to officials, they were flown to an American military hospital, where they were said this morning to be in stable condition following surgery for leg wounds.

headline: Donarl Chapter 11
abstract: Donarl of Florida Inc., a Broadstone Group Inc. subsidiary, has filed a petition seeking protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code in the Federal District Court for the Southern District of Florida. Broadstone is owned by the Arlen Realty and Development Corporation, with a 50.5 percent interest, and by USIF Real Estate, which holds the rest. Legal proceedings have been started against Donarl seeking, in part, to foreclose on a mortgage covering its principal asset, a tract known as Aventura, which it holds for residential condominium development in North Miami Beach, Fla.

headline: SHELL, ESSO ACCEPT $30 BRITISH OIL
abstract: The British National Oil Corporation's $30-a-barrel pricing proposal was accepted by two major buyers yesterday, the Royal Dutch/Shell Group and the Esso Petroleum Company, a subsidiary of the Exxon Corporation.   The acceptance was taken as a strong sign that a price war among oil producers had been averted.  ''If Shell and Esso agree, then I can see everyone else following along,'' said Trevor Bird, a London-based oil trader. Shell and the British Petroleum Company, which is also expected to accept the new price, are the largest and most influential customers for the North Sea oil.

headline: Turkish Court Puts Off A Verdict on Publisher
abstract: A military court today put off until May 9 its verdict in the case of a newspaper publisher accused of inciting people to violate existing legislation through his reprinting of an editorial first published in 1961.

headline: Technology; As Computers Eliminate Jobs
abstract: AUTOMATION is not dehumanizing, at least not for those who buy what automatons make, says Michael Dertouzos, director of the Laboratory for Computer Science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He likes to say, in fact, that it is inherently ''re-humanizing'' because it permits the manufacture of low-cost, high-quality goods of enormous variety with capital equipment that need not be replaced, only reprogrammed.   Enthusiasts, who invariably speak in acronyms, contend that CAD, CAP and CAM, when combined in a factory to achieve CIP, may well bring on the consumer's Golden Age. They are promoting computeraided design, computer-aided planning and computer-aided manufacturing to arrive at computer-integrated production.

headline: Southland Plans Dallas Complex
abstract: The Southland Corporation said it planned to build a $400 million, 3.5-million-square-foot office complex near downtown Dallas. The complex will have two 50-story towers in a 21-acre quadrangle. Construction is to begin next year and occupancy is expected in 1986 and 1987.

headline: END OF A CAREER: FINNISH POLITICIAN AND RUMORS OF ALCOHOLISM
abstract: The once outstanding career of a former Finnish Prime Minister has ended with presidential announcements dismissing him as governor of the Bank of Finland and co-chairman of the Finnish-Soviet Economic Commission.   The removal of 60-year-old Ahti Karjalainen, who was long thought to be headed for the Finnish presidency, followed months of press reports and public discussion of what had become known as his ''personal alcohol problem.''   But Mr. Karjalainen, a chunky private man who rarely smiles, was also widely seen as a victim of what the newspaper Iltalehti denounced in a recent editorial as a ''merciless power struggle'' within his agrarian Center Party over the ''political inheritance'' of former President Urho Kekkonen. Mr. Kekkonen, who was forced to resign for reasons of health in October, 1981, had been Mr.  Karjalainen's political patron through most of his 25 years as president.

headline: SHULTZ IN BEIRUT, IS OPTIMISTIC BUT WARY
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that after completing his first round of talks with Israeli and Lebanese leaders he remained optimistic about reaching an accord on the terms for the withdrawal of Israel's troops but cautioned that he saw no easy way of bridging the difficult issues.   Surrounded by United States marines and Lebanese security men everywhere he went during a seven-hour stay here, Mr. Shultz visited the ruins of the American Embassy and the embassy temporary quarters nearby to lift the morale of the diplomats and staff members who survived the explosion 10 days ago that left some 60 dead.   Before leaving Jerusalem this morning for his first diplomatic shuttle, which took him back there tonight, Mr. Shultz proposed and Prime Minister Menachem Begin agreed that they should start an indepth discussion on overall Israeli-American relations while Mr.  Shultz is in the region over the next week or more.   The purpose of this unusual step, Mr. Shultz said on the flight here this morning, was for a thorough look at relations, which he said had undergone ''a considerable strain'' since Israel's invasion of Lebanon last June and ''to see that everything goes as well as it possibly can.''

headline: Mexico to Repay Debt
abstract: Mexico will complete repayment of a $1.85 billion bridging loan extended by central banks when it falls due in the second half of August, the director of Mexico's central bank, Miguel Mancera, said today.

headline: Canada's Tory Chief to Run
abstract: The newly installed leader of the Canadian Conservative Party, Brian Mulroney, who has never stood for political office in his life, announced today that he would contest a House of Commons seat in Nova Scotia. No date has been set for the special election. Mr. Mulroney, a 44-year-old lawyer from Montreal, won leadership of the main opposition party last weekend.

headline: FACTORY USE UP TO 72%
abstract: Factories in the United States operated at 72 percent of capacity last month, the highest level since February 1982, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.   The capacity utilized rose seven-tenths of a percentage point from April, for the sixth consecutive increase since last November's low of 67.4 percent.

headline: GROMYKO SAYS SUMMIT MEETING DEPENDS ON ATTITUDE OF U.S.
abstract: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko said today that a Soviet-American summit meeting would become feasible only when Washington adopted a ''serious and constructive'' approach to relations with Moscow.   Mr. Gromyko issued the statement through the Tass press agency in what was described as a response to ''various presumptions'' in the West about the possibility of a meeting between President Reagan and Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader.   Mr. Gromyko apparently was referring to various statements made in Washington, as well as in Western Europe and Japan, about the prospects for a summit conference.  But more specifically, his statemebt seemed to be a response to one issued in Washington last week by Secretary of State George P. Shultz saying that the Reagan Administration was looking for a ''constructive dialogue'' with Soviet leaders.

headline: Sears Debt Filing
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Company has filed a shelf registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of up to $500 million of debt securities. The company said it might sell the securities periodically through underwriters or directly to purchasers. It is expected, however, that they will be sold through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company and Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., a Sears subsidiary.

headline: FOREIGN MINISTERS OF NATO REAFFIRM PLANS FOR MISSILES
abstract: Foreign ministers of the Atlantic alliance, meeting for the last time before NATO's planned deployment of new intermediate-range nuclear missiles in Western Europe, asserted again today that they would start to deploy the weapons by the end of the year unless the Soviet Union and the United States agreed on an accord to limit medium-range missiles in Europe.   It was the third time since mid-May that a group of Western leaders had stressed that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization would go through with its plan to start deploying Pershing 2 and cruise missiles in December. Similar statements were made by the chiefs of government at the Williamsburg meeting of the leading industrial democracies and by a gathering of NATO defense ministers in Brussels.    In a preamble to the communique on today's meeting, the foreign ministers said they hoped a verifiable agreement providing for American and Soviet equality in intermediate-range missiles could be achieved at the talks in Geneva. They added, however, ''If concrete results through negotiations cannot be reached, deployments as planned will begin.''

headline: Lloyd's to Pay Millions In Kidnapping of Horse
abstract: Lloyd's of London said today that it had agreed to pay millions in the theft insurance claim for Shergar, the $15 million champion racehorse kidnapped in February from the Aga Khan's stud farm in Ireland.

headline: PRESIDENT REAGAN'S ADDRESS ON CENTRAL AMERICA TO JOINT SESSION OF CONGRESS
abstract: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's address to a joint sesion of Congress yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:   Mr. Speaker, Mr. President, distinguished members of the Congress, honored guests and my fellow Americans: A number of times in past years, members of Congress and a President have come together in meetings like this to resolve a crisis. I have asked for this meeting in the hope that we can prevent one.   It would be hard to find many Americans who are not aware of our stake in the Middle East, the Persian Gulf, or the NATO line dividing the free world from the Commnist bloc. And the same could be said for Asia.

headline: ** Company Reports ** PROLER INTERNATIONAL CORP (N)
Bethlehem Chief Critical of Rival
abstract: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation's top executive defended his company's use of foreign technology and investment capital while condemning the United States Steel Corporation's plan to import unfinished steel slabs from the British Steel Corporation.

headline: Iraq Invites Khomeini To Conference on War
abstract: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq today invited Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Iranian leader, to an Islamic conference here on the Iran-Iraq war.   Commenting on a proposal to invite an Iranian delegation, Mr.  Hussein said, ''We agree and even invite Khomeini himself to attend this conference, the same way the Iraqi people and land hosted him for 14 years'' in his exile before the 1979 Iranian revolution.

headline: POPE'S WORDS LEAVE POLES 'ALL AMAZED'
abstract: ''He has fulfilled his task completely,'' said a portly man in a group from Gdansk, basking here today in the presence of Pope John Paul II. ''He came here and did good.''   The Gdansk contingent - 760 parishioners of St. Stanislaw Kostka Church - stood under a red and white banner. The word ''Gdansk'' was written on it, with the Polish flag growing out of the ''n,'' in the familiar flowing script that was the signature of the outlawed Solidarity union.

headline: Scientific-Atlanta Shifts
abstract: Scientific-Atlanta Inc., a maker of telecommunications and microwave equipment, said yesterday that John Levergood had been named president and chief operating officer. Mr. Levergood has been senior vice president. As president, he succeeds Sidney Topol, who continues as chairman and chief executive. As chief operating officer, he succeeds Jack R. Kelly Jr., who resigned to join a venture capital firm in Atlanta.

headline: ** Company Reports ** DEAN FOODS CO (N)
abstract: Qtr to April 2 1983 1982 Sales 207,814,000 184,690,000 Net inc 4,347,000 3,732,000 Share earns .48 .41 Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split on April 20.

headline: SPECIALTY STEEL HELP IS ADVISED
abstract: The International Trade Commission recommended today that President Reagan place quotas on specialty steel imports for three years to protect American manufacturers.   The unanimous decision by the three commissioners puts pressure on the President to help the domestic industry, which makes such products as stainless steel and other special alloys. But he is not bound by law to do what the commission recommends.

headline: PRETORIA UPHOLDS RULING ON BLACKS
abstract: After several weeks of anxiety and indecision, the Government announced today that it would not seek legislation to overcome a ruling by South Africa's highest court that opens the possibility for black migrant workers to gain permanent rights as urban residents.   Pieter G. Koornhof, the Minister for Cooperation and Development, whose department administers the intricate laws that regulate the lives of blacks, acknowledged in Cape Town that the possibility that migrant workers might gain residence rights had now been ''clearly established'' and that the Government was ''obviously bound'' by an Appeals Court ruling in the case of a migrant named Mehlolo Tom Rikhoto.   But he said the Government would pass legislation before the allwhite Parliament adjourned at the end of the month to make the right of migrants to bring their wives and children to urban areas conditional on official certification that they had acquired adequate accommodation.   It was necessary to insure ''at all costs,'' Mr. Koornhof stressed, ''that unrealistic expectations of instant accommodation in urban areas are not created in the minds of urban workers and their families who are affected by the judgment.''

headline: U.S. RULES ON CABLE TV ARE PASSED BY SENATE
abstract: The Senate approved legislation today that would establish national guidelines for regulation of the growing cable television industry.   The bill, which passed on an 87-to-9 vote, puts limits on the authority of local governments to set cable rates and to charge franchise fees, but it maintains their right to require certain services, to grant monopoly franchises or to build their own cable systems rather than contract with private operators.   All six Senators from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut voted in favor of the legislation.  There is no counterpart to the Senate bill in the House, although hearings are being held to consider such legislation.  Groups representing cable operators and the local governments, after nearly a year of intense lobbying, endorsed the compromise, intended to replace the patchwork of state and local rules with a Federal law. But officials of a number of cities, including New York, continued to oppose it as too restrictive of their authority.

headline: Northern Telecom
abstract: Northern Telecom Ltd. of Montreal, which is 53.4 percent owned by Bell Canada Enterprises Inc., announced that a subsidiary had reached an agreement to supply $70 million worth of equipment over a fiveyear period to Teleglobe Canada.

headline: ** Company Reports ** NORTHEASTERN BANCORP INC (O)
abstract: Qtr to March 31 1983 1982 Net inc 2,434,000 1,584,000 Per share 1.94 1.26

headline: L.M. Ericsson Stock Offering
abstract: An issue of 3.65 million shares of the L.M. Ericsson Telephone Company was priced for offering today at $62.50 a share through underwriters led by Dillon, Read & Company and Morgan Stanley & Company.   The sale is the largest public offering by a Swedish company in this country. The shares are represented by American depository receipts.

headline: E.E.C. Tallies Young Jobless
abstract: One out of every three workers under 25 was jobless in March in some countries of the Common Market.

headline: ** Company Reports ** EATON CORP (N)
abstract: Qtr to March 31 1983 1982 Sales 612,652,000 668,106,000 Net inc 8,264,000 b13,947,000 Share earns .28 .50 b-After a loss of $6,770,000 from discontinued operations.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: SEPARATISTS BLAMED
abstract: A series of bombs exploded in public buildings in the French Caribbean territories of Guadeloupe, French Guiana and Martinique Saturday night and early today, killing one person and causing extensive property damage.   At the same time, three people were injured when two bombs exploded in central Paris. One of the explosions took place near an employment agency for workers from France's overseas territories.

headline: PROCTER & GAMBLE REPORTS 10.1% GAIN
abstract: The Procter & Gamble Company, one of the nation's leading producers of household items and pharmaceuticals, said yesterday that its first-quarter profit increased 10.1 percent, while sales rose 1.3 percent.   The Cincinnati-based company reported net income of $218 million, or $1.31 a share, up from $198 million, or $1.20 a share, in the first quarter of 1982. Sales advanced to $3.13 billion from $3.09 billion.

headline: Gas Service Co.
abstract: The Gas Service Company of Kansas City, Mo. said yesterday that it had filed a lawsuit to block a tender offer by the Missouri Public Service Company on the ground that the offer violates Federal securities and antitrust laws. On Thursday Gas Service rejected Missouri Public Service's tender offer of $14 a share for about twothirds, or 2.9 million, of Gas Service's shares outstanding.  Missouri Public Service said that it believed the courts would find the suit ''without merit.''

headline: California Utility Offers $150 Million in Bonds
abstract: A $150 million issue of Southern California Metropolitan Water Works revenue bonds was offered by Salamon Brothers yesterday.  The bonds due in 1985 were priced to yield 5.25 percent, while the longer-term bonds due in 2013 were priced at 100 to yield 8.75 percent and the 8 percent bonds due in 2023 were priced at a discount to par to yield 8.70 percent.

headline: U.S. SAYS CUBA IS FOSTERING CENTRAL AMERICA SUBVERSION
abstract: The Reagan Administration charged today that Cuba was expanding its ''political-military activism'' in Central America and that Cubans, Nicaraguans and guerrillas from El Salvador were jointly planning terrorism in the region.   The charges were contained in ''Background Paper: Central America,'' a document made public by the State and Defense Departments. It portrayed Cuba as directing subversion throughout the isthmus, working through both the Sandinist Government of Nicaragua and leftist groups in other countries.   The document had little new information. One official called it ''a compendium of background materials'' supporting the Administration contention that turmoil in Central America is caused largely by outside interference. Nearly all the incidents cited took place last year or earlier, and most have been publicized before.

headline: 39 More People Are Arrested In Italy's Crackdown on Crime
abstract: The police said today that they rounded up 39 people overnight as part of a nationwide crackdown on organized crime that has netted 454 people so far.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Atlas Copco North America Inc., Wayne, N.J., the U.S. arm of the Atlas Copco Group, Stockholm, has named C. Frank DeMeo president.   * Cabletex Corp., Garden City, L.I., a wholly owned subsidiary of Cable Applications, has appointed Robert Groll president and Harold T. Adkins senior vice president-engineering.   * Citizens Federal Savings and Loan Association, Miami, has named Alvin A. Hirsch, Thomas A. Christensen, James L. Baxley, John Kuczwanski, Robert J. Bailey, Steven S. Scotti and Richard J. Peters Jr. senior vice presidents.

headline: New York Bell Rating Lowered
abstract: Duff & Phelps, a Chicago-based bond rating company, has lowered the rating of the New York Telephone Company's outstanding refunding mortgage bonds, debentures and notes to D& P-2, High Double-A, from D& P-1, Triple-A.   These ratings are based on Duff & Phelps's analysis of New York Telephone as it will be constituted after its Jan. 1, 1984, divestiture from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. The company's bonds, debentures and notes had been rated D& P-1, Triple-A, on a predivestiture basis.

headline: ARMSTRONG WORLD ELECTS NEXT CHIEF
abstract: Armstrong World Industries, which makes flooring and other interior furnishings, said yesterday that its board of directors had named Joseph L. Jones as chairman, chief executive officer and president, effective Aug. 1.   Mr. Jones, 60 years old, will succeed Harry A. Jensen, who reaches the mandatory retirement age of 65 at that time. Mr. Jensen, who joined the company in 1940, will remain a board member.

headline: Israel Asks U.S. Team To Study Illness Report
abstract: The Israeli Health Ministry said today that it had asked the United States Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta to send a team of experts to assess the Israeli finding that poison was not the cause of mysterious ailments affecting hundreds of West Bank Palestinians.   Baruch Modan, head of the ministry, said there was no doubt about the Israeli conclusions.

headline: HONDURAS REQUESTS A 5 NATION MEETING ON CENTRAL AMERICA
abstract: Honduras called on the nations of Central America today to meet ''as soon as possible'' to work out a settlement to bring peace to the region.   The proposal was made by the Honduran delegate to a special meeting here of the 30-nation council of the Organization of American States.

headline: The U.N. Today; June 14, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Committee on Natural Resources - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Development Program Governing Council - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Subcommittee on Small Territories - 10:30 A.M.

headline: BRITISH AIR, T.W.A. IN FARE STANDOFF
abstract: British Airways yesterday slightly undercut Trans World Airlines' lower fares to London for next fall and winter, a move that was quickly matched by T.W.A. Both carriers also dropped requirements for advance purchases of tickets.   The British carrier announced that it would charge $395 round trip between New York and London and Philadelphia and London effective Oct. 1, which was $3 cheaper than the lower fares announced by T.W.A. on Thursday. Sally C. McElwreath, a spokesman for T.W.A., said that its matching fares would be effective beginning Sept. 20.

headline: Reagan Nominates Enders
abstract: President Reagan today nominated Assistant Secretary of State Thomas O. Enders to be Ambassador to Spain. Secretary of State George P. Shultz announced May 27 that Mr.  Enders, 51 years old, would be replaced as head of the Latin America Bureau.

headline: Pentagon Is Opposed to Use Of Troops in Central America
abstract: Gen. John W. Vessey Jr., Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, has affirmed the opposition of the Pentagon to the use of combat troops in Central America.   ''Neither I, nor any member of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, nor the civilian leaders in the Department of Defense advocate introducing U.S. combat forces to try to implement an American military solution to the problems of Central America,'' he said.   The comments, made in a New Orleans speech May 13, were made available here today.

headline: PESSIMISM IS MATCHING DECLINE IN ECONOMY IN FRANCE
abstract: France has entered a sensitive and difficult period of deepening economic problems, disagreement over how they should be solved and recurring talk of the possibility of social unrest.   A stiff new austerity program, which attempts to reverse the high inflation and external trade deficits of the Socialist Government's first expansionist year, has brought favorable comments outside France, but more doubt than confidence at home. Employing classical, non-Socialist deflationary tools, the plan, announced last month, has been accompanied by a rush on both the left and right of suggestions that the country is dangling at the edge of a deindustrialization process like the one experienced in Britain.   Although some computer predictions about the austerity plan's likely effects on the French economy give it chances of succeeding by the end of 1984, monthly figures released Thursday showed the Government was unlikely to meet its goal of 8 percent inflation for the year, a rate substantially higher than that of France's main industrial partners.

headline: ** Company Reports ** UNION OIL OF CALIFORNIA (N)
Danish North Sea Find
abstract: Indications of hydrocarbons have been found in a Danish North Sea region, a spokesman for the Danish Underground Consortium said today. The section is near Denmark's Gorm oil and gas field, which went into operation in mid-1982 and has estimated oil reserves of 100 million tons, the spokesman said.

headline: AN UPHEAVAL IN MEATPACKING
abstract: Bankruptcy, strikes, employee buyouts and distress sales are spreading like prairie fires through yet another old-line Middle Western business, the meatpacking industry.   According to analysts, the upheaval in the industry, which has sales of $50 billion a year, is on a scale with the vast changes now under way in the steel, auto and machine tool industries. There are many signs of this.   The Greyhound Corporation has put its Armour meatpacking division on the auction block and says it will close 13 plants in December, idling 3,000 workers. Greyhound has already sold three large slaughtering plants to a competitor, Swift Independent. Swift is itself a fledgling corporate castoff, having been spun out of Esmark Inc. less than three years ago.

headline: Dome's Chief Retires
abstract: John P. Gallagher retired yesterday as chief executive officer of Dome Petroleum Ltd., but will retain his position as chairman of the board.

headline: Air Controllers Strike At Ireland's Airports
abstract: A one-day strike by air traffic controllers shut Ireland's three main airports today and stranded thousands of travelers.   The strike by 240 controllers, who say manning levels are dangerously low, affected 90 flights and nearly 18,000 passengers at Dublin, Cork and Shannon airports.   Several thousand passengers were taken by bus to Belfast, in British-ruled Northern Ireland, and some Dublin flights were diverted there.

headline: ORDERS UP 14% IN MAY FOR TOOLS
abstract: Orders for machine tools, a barometer of industrial health, grew 14 percent from April to May, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported yesterday.   Thus, after a dismal 1982 that saw orders fall 49 percent, the tool industry began showing tentative signs of a recovery last month. Orders rose to $135.5 million in May, about 28 percent above the level of a year earlier.

headline: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
abstract: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.69 An index of yields for long-term   A-rated general obligation bonds compiled weekly by The Bond Buyer.  Aa Utility Bonds*12.13 Salomon Brothers' estimate for new long-term issues.

headline: MDS, Ztel and Wiltek Shuffle Top Executives
abstract: Top management at three communications companies was shuffled recently with the departure of Peter S. Anderson, 40, from the presidency of the MDS Systems division of the Mohawk Data Sciences Corporation in Parsippany, N.J.   Mr. Anderson resigned to become chief executive officer of Ztel, a producer of telecommunications systems based in Andover, Mass. His departure was planned for a month, and was followed by the shifting of Robert J. Amman from president of Wiltek Inc. to the vacancy at MDS Systems.

headline: MALAWI EXILES SAY AIDES FLEE TERROR
abstract: Two Cabinet ministers have fled from Malawi to Zimbabwe and four people were killed trying to leave the country in a power struggle over who is to succeed the aging President for Life, Hastings Kamuzu Banda, exile sources said today.   The exiles, in Lusaka, Zambia, said in a telephone interview that at least 10 political leaders had been killed at Dr. Banda's orders and that nearly 60 army officers were missing or presumed dead after apparently backing the ruling Malawi Congress Party's secretary, Dick Matenje, in the power struggle.   They said it was not immediately possible to verify the identity of the Cabinet ministers who fled Malawi, the former East African British protectorate of Nyasaland, which gained independence in 1964.

headline: Salvadorans Seize 2 Officers In Massacre and Kidnapping
abstract: The Defense Ministry said today that it had put two officers under house arrest in connection with a recent massacre and a kidnapping.

headline: Addendum
abstract: * Country Living magazine increasing its circulation rate base 6.6 percent, to 800,000, from 750,000, and its advertising rates by the same percent, effective with the July issue.

headline: Article 233423 -- No Title
abstract: Gulf and Western Industries sold 6,020,000 shares of the General Tire and Rubber Company yesterday in the largest single block of stock in dollar value ever traded on the New York Stock Exchange.   The trade brought $36 a share, or a total of $216,741,600. It represented 25 percent of General Tire's shares outstanding and was Gulf and Western's whole holding in this company.

headline: Mortgage Bonds Yield Up to 9 3/8%
abstract: A $64.6 million issue of A-1-rated Pennsylvania Housing Finance Agency single-family mortgage revenue bonds was offered with a maximum yield of 9 3/8 percent for bonds due in 2011 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

headline: Iran and Iraq Exchange Prisoners in Turkey
abstract: Iran and Iraq completed an exchange of prisoners of war in Turkey today when 32 Iranians flew home after negotiations that stretched well into Saturday night, the Turkish state radio reported.   On Saturday 32 Iraqi prisoners brought to Ankara for the exchange left by air for Baghdad after only brief negotiations.

headline: General Time
abstract: General Time Controls Inc. has told its 140 local employees that they will be laid off June 30.

headline: Insider Reports
abstract: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE   FEDERAL EXPRESS CORP.

headline: ** Company Reports ** SAVOY INDUSTRIES INC
abstract: Qtr to Dec 31 1982 1981 Sales 33,524,000 17,112,000 Net inc 1,466,000 b195,000 Share earns .15 Yr sales 115,794,000 60,065,000 Net inc 874,000 c67,000 Share earns .09 .01 b-Net loss. c-Includes a tax credit of $589,000.

headline: FRANCE PLANS TROOP CUTS IN 5-YEAR MILITARY PROGRAM
abstract: The Government today made public a five-year military program that calls for manpower cuts but that officials say will enhance France's ability to help defend West Germany.   The program involves a reduction of 7 percent in Army manpower and what a military expert involved in the preparation of the plan described as very small cuts in French troops stationed in West Germany. Some generals have warned that the overall reductions would seriously weaken French conventional forces.   As expected, the Government plan, which covers the period from 1984 to 1988, provides for building a seventh nuclear submarine armed with nuclear missiles, France's first nuclear-powered aircraft carrier, three hunter-killer submarines, Hades tactical nuclear missiles and some tactical weapons systems. The plan includes the purchase of airborne early-warning systems, probably American-made Awacs surveillance aircraft.

headline: German Insolvencies
abstract: Corporate insolvencies in West Germany rose 13.4 percent, to 4,301, in the first four months of 1983 from a year earlier, the Government said today.

headline: RATE HOPES PUSH DOW UP 24.44
abstract: Stock prices rose sharply yesterday as interest rates declined.  The Dow Jones industrial average rose 24.44 points, to 1,220.55, its biggest one-day advance in more than three months.  Other major market indicators also finished higher. The New York Stock Exchange's composite index of 1,500 common stocks rose 1.17, to 95.62, while Standard & Poor's 500-stock index added 2.16, to 164.84.    The main exceptions to the market's impressive performance were in the home computer sector, which has been strong.  Most notably, Texas Instruments plunged 39 1/2 points, to 118 1/4, in heavy trading. Texas Instruments said late Friday night that it expected to lose as much as $100 million for the second quarter because of a sharp drop in sales of home computers. Other computer stocks were weak. (Page D12.)

headline: ARAFAT SAYS THE ARAB LEADERS HAVE AGREED TO A CONFERENCE
abstract: Yasir Arafat, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said today that an Arab summit meeting would be convened to discuss Middle East problems. The date and site are under discussion, he said.   Mr. Arafat added that the decision was the result of efforts by Saudi Arabia, Algeria and the P.L.O., whose representatives have been touring the Middle East for the last six weeks seeking Arab consensus on Lebanon and other issues.

headline: SALVADOR VOTES AMNESTY FOR PRISONERS AND REBELS
abstract: The Constituent Assembly today unanimously approved an amnesty law that could lead to freedom for hundreds of political prisoners.   The law also offers amnesty to guerrillas who turn themselves in within 60 days.  In the assembly debate, deputies hailed the proposal as ''a very serious first step'' toward peace and ''a way for the country to emerge from this chaotic situation.'' Human rights activists said the law did not go far enough and expressed doubts that the country's best-known political prisoners would be released or that many guerrillas would surrender.

headline: BELL'S CONSUMER GROUP IN CORPORATE RESHUFFLE
abstract: Only five months after opening for business, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's new subsidiary, American Bell, is shedding a major line of business.   In a corporate reorganization, announced Sunday, A.T.& T said responsibility for consumer telephone products would be moved from American Bell to a newly formed group in the Western Electric Company, A.T.& T.'s manufacturing arm.   American Bell was started Jan. 1 in response to a Federal Communications Commission order that allowed A.T.&.T. to sell customer equipment and computer services free of Government regulation. To do that, however, A.T.&.T. was required to form a separate subsidiary to prevent the deregulated operations from being subsidized by revenues from regulated local and long-distance telephone service.

headline: Advertising; Payment Setup Held 'Outmoded'
abstract: ''This 15 percent approach to agency compensation is now outmoded, a mere vestige of past and simpler days,'' were the earth-shattering words of William M. Weilbacher, one-time agency executive, and now a consultant on advertising management. It was like saying that there is no Santa Claus.   Mr. Weilbacher was down in Grenelefe, Fla., Tuesday to report to the 1983 Workshop on Advertising Financial Management of the Association of National Advertisers on the most recent A.N.A. study of advertiser compensation of agencies, sharing the job with Paul J.  Muller, manager of advertising controls at General Foods.   Mr. Muller handled the numbers and Mr. Weilbacher the overview, of which you have just received a sample.  It was Mr. Muller who supplied the information that among the member and nonmember advertisers who responded 52 percent used the ''traditional commission arrangement,'' and that is down from 57 percent in 1979 and 68 percent in 1976.

headline: Nigeria Bid To I.M.F.
abstract: Nigeria, its economy hard-hit by the international oversupply of oil and the sharp decline in energy prices, has requested aid from the International Monetary Fund, monetary officials said today.   The officials said no specific figure had been attached to the request, although the country was eligible to draw up to $2.6 billion from the fund over three years.

headline: BUSINESS TRAVEL: AMENITIES CURBED
abstract: The chairman of the Xerox Corporation now flies coach class on domestic business trips. The Digital Equipment Corporation will not pick up the tab for drinks employees order with a meal while on the road. And the General Motors Corporation has started to monitor by computer all corporate travel.   The costs of business travel, for more and more corporations, are beginning to seriously stretch budgets. Accordingly, they are tightening up on travel spending, negotiating corporate discounts and using automation to keep track of travel expenses.

headline: N.W. Ayer Is Assigned All Beatrice Candies
abstract: Beatrice Foods has consolidated all of its candy brands into a newly formed unit called Beatrice Confections, which will be based in St. Louis.

headline: Air Force Said to Make Bleak Missile Analysis
abstract: An Air Force official said today that a new study submitted to the Senate Armed Services Committee estimates that as few as 1 percent of American land-based missiles might survive a Soviet first strike.   According to the official, who asked not to be identified, the new estimate put the proportion of surviving missiles after a perfectly executed Soviet first strike in 1989 at somewhere between 1 percent and 7 percent.

headline: U.S.-Soviet Grain Talks
abstract: The Agriculture Department announced today that talks with the Soviet Union on a new long-term grain supply agreement would be held in London next Thursday.   The grain talks will follow Wednesday's regularly scheduled consultative meeting on agriculture.  The current grain agreement expires Sept.30.

headline: REAGAN NOW BACKS INCREASE IN AID FOR ISRAEL
abstract: The Reagan Administration has switched positions and told Congress that it will now support Congressional efforts to increase military and economic grants to Israel by some $400 million, State Department officials said today.   According to the officials, Nicholas A. Veliotes, Assistant Secretary for Near Eastern and Asian Affairs, told a House Appropriations subcommittee on Tuesday that the Administration would support the additional aid as long as it was not taken from some other country's allocation. The Administration is asking Congress to appropriate more money for the extra aid to Israel.

headline: STAKE IN VOLKSWAGEN IS ACQUIRED BY KUWAIT
abstract: The Government of Kuwait has widened its interest in Western European industry by acquiring nearly 10 percent of Volkswagenwerk A.G., the auto manufacturer, industry sources said today.   Ortwin Witzel, a spokesman at Volkswagen headquarters in Wolfsburg, said his company could not confirm the report. He said VW had indications that Kuwait had acquired ''more than 5 percent'' of the shares but was unable to trace purchases made over a long period of time.

headline: Supply System's Chief Joins Nuclear Company
abstract: Robert L. Ferguson, departing chief of the Washington Public Power Supply System, has a new job lined up for the fall. Mr. Ferguson, whose resignation for health reasons becomes effective Friday, will start Sept. 1 as chairman of U.N.C. Nuclear Industries, three miles from his supply system headquarters in Richland, Wash.   ''I have 20 years' experience in the nuclear business, so it is a natural thing,'' said Mr. Ferguson, who is 50. He replaces Dennis Spurgeon, acting chairman, who returns to his position as resource group vice president at the parent company, U.N.C. Resources of Falls Church, Va.

headline: MOTIVE FOR A HITLER HOAX: PRO-SOVIET PROPAGANDA?
abstract: If the volumes purported to be the diaries of Adolf Hitler turn out to be forgeries, the assumption of a number of experts is that they were concocted in Eastern Europe in an effort to undermine West Germany's relationship with its allies.   The first glimpses of the contents of the diaries, published here by Stern magazine and the Sunday Times of London, present no clear present-day political orientation. But as skepticism about their authenticity grows, the fragmentary extracts made public so far have furnished signposts for the analysts who will be looking for a possible manipulation of history as the volumes are disclosed.   They say a central thesis that might be developed in such a manipulation by the East German and Soviet secret services would be that the West turned down opportunities to end World War II, prolonged the suffering it created, and holds the historical responsibility for the eventual division of Germany.

headline: Hughes Satellite
abstract: The Hughes Aircraft Company's subsidiary, Hughes Communications Galaxy Inc., said is planning to launch its first commercial communications satellite, Galaxy One, to transmit cable programming by Home Box Office Inc., Group W Broadcasting and Cable, Times Mirror Satellite Programming, Viacom International, the Turner Broadcasting System and others. The company declined to discuss the cost of the project, but trade publications have put it at $100 million.

headline: ORGANIZED UNITS BLAMED FOR PARIS BRAWL
abstract: A leading police official today accused ''organized and determined groups'' of being behind the new round of street fighting that broke out Tuesday as students continued their demonstrations against the Government's proposed changes in the university system.   The official, Joseph Franceschi, Secretary of State for public security, stopped short of accusing right-wing extremist organizations, but other officials have privately attributed the fighting over the last six weeks to young extremists of the left and right wings and to apolitical brawlers who attach themselves to the groups.   The Government, comparing the protests with those of May 1968 when hundreds of thousands of students were in the streets, says the current demonstrations and brawls appear circumscribed. The crowds have not grown in size since April, no substantial support for the students has developed within the labor movement or the population at large, and the Government has reached agreements ending strikes with some protesters, notably medical students.

headline: The U.N. Today; May 4, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Special Committee on the Charter of the United Nations and on the Strengthening of the Role of the Or- ganizations - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. headline: HIGH COURT IN REBUFF TO I.R.S.
abstract: The Supreme Court handed a setback to the Internal Revenue Service today, ruling unanimously that the agency, like all creditors, can be required to return property seized from a company that later seeks reorganization under the Federal bankruptcy law.   The Court said that one goal of the Bankruptcy Reform Act of 1978 was to facilitate successful reorganizations by permitting bankrupt companies to continue operating. ''The reorganization effort would have small chance of success,'' Associate Justice Harry A. Blackmun wrote for the Court, ''if property essential to running the business were excluded'' from the assets available to the company.   To that end, the Court said, Congress enabled the debtor company to get back its property, including property seized or repossessed by creditors before the bankruptcy petition was filed. ''Nothing in the Bankruptcy Code or its legislative history indicates that Congress intended a special exception for the tax collector,'' Justice Blackmun said.

headline: SKEPTICISM GROWING OVER THE 'HITLER DIARIES'
abstract: Skepticism over the authenticity of Hitler's purported diaries widened yesterday among historians, former aides of the dictator and handwriting experts in Britain, West Germany and the United States as the first excerpts were published.   Disbelief was expressed by David Irving and Lord Bullock, British historians and experts on Hitler; Werner Maser, a West German historian; two of Hitler's former personal aides, and Charles Hamilton Jr., an American expert on handwriting who has just completed an 800-page, two-volume study called ''Autographs of the Third Reich.''   ''I'm sure it's a hoax,'' Mr. Hamilton said in an interview in New York yesterday after seeing three photostatic sheets from the purported diaries, including two bearing Hitler signatures. ''The whole story is a misbegotten prevarication. The forgers are probably luxuriating right now in the south of France.''

headline: SOVIET CALLS REBUFF BY GROMYKO UNEQUIVOCAL
abstract: The official Soviet press agency said today that Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko had been unambiguous in rejecting President Reagan's latest arms control proposal.   The agency suggested that the State Department misinterpreted Mr.  Gromyko's remarks, which he made in a news conference Saturday in Moscow. Although the State Department called Mr. Gromyko's stand ''unconstructive,'' it also depicted his response as an ''initial'' one and stressed its ''relatively restrained'' tone.

headline: Riot Police and Youths Clash in Soweto
abstract: Riot policemen and stone-throwing youths clashed in Soweto today, and cars were set on fire as blacks commemorated the anniversary of the 1976 riots here.

headline: Mexico Approves Debt Plan
abstract: After weeks of negotiations with foreign bankers, the Mexican Government today announced a complicated plan to free up enough dollars to allow Mexican corporations to repay their foreign debts in the future.   The plan, which is limited to companies able to win payment extensions from their foreign lenders, appears to be aimed in part at pressuring foreign banks into rescheduling some $15 billion in outstanding private debt.

headline: ODD MAN OUT IN AFRICA: MALAWI VOTES
abstract: The citizens of this landlocked Central African country voted today in a parliamentary election that will probably cause little change in either their lives or in the way this country has been governed for the last 19 years.   About two million of Malawi's six million people are believed to have registered to vote for candidates bidding for the 101 elected seats in Parliament. As they have little final say over who the candidates are or what they stand for, the true test of sentiment will be the level of abstentions, reflecting apathy or protest.   Malawi is a one-party state run by a Life President, Dr. Hastings Kamuzu Banda, who has led the nation since its independence from Britain in 1964. He has done so in a manner described by friends as paternalistic and by enemies as harshly dictatorial, controlling both the political and the economic life of the country. Apart from the presidency, he also heads the Ministries of Agriculture, Justice, Information, Tourism, Works, Foreign Affairs and Defense.

headline: FAMILY CLASH ON MACANDREWS
abstract: Faith G. Perelman, the estranged wife of Ronald O. Perelman, chairman of MacAndrews & Forbes Group Inc., asserted yesterday that she owns a 33.9 percent controlling block of the candy flavoring company's stock that her husband has long claimed.   The assertion, in a document filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, cast doubts on plans by Mr. Perelman to buy the company and led to a $2 decline in the price of the stock on the American Stock Exchange, where it ended the day at $46.   ''Her claim to that stock is a joke,'' said Roy M. Cohn, Mr.  Perelman's lawyer. ''Every filing for the last six years lists him as the owner, and not once has she ever claimed any kind of interest in that stock.''

headline: I.M.F. SEEN DELAYING LATEST LOANS TO BRAZIL
abstract: The International Monetary Fund has decided to postpone for at least a month the distribution of some $411 million in loans to Brazil because of doubts that the country is complying with an economic austerity program required by the I.M.F., monetary sources reported yesterday.   The funds, part of $2.5 billion in loans promised by the I.M.F. for this year, were to become available to Brazil on June 1.  Monetary officials said, however, that a delay in the loans would not have any serious effects on Brazil's already beleaguered economy.  One of the austerity measures in its agreement with the I.M.F.  required Brazil to reduce inflation to an annual rate of 85 to 90 percent, but it has shot up to an annual rate of 150 percent, from 99.7 percent last year.

headline: ** Company Reports ** BECTON DICKINSON & CO (N)
Market Continues Slide; Dow Off 7.45
abstract: Stock prices fell moderately yesterday, with some of the technology issues registering the largest losses. Trading accelerated from Monday.   The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 7.45 points, to 1,120.16. In the last three sessions, the blue-chip barometer, which includes 30 leading companies, has lost 23 points, mainly because of concern over the recent rise in interest rates.

headline: U.S. IS PLANNING BID TO WIN OVER EUROPE'S YOUNG
abstract: The Reagan Administration is devising a broad strategy to counteract what it views as growing anti-American tendencies among younger Europeans, according to Government officials.   The target of this strategy is a new generation of European leaders who share none of their parents' experience immediately after World War II, when Americans and Europeans worked closely to form a military alliance and reconstruct Europe's shattered economies.   Government and private public-opinion polls show that these young leaders - known here as the ''successor generation'' - have a far less positive image of the United States, partly because their perceptions have been shaped by American involvement in Vietnam and by domestic crises like Watergate. Troublesome Implications Seen   Government and private analysts are warning that the emergence of a new, far more skeptical generation of European leaders, if their attitudes persist, has troublesome implications for future cooperation between Western Europe and the United States.

headline: Washington Watch; Congress Slow On Rivlin Post
abstract: THE wheels of Congress roll slowly. It has been seven months since Alice M. Rivlin, the director of the Congressional Budget Office, announced she was leaving this year. But Congress - specifically the House and Senate budget committees - has barely moved to seek, much less choose, a new director.   Asked where the selection process is, one Congressional aide replied, ''You've heard of that lovely place called limbo.'' Rudolph G. Penner, the conservative economist and budget expert from the American Enterprise Institute, is still the front-runner.  But as of last week, he said, he hadn't heard word one. He said he is keeping himself in the race, however.

headline: KISSINGER SAYS ASSERTIONS OF DOUBLE-DEALING ARE 'SLIMY LIES'
abstract: Henry A. Kissinger denied today that he had offered his services to both sides in the Presidential campaign of 1968.   A new book by Seymour M. Hersh describes the former Secretary of State as offering to share derogatory files about the Republican, Richard M. Nixon, with the camp of the Democrat, Hubert H. Humphrey, and offering later by letter to work for Mr. Humphrey at the same time he was giving the Nixon camp information on the Vietnam negotiations being conducted by the Administration of Lyndon B.  Johnson.   ''There were no derogatory files,'' Mr. Kissinger said in a telephone interview, ''only a compilation of Nixon speeches.'' ''There was no offer on such a file,'' he added. ''There was no letter to Humphrey. These are slimy lies. No one will be able to produce any evidence to the contrary. Let them produce the letter.  They will not be able to produce such a letter.''

headline: Eurobonds Rise Slightly
abstract: Dollar Eurobond prices rose slightly today in quiet trading ahead of the Association of International Bond Dealers meeting, which starts Wednesday. Dealers said that trading was likely to remain light until after the bond dealers' meeting, which ends Friday, and the Monday bank holiday in Britain.  The new $75 million I.C.I. 8 7/8 percent 1991 issue with equity warrants was initially priced at 99 1/2 to 100 1/4.

headline: LITTLE JOY AFTER COMMON MARKET SESSION
abstract: A three-day meeting of Western European leaders ended today without a resolution to the European Economic Community's grave financial problems and with a victory for Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on reducing Britain's contribution to the group's budget.   Camouflaging the lack of a substantive accord, the 10 heads of Government agreed that their Foreign and Finance Ministers would meet under ''a special emergency procedure'' to draft a package of proposals to be submitted to the next Common Market summit meeting in Athens in December.   Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who strove to keep the meeting from breaking up in open disagreement, acknowledged at a news conference that its outcome ''gave no reason to be excessively joyful.'' But he expressed the hope that a ''process'' had been started that could lead to wider agreement.

headline: THE RIFT OVER PROTECTING THE CONSUMER
abstract: WASHINGTON ''M R. S. lost his job and was unable to keep up the loan payments,'' begins a case history from the Legal Aid Society. ''The creditor is now seizing the car and household furnishings. They are taking the furniture several pieces at a time on different days. Essentially, they appear to be doing this to force Mr. S. to make payments on the loan.''   Whether he knew it or not, ''Mr. S.'' had signed a loan contract giving the creditor a blanket security interest in his household goods, which include pots, pans, the baby's crib and the family Bible. These goods rarely have significant resale value, but they usually have great psychological value to their owners. Finance companies, banks and credit unions use the security interests to ''threaten the consumer with extreme deprivation to induce the consumer to acquiesce to the creditor's demands, whether or not the demands are reasonable,'' according to a Federal Trade Commission staff report.   The F.T.C. staff has urged that such credit practices be made illegal. But the self-styled ''deregulators'' now managing the commission are showing no signs of wanting to approve the change.  ''Consumers are not as ignorant as you might suspect,'' said Wendy Lee Gramm, director of the F.T.C.'s Bureau of Economics, implying that people could shop around for the best loan contract.
