headline: Around the World; 90 Are Reported Hurt In Kashmir Brawling
abstract: At least 90 people were injured today in political clashes in the north Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir, which holds local elections on June 5, the Press Trust of India, a news agency, reported.   The report said the fighting was between supporters of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Congress Party and those of the National Conference Party, which rules the state.

headline: Executive Pay Off a Bit
abstract: Although many top executives took pay cuts last year because of the recession, the reductions were much less than the decline in corporate earnings, according to a report published today. U.S. News and World Report said the average pay of the heads of leading corporations was $365,000 last year, down 2.7 percent from 1981, while profits after taxes plummeted 22.4 percent.  Twenty-nine of the 916 executives surveyed made more than $1 million a year, three more than in the previous year.

headline: U.S. Said to Shift Burdens
abstract: The Reagan Administration wants to exploit the seven-nation Williamsburg economic summit meeting to solve economic problems of the United States at the expense of its allies, Tass said today. The Soviet press agency said that because the West was plagued by economic problems and high unemployment, ''the United States seeks to shift the consequences of the crisis on its partners.''

headline: OUTLAYS UP
abstract: Two months after securing a multibillion-dollar rescue package through international financing, Brazil, the world's largest debtor nation, is seeking to borrow more money.   The country's spending in the first quarter of 1983 has grown far beyond the guidelines established with the International Monetary Fund, which sponsored the rescue package along with the United States Treasury and a consortium of European and American banks, and an I.M.F. official from Washington is in Brasilia, the capital, asking for explanations.   ''The program really only got started in March, and the I.M.F. may have overlooked the fact that it takes time for exports and payments of this type to generate cash surpluses,'' said Antonio Gebauer, vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and the principal American banking figure in the international operation of assistance to Brazil. Alarm on Public Deficit   He added, however, that the country would have to get ''tougher'' with the giant state companies whose debts have swollen the public deficit to a point that has alarmed the I.M.F.   Brazilian officials are telling their creditor banks that they require at least $1.5 billion to overcome cash-flow problems between now and June. More pessimistic estimates in the banking community put the country's needs at $3 billion to $4 billion.

headline: RED CROSS CRITICIZES IRAN AND IRAQ
abstract: The International Committee of the Red Cross said today that both Iran and Iraq had violated international law in their treatment of war prisoners. It accused the two countries of ''summary executions of captive soldiers, abandoning of enemy wounded on the battlefield and indiscriminate bombardment of towns and villages.''   The statement was an unusual departure from Red Cross practice of not making charges public. The private, all-Swiss committee said it had decided to speak out because Iran and Iraq had ignored appeals to cease ''grave and repeated violations of international humanitarian law'' during their war, which began in September 1980.

headline: ARAFAT REACHES AMMAN, BUT HUSSEIN DELAYS MEETING
abstract: Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, arrived here today for talks with King Hussein that are expected to determine whether Jordan will enter peace negotiations with Israel on the basis of the President Reagan's Middle East peace plan.   Mr. Arafat was expected in Amman last Sunday for a long-awaited meeting with King Hussein, but instead of coming directly to the Jordanian capital he traveled around the eastern Arab world, consulting with the leaders of Saudi Arabia, Iraq, Bahrain and Kuwait and with senior P.L.O. officials in Damascus.   Now that Mr. Arafat has finally arrived in Amman, King Hussein seems to be taking his time about seeing him, apparently retaliating for the P.L.O. leader's tardiness.   Shortly after Mr. Arafat drove into the capital from Damascus in a silver Mercedes, senior Jordanian officials indicated that the Arafat-Hussein meeting was not expected to take place before Saturday. The King was reportedly busy tonight and intent on taking his day of rest Friday, the Moslem sabbath and Jordanian weekend.

headline: U.S. Reinstates Travel Curbs On Cuban Diplomats at U.N.
abstract: The United States has reinstated restrictions on the travel of Cuba's United Nations diplomats to an area within 25 miles of New York City, the State Department said tonight.   In a written statement, the Department said the Cuban officials at the United Nations have ''misused their freedom to travel by engaging in unlawful activities such as espionage.'' The restriction does not apply to officials of the Cuban Interests Section in Washington.

headline: ** Company Reports ** STRUTHERS WELLS CORP (A)
abstract: Qtr to Feb 28 1983 1982 Revenue 11,784,911 16,390,623 Net loss b939,880 c199,799 Share earns .06 Shares outst 3,045,730 3,009,730 b-After an extraordinary gain of$31,198. c-Net income includes an extraordinary gain of $16,182.

headline: Prudential Realty Issues New Mortgage Security
abstract: Prudential Realty Securities Inc. introduced a new kind of mortgage-backed security yesterday with a $300.2 million issue of zero-coupon bonds due annually from 1984 to 1997.   The bonds, which are offered by Salomon Brothers and Prudential-Bache Securities, are backed by a pool of conventional home mortgages that were originated by the Prudential Insruance Company of America in the 1960's.

headline: TUESDAY, MAY 24, 1983
abstract: Markets   Stock prices staged a dramatic turnaround after falling sharply in early trading. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 10.54 points, to 1,200.56; at 10:30 A.M., it was down almost 13 points. Over all, advances outnumbered declines by 835 to 790; in the first half hour, declines were ahead by a ratio of more than 9 to 1. (Page D1.)   Bond prices rose slightly, but rates on three- and six-month Treasury bills rose to the highest level in seven weeks at the weekly auction. (D10.) The dollar was mixed against other currencies, while gold prices rose a dollar an ounce in New York, to $437.50. (D16.) Prices of precious metals futures finished higher. (D16.)

headline: ECONOMY UP 2.5% IN 1ST QUARTER
abstract: The economy grew at a 2.5 percent annual rate, after adjustment for inflation, in the first quarter this year, slower than originally estimated, the Commerce Department reported today.   The downward revision from an original estimate of 3.1 percent was a result of a sharper decline in inventories than had been assumed, however, and does not change the outlook for significantly stronger growth this quarter, economists said.   Several measures of corporate profits released today left a mixed picture of business activity in the quarter. The Commerce Department's preferred measure, profits from current production, jumped 12.4 percent from last year's fourth quarter, after having slipped 1 percent in the fourth quarter. The better-known measure of after-tax profits declined 4.6 percent after falling 1.3 percent in the fourth quarter.

headline: ABC Net Outlook
abstract: The American Broadcasting Companies will report that first quarter earnings fell about 35 cents a share from the period a year before, Frederick S. Pierce, ABC president, told security analysts.

headline: BENKINS TO BE SOLD TO JACOBS
abstract: Irwin L. Jacobs, the multimillionaire Minneapolis investor in undervalued companies, has won a short-lived battle with the Belzberg brothers of Canada to acquire the Bekins Company, a major Los Angeles-based moving corporation.   Bekins and Minstar Inc., a boat manufacturer headed by Mr. Jacobs, announced yesterday that they had signed definitive agreements for Minstar to purchase Bekins for $89.2 million, or $23 a share. In addition to the cash tender offer, Minstar has acquired an option from Bekins to buy 1 million unissued shares of Bekins for $23 a share.   Last Saturday, Bekins announced an agreement in principle to be acquired by a subsidiary of the Far West Financial Corporation, a savings and loan holding company controlled by the Belzberg family, for $21 a share. That offer came shortly after a $20-a-share offer for Bekins from Far West was rejected. However, Far West did not purchase any Bekins shares before or after this announcement, while Mr. Jacobs and three associates bought 9.4 percent of the 3.9 million outstanding shares of Bekins on Monday.

headline: ** Company Reports ** NELSON RESEARCH & DEVELOPMENT CO (O)
abstract: Qtr to March 31 1983 1982 Revenue 608,000 365,000 Net inc 37,000 b8,000 Share earns .01  b-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $4,000.

headline: A MOSCOW SPRING: EASTER EGGS AND WAR RIBBONS
abstract: Sunday was Orthodox Easter, and in an observance gaining more popularity with every year, tens of thousands of Muscovites flooded the city's cemeteries with flowers, traditional Easter foods and colored eggs.   Today was Victory Day, and hundreds of thousands more turned out resplendent in medals and campaign ribbons to seek out comrades and relive the dimming feats of arms. It was an unlikely pairing, but the rare convergence of two of the Soviet Union's most popular holidays drew some of the largest crowds in memory to Moscow's churches, parks, squares and streets.   Few holidays would appear as disparate here. Easter, the most important celebration in the Russian Orthodox Church calendar, is officially nonexistent and tolerated only reluctantly by the atheistic regime.

headline: Congressmen Attacked Over El Salvador Stand
abstract: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, chief United States delegate to the United Nations, was quoted today as saying that some members of Congress would like to see a Marxist administration in El Salvador. She did not name them.

headline: Prices to Farmers Rise
abstract: Prices farmers get for raw products rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in March, the third consecutive monthly increase, matching levels of a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today. Higher prices for beef cattle, tomatoes, corn, eggs and wheat were mostly responsible for the increase, but lower prices for hogs, oranges and broilers partially offset the gains for the other commodities, the department said.

headline: Thrift Unit Trial to Begin
abstract: A Federal judge refused today to delay a challenge to the Federal takeover of Biscayne Federal Savings and Loan Association, saying the trial was too important to wait until June.   Biscayne and its principal stockholder, Kaufman & Broad Inc., had asked Judge Eugene P. Spellman to put the trial off until June 30 so he could take more depositions and closely examine tapes of meetings of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: 169 Products Introduced
abstract: Thanks to a smorgasbord of new cheeses, snacks and health foods, 169 new products were introduced last month, a 19-year, 5-month record.

headline: LIFE INSURANCE NEEDS: IGNORE THE RULES
abstract: YOU should carry life insurance equal to seven times your annual income. For years that has been one of the verities of middle-class economic life, ranking with the conventional wisdom about having a will and keeping receipts.   But many old beliefs about life insurance are being challenged by recent sociological developments. The archetypal nuclear family with a breadwinning husband, a housekeeper wife and several children is giving way to more two-income families, childless couples and single-parent households. And each category generates different insurance needs. So does the growth in other types of income support programs - such as pension and profit-sharing plans - that might supplement life insurance.

headline: MANY STOCK MARKETS ABROAD REPORT GAINS IN FIRST QUARTER
abstract: Signs of economic recovery were a stimulus to share prices on the world's major equity markets during the first quarter. But in dollar terms, no overseas exchange performed as well as in the United States, where signals of resurgence are strongest and where the stock market continued the rally that started last August.   ''Most of the major markets made some net progress in the first quarter,'' said M. David Testa, chairman of Rowe-Price Fleming International, an investment advisory firm based in Baltimore, ''but there is a sense that the United States will have to take the lead in triggering the recovery.''   ''When that becomes a more assured prospect,'' he added, ''foreign markets will move ahead more vigorously.'' For the first two months of the year, the Capital International World Index of prices on all major exchanges rose 3.7 percent.  Capital International is a Swiss-based investment group that monitors developments on international equity markets.

headline: LABOR PARTY CHIEF TO QUIT AFTER LOSS TO MRS. THATCHER
abstract: The leader of Britain's Labor Party, Michael Foot, indicated today that he planned to step down in October after his party's defeat in last week's general election.   Within minutes of Mr. Foot's disclosure, which came more quickly than expected, two prominent party figures said they would seek the 69-year-old leader's job. They are Neil Kinnock, the party's 41-yearold spokesman on education, a Welsh left-winger who is considered Mr. Foot's protege; and Peter Shore, 59, the economic spokesman, who is perhaps best known for his passionate opposition to Britain's membership in the Common Market.   Roy Hattersley, a 50-year-old Yorkshireman, announced his candidacy for the leadership six hours later. He is widely believed to have the best chance of stopping Mr. Kinnock. Mr. Hattersley, Labor's spokesman on domestic policy, who has a large following among party right-wingers, urged on television that a bruising internal fight be avoided at all costs.

headline: 400 OF 4,000 SITES DRAW OIL BIDDERS
abstract: At the Interior Department's latest - and largest - offshore leasing auction, held in New York yesterday, 12 oil companies, led by Shell Offshore Inc., the Atlantic Richfield Company and the Gulf Oil Corporation, bid on only 40 of the more than 4,000 blocks in the mid-Atlantic that were available.   Together, the 12 companies placed 52 bids, totaling $86.8 million.  The high bids on the 40 blocks they sought came to $71.1 million.  The auction took place under something of a legal cloud, since three states, New York, Virginia and Maryland, have filed lawsuits to block the sale of hundreds of parcels among the 4,050 leases on the outer continental shelf in the mid-Atlantic. But only four tracts in contested areas ended up attracting bids, all of them in New York regions.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * Comserv Corp., Minneapolis, has elected Richard Daly chairman and Ted Priem as president.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: SOVIET IS CRITICAL OF CHINESE AGAIN
abstract: A Soviet newspaper today criticized China more harshly than at any time since moves toward better relations between the two countries began last year.   The Government newspaper Izvestia said Peking, despite avowals of readiness to improve relations, had persisted in a policy of ''anti-Sovietism.''   A commentary noted the ''atmosphere of normalcy'' that had been achieved in two rounds of talks and reiterated readiness to improve ties. But it said Chinese words and deeds were having a negative impact.

headline: SOVIET IS CRITICAL OF NEW MISSILE BID
abstract: The first Soviet commentary on President Reagan's offer to reduce the planned deployment of missiles in Europe said today that the plan would upset the strategic balance between the United States and the Soviet Union and ''can hardly play a constructive role.''   The commentary, by the Novosti press agency, said Mr. Reagan's proposal, which is contingent on agreement on an equal number of warheads on Soviet and American medium-range missiles, was not aimed at an accord with Moscow so much as seeking to pacify Western European public opinion.

headline: Times Microfilms Licensed to Xerox
abstract: The New York Times Company and the Xerox Corporation announced yesterday that they had signed an exclusive licensing agreement under which University Microfilms International, which is owned by Xerox, will take over the production and marketing of microfilms of The New York Times and The Times Index.   The terms of the agreement were not disclosed, but the Times Company said that the transaction, involving license fees, royalties and inventory, would contribute approximately 40 cents a share to its second-quarter results. Earnings for the second quarter last year were $1.19 a share.

headline: Bush Begins a Trip to Europe To Explain U. S. Latin Policy
abstract: Vice President Bush left today for a two-week tour of Europe, where he will try to convince Governments there that the Reagan Administration is trying to promote democracy in Central America, ''imperfect as some of the systems are.''   Mr. Bush flies first to London, where he will meet with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, and will go on to West Germany, Norway, Sweden, Finland, Denmark, Ireland and Iceland.

headline: ARAFAT PUTS OFF RETURN TO AMMAN
abstract: Yasir Arafat chose not to return to Amman today to complete his talks with King Hussein because of substantial differences that remain between the two men over how to respond to President Reagan's Middle East peace proposal, P.L.O. officials said.    The P.L.O. chairman's failure to come back from Kuwait as scheduled appeared to quash any immediate hopes that the P.L.O. would grant the Jordanian King a mandate to negotiate with Israel on its behalf, or of working out a joint P.L.O.-Jordanian formula that might have permitted both parties to take part in American-sponsored peace talks.   Mr. Arafat had asked King Hussein for a recess in their negotiations Tuesday morning so he could fly to Kuwait for further consultations with his Palestinian colleagues. The P.L.O. leader indicated to the Jordanians when he left that he would be back by Thursday or today to wind up the talks and the Jordanians issued a communique to that effect.

headline: Canada Investment Plan
abstract: Canada will streamline its review process for potential foreign investors, the country's International Trade Minister, Ed Lumley, announced today. Canada's Foreign Investment Review Agency has been criticized in the United States as an obstacle to trade between the two neighbors.

headline: MOST WEST BANK ARABS BLAMING U.S. FOR IMPASSE
abstract: Leading Palestinians living under Israeli occupation are blaming a variety of parties for the breakdown in talks between King Hussein of Jordan and the Palestine Liberation Organization. Some are still hoping for a renewal of the Jordanian-P.L.O. dialogue on entering American-sponsored negotiations with Israel over the future of the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.    Depending on their political viewpoints, some Palestinians hold Israel responsible for discouraging negotiations by continuing construction of Jewish settlements in the territories. Most blame the United States for failing to force Israel to halt the settlements.  Some pro-Jordanians blame Palestinian radicals for refusing to abandon their illusions and confront political reality. And some pro-P.L.O. figures blame King Hussein for resisting the creation of a Palestinian state and seeking merely to reoccupy the West Bank.

headline: Tennessee Banks
abstract: The failure of five Tennessee banks last week will cost the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation nearly $80 million for bad loans not assumed by the banks' new owners, the agency said. The Feb. 14 collapse of the United American Bank of Knoxville, which led to last week's failures, will cost at least $90 million.

headline: Austrian Chancellor Resigns; His Deputy to Form Coalition
abstract: Chancellor Bruno Kreisky formally stepped down today in favor of his deputy, Fred Sinowatz.  Mr. Kreisky announced he would resign as Chancellor after the Socialists lost their majority in Parliament on April 24.

headline: SOVIET OIL REVENUE ROSE IN '82
abstract: The Soviet Union, contrary to expectations of some Western analysts, managed to overcome a decline in world oil prices and to increase its crucial hard-currency revenue from oil exports in 1982.   Foreign trade statistics recently released in Moscow show that income from exports of crude oil and refined petroleum products to Western Europe, the principal non-Communist market for Soviet oil, rose by 13 percent last year, to some $16 billion, using the official conversion rate for the ruble.   This represented about 60 percent of the Soviet Union's foreign exchange earnings, which the Russians need to pay for imports of grain and high technology from the West.   ''They evidently decided that they must earn a certain amount of foreign exchange for planned imports from the West, and are able to mobilize the additional supplies,'' said Marshall Goldman, associate director of Harvard University's Russian Research Center, in commenting on last year's oil-export drive.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Aetna Life and Casualty, Hartford, has named James S. Dailey president and chief executive officer of its Ponderosa Homes subsidiary.   * Allegheny Beverage Corp., Baltimore, has appointed Harry J. Conn, A. Joseph Hering, Milton H. Neidlinger and James P. Sheridan senior vice presidents.

headline: Citicorp Shares
abstract: Citicorp said that it had acquired four million shares of its common stock, for $166 million, in open-market transactions and that the repurchase program announced Feb. 15 had been completed. Citicorp purchased the shares with part of the $390 million proceeds of a four-million-share offering of $100 liquidation value adjustablerate preferred stock sold in February. The remainder of the proceeds of the issue have been added to the corporation's equity capital, which totaled $5.2 billion at the end of March.

headline: Kennecott Raises Prices
abstract: The Kennecott Corporation said today that it was raising its base price for copper by a cent a pound, to 83 cents, effective immediately. Several other copper manufacturers have raised prices recently.

headline: Bonn Official Supports Weinberger on Missiles
abstract: Defense Minister Manfred Worner, in an interview published today, backed recent assertions by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger that the Soviet Union had deployed nuclear weapon systems in countries of Eastern Europe.   Mr. Worner said in the interview, in Hamburg's Welt am Sonntag, that the Soviet Union has had such weapons systems in Warsaw Pact nations ''for a long time.''

headline: C.I.A. REPORTED BLOCKED IN PLOT ON SURINAMESE
abstract: The Reagan Administration dropped a plan this year to overthrow the Government of Suriname, the former Dutch colony in South America, after Congressional committees objected, Administration officials said today.   The plan, according to the officials, called for the formation of a small paramilitary force composed mainly of Surinamese exiles opposed to the authoritarian Government of Lieut. Col. Desi Bouterse. The force was supposed to infiltrate the capital, Paramaribo, and oust the Government, the officials said.   Colonel Bouterse, who seized power in a military coup in 1980, is viewed by Reagan Administration officials as an unpredictable leader with pro-Communist sympathies. Last December his regime rounded up 15 leading opponents, including prominent citizens, and had them summarily executed, according to the Administration.

headline: American Ship Building Names New Top Officer
abstract: George M. Steinbrenner 3d, chairman of the American Ship Building Company, has announced that George A. Chandler will be elected president and chief executive.   Mr. Steinbrenner is also principal owner of the New York Yankees, and Mr. Chandler's job might seem akin to Billy Martin's management duties at the Yankees.   But the comparison is feeble, especially when it comes to tenure.  Edward C. Forbes, who is leaving the posts at the age of 67, has held them since 1978. He will remain a director and vice chairman of the company.

headline: Fotomat Suit
abstract: The Fotomat Corporation has agreed to pay $10 million to 23 holders of its photo-processing franchises to settle a six-and-a-half-year-old antitrust suit.

headline: PREVIOUS VOTES ON COVERT AID
abstract: In action previous to today's vote by the House Foreign Affairs Committee to end covert aid to Nicaraguan rebels, Congressional committees took these steps:   - On May 3 the House intelligence committee approved and referred to the Foreign Affairs Committee a bill that would force the President to stop, sometime during this fiscal year, all covert aid for the anti-Government forces in Nicaragua. The bill also authorized $80 million in this fiscal year and the next to help countries in Central America block the cross-border shipment of arms to leftist guerrillas.

headline: UNDERWRITINGS SURGE IN NUMBER AND IN SIZE
abstract: Corporate underwritings for the first five months of 1983 reached $49.6 billion, more than double the amount in the period a year before, according to Salomon Brothers, the investment banking firm.  The number of underwriting deals more than tripled, to 798, between January and May; a year ago, there were 263 deals, which raised $20.9 billion.   ''In 20 years in the business, I cannot remember anything comparable, in terms of the number or size of deals,'' said T.  Anthony Brooks, managing director of Salomon's syndicate department.  He cited such offerings as the one by the Chrysler Corporation - the largest industrial issue, with 26 million shares - the California Federal Savings and Loan Association and the Lockheed Corporation.  The growth has been made possible, he added, ''by unprecedented demand for equities by institutions.''

headline: GEMAYEL URGES SHULTZ TO ASSIST IN SYRIAN TALKS
abstract: President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon said today Secretary of State George P. Shultz should return to the Middle East as soon as possible to help his country negotiate a withdrawal of Syrian forces.   In an interview on the eve of the signing of the Israeli-Lebanese troop withdrawal agreement, the Lebanese President made it clear that he did not take Syria's refusal to withdraw as its final word and added that there was a good deal that Washington could offer to Damascus to help change its position.   (In Washington, a senior State Department official said Mr.  Shultz was inclined now to stay away from the Middle East for the present and let the Arabs take the lead in the negotiations over Lebanon. Page A13.) 'Full Support' of U.S. Sought   On the withdrawal of Syria's estimated 40,000 troops in Lebanon - which is a condition for carrying out the Israeli-Lebanese accord - President Gemayel indicated that the Lebanese, acting alone, would not be able to bring about a pullout.

headline: BEWILDERMENT AND DISMAY VOICED BY U.S. SPORTS AND CULTURE GROUPS
abstract: There was mixed reaction in the United States yesterday to China's announcement that it would not take part in 10 sports events and 9 cultural exchanges scheduled for this year. Some groups expressed bewilderment and others dismay, and still others said the Chinese action did not matter.   The cultural programs canceled by China in retaliation for the American decision to grant asylum to Hu Na, a 19-year-old tennis star, were all arranged by agencies of either Government. The sports events were arranged by Chinese sports federations and independent American amateur sports groups.

headline: Michelin Tire Leaving Lefton
abstract: The Michelin Tire Corporation is splitting with the Al Paul Lefton Company, its first American ad agency, after more than a decade, because Lefton cannot supply marketing help in a number of international markets where Michelin needs it.   Although neither party will disclose the size of the ad budget, Leading National Advertisers, the independent media measuring company, estimates that last year for both passenger and truck tire advertising the French tire company spent more than $13 million in this country.

headline: STEEL TOWN WARY OF BRITISH
abstract: When it opened in 1951 on a bend in the Delaware River 30 miles north of Philadelphia, the United States Steel Corporation's Fairless Works created some 7,400 jobs, drawing thousands from depressed coal mining towns in upstate Pennsylvania and elsewhere. Many towns grew in its shadow, among them Levittown, Pa., whose 17,300 look-alike homes make up the world's largest, and most studied, planned suburban community.   The plant, with nine huge open hearth furnaces, was a model of postwar industrialization: A facility where steel was actually produced, as well as ''finished'' -shaped into final products such as beams or rails. But the open-hearth method has become outdated, lower-priced foreign imports are threatening and now the future of the plant, along with that of thousands of workers and the economy of lower Bucks County, hangs in the balance.

headline: ** Company Reports ** STUDENT LOAN MARKETINGASSN
abstract: Qtr to March 31 1983 1982 Net inc 12,200,000 7,600,000 Share earns 10.31 7.60

headline: Ford Unit in Hertz Deal
abstract: The Ford Motor Company's tractor operations signed a $5 million contract to provide the Hertz Equipment Rental Corporation with farm and industrial tractors during the next two years, Ford Tractor announced today.

headline: South African Loans
abstract: The Finance Ministry said today that South Africa would prepay some of its $860 million of International Monetary Fund loans if financial reserves and gold prices remained satisfactory. The amount of the payment has not yet been determined.

headline: Milwaukee Road
abstract: A Federal Bankruptcy Court in Chicago approved a plan by the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul & Pacific Railroad to pay accrued interest of about $28.4 million to certain bondholders. Under the plan, the Milwaukee Road, as it is generally called, will pay interest claims accrued through Dec.31, 1982, and certain litigation settlement amounts, with funds from the railroad escrow accounts. The payments for each $1,000 face amount, to be made by June 30, 1983, range from $220 for first mortgage bonds to $415.85 for series B general mortgage bonds.

headline: Dow Up 6.71 as Volume Rises
abstract: Favorable economic news enabled the stock market to post a moderate gain yesterday following its sharp advance on Monday.  The Dow Jones industrial average, which was up slightly more than 3 points at 3 P.M., finished ahead 6.71 points, to 1,227.26. On Monday, the 30 issues that make up the key average soared 24.44 points as interest rates fell.   The widely followed indicator is now within striking distance of its record close of 1,232.59 set on May 6.  Analysts said that the news announced in midafternoon yesterday that auto sales in the early June period climbed 21.1 percent from the period in 1982 fueled the late rally. This was regarded as additional evidence that the economic recovery was still in high gear.

headline: Holiday Inns Workers Get Campaign Preview
abstract: A new Holiday Inns campaign begins today on the three major television networks and in radio and print media with the theme line: ''A Better Place to Be.'' Conceived by Kenyon & Eckhardt of New York, the campaign emphasizes the chain's new hotels and major innovations.

headline: Pakistani Visits Soviet As Afghan Talks Near
abstract: Foreign Minister Sahabzada Yaqub Khan met with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko today, Tass reported. United Nations-sponsored talks between Pakistan and Afghanistan are scheduled to resume next week.

headline: VATICAN NEWSPAPER SAYS WALESA 'HAS LOST HIS BATTLE' WITH REGIME
abstract: The Vatican newspaper said today that Lech Walesa had ''lost his battle'' and indicated that he was no longer in a position to play a public role as head of Poland's outlawed Solidarity union.   At the same time, the Holy See withheld the release of a photograph of Mr. Walesa's private meeting with Pope John Paul II in Poland on Thursday, the last day of the Pope's eight-day visit to his homeland.    The Vatican did not explain its delay in making public a photograph of the meeting. The photographer of the Vatican newspaper, L'Osservatore Romano, Arturo Mari, was present briefly at the meeting and reported that he had taken photographs. Vatican spokesmen refused to comment on the delay.

headline: GAF Sees Delay In Certification
abstract: The GAF Corporation said Judge Lloyd F. MacMahon of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York had indicated he would issue a temporary restraining order prohibiting for 10 days the certification of the shareholders' vote in GAF's election of directors.   The restraining order would further prolong the proxy fight between GAF and Samuel Heyman, a dissident shareholder who has claimed an ''overwhelming victory'' in his attempt to unseat GAF's management.

headline: One Killed in Beirut Protest
abstract: One person died and 10 others were wounded in a clash between Lebanese Army troops and Shiite Moslems protesting the Lebanese-Israeli troop withdrawal accord, official sources said.

headline: Litton Microwave
abstract: Litton Microwave in Minneapolis is moving its advertising account in-house and has assigned all of its media buying activity to SFM Media Corporation. It will be leaving the Bozell & Jacobs office in Minneapolis. The agency has told its people that the reason for the client's move was economic and that it would be spending less for media advertising, but Lyle Cavanagh, director of marketing and advertising for the company, , said this would not be the case and that the $6 million budget would be maintained.

headline: Keynes Revisited
abstract: To the Business Editor: Professor Samuelson's ''The House That Keynes Built'' (May 29) dodges, with considerable skill, the underlying problem with this remarkable though terribly flawed theory of economic capitalism.   It is that Keynes's economics ascribes no special weight, long run, between public or government spending as compared to privately financed spending by business for investment. All that counts is total spending. There is no ''crowding out,'' no Keynesian criteria for resource misallocation as between public, private or investment sectors. In economic terms his theory imputes the same marginal efficiency to all spending.

headline: WEEK IN BUSINESS; BANK-BUYING BINGE GETS A YELLOW LIGHT
abstract: The Reagan Administration, eager to bring order out of the regulatory chaos in the financial industry, proposed a ''moratorium'' on the purchase of banks by nonbanks. Treasury Secretary Regan urged state governments and Federal regulators to hold off, at least for the rest of this year, on allowing companies to use a loophole-turned-chasm in the Glass-Steagall Act as a way into the banking business. He said this would give Congress time to decide for itself just who should be able to buy a bank. It might also settle the tiff between the Comptroller of the Currency, who has been quick to approve bank purchases, and the go-slow Federal Reserve. Mr. Regan's moratorium would exclude brokerage firms, which, he said, would still be allowed to buy S.& L.'s.  That's exactly what Thomson McKinnon wanted to hear. The Wall Street securities firm agreed to buy First Federal Savings & Loan Association of Madison, Conn., for $10 million, thus becoming the first broker to buy an S. & L. It won't be the last. After years of watching the banks gobble up discount brokers, the securities firms are starting to fight back. Merrill Lynch - Treasury Secretary Regan's old firm - as well as Shearson/American Express are looking more wistfully at the thrifts and their billions of dollars of deposits.

headline: Unions, Management and Politics; RIGHT AND A WRONG COURSE FOR LABOR
abstract: DEEPLY concerned with the long-term ability of America's manufacturing sector to compete with its foreign counterparts, management and labor are casting about for solutions that will salvage both profitability and jobs.   We are no longer the most efficient producers of steel or automobiles, and our lead in many of the so-called high-tech industries is being challenged by competition that we hardly noticed 10 years ago. Manufacturing employment, which represented 35 percent of our work force in 1947, is now down to 21 percent, and it may well further diminish to 13 percent by the year 2000.   American workers have long been accustomed to the support of almost unlimited capital, the best technology and highly trained management, which allowed them to outproduce lower-paid workers throughout the world. They no longer have this advantage. Technology, capital and management skills now readily flow across national bounderies. And in recent years, American workers have found themselves for the first time in serious competition with workers not only in Europe and Japan, but in Taiwan, South Korea and Indonesia as well.

headline: Technology; Bubble Policy: Pros and Cons
abstract: SINCE 1979, when the Environmental Protection Agency adopted its ''bubble'' policy, a number of companies have avoided costly changes at their plants to meet air quality standards. While the economic advantages to private companies are clear, not everyone is pleased with the way the policy is being applied.   Instead of enforcing limits on each source of air pollution within an industrial facility, the E.P.A., under the bubble policy, allows one overall reduction target for each pollutant type - as if the entire complex were covered by a bubble. If a company can achieve the goal through some innovative procedure, it is encouraged to do so.

headline: P & O Takeover
abstract: Shares in the Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company, which owns the liner Canberra, gained 15 percent, to $2.93, on the London stock market amid speculation about a possible takeover bid by Trafalgar House, owners of the rival Cunard passenger line.

headline: People
abstract: * Eugene O'Sullivan, a senior vice president of Young & Rubicam/New York, promoted to director of client services.

headline: Less Gas From Mexico
abstract: Exports of natural gas to the United States have been reduced, and the price has been cut, the state monopoly Petroleos Mexicanos said yesterday. Border Gas, a consortium of American importers, has decided to buy 180 million cubic feet a day, down from 300 million. Pemex and Border Gas agreed to lower the price to $4.40 a million British thermal units from $4.94.

headline: U.S. SECURITIES: MORE QUOTES
abstract: Modern communications is making it easier for investors and small securities firms to get an inside view of Government securities prices that were once the exclusive domain of firms specializing in that market.   While major securities dealers rely primarily on telephone calls and personal visits with their customers, modern technology is making bid and asked prices available to thousands of potential customers who have video screens operated by Telerate Systems and Reuters Inc.   In recent months, two developments have dramatically broadened the availability of information about the Treasury securities market. In early April, Newcomb Securities began a brokerage operation in which quotes were published on thousands of video screens operated by Reuters. Yesterday, Telerate announced that 16 primary dealers in Government securities would publish quotes for Treasury and agency issues throughout the business day.

headline: Southwestern Bell
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Southwestern Bell subsidiary said it would soon file with the Texas Public Utility Commission for a rate increase that could be more than $1 billion.

headline: Plane Crashes in the Sudan
abstract: A Liberian airliner crashed into a house soon after takeoff today from Khartoum, the capital of the Sudan, killing 14 people. The Middle East News Agency said the plane's captain parachuted to safety.

headline: POLISH RIOT POLICE GIRD FOR PROTESTS
abstract: Workmen put the finishing touches today on reviewing stands for the Government's annual May Day celebrations Sunday, while riot policemen gathered to prevent demonstrations called by the Solidarity underground.   Friday night a mysterious radio broadcast, claiming to be the voice of the underground, announced that the demonstrations had been called off.   Unlike the weak, faltering signals of recent efforts by Solidarity's clandestine transmitters, which have been quickly drowned out by loud music, the signal of the broadcast Friday night was strong, clear and not jammed, suggesting that it was a lastminute ruse on the part of the authorities.   The broadcast was neatly devised to discourage any gatherings, saying the authorities had ''thrown into Warsaw herds of secret police who have carried out mass arrests and searches.''

headline: ** Company Reports ** STANDARD OIL CO (IND) (N)
TENNECO ORDERED TO BUY GAS IN 'HIGH-COST' PACT
abstract: The Superior Oil Company has won a preliminary injunction that requires the Tennessee Gas Pipeline Company to abide by the terms of contracts it signed to purchase high-priced gas when supplies were tight.   The action could have a major impact on the natural gas industry.  The injunction, issued late Friday by a state court in Louisiana, was the first move by any court since a dozen gas producers, including such industry giants as the Exxon Corporation, Texaco Inc.  and the Standard Oil Company of California, began filing suits against Tennessee Gas in early May. The pipeline company, a unit of Tenneco Inc., is the nation's largest.

headline: Mission's Chief To Step Down
abstract: E. Richard De Rosa, president and chief executive of the Mission Insurance Group of Los Angeles, said yesterday that he would resign by Jan. 31.

headline: WHAT'S NEW WITH THE I.R.A.'S
abstract: With the April 15 tax deadline only days away, thousands of Americans are scrambling to the nearest bank or savings and loan to open Individual Retirement Accounts.  Anyone who earns income can deposit up to $2,000 (but not more than a year's earnings) and enjoy a double tax break: Deposits into an I.R.A. are tax deductible and earnings of the account are tax deferred.  But I.R.A.'s will not turn common folk into millionaires as some advertisements would have us believe. An investment of $2,000 per year at a 10 percent interest rate over 35 years would produce a retirement nest egg of more than $500,000. But if the inflation rate over that period is 8 percent, $500,000 will only have the buying power of $34,000 today. Nonetheless, an I.R.A. is considered an excellent way to save - and for many taxpayers, will result in twice the retirement assets that a non-I.R.A. investment would produce for the same annual outlay.

headline: SPAIN OFFERS COMPROMISE AT EAST-WEST TALKS
abstract: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez has presented a compromise to try to break the deadlock between the Soviet and Western bloc nations at the two-and-a-half-year-old Conference on European Security and Cooperation.   The Prime Minister, who called the heads of delegations from the 35 participating countries to his official residence Friday to present the plan, said Spain did not want to impose a solution but merely to expedite one in its role as host to the conference.   The 35 nations, signers of the 1975 Helsinki agreements on human rights, have been trying to review how the accords have been carried out and to draw fresh guidelines on issues ranging from human rights to new all-European disarmament talks.   While the two sides were bickering publicly the gap between their positions has narrowed. But neither has seemed willing to make any more concessions for an agreement.

headline: BIG THREE AUTO SALES SOAR 73%
abstract: The nation's Big Three automobile manufacturers reported yesterday that sales of new cars in the June 11-20 period rose a substantial 73 percent from a year earlier.   Although the size of the increase reflected extremely depressed sales in the same period of 1982, industry experts said the gain nonetheless signaled continued recovery for the industry.   Philip K. Fricke, an industry analyst for Goldman, Sachs & Company, said: ''The numbers are a very pleasant surprise. The upturn in sales is based on solid consumer economics, not on something hollow.''

headline: DOW DROPS BY 16.16, TO 1,199.98
abstract: Stock prices plunged yesterday because of spreading concern that interest rates may soon move higher.  The Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 16.16 points, to 1,199.98, after being down only 5 points at noon.  The decline was broad, with stocks that fell on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbering those that rose by an almost 3-to-1 ratio.  The worst performers were some of the technology, blue-chip and precious metals issues. Official's Comment a Factor   A major factor in the price decline was an early-afternoon report of a comment by a senior Administration official, who asked not to be identified, that the Federal Reserve might have to tighten its monetary policy because of the rapid rise in the nation's money supply.

headline: ** Company Reports ** SYSTEMS PLANNING CORP (A)
FRAUD SUIT CITES GENERAL DYNAMICS
abstract: The General Dynamics Corporation, a major military contractor and shipbuilding company, was accused yesterday of indirect participation in a conspiracy to extract $4.5 million in kickbacks from a subcontractor. It denied the charge.   The suit, in Federal District Court in New York, was filed by the bankruptcy trustee for the subcontractor, the Frigitemp Corporation, which entered bankruptcy proceedings in 1978. The action does not accuse General Dynamics' top management of playing an active role in the alleged kickback scheme.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Atari Suit Filed by Mattel
abstract: Mattel Inc., the big toy maker, has charged that its rival, Atari Inc., lured three of its employees away and with their help developed game cartridges compatible with Mattel's Intellivision units.   In a suit filed in California's Superior Court, Mattel asks $40 million in punitive damages from Atari and the three former Mattel employees, Eric S. Wels, Russell A. Haft and Michael Winans, plus an unspecified amount for actual damages.

headline: House of Keynes
abstract: To the Business Editor: Paul Samuelson's ''The House That Keynes Built'' (May 29) buries the real genius of Keynes - that a 52-year-old person could, in effect, repudiate the system of economic ideas in which he had so heavily invested. The dichotomy between the two Keyneses is best illustrated by a comparison of Keynes's thinking after Versailles with the implications of the ''General Theory.''   Keynes had originally held the view that $30 billion was too great a burden for the postwar German nation to pay. But as Etienne Mantoux saw clearly, the newly reborn Keynes's theory supported ''the view that the payment of reparations would in itself have actually helped Germany to become the greatest industrial nation in Europe.''

headline: Canadian Tire
abstract: The estate of one of the founders of the Canadian Tire Corporation said it would make a tender offer to the public for the sale of its 30.4 percent interest in the retailer of automotive parts and hardware. The shares, which were put in trust by John W. Billes, one of the two founders of the company, have been ordered sold by a court in Ontario.

headline: Irish Police End Search For Missing Racehorse
abstract: The police have called off their search for the racehorse Shergar, concluding that the masked gunmen who abducted the stallion in February killed it when they did not receive a ransom.   ''We're convinced he's dead,'' a senior police officer in Belfast said in an interview.

headline: Careers; Humanities Majors in Business
abstract: JUST at the time a national survey indicated severe educational lacks in mathematics and communications skills at the high school level, some embattled professors from college humanities departments met for three days in Princeton, N.J. Their subject: The Humanities and Careers in Business.   They fretted and talked about the declining numbers of students majoring in the humanities and the students' inability to find jobs upon graduation.   From prestigious business leaders, also participating in the conference, they received some suggestions about how to do a better job preparing humanities majors for jobs in business. Distilled from the usual platitudes, there emerged a consensus for more cooperation between business and colleges.

headline: STOCKS UP IN HEAVY TRADING
abstract: A late rally enabled stock prices yesterday to score their third consecutive advance in one of the heaviest trading sessions this year.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which was off 1.26 points at 3 P.M., closed ahead 9.97 points, at 1,229.01. That was within striking distance of its record close of 1,232.59 on May 6.

headline: WEINBERGER TO MEET SAUDI DEFENSE MINISTER IN PARIS
abstract: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger will meet in Paris this week with the Saudi Defense Minister to discuss the Middle East, according to American and French officials.   The officials offered few details about the talks with the Saudi Defense Minister, Prince Sultan. Mr. Weinberger's trip to Paris, where he is expected Tuesday, also coincides with the arrival of Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq, who is also Foreign Minister, and a visit here by Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who arrived here today after a two-week trip to the Middle East.   Mr. Shultz is scheduled to attend the annual ministerial meeting of the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development, and Mr.  Aziz plans to talk to French officials. Their presence in Paris, along with that of Prince Sultan, comes at a time of intense activity on the situation in Lebanon.

headline: KENNAN CRITICIAL OF U.S. POLICY
abstract: In a rare public appearance, former Ambassador George F. Kennan said today that Soviet-American relations were in a ''dreadful and dangerous'' state that had ''unfailing characteristics of a march toward war.''   Speaking at a luncheon sponsored by the American Committee on East-West Accord, a private group, he called on the Administration to reestablish normal trade and to abandon both the quest for military superiority and for democratization of the Soviet system.   Mr. Kennan, who at 79 is widely regarded as the dean of American specialists on the Soviet Union, blamed both sides for the ''antagonism, suspicion and cynicism'' that he said now permeated their relations.

headline: Foreign Markets Closed
abstract: Markets had holiday closings yesterday in Austria, Belgium, Denmark, France, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland and West Germany. Canadian markets were closed for Victoria Day.

headline: Gulfstream Goes Public
abstract: Shearson/American Express yesterday announced an initial public offering of 8 million shares of the Gulfstream Aerospace Company at $19 a share.

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: Syria's expansion of ground, armored and air forces and the installation of SA-5 missile sites manned by Soviet soldiers raise two questions for United States and other intelligence services.   Are military developments in Syria part of a countdown to another Israeli-Arab confrontation? Or is the improvement in Syria's military position as a result of Russian arms transfers simply a means of reestablishing the Soviet Union's presence in the region?   There is general agreement among Western intelligence sources, however, that there are no signs that Israel, as the Kremlin has charged, is preparing for a spring offensive against Syria. On the contrary, there are indications that the Israeli high command would like to run down its troop commitment in Lebanon, possibly by thinning out the forces in the Shuf Mountains in the north.

headline: ** Company Reports ** ASTROCOM CORP
