headline: BLACKS SEEN TO APPLAUD BOMB ATTACK IN PRETORIA
abstract: In virtually all their pronouncements on Friday's car bomb explosion in Pretoria, South African officials have emphasized the black casualties, apparently in the belief that sympathy among blacks for the outlawed African National Congress would give way to revulsion over the brutality of an urban bombing.   However, soundings taken today among a rough cross-section of politically involved and also ordinary urban blacks indicate that the reaction among the section of the population that matters most to the African National Congress has been the opposite of what whites tend to assume.   The state broadcasting monopoly and the press, as well as the Government officials, have tended to emphasize black casualties and to assume a convergence of white and black reactions to the attack.  Thus on Monday, when Defense Minister Magnus Malan pledged to avenge the dead be they ''white, black or colored,'' The Johannesburg Star commented in an editorial deploring the cycle of violence that ''South Africans mourn the Pretoria dead'' and ''perhaps even exult in the swift revenge at Maputo'' - the capital of Mozambique, which had just been the target of a reprisal attack. Leaders in 'Homelands' Quoted   It was striking that the editorial drew no distinction between the reactions of whites and blacks. On a facing page, a headline declared, ''Black Leaders Damn Attack.'' That article quoted the reactions to the Pretoria blast only of officials in the black ''homelands'' that South Africa has created within its borders.

headline: ISLAMIC ATTACKERS SEEN AS PRO-IRAN
abstract: The Islamic Jihad Organization, which took responsibility for today's bombing of the United States Embassy here, is believed to be an underground group associated with Moslem Shiite fundamentalists in Lebanon who support the Iranian leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.   Jihad is an Arabic term meaning ''holy war.'' An anonymous caller told the Beirut leftist daily newspaper Al Liwa that today's attack was ''part of the Iranian revolution's campaign aginst imperialist targets throughout the world.''   The caller added, ''We shall keep striking at any imperialist presence in Lebanon, including the multinational force.'' The same group, in telephone calls to Beirut radio stations last month, also took responsibility for a series of attacks in mid-March on American, Italian and French contingents of the peacekeeping force. Nine Italian soldiers were wounded, one fatally, in the attacks, which stretched over three days beginning March 15. Five American marines were wounded March 16 when a grenade was tossed at them from a second-story window.

headline: Computer Crime
abstract: To the Business Editor:   The articles on amending the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (March 20) neglected the act's contribution to controlling computer crime and abuse. The act requires management to establish internal controls to provide ''reasonable assurances'' that transactions are recorded, executed and reviewed in accordance with management's authorization.

headline: OIL PRODUCERS VIE FOR EXPLORATION FUNDS
abstract: When the 13 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed to drop their benchmark price for crude by $5 a barrel in March, a prolonged spate of infighting appeared to come to an end and oil prices stabilized.   But now another significant - if less visible - issue is breeding divisiveness as producing nations compete for the diminishing funds earmarked by the oil companies for exploration.   ''The drop in oil prices has an effect on the whole industry,'' said George McCourt, liaison for exploration and production at Phillips Petroleum. ''There is likely to be a lot more competition among countries for the increasingly scarce capital for exploration.''

headline: Iranians Might Attend War Talks in Baghdad
abstract: The Iranian Prime Minister, Mir Hussein Moussavi, was quoted as saying today that Iran would be willing to send a delegation to attend an Islamic conference in Baghdad on the Iran-Iraq war if the Iraqis met certain conditions.   His comments, reported by the official Islamic Republic News Agency, came after the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, on Saturday invited Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Iranian leader, to attend the Baghdad meeting.

headline: Caterpillar Tractor
abstract: The Caterpillar Tractor Company has put into effect a previously announced callback of 2,000 employees and the layoffs of 1,450 others nationwide. The company has 46,000 employees nationwide. James O'Connor, president of Local 974 of the United Automobile Workers, said the union had filed complaints with the National Labor Relations Board charging that Caterpillar is violating the seniority rights of employees.

headline: Equitable Realty Unit Gets $400 Million Credit
abstract: The Equitable Relocation Management Corporation, a subsidiary of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, has signed loan agreements totaling $400 million with a group of 11 foreign banks and the Chase Manhattan Bank, which acted as agent.   The relocation company provides real estate-related services to transfered employees of more than 500 corporations.

headline: Stroh, Pabst To Swap Plants
abstract: The Pabst Brewing Company and the Stroh Brewery Company announced an agreement to exchange plants in St. Paul and Tampa, Fla., in an even trade with no financial outlays involved.

headline: Sanko Orders 22 More Ships
abstract: The Sanko Steamship Company said today that it had ordered 22 more bulk carriers of 20,000 to 40,000 tons each from 13 Japanese shipyards, with delivery to be completed by early 1986.

headline: What's New in Lobbying; MAIL THAT SPEAKS LOUDER THAN WORDS
abstract: In the nation's early days, before the dome of the Capitol was even completed, lobbyists operated in the hallways of Congress and in the saloons of the capital. There were only a handful of them, shadowy figures mostly, and they wooed legislators with the traditional medium of political exchange, grub and grog.   Lobbyists still stand, handwritten scorecards in hand, in the paneled anterooms of Congress. But in the age of the computer the opinion poll and the political action committee, the most effective lobby campaigns often are not waged by lobbyists at all. These campaigns may be guided by modern computers, but increasingly they are undertaken by one of the most ancient technologies of all: the mail.

headline: PRITZKER SAID TO SEEK BRANIFF BACKING ON DEAL
abstract: Jay A. Pritzker, the chairman of the Hyatt Corporation, will meet with officials of Braniff International today in Dallas to ask them to approve his offer to revive the airline and to get their authority to negotiate directly with secured creditors, a source close to the negotiations said yesterday.   Last week Mr. Pritzker offered to invest $35 million - $20 million in cash and $15 million in loans - in the airline, which is operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, in exchange for a controlling stake in Braniff and the right to manage the company.   Today's meeting with the Braniff board has been scheduled for 2 P.M. Braniff also faces a deadline today of filing a reorganization plan with the Bankruptcy Court in Fort Worth. It was not immediately clear whether Braniff would ask the court for a postponement in view of the continuing negotiatons.

headline: Texas Airport Bonds Will Pay 6.75% and Up
abstract: A $76.3 million revenue refunding bond for the San Antonio airport was priced at par yesterday. Proceeds will be used to pay off a maturing bond issue and to finance additional construction.

headline: Insider Reports
abstract: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE   AIRBORNE FREIGHT CORPORATION-Robert Stanley Cline, vice chairman, sold 10,000 shares leaving him directly with a balance of 49,306 shares.

headline: Salary Restoration At Allis-Chalmers
abstract: The Allis-Chalmers Corporation will restore about 6,500 employees' salaries to the level that existed before a 10 percent cut was introduced in September 1982, a company official said.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * American Broadcasting Cos. said it had completed the acquisition of the stock outstanding of Compute Publications Inc. in exchange for 327,000 newly issued ABC common shares.   * G.D. Searle & Co. said it had established, effective May 15, Searle U.S. Consumer Products division, a separate unit to be headed by Marcel C. Durot, a vice president.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Rates Move Slightly Lower; Many Dealers On Sidelines
abstract: Interest rates declined slightly yesterday as bond prices traded in a narrow and choppy pattern. Dealers reported scant buying interest from investors.  ''The opinion is split in the street over where rates are going in the near term,'' said Maria Ramirez, senior money market economist at Merrill Lynch.  This uncertainty caused prices to move up and down during the day in light trading volume. Many government security dealers were on the sidelines taking a wait-and-see attitude toward where rates would move. ''You don't force a dull market,'' one trader said, summing up the market's attitude.

headline: PERU ARRESTS HUNDREDS IN AN EFFORT TO STAMP OUT GROWING INSURGENCY
abstract: Hundreds of people were taken into custody for questioning today as the police hunted for members of a small but growing guerrilla insurgency that has prompted the Government of President Fernando Belaunde Terry to declare a 60-day state of emergency.   The arrests, the police said, occurred mostly in and around Lima and Ayacucho, the departmental capital 200 miles southeast of here that has been the center of operations of leftist guerrillas belonging to a movement that calls itself Shining Path. More than 500 people were reportedly arrested and the roundup was said to be continuing.   The army under the elected Government of President Belaunde Terry reports that 823 people have been killed since the beginning of the year in the fighting between Government forces and guerrillas, compared with about 200 in the previous two and a half years.  Officials say about two-thirds of the dead were guerrillas; the rest - soldiers, policemen and peasants - were said to have been killed by guerrillas.

headline: Palestinian Rights Parley
abstract: The Committee on Conferences gave final approval Friday to plans to hold a conference on Palestinian rights Aug. 29 to Sept. 7 in Geneva.

headline: SOVIET SHOWING UNUSUAL ANGER OVER PARIS ACTION
abstract: The Kremlin, in what was considered here to be part of its response to the expulsion of 47 of its officials from Paris, has chosen the unusual measure of starting a campaign of letters from surprised and indignant citizens.   French diplomats and Soviet sources said it was too early to gauge whether the letters will be followed by further retaliatory measures, or whether they are meant to signal that Moscow plans to treat the expulsions as a low act of political expediency that it is prepared to swallow in the name of sustaining some form of the special relationship developed with Paris under earlier French governments.   Whatever will follow, the sources said the campaign of letters - though frequently used to demonstrate national feelings on issues like disarmament -seems to be a new response to a diplomatic protest followed by retaliatory expulsions.

headline: Amoco Leases
abstract: The Amoco exploration and production subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) announced that the United States Minerals Management Service had accepted 53 of 68 high bids submitted by Amoco on May 25 in outer continental shelf lease sale No.72. The remaining 15 high bids by Amoco are being reviewed by Minerals Management. The 53 tracts awarded to Amoco so far represent a net outlay of $408.5 million for a total of about 214,000 acres.

headline: New Products Show Up At A Brisk Pace
abstract: New product introductions continued to boom in March, according to the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News, which reports that there were 151 introductions in March compared with 104 in March 1982, a gain of 45.2 percent.

headline: WITHDRAWAL
abstract: Following is the official text of the Lebanese-Israeli troop withdrawal agreement with its annex, appendix and agreed minutes, as made available today by Lebanese officials:   The Agreement   The Government of the Republic of Lebanon and the Government of the State of Israel, BEARING in mind the importance of maintaining and strengthening international peace based on freedom, equality, justice and respect for fundamental human rights,   REAFFIRMING their faith in the aims and principles of the Charter of the United Nations and recognizing their right and obligation to live in peace with each other as well as with all states, within secure and recognized boundaries,   HAVING AGREED to declare the termination of the state of war between them, DESIRING to insure lasting security for both their states and to avoid threats and the use of force between them, DESIRING to establish their mutual relations in the manner provided for in this agreement, HAVING delegated their undersigned representatives plenipotentiaries, provided with full powers, in order to sign, in the presence of the representatives of the United States of America, this agreement,   HAVE AGREED to the following provisions: Article 1   1.The parties agree and undertake to respect the sovereignty, political independence and territorial integrity of each other. They consider the existing international boundary between Lebanon and Israel inviolable.

headline: THROUGH THE EYES OF LORD KEYNES
abstract: A WARNING OF WAR   In 1919, John Maynard Keynes was appointed the representative of the British Treasury in the Versailles Peace Conference that officially ended World War I. However, he resigned in protest over the heavy war reparations demanded of Germany and the same year wrote "The Economic Consequences of the Peace," excerpted below.   "The danger confronting us, therefore, is the rapid depression of the standard of life of the European populations to a point which will mean actual starvation for some (a point already reached in Russia and approximately reached in Austria).   Men will not always die quietly. For starvation, which brings to some lethargy and a helpless despair, drives other temperaments to the nervous instability of hysteria and to a mad despair. And these in their distress may overturn the remnants of organization, and submerge civilization itself in their attempts to satisfy desperately the overshelming needs of the individual.

headline: NIGERIA FACES DEBT PROBLEMS
abstract: Not long ago, Nigeria was every banker's favorite African country.  Abundant oil reserves, a large population, a free market economy and solidly Western orientation were among the attributes that made Nigeria the kind of customer that inspires confidence in those who make it their business to lend money.   Recently, however, the fall of world oil prices and the continuing deterioration of Nigeria's domestic economy have combined to put this most powerful of black African nations into arrears on its short-term foreign debts. And foreign commercial bankers have been reluctant to write new loans until Nigeria puts its economic house in order.

headline: SUPPLIER OF HITLER FORGERIES GIVES UP
abstract: The man who supplied the bogus Hitler diaries to a journalist at Stern magazine turned himself over to the police today and denied that he had forged the notebooks, his lawyer said.   Konrad Kujau, a Stuttgart dealer in Nazi memorabilia who has also used the alias Konrad Fischer, was reported to have given himself up to the West German police at the Austrian frontier and, according to his lawyer, was in detention in Hamburg tonight.   The lawyer, Rolf Schmidt-Diemitz, said in a telephone interview that Mr. Kujau said he received $1 million for the diaries from Gerd Heidemann, the Stern reporter who has since been dismissed by the magazine, and kept only $125,000 for himself.   Stern, which has also sued Mr. Heidemann for fraud, has said it gave him $3.7 million for the 60 volumes of diaries and other notes.

headline: LEBANESE HASHISH IS INVADING ISRAEL
abstract: In the year since the Israeli invasion of Lebanon, the heavy, loosely controlled traffic across the border has allowed so much Lebanese-grown hashish to come south that the police say it is more abundant here now than it has been in years.   The hashish, from the Syrian-controlled region of the Bekaa, Lebanon's eastern valley, has made itself evident in two ways: an increase in arrests of smugglers and dealers and a decrease in the drug's market price.   A police spokesman said the wholesale price of hashish had fallen from about $1,100 a pound before the war to less than half that now.  He said this was a ''sure indicator of the significant rise in the supply of hashish to the local black market.'' The police say a ''finger'' of hashish, a finger-sized slice weighing three or four grams, retails for about $12 on the Israeli market.

headline: Martin Marietta
abstract: The Martin Marietta Corporation said its issue of 1.8 million shares of common stock were purchased by Goldman, Sachs and Kidder, Peabody for $55 per share. The net proceeds are to be used to purchase enough shares of its common now held by the Allied Corporation to reduce Allied's holding to 20 percent, from 39 percent.

headline: ** Company Reports ** FIRST FINANCIAL SAVINGS & LOAN (WISC)(O)
abstract: Qtr to March 31 1983 1982 Net inc 478,653 b93,986 Share earns .66  b-Net loss.

headline: France to Airlift Military Supplies to Chad
abstract: France agreed to airlift 35 tons of military supplies, including antitank weapons and rockets, to help Chad fight a Libyan-backed invasion, French radio said today   The African service of Radio France International said the airlift to the former French colony in north central Africa would begin immediately.

headline: A Soviet Military Attache Is Expelled by Norway
abstract: Norway expelled the assistant military attache at the Soviet Embassy in Oslo today on charges of military espionage.

headline: Greece and Turkey Seek To Improve Relations
abstract: The Foreign Ministers of Greece and Turkey met for more than two hours on Thursday in an effort to improve relations.

headline: Remains of 100 People Found in Colombia Cave
abstract: The skeletal remains of 100 people believed killed by smugglers during illicit marijuana operations have been found in a remote cave in northern Colombia, the authorities said today.   They said the skeletons were found accidentally by a military squad near Becerril in the district of Cesar, 400 miles north of Bogota, which borders on Venezuela. A military police spokesman said the remains may have been in the cave for as long as five years.

headline: Bell Expands Its Data System
abstract: The American Bell division of American Telephone and Telegraph announced an expanded version of its office information system, used by relatively large offices to transmit voice and data messages.   The new system adds a larger processor and provides for about eight times the line capacity of the system currently offered by the company. It also provides for high-speed digital transmission of data between computers.

headline: Clinch River Funds Seen
abstract: Private investors may be willing to put more than $1 billion into the controversial Clinch River Breeder Reactor project, but only if they are assured the plant actually will be built, Energy Secretary Donald P. Hodel said today.   Mr. Hodel, testifying before a House subcommittee, said an industry task force has found ''a high likelihood'' that investors would be willing to put more private money into the $3.6 billion demonstration nuclear plant.

headline: PRESIDENT APPEALS BEFORE CONGRESS FOR AID TO LATINS
abstract: President Reagan, declaring that the security of all the Americas was at stake, appealed to Congress tonight to support his program of military and economic assistance to El Salvador and other nations in the region.   In an unusual address to a joint session of Congress, Mr. Reagan invoked the memory of the 1947 request by President Harry S. Truman for aid to Greece and Turkey, saying the turmoil in Central America posed a threat to the United States comparable to what it faced in Europe after World War II.   He called on the legislators to set aside ''passivity, resignation, defeatism'' in facing ''this challenge to freedom and security in our hemisphere.'' U.S. Called in Jeopardy   With Congress deeply reluctant to approve his proposed aid package for the region, Mr. Reagan sought to put the sum requested in perspective: He said the $600 million he is asking for Central America for the 1984 fiscal year amounted to ''less than one-tenth of what Americans will spend this year on coin-operated video games.''

headline: Vietnamese Archbishop Excommunicated Again
abstract: The Roman Catholic Church has excommunicated for the second time a Vietnamese Archbishop for consecrating bishops without papal authority, the Vatican said today.   The Archbishop, Pierre Martin Ngo Dinh Thuc, brother of the late President Ngo Dinh Diem of South Vietnam, was excommunicated along with six other followers of a Spaniard who says he is Pope Gregory XVII.

headline: XEROX AND ANHEUSER UP
abstract: The Xerox Corporation reported yesterday that earnings in the first quarter of this year, helped by the results of its Crum & Forster subsidiary, increased 17.5 percent.   The office machines company, based in Stamford, Conn., said that net income increased to $128.7 million, or $1.25 a share, from $109.5 million, or $1.29 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Revenues increased 2.4 percent to $2.1 billion, from $2.05 billion.   In January, Xerox completed the acquisition of Crum & Forster, a major property casualty insurer, for cash, common and preferred stock valued at about $1.6 billion. First-quarter earnings reflect the acquisition on an equity basis.

headline: People
abstract: * Gerald Karp has been appointed executive vice president at Nadler & Larimer.   * Randall Malin elected to the new position of executive vice president-marketing for USAir, Washington.

headline: Japan's Car Output Off
abstract: Japan produced 938,495 vehicles in April, down seven-tenths of 1 percent from a year earlier, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers' Association said today. Association officials attributed the decline to slower sales both in Japan and abroad.

headline: Australian Declares U.S.  Can Rely on Close Ties
abstract: Australia's new Prime Minister, Robert Hawke, met with President Reagan today and said his Labor Party Government would be a close ally of the United States.   ''There will be no country that this country can rely on more than Australia,'' Mr. Hawke said. The two leaders held a first meeting at the White House today.

headline: UMC Industries Picks G.E. Executive for Post
abstract: An executive of the General Electric Company had been tapped by UMC Industries to be its president and chief operating officer.  Edwin F. Phelps, 49, general manager of the energy applications program at G.E., succeeds H. Ridgely Bullock in the UMC position, effective July 1. Mr. Bullock, 49, continues as chairman and chief executive.

headline: ** Company Reports ** COMMONWEALTH ENERGY SYSTEM (N)
Chrysler Trims Finance Rate
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it is offering rebates or 9.8 percent financing on certain 1982 and 1983 models to replace the 11.9 percent financing promotion that expired today.   The financing promotion offers a rate that is one-tenth of a percentage point below similar programs offered by the General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the American Motors Corporation.

headline: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: SHULTZ WAITS FOR LABORS TO PAY OFF
abstract: Shortly before 11 o'clock tonight, during a break in final discussions with American officials on a Lebanese-Israeli draft agreement on troop withdrawals, a senior Israeli Foreign Ministry official wandered down to the coffee shop in the King David Hotel here.   Asked by a reporter if the accord would be approved by the Cabinet on Friday, the official grinned. He turned his thumb down, and then quickly pointed it up. And then pointed it horizontally. If he knew the answer, he was not going to let on this close to the time of decision.

headline: Reagan Urges U.S. Investors To Back Latin America Policy
abstract: President Reagan, denying that there had been any change in his policy in the Central American nations, today urged corporate investors to support his program.   ''They must have our help in stemming that violence so that you can go forward with investment,'' the President said, speaking at the White House to the Council of the Americas, a business group.   ''It is a pleasure to speak to a group that does not need to be convinced of Latin America's vital importance to the United States,'' Mr. Reagan declared.

headline: 2 Creditor Groups Back Braniff Plan
abstract: The full committees representing two major groups of creditors of Braniff Airways have voted to accept a $70 million offer made by the Hyatt Corporation to restart part of the airline.   The committees approved a plan worked out last week among seven representatives of the secured and unsecured creditors.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: The Cleveland Clinic Foundation, a hospital with a double-A bond rating much esteemed by investors, has taken advantage of lower interest rates by announcing an early re-funding of bonds it sold last year when interest rates were much higher.   The $260 million financing through the Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group is the largest bond issue ever sold for one hospital, eclipsing a $228.2 million Cleveland Clinic sale last year.

headline: French Seeking Loan
abstract: France has asked the European Economic Community for a loan to help finance its huge balance-of-payments deficit, European monetary officials said today.

headline: East-West Trade Turnabout
abstract: In a historic turnabout in East-West trade, the West last year recorded its first trade deficit with the Soviet bloc in two decades, according to a United Nations agency report released today.   The report by the United Nation's Economic Commission for Europe said the Western deficit was just under $2 billion in 1982, compared with a surplus of about $2 billion in 1981.

headline: Optic Researcher
abstract: To the Business Editor: I am reasonably certain that the mysterious name ''Rowland'' in the Rowland Institute of Science is in honor of Prof. Henry A. Rowland (''Edwin Land: Still Searching, at 74,'' May 15).   Professor Rowland, 1848-1901, did seminal work in optics at Johns Hopkins University.

headline: SANDINISTS SAY U.S. ARMS THE REBELS
abstract: The Nicaraguan Government has accused the Reagan Administration of sending arms to a new rebel front on its southern border with Costa Rica.   ''We have absolute certainty that the Central Intelligence Agency has sent bazookas, Chinese A.K. rifles and 60-and 81-milimieter mortars to Costa Rica,'' said Daniel Ortega Saavedra, coordinator of the Nicaraguan junta.   In an interview Monday night, Mr. Ortega offered no evidence but said the arms shipments, starting late last year, were destined for Eden Pastora Gomez, the Nicaraguan leader who turned against the Sandinists, and other anti-Sandinists. He described the weapons as similar to those that he said the C.I.A. had sent to the rebel groups operating from Honduras.

headline: Chrysler Models
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation said it would discontinue two slow-selling models this fall, the two-door, rearwheel-drive Cordoba and the Mirada, both midsize models.

headline: 5 More Die in Fighting In Hills Around Beirut
abstract: Christian and Druse militamen clashed in the hills overlooking Beirut in the night, leaving 5 more dead and raising the three-day toll to 23 killed and 70 wounded, the police said today. The shelling tapered off at dawn.

headline: Newsprint Price
abstract: Consolidated-Bathurst Inc. said its sales unit in the United States would raise newsprint prices by $31.50 a metric ton, to $500, effective July 1.

headline: U.S. ENVOY AT GENEVA TALKS CALLS FOR FLEXIBILITY BY SOVIET
abstract: The United States negotiator at the talks on reducing medium-range nuclear missiles said today that an accord ''should be possible'' if the Soviet Union showed some flexibility.   On his arrival for Tuesday's resumption of the talks, which have been recessed for nearly seven weeks, the American negotiatior, Paul H. Nitze, said the so-called interim agreement that President Reagan had proposed for a cutback in missiles to equal levels on both sides ''provides the opportunity and the dynamics needed for progress.''   ''With comparable flexibility and commitment on the Soviet side, it should be possible to reach a solution which is in the interest of both the West and the East,'' Mr. Nitze said.

headline: U.N. Chief Criticizes Article in The Times
abstract: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar has criticized as ''totally deformed and truncated'' an article in The New York Times reporting on his closed-door meeting Monday with journalists from the United States.   The article quoted Mr. Perez de Cuellar as describing as ''misguided'' attempts by members of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization to curb press freedom.

headline: TAKEOVER REFORM A TENDER TOPIC
abstract: The subject was reforming corporate takeover rules, and for some of the participants who crowded into a 28th-floor conference room at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company last Friday, it was clearly a tender topic.   The occasion was a session of a blue-ribbon committee created by the Securities and Exchange Commission last February to consider whether the corporate takeover game has gotten out of hand.   The panel itself is under criticism as being top-heavy with Wall Street lawyers, investment bankers and others who thrive on tender offers. It includes such specialists as Joseph H. Flom, a lawyer, and Bruce Wasserstein, a managing director at the First Boston Corporation.

headline: Changes at Stan Kovics And Earl Newsom
abstract: Stan Kovics Advertising, with about $5 million in billings, has closed down and reopened as Kovics & Ciociola, reflecting the new partnership of Mr. Kovics and Mel Ciociola, who is also a copywriter. He previously worked at Young & Rubicam; N.W.Ayer; Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, and Cunningham & Walsh, to name most. Mr. Kovics has passed through the doors of Doyle Dane Bernbach; Campbell-Ewald, New York; Van Brunt, and Griswold-Eshleman, and has had his own place for 10 years.

headline: Ex-Microsoft President To No. 2 Job at Metheus
abstract: James C. Towne, who resigned Monday as president and chief operating officer of the Microsoft Corporation, begins work today as president of the Metheus Corporation, a two-year-old computer-aided design and graphics company based in Hillsboro, Ore.   Mr. Towne, who is 40, joined Microsoft a year ago.

headline: EAST GERMANY FINALLY EMBRACES LUTHER
abstract: A few years ago, in the land of his birth, Martin Luther was a prophet without honor, regarded by Marxist historians and Communist propagandists as a lackey of reactionary 16th-century princes and an enemy of peasant rebels.   Now, in a gesture of rehabilitation, the atheistic leadership of East Germany has embraced the father of the Protestant Reformation as the 500th anniversary of his birth on Nov. 10 nears.   In April, at a symbolic gathering at the Wartburg castle, where Luther hid from his persecutors and completed his translation of the New Testament in 1521-22, the East German Communist leader, Erich Honecker, declared that ''our socialist state considers it a noble duty to care for and advance the progressive inheritance of our people.'' 'Landmark of German History'   The Wartburg castle, Mr. Honecker said, represents a ''landmark of German history,'' and visits to it by East German citizens will ''strengthen their feelings of nationality and homeland.'' Mr.  Honecker then held an hourlong meeting with East German Protestant clergy.   The gathering at the Wartburg castle was one event in a panoply of Luther ceremonies, seminars, speeches, films, books and stamps in East Germany this year. East Germany has a near monopoly on Luther pilgrimage sites.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues   * Cessna Aircraft Co.'s $100 million issue of 8 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2008 and convertible to common stock at $32.50 a share was priced at par through Kidder, Peabody & Co.; the issue is rated BBB by Standard & Poor's.   * Charter Medical Corp. filed for an offering of $25 million of sinking fund debentures due in 2003, through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.   * Pier One Imports filed for an offering of 25,000 units, each consisting of $1,000 principal amount subordinated debenture due in 2003 and 40 common stock purchase warrants, through Bear, Stearns & Co.

headline: PATENTS; An Ozone Generator For Swimming Pools
abstract: An ozone generator for swimming pools was patented this week by Thomas D. McBride, an electrician in Westwood, N.J. He assigned patent 4,386,055 to Joan McBride, his wife.

headline: U.S. BIDS CUBA TAKE SEVERAL THOUSAND OF ITS EXILES BACK
abstract: The United States has asked Cuba to take back as many as several thousand of the 125,000 Cubans who came to this country as part of the boatlift from the port of Mariel in 1980, the State Department said today.   The department, in a formal statement, said that Thomas O. Enders, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, met on Tuesday with Ramon Sanchez-Parodi, the head of the Cuban Interests Section here, to make the request and officially inform him that until Cuba agreed to the return of the so-called ineligibles, no more immigrant visas would be granted to Cubans except for immediate relatives of those already in the United States.   A department official said Mr. Enders gave Mr. Sanchez-Parodi a list of 789 people now in Federal prison in Atlanta who are subject to deportation under the legal status of ''final order of exclusion.'' The United States, the official said, wants these 789 to be accepted as part of a total that could run to ''a few thousand,'' he said.

headline: I.R.S. Ruling Aids Bid by Internorth
abstract: The Internal Revenue Service has given a ''favorable tax ruling'' that will allow Internorth Inc. to go ahead with its acquisition of Belco Petroleum Corporation, the two companies announced.   As a result of the ruling, the Internorth securities to be issued in the merger will be shares of $10.50 cumulative preferred stock and $10.50 cumulative convertible preferred stock of Internorth.

headline: Magazine Ad Pages Rose by 6% in March
abstract: Things appear to be improving in the magazine business, according to the latest report from the Publishers Information Bureau.  In March, member publications increased their advertising pages 6 percent from March 1982, to more than 11,584, and revenues were up 11 percent, to $320.6 million.   The affiliate of the Magazine Publishers Association also said that first-quarter revenues totaled $825.7 million, the first time the members topped $800 million in advertising revenues for the first quarter.

headline: Mrs. Thatcher to Get Award
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain will be given an award by the Winston Churchill Foundation of the United States at a dinner at the British Embassy May 27 during her visit to Washington.

headline: German Metalworkers
abstract: The West German metalworkers' union and the industry's employers group urged workers today to accept a 3.2 percent pay increase for the current year.  Their call followed the signing of a one-year wage accord for that amount on behalf of one million metalworkers in North Rhine-Westphalia.

headline: BRAZIL AND LIBYANS ARE SAID TO DISCUSS UNLOADING OF PLANES
abstract: Brazilian officials and Libyan diplomats reportedly discussed procedures today for unloading four Libyan cargo planes being held by Brazil after they were found to be carrying arms and explosives destined for Nicaragua.   The planes, three Soviet-made Ilyushins and an American-built Hercules C-130, were being guarded in the cities of Manaus and Recife by Brazilian Air Force troops.   Officials here said that at issue in the meetings between Libyan diplomats and Foreign Ministry officials was whether Libya would accept an offer to have observers at the unloading.

headline: BEING YOUR OWN BOSS - WITH BENEFITS
abstract: ''F REEDOM,'' ''self-fulfillment'' and even ''off the books'' are all familiar lyrics from the siren song of self-employment, but ''fringe benefits'' generally is not. Indeed, many of those eager to be their own boss only belatedly ask how they can replace the benefits that come with being someone's employee.   A job with a big organization these days may provide everything from medical insurance and profit-sharing plans to free stop-smoking clinics. Consequently, says Jerry Rosenband, a New York City accountant, ''Going out on your own warrants a good deal of thinking about how you're going to replace those benefits in a way that protects your financial security without eating up your income.''

headline: ** Company Reports ** INITIO INC (O)
A THATCHER RIFT WITH PYM WIDENS
abstract: During a crucial council of war five days before Britain invaded the Falkland Islands last year, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher denounced the members of a delegation from the Foreign Office, telling them they were incapable of advising her adequately.   Ever since, newspapers and politicians here have been watching with fascination and occasional alarm the struggle between the Prime Minister and the elite, tradition-encrusted Establishment in King Charles Street, where British diplomacy is managed, just a few steps from 10 Downing Street. The Financial Times speaks of ''the decline of a proud department,'' The Guardian of ''a disconsolate department.''   Dr. David Owen, once a Labor Foreign Secretary and now a leader of the new Social Democratic Party, wrote recently of a ''yawning chasm that separates 10 Downing Street from the Foreign Office across the road.'' And Lady Falkender, once a key adviser to Prime Minister Harold Wilson, added that the Foreign Secretary, Francis Pym, ''is in such rapid decline that only a parachute will delay the inevitable.''

headline: REAGAN'S FRIEND AT THE BANK BOARD
abstract: WASHINGTON WHEN White House aides leave their jobs, they usually get a send-off luncheon at a local restaurant and some farewell cards.  But when Edwin J. Gray left last August to return to private industry, President Reagan and Vice President Bush were the co-hosts at his farewell party in the packed Roosevelt Room, across from the Oval Office. Edwin Meese 3d, James A. Baker 3d and Michael K. Deaver, the trio who run White House day-to-day operations, were there to raise a champagne toast, and the gifts included a set of glasses engraved with the Presidential seal. Even before the party began, the President slipped Mr. Gray a handwritten note, saying he felt a ''great sense of loss'' at Mr. Gray's departure for California. He also asked Mr. Gray to send a hug for him to the two teen-aged Gray daughters.

headline: SALVADORANS TAKE REBEL BASE
abstract: The Salvadoran military met little resistence from guerrilla forces as it moved to occupy Chinchontepec Volcano in the central province of San Vicente and to secure the towns at the base of the volcano, according to military officers.   The leftist opposition has long used the 7,100-foot volcano as a base from which to attack the towns.

headline: Panel Clears Funds For Synthetic Fuels
abstract: The United States Synthetic Fuels Corporation today made its first monetary award, assigning funds to a North Carolina project, and also signed a promised $120 million letter of intent for a California proposal, a spokesman said.   Karen Hutchison said the synthetic fuels board had assigned $820,750 to refine cost estimates of the the First Colony peat-tomethanol project in Creswell, N.C. Initial cost estimates for the project have not been made public.

headline: ARE U.S. COVERT ACTIVITIES BEST POLICY ON NICARAGUA?
abstract: The Reagan Administration and Congress are struggling over covert operations in Central America. At stake in the short term is the future of aid to rebels in Nicaragua; over the longer term, the debate will help define when and how covert action should be an instrument of foreign policy.   Few subjects generate as much heat as covert activities, even one as overt as the Nicaraguan operation has become. The members of Congress who support legislation to cut off money to the Nicaraguan insurgents insist that the Reagan Administration is engaged in a secret war against the Nicaraguan Government that violates international law, common sense and a statute adopted by Congress to limit covert actions against Nicaragua. Both the House Select Committee on Intelligence and the House Foreign Affairs Committee have voted recently to stop financing the covert operation. An Extra Dimension   Defenders of the covert activity say it adds a vital extra dimension to United States policy in Central America that supplements overt diplomacy and military assistance. Specifically, they say, aiding rebel paramilitary forces is the best way to fight Soviet and Cuban arms shipments to guerrillas in El Salvador and to inflict enough pain on the Nicaraguan Government to bring it to the negotiatiing table.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA JETS RAID MOZAMBIQUE IN REPLY TO REBELS
abstract: South Africa said today that its planes staged an early morning raid on installations and residences of the African National Congress in the Mozambican capital of Maputo.    The official Mozambican press agency reported that 4 people were killed and 24 were wounded. The agency identified the dead as two women, a factory worker and a child.   It did not say anything about casualties among South African exiles belonging to the underground movement, which accepted responsibility in a statement issued in Dar es Salaam for Friday's car-bomb explosion in Pretoria that provoked the raid on a Maputo suburb.

headline: HITACHI-F.B.I. TAPES ARE RELEASED
abstract: Tapes of a Federal Bureau of Investigation ''sting'' operation in California last year show that two executives of Japan's Hitachi Ltd. knew they were dealing in stolen goods when they offered to purchase I.B.M. computer components from agents posing as consultants.   The video and audio tapes, transcripts of which were ordered unsealed by Federal Judge Spencer Williams in San Jose on Friday, show the two executives, Kenji Hayashi and Isao Ohnishi, explaining to the bogus consultants why Hitachi needed the International Business Machines Corporation parts and documents - to cut the time needed to develop their own, similar computer - and why time was of the essence.   The F.B.I. operation, conducted through a phony consulting firm, Glenmar Associates, lasted from August 1981 through June 1982 and resulted in charges against Hitachi, the Mitsubishi Electric Corporation and 21 individuals. Guilty Pleas   Hitachi and four of its employees, including Mr. Hayashi and Mr.  Ohnishi, subsequently pleaded guilty of conspiracy to obtain stolen secrets and were fined. Tom Yoshida, a Santa Clara businessman who acted as an intermediary for Hitachi, pleaded no-contest on Friday to charges of conspiring with the two Japanese companies.

headline: Friendly Frost Stock Slides 46%
abstract: The common stock of Friendly Frost, which trades on the Americcan Stock Exchange, plunged 46 percent on a volume of 158,500 shares.  The 4 5/8-point decline in the price of the common stock of Friendly Frost Inc. yesterday, from 10 1/8 to 5 1/2, apparently stemmed from an announcement late Wednesday that the Swanton Corporation would defer indefinitely its previously announced plan to acquire all the remaining outstanding shares of Friendly Frost, a spokesman for the company indicated.

headline: Turkish Scholars Protest Takeover
abstract: Turkish scholars expressed concern today over a new move to establish state control over the country's two most influential independent cultural institutions.   It was confirmed that the Consultative Assembly's budget commission had approved a proposal by the military leadership to merge the Turkish Language Association and the Turkish Historical Society and put them under the jurisdiction of an undersecretary in the Prime Minister's office.

headline: Thrift Unit Aided
abstract: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board took over the North Mississippi Savings and Loan Association of Oxford, Miss., which has assets valued at $150 million, after the Mississippi commissioner of savings associations asked a state court to appoint a receiver for the thrift unit. A spokesman for the bank board cited ''concern about the financial condition'' of the thrift unit.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Amdahl Corp., Sunnyvale, Calif., has named Jack Lewis, president, to the additional post of chief executive.   * Chromalloy American Corp., St. Louis, has elected Charles E.  Self corporate treasurer.

headline: Iran and Iraq Join Parley On Controlling Oil Slick
abstract: Iran and Iraq joined other Persian Gulf countries today at talks here on controlling a giant oil slick threatening their coasts, according to officials of the conference.   Technical experts were trying to draw up antipollution guidelines after the collapse of ministerial talks last month on capping Iranian wells that have been spewing oil into the gulf, the officials said.

headline: Gold Bullion Exchange
abstract: A curator was named today to secure the assets of the International Gold Bullion Exchange, a precious metals concern that another judge had ordered shut down.   State Circuit Judge Robert Andrews shut down the concern at the request of Florida Attorney General Jim Smith, who filed a complaint charging the concern's principals with unlawfully using consumers's money.   The concern has been given until 5 P.M. Monday to decide whether to file a petition for Federal bankruptcy court protection from creditors' lawsuits.

headline: Palestinians Stone Israelis
abstract: Palestinian youths stoned Israeli vehicles and threw bottles at security forces today during scattered protests in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, security officials said.  The Palestinians said they were protesting the wounding Sunday of a Palestinian who was shot in the thigh when he escaped from a military vehicle during demonstrations.

headline: AMERICAN EXPRESS ROSE 37.3% IN FIRST QUARTER
abstract: The American Express Company said yesterday that its first-quarter profit rose 37.3 percent from a year earlier, mainly because of improved earnings in financial services.   The company said that net income was $162 million, or $1.20 a share, compared with $118 million, or 93 cents a share, a year ago.  Revenue increased 27.7 percent, to $2.3 billion, from $1.8 billion.

headline: Medical Care Issue Yields 8% to 9 3/4%
abstract: Merrill Lynch priced a $108 million bond issue for the New York State Medical Care facility finance agency yesterday at yields ranging from 8 percent to 9.75 percent.   The bonds are to used for the construction and renovation of Syosset Community Hospital and Brooklyn Caledonian Hospital.

headline: SALVADORAN SLAYING CARRIES MESSAGE FOR POLITICIANS
abstract: In El Salvador, death threats often come by telephone. Friday night the message was more direct. The body of a young man who had apparently been strangled and then shot in the head was found in a hotel parking lot with a warning for a Salvadoran politician.   In his pocket and strewn around his body were copies of a communique in which the secret anti-Communist army E.S.A. took responsibility for the murder. The notice warned Mauricio Armando Mazier Andino, a Christian Democratic deputy, that the same penalty would fall to ''those civilian or military individuals who collaborate directly or indirectly with the Communist guerrillas.''

headline: G.M. AND FORD CUT RATE ON SOME LOANS TO 9.9%
abstract: With sales of its small cars languishing, the General Motors Corporation announced today that it was cutting its auto loan rate to 9.9 percent from 11.9 percent for consumers who purchase its compact and subcompact cars and light trucks.   The Ford Motor Company quickly responded with a comparable program. The Chrysler Corporation, G.M.'s other major domestic competitor, is expected to follow G.M.'s lead in the next few days.  The G.M. and Ford programs, covering loans of any term, are available beginning Friday on 1983 models delivered by May 31, when the program ends, or ordered by April 30.

headline: I.R.S. Studying Certain Notes
abstract: The Internal Revenue Service said it is studying the tax treatment of adjustable-rate convertible notes issued by several companies in recent months.   The notes, which are convertible into common stock, pay an interest rate based on the dividend of the company's stock and usually have a principal amount that is less than the value of the stock into which they are convertible.   The I.R.S. said it understands that issuers are treating the securities as debt for tax purposes and are deducting the periodic payments to noteholders as interest payments, rather than regarding the payments as nondeductible dividend payments.

headline: A Boston Agency Tries To Lure New Yorkers
abstract: Oh how easy it is to buy a fellow's loyalty.  Remember Wilson A. Seibert Jr., who was nice enough to be known as Bill in the old days as senior vice president responsible for the creative product worldwide of the giant J. Walter Thompson Company?  He was based in New York and was one of your better Big Apple polishers, a real friend of Gotham.

headline: ENTERPRISES RUN BY WOMEN WIDEN CUSTOMER BASE
abstract: When the Feminist Press was created in 1970, its main goal was to provide educational material for teachers and students of feminist studies. Now it is broadening its consumer base by publishing general interest books, such as fiction by female authors, in addition to classroom texts.   Like other businesses formed to serve women's interests and promote the feminist cause, the Feminist Press has had to adjust to the increasing public awareness of women's rights over the years. It can no longer survive, says Arlene Winnick, the company's director of public affairs, by aiming solely at ''already politicized readers.''

headline: SOVIET INCREASED 1981 ARMS OUTLAY
abstract: The Central Intelligence Agency and the Defense Intelligence Agency have told Congress that Soviet military spending continued to rise in 1981 at a steady rate despite a stagnant economy and a decline in Soviet citizens' standard of living.   In a report made public today, senior officials of the intelligence agencies said that Soviet military spending in 1981, the most recent year measured, was 4 percent higher than in the previous year and in line with earlier rates of increase.   At the same time, the intelligence officials said the Soviet economy grew only slightly, had setbacks in agriculture and key industries and had inflation that cut into the standard of living.   The confidential testimony before the Joint Economic Committee by the C.I.A in December and by the D.I.A. last June seemed likely to be cited by the Reagan Administration to justify its proposals for increased United States military spending and for trying to apply economic pressure on the Soviet Union.

headline: Wheeling Loss At $23.9 Million
abstract: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation reported today that it lost $23.9 million in the first three months of 1983 in contrast to a profit of $13.6 million a year earlier.   The profit a year ago, which amounted to $3.19 a share, included a credit of $20.2 million because of a change in the accounting of depreciation expense.   The company said it had sales of $172.7 million on shipments of 335,975 tons of steel in the latest quarter, down sharply from sales of $216.7 million on shipments of 371,478 tons in the first quarter last year.

headline: A SECOND COMING FOR TAPES
abstract: As a means of storing computer data, cassette tapes have been losing out to floppy disks. Tape systems are cheaper, but they are painfully slow and unreliable. But new types of tape machines have been developed that are swifter than cassettes and might lead to a resurgence in the use of tape as a storage medium.

headline: G.P.U. Optimism
abstract: The General Public Utilities Corporation, whose Three Mile Island nuclear plant was shut down four years ago, today expressed optimism that its troubles were now history.

headline: U.S. REPORTED TO SEEK OUSTER OF SALVADOR'S DEFENSE CHIEF
abstract: The United States is seeking the removal of El Salvador's Defense Minister, Gen. Jose Guillermo Garcia, because of the lagging combat performance of the nation's armed forces and poor morale in the military, Reagan Administration officials said today.   ''We have on more than one occasion indicated he had to go,'' one official said.  Complicating the issue, the official said, is the problem of achieving this aim without seeming to make demands on the Salvadorans, including General Garcia himself.   Beyond this, the United States Embassy in El Salvador is known to have told the State Department that the alternatives to General Garcia, who remains one of the most powerful figures in the Government, ''are very limited.''

headline: SIHANOUK OFFERS TO STEP DOWN AS PRESIDENT IN EXILE
abstract: Prince Norodom Sihanouk has offered to resign the presidency of Cambodia's government in exile if his coalition partners do not like his talk of resolving the Cambodian conflict through political means, a representative of the Prince said today.   The reports of the Prince's offer to quit came from Peking and were confirmed here today by the representative, Lah Tol.  The offer to quit, which was made in a cable June 3 to the coalition's Vice President, Khieu Samphan, came in response to criticism that the Prince was beginning to sound as if he wanted to reach an accommodation with Vietnam, whose troops have occupied Cambodia since early 1979.

headline: FEBRUARY ATTEMPT BY REAGAN TO ASSURE SOVIET IS DISCLOSED
abstract: President Reagan met with the Soviet Ambassador, Anatoly F. Dobrynin, in February to assure him that the United States was sincere about negotiating with Moscow, White House officials said today.   The meeting took place after news reports had suggested that Mr.  Dobrynin was about to abandon his post in frustration over the lack of serious negotiations with the United States.   Administration officials said Mr. Dobrynin, who has been ambassador here for 21 years, has come to personify a channel for secret dealings between the two Governments. The officials said his departure would have been read as a signal of rupture and lack of hope.

headline: LEBANON
abstract: An Israeli military spokesman said today that Syrian fighter planes had fired two air-to-air missiles at Israeli reconnaissance planes flying over Lebanon but had missed. The incident was the first aerial encounter since the war last summer.   The Israelis did not retaliate, the spokesman said in Tel Aviv, and all planes returned safely.  But Lebanese security sources and local radio stations here reported that the Syrians had shot down a pilotless Israeli reconnaissance plane over the Bekaa, a valley in eastern Lebanon. The Israelis denied this.

headline: A Saigon Premier of 60's Among 'Boat People'
abstract: A Prime Minister of South Vietnam was among a boatload of refugees that has arrived in Singapore, a senior United Nations refugee official said today.   Nguyen Van Loc, who was Prime Minister for seven months in 1967-68, told the local office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees that he had escaped from a port in southern Vietnam on his 14th attempt.   Mr. Loc, 62 years old, arrived with 32 other so-called boat people on May 13 after being picked up by a French cargo ship.

headline: Article 235444 -- No Title
abstract: Six million new shares of the Sperry Corporation were offered yesterday by an underwriting group led by Salomon Brothers at a price of $37.50 a share.

headline: Newspaper Revenue Up
abstract: Americans spent $6.7 billion on daily and Sunday newspapers last year, a 7.3 percent increase from 1981, according to the Newspaper Advertising Bureau. That represented 62.4 million daily newspapers each weekday and 56.2 million each Sunday. Readers and advertisers together spent $24.4 billion on newspapers last year.

headline: PERSONAL INCOME UP 0.8%
abstract: Americans' personal income jumped eighttenths of 1 percent in April, the biggest gain since last summer, the Commerce Department reported today.   Consumers' spending, up a seasonally adjusted 1 percent, rose even faster in April compared with March. Analysts said the gains in both categories meant companies were likely to continue to increase production and hiring.

headline: THE 'OFF-PRICE' RETAILING BOOM
abstract: Discounting brand-name fashions -or ''off-price'' selling, as it is known nowadays - has become such a powerful force in the retail market that some of the nation's largest and most successful department stores are opening their own discount outlets or buying existing discount chains.   ''Off-price retailing is the fastest-growing segment of the business today,'' said Edwin G. Roberts, chairman of Dayton-Hudson's new off-price division called Plum's, the Elegant Discounter, which opened three California stores last month and plans to open at least six more before the year ends.   In addition, the Associated Dry Goods Corporation has announced that it will buy Loehmann's Inc., the pioneer fashion discounter, and K Mart is extending its ''Names for Less'' program to 100 stores.   The Zayre Corporation is also planning extensive growth in the field. It told New York analysts last week that it would expand its two off-price apparel chains, opening 30 T.J. Maxx stores and about 75 Hit or Miss stores annually for the next several years. This would give Zayre about 800 off-price clothing stores by the end of 1986, compared with 300 of its regular discount stores.

headline: Convertible Eurobonds Up
abstract: Japanese Eurobonds convertible to equity rose sharply in active trading today. Prices rose on average around 2 or 3 points with some issues showing gains of up to 10 points.

headline: Union Leader Held in Peru
abstract: The head of Peru's largest labor coalition, Baldomero Valenzuela, has been arrested on charges of creating ''public disorder'' by staging nationwide strikes in 1981 and in March of this year and planning a third in defiance of a state of emergency, the police said today. Mr. Valenzuela, leader of the leftist Popular Democratic Union, was also arrested on charges of training guerrillas.

headline: ** Company Reports ** UNITED EDUCATION & SOFTWARE (O)
** Company Reports ** FIRST BANCORP INC (O)
abstract: Qtr to March 31 1983 1982 Net inc 1,844,000 1,609,000 Per share 1.23 1.07
