headline: AMERICAN WOMAN WILL HEAD OFFICE OF U.N. IN WASHINGTON
abstract: In a long career in public relations, Phyllis Kaminsky has promoted the casino in Monaco, helped gather Jewish votes for Ronald Reagan and served as the chief press officer for the United States Information Agency.   On Wednesday, she starts what could be her toughest task: selling the United Nations to the Reagan Administration and vice versa. She will be the first American to direct the United Nations information center in Washington, a $69,000-a-year post that makes her the highest paid American woman on the United Nations staff. She is replacing Marcel Tamayo of Bolivia.

headline: Data BankData Bank  April 3, 1983
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: DeLorean Bid By Sinclair
abstract: Sir Clive Sinclair, founder of Sinclair Electronics, may buy the closed DeLorean sports-car plant in Belfast to manufacture an electric car, a spokesman for Sir Clive said today.    The spokesman said Sir Clive had acquired an option to buy a major share of the assets of John Z. DeLorean, who is awaiting trial in Los Angeles on drug smuggling charges.

headline: Rioters in Brazil Protest Economic Conditions
abstract: The police drove back a mob attacking the governor's palace today, but rioting over unemployment and the high cost of living continued here into the night. It was the second day of violent protest.

headline: Market Place
abstract: ONLY eight months ago, the Martin Marietta Corporation, one of the nation's major defense suppliers, was in dire condition. Today, Wall Street analysts are recommending the stock and Marietta is moving up. At the close of trading last Friday, its stock was priced at 55, up from 47 at the end of March.  William M. Agee, the former chief executive of the Bendix Corporation, recognized last summer that Marietta was undervalued and he tried to take it over for $43 a share. He ran into a brick wall and offered $48, but Marietta management still resisted. Bendix went ahead and bought Marietta, anyway, but Marietta borrowed $930 million that it could not afford in order to buy Bendix.

headline: Clorox Seeking Du Pont Paints
abstract: The Clorox Company said it was planning to buy American rights to make Lucite house paints from the Du Pont Company. It refused to say how much it would pay, but Wall Street sources said that, based on 1982 Lucite sales of about $60 million, it probably would pay between $50 million and $60 million.

headline: Penzoil Increases Its Stake in Pogo
abstract: The Pennzoil Company reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had raised its stake to 1,469,000 shares, or 5.8 percent, of the common stock of the Pogo Producing Company, the Houston energy company. Pennzoil also said it intends to increase its holdings in Pogo, but added that it had no intention of seeking control of the company.

headline: President of the Ivory Coast Sees Reagan at White House
abstract: President Reagan met with President Felix Houphouet-Boigny of the Ivory Coast today to discuss economic prospects and the political situation in Africa.

headline: Judge Denies Pepsico Bid
abstract: A request by Pepsico Inc. that it be given ''timely notice'' when the Securities and Exchange Commission subpoenaed witnesses to testify in a Government investigation of top company officials was denied yesterday by Judge Abraham D. Sofaer in United States District Court in Manhattan.   Judge Sofaer ruled that to grant such relief to the bottling company would ''greatly hamper Federal agencies in the performance of their public responsibilities.''

headline: U.S. Sergeant Sentenced In Athens Car Mishap
abstract: An American master sergeant was sentenced in absentia today to three years' imprisonment by an Athens court for injuring a Greek base employee last November as the sergeant tried to enter the United States air base in Athens.   The court ruled that Norman H. Montelius, 40 years old, serving with the air base here, was guilty of deliberately trying to force his way by car through a crowd of striking personnel who were blocking the entrance.

headline: Steel Output Down 4.1%
abstract: Steel production fell 4.1 percent last week, to 1.63 million tons, from 1.7 million tons a week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute says. It was 56.3 percent of capacity, down from 58.7 percent. So far this year, output totaled 32.39 million tons, off 7.5 percent from 34.99 million tons.

headline: Mocatta Metals Fills Post of President
abstract: The Mocatta Metals Corporation, one of the world's largest bullion dealers, has elevated George McLaughlin to be its president.  Mr. McLaughlin, 46 years old, has been a vice president since 1977. The president's position has been vacant, he said, and the reason it is now being filled ''is because of growth in the company and Henry's continued involvement with the international aspects.''

headline: Reagan Says the Third World Won't Be Forgotten at Parley
abstract: President Reagan said today that he had received letters from several third world leaders and that the economic summit conference here would keep in mind the problems of the world's poorest nations.   The President, in a written statement, said, ''We meet here in Williamsburg in a spirit of common purpose with all free nations of the world and a common dedication to achieve sustained noninflationary growth and an improved international trading and financial system.   ''We are mindful, in particular, of the circumstances and concerns of the poorest countries who need our cooperation most.'' Mr. Reagan said he had received letters from, among others, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India and President Belisario Betancur of Colombia.

headline: ALASKA'S OIL RICHES BRING COSTLY FIGHTS ON TAXES, TARIFFS
abstract: When oil pushed Alaska into the limelight in the 1970's, it did more than swell the state's treasury. With the money came a series of high-stakes legal confrontations with the big oil companies that pump the state's crude.   At present, Alaska and the companies are involved in lawsuits with claims totaling between $5 billion and $7 billion. Three of the five suits are worth from $1 billion to $4 billion each to the party that prevails, based on current oil prices.

headline: Cities Service Co.  Backed in Oil Suit
abstract: A Federal judge has given the Cities Service Company a first-round victory in its $3 billion breach-ofcontract suit against the Gulf Oil Corporation.

headline: Insider Reports
abstract: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE   GOULD INC.

headline: Careers
abstract: WHILE many young lawyers are looking for jobs, there is one area that urgently needs legal expertise: the field of computer contracts and computer crime.   Computer age law is so new that legal experts know of no law school with a course devoted to it. They say there are virtually no state laws applying primarily to computers. So far, there are few legal precedents for guidance. And the field is extremely broad because telecommunications, robotics and many other electronic developments rely on computers.

headline: DOW ADVANCES 4.35
abstract: Stock prices advanced broadly yesterday after a two-day slide, propelled by encouraging Government reports concerning inflation and the economy.   In the overall market, advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered those that fell by almost a 2-to-1 ratio. The secondary issues this week outperformed the widely followed Dow Jones industrial average, which has been under selling pressure.   The Dow average, which is made up of 30 major stocks, rose 4.35 points yesterday, to 1,218.75, after dropping more than 15 points in the previous two sessions. For the week, it lost 13.84 points.

headline: A New 4-Party Coalition Announced in Thailand
abstract: A four-party coalition and 44-member Cabinet have been formed after nearly three weeks of talks among winners of general elections held April 18, the Thai radio announced.    It said the new coalition Government of Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda would include the centrist Social Action, Democrat and Thai National Democratic parties and the rightist Thai Citizen Party.

headline: Office of Chairman Created at Upjohn
abstract: The Upjohn Company, a major pharmaceuticals and health-care concern based in Kalamazoo, Mich., has announced a reorganization of top management to prepare for the coming retirement of two executives.   Ray T. Parfet Jr., 60 years old, chairman and chief executive, said he would set up an office of the chairman ''to help us prepare for the management changes that lie ahead in 1984.''

headline: A Ban Lifted, Turks Say They'll Lead Parties
abstract: Several well-known Turks announced today that they would lead political parties, a day after the military Government announced that it would allow the establishment of parties starting May 16.

headline: JAPAN'S BESIEGED CYCLE MAKERS
abstract: Japan's motorcycle industry, the world's unchallenged sales leader, is finding out that it is not easy being No.1. As with Japanese steel, auto and consumer electronics products, the industry's continued success is being threatened by increasing restrictions on its exports and a sated domestic market.   Last Friday, President Reagan ordered a tenfold increase in tariffs on large motorcycles imported almost entirely from Japan - a strong protectionist measure to help America's lone surviving producer, the Harley-Davidson Motor Company.   The blow from the United States could scarcely have come at a worse time for the Japanese motorcycle industry. Both production and exports declined last year when industry executives had anticipated an upturn.

headline: SHULTZ IS CHEERED BY SAUDI REACTION TO PULLOUT PLAN
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that he was very encouraged by Saudi Arabia's reaction to the Israeli-Lebanese withdrawal agreement and to his efforts to bring about a pullout of Syrian troops from Lebanon.   Mr. Shultz spoke to reporters on his Air Force plane as he wound up a two-week tour of the Middle East. He began the day in Saudi Arabia and then went on to Israel and Lebanon before flying here tonight.   After his talks with Saudi leaders in Jidda, Mr. Shultz said both King Fahd and Prince Saud al-Faisal, the Foreign Minister, had questioned him extensively about the details of the Israeli-Lebanese agreement, which Syria criticized sharply on Saturday. He said of the Saudis, ''I don't want to speak for them, but I considered it to be very worthwhile and encouraging from our standpoint.''

headline: Reports of Malawi Exiles Denied in Zimbabwe
abstract: Government sources today denied reports that former Cabinet ministers from Malawi fled into Zimbabwe last week to escape a political purge.   No Malawians have sought santuary here since one top exile was assassinated earlier this year, and no Cabinet-level politicians are known to have entered the country for any reason, the sources said.

headline: Continental Plan
abstract: Continental Mortgage Investors, involved since 1976 in reorganization proceedings under the Bankruptcy Act, announced it had consummated its plan of reorganization as previously approved by the Massachusetts District Court and security holders.

headline: NOW IT'S OFFICIAL: ATHENS SMOG IS EUROPE'S WORST
abstract: Athenians have grown increasingly worried about a brown cloud of pollutants they call nefos that hovers over the capital for much of the year.   Now their fears have been confirmed; Athens has won the dubious honor of being proclaimed Western Europe's most polluted city.  The European Parliament's environmental committee issued its conclusion last month on the basis of long research. The report said the Western European cities most affected by pollution were Athens, Nice and Milan, where statistics show that the average dweller's life span has been shortened and pulmonary abilities halved.

headline: Europe Jobless Outlook
abstract: European Chambers of Commerce and Industry expect unemployment to continue to rise this year but more slowly than in 1982 as protectionism threatens to abort a weak economic recovery. The Permanent Conference of European Community Chambers of Commerce and Industry said in its annual report that companies did not now believe any economic revival would last long.

headline: What's New in Lobbying; THE CANADIAN CONNECTION
abstract: In the past year, as the recession lingered and as protectionist forces grew in Congress, a vigorous new lobbying effort has emerged from an unlikely source: Canada.   As the nation's largest trading partner and closest ally, Canada has always had an economic interest in political developments on the other side of the 49th parallel. Only recently, however, has Canada established an important presence on Capitol Hill, where each session hundreds of bills have a potential effect on that nation's 24 million people.

headline: 3 U.S. Yachts Detained At a Port in Nicaragua
abstract: A Nicaraguan patrol boat escorted three American yachts to port after a storm nearly beached them during a trip to Costa Rica. One of the captains said today that they would soon be on their way.

headline: ** Company Reports ** DEXTER CORP (N)
U.S. Steel to Talk With British Steel
abstract: David M. Roderick, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, said he would hold discussions this weekend at his home with the chief executive officer of the British Steel Corporation, Ian MacGregor, but said there was only a ''50-50 chance'' that an deal would be reached on a joint venture involving U.S. Steel's Fairless Works in eastern Pennsylvania.   Mr. Roderick said agreements must still be reached on three areas of the plan, under which the two companies would jointly own the Fairless Works.

headline: ** Company Reports ** STATE STREET BOSTON FINANCIAL CORP (O)
abstract: Qtr to March 31 1983 1982 Op earn 8,044,000 7,815,000 Per share 1.87 1.86 Net inc 7,896,000 7,485,000 Per share 1.83 1.79 Shares outst 4,306,447 4,198,544 The latest quarter includes estimated loss on sale of subsidiaries of$2,458,000. The per share earnings and theshares outstanding have been restatedto reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid inMay 1982.

headline: Indonesian Oil Exports
abstract: The value of Indonesia's oil exports fell 18.25 percent in 1982 from 1981, according to preliminary statistics reported today by Bank Indonesia.

headline: Phibro-Salomon
abstract: Phibro-Salomon Inc. declared a 2-for-1 stock split and increased the quarterly cash dividend on the presplit shares to 27 cents, from 23 1/2 cents. The dividend will be 13 1/2 cents a share after the split. Both the dividend and the split shares will be distributed June 30 to shareholders of record on June 20.

headline: Mattel Loses $20.4 Million
abstract: Mattel Inc., hurt by depressed sales of its electronic games, today announced a deficit of $20.4 million for the fiscal first quarter, ended April 30.   In the corresponding quarter of 1982, Mattel earned $17.1 million, or 76 cents a share.

headline: U.N. Calls on Turkey To Pull Out of Cyprus
abstract: The General Assembly called on Turkey today to pull its forces out of Cyprus.

headline: ** Company Reports ** COLUMBUS MILLS INC (O)
U. N. Session Criticizes The West on Namibia
abstract: A weeklong United Nations conference here on South-West Africa has ended with the issuance of a strong statement against United States insistence on linking the area's independence with the withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola.   However, Western diplomats said that despite the anti-Americanism of many of the speeches by African delegates, most African leaders understood that a continuing role by the United States and other Western countries was needed to persuade South Africa to grant independence to the area, which is also known as Namibia.

headline: OBSCURE GERMAN PILGRIMS STAR IN A TRICENTENNIAL
abstract: Three hundred years ago, 13 families from Krefeld, subjects of the Dutch House of Orange, left their homes to make a new life in a God-fearing community being founded in America by an Englishman named William Penn.   The few scholars who have investigated this modest emigration to Penn's Holy Experiment cannot agree whether the Krefelders were Mennonites or Quakers. While the Krefelders spoke German, some of their names - such as op den Graeff - are evidently Dutch, and Penn himself referred to them as Hollanders.   Until 1983, the Krefeld pilgrims and the Concord, the ship that carried them from Gravesend in England to what is now Philadelphia in 1683, were decidedly obscure.

headline: U.S. Missile Truck Crashes
abstract: A United States Army truck carrying three Hawk missiles flipped over in a crash on a West German highway today, seriously injuring two soldiers.

headline: SAFEGUARD SCIENTIFICS, AFTER LEWELLYN
abstract: For Safeguard Scientifics Inc., 1982 would have been bad enough without Gary Lewellyn.   Battered by the economy, the tiny Pennsylvania machine parts manufacturer lost $6.7 million on sales that fell to $38.9 million from $39.1 million. Then because of Mr. Lewellyn, a previously unknown stockbroker from Des Moines, Safeguard found itself an unwitting party to one of the most bizarre stock manipulation schemes in Wall Street history.

headline: Louisiana Land Tallying Votes
abstract: The Louisiana Land and Exploration Company's proxy fight came to a subdued ending today at the company's annual meeting here, but the outcome will not be announced for a week or more.   John G. Phillips, the company's chairman, moved quickly through the business of the meeting, announcing the names of the contesting nominees for the board.

headline: ISSUE IN POLISH DEBT: HOW TO BORROW AGAIN; Economic Analysis
abstract: The opening moves were made this week in the latest match between the Polish Government and international banks. Both sides met Monday and Tuesday in Vienna to talk about rescheduling about $2.5 billion in bank debt due this year that the Poles say they cannot pay.  But economists say a more fundamental issue - one that apparently was not discussed this week - may be the real import of the talks, which resume later this month in Zurich. That issue is what Poland has to do to regain access to Western credit markets for the funds it desperately needs to finance an economic recovery.

headline: Your Money; Using a Car For Business
abstract: A CHANGE in the procedure for calculating automobile deductions made late last year by the Internal Revenue Service could have an important impact on individuals who use a car for business purposes.   Although the I.R.S. retained the maximum standard rate of 20 cents a mile for the first 15,000 miles a year, and 11 cents a mile thereafter, it established new rules limiting the number of miles for which the business-use deduction can be taken. This limit, based on the revenue service's projection of the useful life of a typical automobile, is now 60,000 miles, compared with the former limit of 75,000 miles - at 15,000 miles per year - for those who retained their vehicles for five years or more.   Thus, the current regulations consider the vehicle to be fully depreciated after 60,000 miles, with the 11 cents a mile considered as the overall operating costs.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * AGS Computers Inc., Mountainside, N.J., announced that it had completed the acquisition of Disc Inc., a Baltimore-based software products company, for $6.9 million in cash and notes.   * Biotech Research Laboratories Inc., Rockville, Md., said it had developed a commercial assay kit for the detection of the antibody to human T-cell leukemia virus, and that the kit would be available to medical researchers immediately.   * Cordis Corp., Miami, announced that its 50 percent stake in Cordis Dow Corp., a maker of artificial kidneys, was up for sale.

headline: ** Company Reports ** TEXAS OIL & GAS (N)
Bid For Missouri Utility
abstract: The Missouri Public Service Company yesterday announced a tender offer to buy 2,894,000 common shares, or two-thirds of those outstanding, of the Gas Service Company for $14 apiece. Both utilities serve Kansas City, Mo.   Missouri Public Service said that if its offer succeeded before the Sept.16 deadline, it would exchange its shares on a one-for-one basis for shares in a new parent company, the Mid-America Public Service Company.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Cigar, a division of American Brands, has appointed Felipe Silva chairman and chief executive officer; George L.  Theophilos president and chief operating officer, and M.B. Hiott Jr.  executive vice president.   * Bath Iron Works Corp., Bath, Me., the shipbuilding unit of Congoleum, announced that Eddy G. Nicholson, president, is assuming the additional post of chairman, succeeding John F. Sullivan Jr. who is retiring.   * A.H. Belo Corp., Dallas, has named Robert G. Norvell vice president and treasurer, and elected to its board Reece A. Overcash Jr., the chairman and chief executive of the Associated Corporation of America subsidiary of Gulf and Western Industries, and William T.  Solomon, president and chief executive officer of Austin Industries.

headline: New Group Picks Salomon Brothers
abstract: The National Financial American Network, a newly formed organization of 40 savings and loan insitutions and savings banks across the country, announced the selection of Salomon Brothers as the investment banker for the group.   The organization, formed in March, represents total assets of member banks of $80 billion, of which $4 billion is available for investments in large-scale commercial loans that the banks would be unable to participate in as individuals.

headline: BUILDING OUTLAYS DOWN 2%
abstract: Spending on new construction dipped 2 percent in February after showing a robust 7.2 percent increase in January, the Commerce Department reported today. The decline had been expected because February's weather conditions were markedly worse than in January.   Commerce Under Secretary Robert Dederick said he was not disturbed by the February figures. ''Construction activity is making an unexpectedly large contribution to the current business recovery,'' Mr. Dederick said in a prepared statement.

headline: ** Company Reports ** SUBURBAN AIRLINES
abstract: Qtr to March 31 1983 1982 Revenue 4,095,750 3,792,559 Net loss 23,786 b115,927 Share earns .05 b-Net income.

headline: Advertising; Team Has Grim Story To Tell
abstract: FREQUENTLY at ad agencies, people in the creative departments volunteer to work on public service assignments for the opportunity of working on something a little more dramatic than selling soap.   The problem for the dedicated Young & Rubicam team working for Covenant House, however, has been that the stories are too dramatic.  As far as television went, they are almost too hot to handle.   Covenant House and its Under 21 centers care for the victims of some of the most perverse segments of society. To tell their stories frankly in a television commercial would be to have the spots censored, or at the very least to have the charity and the agency accused of sensationalism and bad taste.

headline: WORLD TRADE UNIT FORMED BY K MART
abstract: K Mart Corporation, the nation's second largest retailer, announced yesterday that it would set up a trading company to provide a variety of services for exports and imports.   The K Mart move is part of trend among major American retailers to venture into international trading companies to capitalize on their big buying power, merchandising expertise and the increasing demand for varied merchandise in many countries.   K Mart said that it would set up K Mart Trading Services Inc. to provide management services for exports and imports, bartering and retail marketing of consumer goods. John S. Benner, managing director of the subsidiary, said it was an expansion of what K Mart had done for some time and the company expected within five years to transact ''several hundreds of millions of dollars.''

headline: Boeing Records 47.5% Increase
abstract: The Boeing Company today reported a 47.5 percent profit jump for the first quarter. It cited higher sales, as well as lower costs related to the development of new jet transport programs.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM MONDALE'S ADDRESS TO PUBLISHERS
abstract: Following are excerpts from a speech by former Vice President Walter F. Mondale to the 97th annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association in New York yesterday, the text of which was made available by his staff:   Today I want to speak about our national security. I speak as a Presidential candidate and as an American.  I believe that a bipartisan consensus exists on first principles.  All Americans treasure freedom. All Americans recoil from the prospect of war. All Americans insist on unquestionable defenses.All Americans accept the link between strength and peace.   And all Americans recognize the threat posed by the Soviet Union.  We do not believe that the Soviets are the misunderstood friends of freedom. We do not believe that Yuri Andropov is the chairman of the Moscow branch of the United Way.   We all know that Soviet leaders are cynical, ruthless and dangerous. They repress their citizens. They maintain their pact by force. In Poland, they destroy trade unions. In Afghanistan, they murder. In the Middle East, they sabotage peace. From Angola to Central America, their proxies exploit instability. Their relentless military buildup, well beyond defensive needs, directly challenges Western security.

headline: Stronger U.S.  Bayer Units
abstract: Bayer A.G. expects its United States operations to contribute strongly to world group profits in 1983 after costing it about $78 million last year, the managing board chairman, Herbert Gruenewald, said today.   He told a news conference that the loss was a result of measures to tighten United States activities that have now been completed.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: The resignation under fire of Gen. Jose Guillermo Garcia as El Salvador's Defense Minister this week was a symbolic end to an era that began when a group of reform-minded officers overthrew the   Government of Carlos Humberto Romero in 1979.  General Garcia was one of the last members of the Government formed after the coup to remain in office. His departure after weeks of criticism by Salvadoran and and American officials over his handling of the leftist insurgency is only one of many developments that indicate the military and political situation in El Salvador has changed greatly since 1979.   The American presence has become much more visible and intense, as demonstrated by the sharp increase in aid and the proposal to send a special envoy to monitor the move toward presidential elections in December.

headline: U.S. Exports to China
abstract: United States exports to China, hurt by sharply declining agricultural sales, dropped 26 percent in the first quarter of 1983, and the United States trade surplus plunged 61 percent from a year ago, the United States Embassy said today. The embassy said exports totaled $668.6 million, compared with $905.2 million in January-March 1982, while imports from China fell from $556.6 million, to $534.3 million. The surplus dropped from $348.6 million, to $134.3 million, the embassy said.

headline: Bergt Quits at Western
abstract: Neil G. Bergt, a colorful entrepreneur and one-time bush pilot, resigned yesterday as chairman and a director of Western Airlines.  Western said Mr. Bergt would be succeeded as chairman by Gerald Grinstein, a Seattle lawyer who has been on Western's board since 1977.

headline: LAST LIBYAN PLANE DETAINED BY BRAZIL DEPARTS
abstract: The last of four Libyan planes carrying arms destined for Central America left Brazil for Tripoli today, nearly two months after being detained for false declaration of its cargo.   The air command in the northeastern city of Recife said the Hercules C-130 transport plane left this morning bound for the Libyan capital with an intermediate stop in Mauritania. The development appeared to put an end to a prolonged impasse that provoked angry exchanges between two countries with a history of friendly diplomatic and commercial relations.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: THURSDAY, MAY 19, 1983; The Economy
abstract: Personal income rose 0.8 percent in April, the biggest gain since July, the Commerce Department reported. It said consumer spending rose even faster than income - by 1 percent. The gains in both categories mean that companies are likely to continue recent increases in production and hiring, according to analysts. (Page D1.)    The Senate Budget Committee approved a 1984 proposal that would create large deficits but call for only the minor tax increases believed acceptable to the President. A similar plan was defeated last week on the Senate floor. (A1.) In recent days, Mr. Reagan has signaled that he will compromise no further on the budget. (B14.)

headline: Seafirst Payout Is Put in Doubt
abstract: The Seafirst Corporation has been forced to dip into a $1.5 billion ''safety net'' credit line, because some holders of large certificates of deposit are not renewing them, the company's chairman said.   Richard P. Cooley also said the parent of Washington state's largest bank, Seattle First National Bank, may not pay its quarterly dividend of 12 cents a share, which would save about $2 million.

headline: Italy's Payments Deficit
abstract: Italy's overall balance of payments deficit widened sharply in March, to a provisional $951.3 million, from a provisional $207.3 million in February, the Bank of Italy said today.

headline: Some Conrail Rates Cut
abstract: Conrail said today that it had reduced rail-motor rates for iron and steel shipments from 30 steel mill locations to the Detroit and Philadelphia metropolitan areas. Conrail said the new rates for bars, billets, blooms, ingots, slabs, sheet or strip steel are about 10 to 17 percent cheaper than those charged by truck companies between the same points, and are a part of continuing effort to compete with all truck service.

headline: AIDES SUED AT DEFUNCT THRIFT UNIT
abstract: The Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation yesterday sued the top officers and directors of the defunct New York and Suburban Federal Savings and Loan Association, accusing them of self-dealing and failure to manage the association prudently.   Thomas P. Vartanian, the F.S.L.I.C.'s general counsel, said that similar suits were being prepared against officers and directors of ''9 or 10'' other savings and loan associations, whose deposits were insured by the agency and which were forced into mergers to avoid failure.   Last February, a similar suit was filed against the First Savings and Loan Association of Suffolk, Va.  According to a news release issued yesterday by the F.S.L.I.C., New York and Suburban had $500 million in assets and was failing when it was forced by the agency to merge into another New York City institution, the Anchor Savings Bank, on May 29, 1981. So far, the F.S.L.I.C. has provided $137 million in such assistance.

headline: LIST OF TREASURY FINANCINGS IS LIGHT
abstract: While the schedule of Treasury financings remains light, the volume of new corporate and tax-exempt issues continues to be heavy.  In the corporate market, published calendars of new issues are misleading, as demonstrated last week, when only a handful of new issues was scheduled though more than $1 billion of fixed-rate notes and bonds were ultimatly sold by 10 companies.   Treasury financings this week include the regular auction of threeand six-month bills on Monday, followed by $7.75 billion of new twoyear notes on Wednesday. As of late Friday,three- and six-month bills outstanding were bid at rates of 8.1 percent and 8.21 percent, while dealers offered the approaching two-year notes with a yield of 9.48 percent.

headline: Occidental Unit Gets Chairman
abstract: Thomas D. Jenkins, 55 years old, has been named chairman and chief executive officer of the Occidental Gas and Oil Corporation, a subsidiary of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation responsible for overseas exploration. David R. Martin, 52, succeeds him as president and chief operating of officer of the subsidiary, which is based in Bakersfield, Calif.   The changes follow the decision by Robert A. Teitsworth, 53, who had been chairman and chief executive, to take early retirement after eight years as head of the subsidiary.

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: The challenge to Yasir Arafat's leadership of the Palestine Liberation Organization has stirred serious concern in intelligence circles of the United States, other North Atlantic Treaty Organization countries and Israel, too.   The worst development, some intelligence sources said, would be the ouster of Mr. Arafat by left-wing organizations such as the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, backed by Syria with the blessing of the Soviet Union. The sources said a consequence could be a more aggressive P.L.O. in which the number of fully armed battalions could be increased with Soviet help to at least five, from the present three.   A NATO intelligence officer said the flow of Soviet arms into the region was such that, ''if they wish, the Russians are able to equip 12 battalions with modern weapons.'' Palestinian guerrilla battalions are believed to consist of about 750 men.

headline: U.S. SHARE OF DEBT MARKET UP
abstract: Treasury borrowings continued to dominate the financial markets, absorbing a record share of the nation's investment funds in the first quarter, according to a Federal Reserve report.   But the Fed's quarterly flow-of-funds report showed that, despite the Treasury's strong demand for funds, interest rates were able to decline because the Treasury's needs were offset by weaker credit demands from businesses and individuals.   The flow-of-funds data, which are used by many economists as a tool to forecast interest rates, identify the sources and uses of capital in the economy much as the gross national product measures the output of goods and services from various sectors.   Net new borrowing in the credit markets was at an annual rate of $529.6 billion in 1983's first three months, up from $433.1 billion in the same quarter a year ago, the report said. However, the growth in Treasury borrowing was far faster: the Government sold securities at an annual rate of $179.1 billion in the period, up from $77.7 billion a year ago.

headline: Apple Expects Net Rise
abstract: Apple Computer Inc. expects to report today a 74 percent increase in earnings for its second quarter ended April 1, said A.C. Markkula Jr., president and chief executive. He said revenues rose to about $228 million, from $131 million in 1982, and estimated net income at 40 cents a share, up 66.6 percent.

headline: DeLorean Car Discounts
abstract: About 700 or 800 of the stainless steel, gull-wing DeLorean sports cars are left for sale, the president of the company that bought the autos said today.

headline: New Mexico Bond
abstract: A $71 million issue of Aa-2-rated Farmington, N.M., pollution control revenue bonds due in 2013 was tentatively priced at 100 with a 9 percent coupon by underwriters led by E.F. Hutton & Company. The bonds are secured by payments from the Southern California Edison Company.

headline: Soviet Imprisons Head Of Solzhenitsyn Fund
abstract: A Leningrad court today sentenced the local manager of the Solzhenitsyn Fund, an organization that assists political prisoners and their families, to a two-year jail term followed by three years in exile.   The comparatively light sentence followed a six-day trial in which Valery Repin, 32 years old, pleaded guilty to treason and declared in the dock that he had used his position with the fund to channel ''secrets'' about political repression to the United States Central Intelligence Agency.   ''I declare that I am being tried not for my convictions but for concrete crimes,'' Tass, the official press agency, quoted him as having told the court.

headline: CORSICAN REBELS SET OFF 43 BOMBS IN POLITICAL WARNING TO MITTERRAND
abstract: Corsican separatists blasted banks, a police station, homes and businesses in 43 separate bomb attacks on the Mediterranean island early today, the police said.   A 27-year-old man was critically wounded in one of the explosions, the police said.  Corsican nationalist sources were quoted as saying the explosions constituted a warning to President Francois Mitterrand before his planned visit to Corsica next month.

headline: Commodities; '17-Hour Option' For Metals
abstract: BECAUSE their markets operate around the clock for most of the week, sleep has always been a precious commodity for metals traders.  To protect their clients' futures or cash positions in these commodities, many brokerage houses keep their metals departments staffed throughout the night in case some important development affects the platinum, gold, silver or copper markets.   Those houses with branches in Australia, Hong Kong, London and other major metals markets also ''pass the book'' electronically through the various times zones as another form of protection. But the average floor trader or investor in these metals must often make or receive phone calls to and from distant markets in the postmidnight hours in order to be able to cover their positions should adverse news develop somewhere.

headline: ** Company Reports ** BAYBANKS INC (O)
NORTHWEST'S POWER TANGLE
abstract: A default later this year by the nation's biggest borrower in the tax-exempt bond sector became more likely when the Washington State Supreme Court ruled this month that the state's utilities were not obligated to repay the $2.25 billion raised by the Washington Public Power Supply System to construct two now-abandoned nuclear power plants.   Not only would a default leave the bonds unpaid but also it could pose a threat to investor confidence in the nation's municipal bond market. Bond specialists estimate that investors who own the bonds - mostly individuals - eventually might get only half of the face value.   Following is a discussion of the utilities' problems and the uncertainty they have brought to the municipal bond market.  Q. What is the Washington Public Power Supply System? A. It was created in 1957 to oversee construction of electrical power plants and manage them for 23 municipal utilities and rural cooperatives in Washington State. When anticipated energy demand rose sharply in the early 1970's, the Supply System initiated plans to build three nuclear plants, known as Projects 1, 2 and 3.

headline: ** Company Reports ** MASSMUTUAL CORPORATE INVESTORS INC(N)
A Pennsylvania Issue Is Priced
abstract: An $85 million Commonwealth of Pennsylvania capital improvement general obligation issue was won in competitive bidding by the First Boston Corporation.

headline: ANTITRUST CHIEF OFFERS GUIDELINES ON RESEARCH
abstract: William F. Baxter, the Justice Department's antitrust chief, offered business executives specific benchmarks today that should make it easier for them to judge when companies can do joint research without violating the law.   Mr. Baxter's statement, probably the most explicit ever made on the subject by any Administration, could be another incentive to increased joint research and development efforts by American companies. Many business executives have complained that American antitrust laws have helped undermine the nation's ability to compete successfully against Japan and other foreign countries.

headline: ISRAEL DISMISSES CHARGE IT PLANS TO STRIKE SYRIA
abstract: Prime Minister Menachem Begin today dismissed allegations that there was a threat of war with Syria, saying a Soviet warning of such a danger was ''artificial.''   ''I do not think Syria is going to attack us,'' Mr. Begin told reporters.

headline: 700 Filipinos Protest Ruling Upholding Power of Marcos
abstract: About 700 people chanting anti-Government slogans and waving banners blocked traffic in central Manila for three hours today in a demonstration against a court ruling backing President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

headline: FED BACKS ACQUISITION OF SEAFIRST
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board yesterday approved a proposal by the BankAmerica Corporation to acquire the ailing Seafirst Corporation for $400 million. The purchase would be the largest bank acquisition ever across state lines.   The Federal Reserve Board said the merger, which its governors approved, 6 to 0, with one abstention, at a meeting in Washington, was in the public interest because of the ''serious financial condition'' of Seafirst. The Fed itself has been lending Seafirst money in recent weeks and its approval of the merger had been expected.

headline: Thrift Agency Gets Chairman
abstract: President Reagan today designated Edwin Gray as chairman of the three-member Federal Home Loan Bank Board, the agency that regulates federally insured savings and loan associations.   Mr. Gray, 47 years old, will assume the top post occupied by Richard Pratt. Mr. Pratt announced his resignation last month and plans to return to the private sector.   Mr. Gray was a top executive at the Great American Federal Savings and Loan Association in San Diego before joining the bank board.

headline: U.S. Soldier Killed in Sinai
abstract: A United States soldier was killed and another was injured when their water truck overturned on a road in Egyptian Sinai, the Multinational Force and Observers announced today. The peacekeeping force said Spec. 4 Junior E. Hudgins, 23 years old, of Anniston, Ala., was killed and a second soldier, whose identity was not released, was hurt in the accident Thursday afternoon.

headline: P.O.W.'S IN VIETNAM AREN'T RULED OUT
abstract: A senior Reagan Administration official said today that the United States had information that kept it from ruling out the possibility that some Americans captured during the Vietnam War are still alive.   The official said the Administration ''has information in its possesion that precludes ruling out the possibility that live Americans are being held captive in Indochina.''   The official said more than 200 reports from refugees who claimed to have seen American prisoners in Indochina in recent years could not be dismissed. He said polygraph tests supported many of the refugees' reports.

headline: Wheeling Steel Shares
abstract: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation said yesterday that two investors had purchased a ''substantial'' number of its common shares. It identified them as Allen E. Paulson, chairman and president of the Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation, and Burt Sugarman, a private investor.

headline: PRESIDENT TERMS FREE UNIONS KEY TO AID TO POLES
abstract: President Reagan said tonight that if Polish authorities allowed a revival of free trade unions in Poland the United States would ''turn back'' some of the sanctions imposed when martial law was declared in 1981.   In a news conference at the White House, Mr. Reagan said he had no special information on what took place in the private talks between Pope John Paul II and the Polish leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, or between the Pope and Lech Walesa, the head of the banned Solidarity movement.   ''I don't know what that situation is,'' he said. ''I only know what the Pope himself has stated and that is, he has urged the Government of Poland to allow a free union that is not subject to Government control. And if they did that, I think that we would review what we were doing and turn back from some of those things.''

headline: MARTIN MARIETTA MAKES $420 MILLION LOAN DEAL
abstract: The Martin Marietta Corporation yesterday announced the execution of a definitive long-term loan agreement with 13 major banks to refinance the remainder of the loans it took out last year in its takeover battle with the Bendix Corporation.

headline: Real Estate; Two L.I.  'Boutique' Malls
abstract: WOODBURY, L.I.  THE similarities between the Woodbury Common shopping center in this northern Long Island community and the Southgate Shopping Center in Massapequa Park, 10 miles to the south on the Atlantic Ocean, are apparent at first glance.   Both are of intermediate size, both are distinguished by clock towers of 58 and 38 feet and both have a Tudor-style architecture that brings to mind a European village square.   Not surprisingly, both were developed and are owned by the same firm, Kabro Associates of Massapequa Park. Kabro is the corporate name of the Melvin Kaplan family. Mr. Kaplan; his brother, Lawrence; his two sons, Neal and Lee, and his nephew, Steven, are the owners.

headline: Rates Decline For New Homes
abstract: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday that conventional home mortgage interest rates offered on new commitments for the purchase of newly built homes continued to decline from early April to early May.

headline: ** Company Reports ** FALCONBRIDGE COPPER LTD
REAGAN CALLS BOMBING COWARDLY
abstract: President Reagan denounced ''the vicious terrorist bombing'' of the United States Embassy in Beirut today as ''a cowardly act.'' He vowed that the United States would not be deterred from its efforts to bring peace to the Middle East and the withdrawal of foreign troops from Lebanon.   In a brief statement in the White House Rose Garden about six hours after the attack, Mr. Reagan said he would ''rededicate the efforts of the United States'' to those goals.   Washington was unable to provide exact casualty figures immediately because some bodies were unrecognizable, officials said, and more dead and wounded were expected to be found in the rubble.

headline: Bankers Trust Official Announces Resignation
abstract: Carlos M. Canal Jr., a member of the management committee at the Bankers Trust Company, has resigned, the company said yesterday.  Mr. Canal, 52, was executive vice president in charge of the Administration Function, a term used by the bank when it centralized its administrative tasks in a reorganization announced last July.   Mr. Canal was named to the post at that time.

headline: ** Company Reports ** KANSAS CITY SOUTHERN INDUSTRIES INC (N)
PATENTS; Aircraft Is Attached To the Pilot's Back
abstract: An aircraft patented this week is to be attached to the pilot's back in saddle fashion, fitting around his sides and shoulders. A support forward is to be provided for his head and one at the rear for his feet, with power supplied by two jet engines.

headline: Energy Unit Mounts Nuclear Safety Drive
abstract: The United States Committee for Energy Awareness is a Washingtonbased organization founded after the Three Mile Island accident and it is going to mount a major television campaign to persuade the American people that nuclear energy is economical and safe.   It has just picked up two ad agencies to do it, Ogilvy & Mather, New York and Houston, for national programs, and Winner/Wagner, Los Angeles, for regional and local advertising programs. W.W. has been working for the committee since 1981.

headline: New Business Weekly For Three-State Area
abstract: New York Business, a weekly publication devoted to business in the New Jersey-New York-Connecticut area, will be introduced in October by the Hagedorn Communications Corporation.

headline: Olof Palme Renews Call For Nuclear-Free Zones
abstract: Prime Minister Olof Palme of Sweden called today for nuclear-free zones in Scandinavia and central Europe, in an address before the North Atlantic Assembly.   Mr. Palme, the first person from a non-NATO country to address the semiannual assembly, said he believed such zones could delay the intensification of a war and ''give leaders urgently needed time to ponder future actions and policies.''

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: THE OTHER TALKS
abstract: A senior Administration official, taking a break from diplomatese, chose the word ''boring'' to describe the performance of French President Francois Mitterrand at the leaders' final working dinner.   The characterization was offered in a spirit of relief more than meanness, for only 48 hours earlier the Reagan team had been prepared to find a much more combative President Mitterrand arriving at the summit conference. But instead of the feisty man called ''Ton-Ton'' in French politics, the Americans found an amiable, even cooperative head of state. Best of all, in the view of this Reagan strategist, Mr. Mitterrand was safely ''boring'' at the final working dinner.

headline: Socialists Sign Accord On Austrian Coalition
abstract: Austria's Socialist and Freedom parties announced agreement today on the first coalition Government in 17 years, amid a furor over the possibility that a former Nazi SS man may become a Parliament leader.

headline: Sun Will Sell Flagship Units
abstract: Sun Banks Inc. of Orlano announced agreements today to sell 11 units belonging to Flagship Banks Inc. of Miami for $132 million, an essential step in a $334 million merger of the two institutions.

headline: Hamilton Sells Stake
abstract: The Hamilton Brothers Petroleum Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its equity position in the Gulf Energy and Development Corporation to the Penn Central Corporation for $22.3 million in cash. Hamilton Brothers owns all of Gulf Energy's outstanding convertible preferred stock and warrants to a purchase of common stock. On a fully converted and exercised basis, its position represent 24.3 percent of Gulf Energy's common stock.

headline: BATUS NAMES HEAD OF RETAIL DIVISION
abstract: Batus Inc. said yesterday that it had appointed a new chairman and chief executive officer for its retail division, which operates such stores as Saks Fifth Avenue, Gimbels and Marshall Field. The division's sales total $3 billion a year.

headline: A Defiant Argentine Admiral Is Sentenced to Year in Prison
abstract: The chief of the critical Southern Naval Zone was sentenced to a year in jail today for criticizing the way his superior handled last year's disastrous Falkland Island war with Britain, the official news agency Telam reported.   The agency said Adm. Horacio Zaratiegui, under arrest since he was replaced as commander of the southern zone Sept. 20, was found guilty of ''insubordination, disrespect and usurpation of command.''

headline: University Revisions Approved in France
abstract: The French National Assembly today approved university revisions, proposed by the country's Socialist Government, that led last month to violent protests by students throughout the nation.   The Assembly, where President Francois Mitterrand's Government has an absolute majority, adopted the bill by 325 votes to 160.  During the debate, Education Minister Alain Savary told Parliament that the revisions, which introduce new examinations and greater nonacademic influence on university boards, would make the universities more responsive to France's economic needs.

headline: Ex-SS Officer Confesses To Massacre in France
abstract: A former Nazi SS officer admitted at his trial today to rounding up French villagers and gunning them down before razing their village.   The former Nazi officer, Heinz Barth, 62 years old, broke down repeatedly in sobs as he described to an East Berlin court the shooting of 20 men with two bursts from his machine pistol during the massacre at Oradour-sur-Glane on June 10, 1944.

headline: PATENTS; Abandoned Mine's Coal Is Burned for Energy
abstract: A method of burning out the coal in abandoned mines and recovering the energy for electric power was patented this week for the Department of the Interior. Robert F. Chaiken, a supervisory research chemist in the Pittsburgh research center of the Bureau of Mines, was granted patent 4,387,655.

headline: G.M.-Toyota Pact Studied
abstract: A decision from the Federal Trade Commission on the proposed joint car production deal between the General Motors Corporation and the Toyota Motor Corporation will most likely be made in 50 to 60 days, the F.T.C. chairman, James C. Miller 3d, said today.   But Mr. Miller raised the possibility that the agreement, under fire from the Chrysler Corporation on antitrust grounds, could be subject to unusual open hearings.

headline: Sorg Receives Bid
abstract: The Sorg Paper Company said it had received an offer to be acquired but it did not identify its suitor.

headline: STRAINS IN SEABROOK PROJECT
abstract: The managers of New Hampshire's largest electric utility are wagering the company on what many analysts call a long shot that grows longer every day: the Seabrook Station nuclear power project.  Despite major cost increases, extended completion schedules, uncertain future financing and a torrent of criticism, the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, the lead participant in the two-reactor, 2,300-megawatt project, has vowed to proceed. So far, the company has been able to hold up its end of an increasingly heavy financing burden, and has retained the support of a majority of the project's other owners.  But cracks have appeared in the once united front. A growing minority of the power companies with equity shares in the Seabrook project want the second reactor, now about 15 percent finished, either canceled or delayed while work continues on Seabrook 1, which is more than half completed.

headline: ** Company Reports ** DST SYSTEMS
REGIONAL BROKERS: ENDANGERED SPECIES
abstract: A few years ago, Advest Inc., a Hartford-based brokerage house, had to make a choice. The firm, then privately owned, needed fresh capital. Its options were to accept a takeover by a well-capitalized financial organization, thus exchanging independence for security, or to try to raise the money by selling public shares.   Advest chose independence - going public in 1980 and gaining a listing on the New York Stock Exchange in 1982 - and today it remains independent. But it is a member of an endangered species as one after another of its fellow regional firms are being bought up by powerful outsiders.

headline: REGAN URGES DELAY IN LIFTING OF BANKING INDUSTRY BARRIERS
abstract: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan today called on Federal bank regulators to impose a moratorium that would prevent companies outside the banking industry from getting into commercial banking and would prevent both banks and savings institutions from getting into other fields.   This followed and amplified the move Tuesday by the Comptroller of the Currency to establish its own moratorium until January on efforts by nonbank companies to establish banks.   Mr. Regan said that while the Administration supports tearing down barriers between the banking industry and other financial businesses, it wants Congress to make the decisions, rather than various regulators.   The broader moratorium would prevent savings and loan associations and banks from moving into such nonbanking businesses as real estate, securities and insurance. In addition, such a moratorium would stop companies outside banking from setting up banks by using a loophole in Federal law.

headline: U.S. URGED TO SEEK BAN ON WEAPONS IN SPACE
abstract: A group of scientists, retired military officers and several senators urged today that negotiations be opened with the Soviet Union on a treaty banning the testing and use of weapons in space.   Two senior Government spokesmen said, however, it was the view of the Reagan Administration that negotiations should be postponed until it is certain that ''daunting'' problems of treaty verification have been solved and the United States is certain it is willing to forgo the ability of blinding Soviet satellites.   Senator Paul E. Tsongas, Democrat of Massachusetts, said he interpreted the testimony of Kenneth L. Adelman, the new director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, and of Fred C. Ikle, Under Secretary of Defense for Policy, as meaning that the Administration would ''stall'' and avoid negotiations because of a desire to test and deploy a United States antisatellite weapon now under development and to preserve President Reagan's proposal for space-based defense against ballistic missiles.   The issue was discussed in a hearing of the Arms Control subcommittee of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. The subcommittee chairman, Larry Pressler, Republican of South Dakota; the full committee's chairman, Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois, Senator Tsongas and Senator Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island, all urged that the Administration move more promptly to test the negotiating waters before a highly expensive extension of the arms race into space occurred.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: * American Electric Power Inc.'s Indiana & Michigan Electric Co.  subsidiary announced that it would sell, from time to time, up to $70 million of first mortgage bonds and up to $25 million of $25 par value preferred stock at competitive bidding on or about July 27.   * Citicorp said an average rate of 9.355 percent was set at the weekly auction of its 91-day commercial paper, up from 9.33 percent at last week's auction.   * Digicon Inc.'s offering of 35,000 units consisting of $35 million of 12 7/8 percent senior subordinated notes due in 1993 and warrants to purchase 945,000 common shares is under way through Drexel Burnham Lambert.

headline: ARAFAT EXPELLED AFTER SAYING SYRIA AIDS P.L.O. REVOLT
abstract: Syria expelled Yasir Arafat today, one day after the guerrilla leader accused President Hafez al-Assad of orchestrating the anti-Arafat rebellion among Palestine Liberation Organization troops in Lebanon.   A statement by the official Syrian press agency said, ''Because of Arafat's continued slanders against Syria and its sacrifices, and its positions of principle, he was informed today of Syria's desire for him not to continue coming to its territory.''   The statement was issued several hours after Mr. Arafat was escorted to the Damascus airport by Syrian security officials in six cars and put aboard a regularly scheduled Air Tunisia flight for Tunis. Given 3 Hours to Leave   Syrian officials said the expulsion order was written by the Syrian Army Chief of Staff, Maj. Gen. Hikmat Shehabi, who had it delivered to Mr. Arafat's Damascus office at 11 A.M. According to the officials, the letter gave Mr. Arafat three hours to get out of the country, ''otherwise we will make sure you leave ourselves.''

headline: Losses at Alcoa And National
abstract: The Aluminum Company of America, the world's leading aluminum producer, said today that it lost $14.3 million in the first quarter of 1983, compared with net income of $43.8 million, or 57 cents a share, in last year's first quarter. The 1982 figure included an extraordinary gain of $19.9 million from the exchange of Alcoa stock for sinking fund debentures.

headline: Europe Auto Forecast
abstract: Roger B. Smith, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, said today that car sales in Europe would rise to 11.5 million in 1985 and 13 million by 1990 from about 10 million at present. He told a conference on motor components that he expected G.M. to maintain its 11.2 percent share of the European market.

headline: Market Place; Cautious View Of the Market
abstract: BY the standards of most Wall Street money managers, the San Mateo, Calif., firm of Bailard, Biehl & Kaiser Inc., which provides financial planning and investment advisory services mainly to wealthy individuals, is taking a rather cautious view of the stock market.   ''At present, only 27 percent of a typical client portfolio is devoted to domestic common stocks,'' said David L. Biehl, executive vice president. ''We are underweighted in equities because of our belief that the real economic recovery won't take hold until the second half of 1984. In particular, we generally are avoiding such market sectors as high technology, consumer durables and basic capital-goods industries.''

headline: Chilean Strikers Soften Their Demands
abstract: Truckers and other workers who joined a protest strike against President Augusto Pinochet's military Government softened their demands today, calling for more democracy but not necessarily the ouster of Mr. Pinochet.

headline: ** Company Reports ** GROW GROUP INC (N)
U.S. JEWISH STUDENTS PROTEST ISRAELI POLICY IN A LETTER TO BEGIN
abstract: Jewish students at three leading American law schools, in a letter to Prime Minister Menachem Begin, have protested Israel's invasion of Lebanon and its treatment of Palestinians in the occupied territories.   A total of 133 law students from Harvard, Yale and New York University signed the letter, which voiced their ''strong opposition to recent Israeli Government actions.''   The letter was delivered late Friday to the Israeli Mission to the United Nations. A spokesman for the mission said there would be no comment until Yehuda Z. Blum, the Israeli delegate, had read the letter.

headline: MRS. KIRKPATRICK REJECTS AWARDS
abstract: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the United States delegate to the United Nations, today rejected awards from Barnard and Smith colleges because they had provoked controversies on both campuses.   In similar letters to officials at the two schools, Mrs.  Kirkpatrick wrote, ''As a faculty member myself, I feel deeply that a university or college is defined by its faculty and students.''

headline: Philippine Journalist Released After 18 Days
abstract: President Ferdinand E. Marcos today ordered the release under house arrest of Antonio Nieva, a journalist who had been held 18 days in a military stockade for purported Communist ties.   Greg Cendana, Minister of Media Affairs, said President Marcos had taken the action in response to an appeal by Mr. Nieva's wife, Concepcion, and a request by Ben Rodriguez, president of the National Press Club, to allow Mr. Nieva to take part in club elections Sunday. Mr. Nieva is running for re-election as club director.

headline: DAVID OWEN FIGHTING FOR POLITICAL LIFE
abstract: The young man told David Owen that he was worried about the Labor Party's winning the general election because ''they're so weak on the Falklands and on defense.'' He said he guessed that he would have to vote Conservative.   Dr. Owen, the former Labor Foreign Secretary, who left his comrades to help found the Social Democratic Party, saw a chance to make a convert. He told his questioner that the Tory candidate in Plymouth Devonport, his constituency, had no chance of winning and launched into a plea for what the British call a ''tactical vote.''

headline: Press Group Protests Law Planned in Turkey
abstract: The International Press Institute, representing nearly 2,000 editors and publishers around the world, has protested a press law being prepared by the military Government of Turkey, saying the matter should be left to the government formed after the election promised for November.   The protest was made in a message from Peter Galliner, director of the institute in Zurich and London, to Turkey's head of state, Gen.  Kenan Evren.

headline: 4 RETAILERS POST STRONG GAINS
abstract: Four of the nation's largest retailers yesterday reported sharp increased earnings in their first quarter as a result of improved sales, higher margins and better internal controls.   The biggest gainer was the K Mart Corporation, with a more than seven-fold gain in net income. The Allied Stores Corporation had more than a fivefold surge in its net; the May Department Stores Company had 76.5 percent higher profits, and the Dayton-Hudson Corporation had a 4.6 percent earnings increase.   ''All the results showed that inventory and expenses are under excellent control and therefore there is a good flow-through of the relatively favorable sales performances,'' said Jeffrey M. Feiner, retail analyst for Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith. ''While the rate of the earnings gains for the remainder of 1983 isn't likely to be as great, we still look for industry profits to increase 15 to 20 percent this year over last year,'' Mr. Feiner said.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS; U.S. SECURITIES CLIMB IN YIELD
abstract: Prices of Government securities fell and yields rose yesterday amid some nervousness over large bill auctions this week. Dealers expressed concern that yesterday's quiet trading session, where retail interest was minimal, signaled higher rates and lower investor participation during the auctions.  The rate on $12.4 billion in three-and six-month bills auctioned yesterday hightened that concern. The three-month bill was at 8.98 percent, up from 8.73 percent at last week's auction and the highest since the 10.02 percent rate at the auction on Aug. 9, 1982.

headline: Cockpit Entrepreneur: Allen E. Paulson
abstract: BY LANDING GULFSTREAM ON WALLSTREET, THE COMPANY'S CHIEF CASHES IN By AGIS SALPUKAS FOR most of his 61 years, Allen E.  Paulson used his hands to earn his keep. When he was younger, he c leaned rooms in a hotel, hawked papers and milked cows. After World W ar II he fixed cars and refurbished old planes.   Then he began to break apart surplus airplane engines. With spare parts and some tinkering he developed a valve that solved a major problem of a widely used engine. From that base he built a business and gained the experience that enabled him to put together a major executive-airplane company, the Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation.

headline: Baker International
abstract: The Baker International Corporation announced it would establish reserves during the third fiscal quarter ending June 30 that would reduce after-tax earnings by about $98 million, or $1.40 a share.

headline: The U.N. Today; June 6, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Working Group on Protection of the Rights of Migrant Workers and Their Families - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.  Committee on Science and Technology for Development - 10:30 A.M.  and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   United Nations Development Council Governing Council - 10:30 A.M.  and 3 P.M.

headline: TRADE GAP A RECORD
abstract: The nation's foreign trade deficit surged to a single-month record of $6.9 billion in May, the Commerce Department said today. One department economist said the deficit for all of 1983 would probably top expectations.

headline: ** Company Reports ** NORWESCO INC (O)
INDIANA STANDARD OFF 15.1%
abstract: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana), the first of the nation's major oil companies to report first-quarter earnings, said yesterday that net income fell 15.1 percent, to $399 million, or $1.36 a share, largely because of falling gasoline prices.   John E. Swearingen, chairman and chief executive officer, said that ''competitive gasoline market conditions'' had affected Indiana Standard's United States refining, marketing and transportation operations.

headline: Millions Are Surprised By Start of Ramadan
abstract: Ramadan, the Moslem holy month of fasting from surise to sunset, arrived today one day earlier than expected and caught millions of Moslems off guard.   Half an hour after midnight a special television broadcast announced that religious astronomers in Saudi Arabia had sighted the crescent new moon Friday evening, meaning that Ramadan had to begin today, not Sunday as predicted earlier.

headline: Pan Am Terminal
abstract: Pan American World Airways, saying that its financial condition had improved, reported it had ended discussions with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey about the sale of its terminal at Kennedy International Airport.

headline: BBDO Earnings Up
abstract: BBDO International is the first of the publicly held agencies to get out of the gates with its first-quarter earnings. And they are up. Revenues were $57.8 million, a 22.5 percent gain from the $47.2 million in the comparable period last year, while net income rose 15.6 percent, to $3.7 million, or 64 cents a share, from $3.2 million, or 57 cents a share.

headline: Freer Trade
abstract: To the Business Editor: A strict reciprocal policy must be established with our major trading partners (''Peeling Away Japan's Trade Barriers,'' April 17).

headline: G.& W. Sells 2 More Stakes
abstract: Gulf and Western Industries said that it had sold its stake in two companies as part of its continuing strategy of reducing its stock portfolio to lower its debt.   G,& W. said it had sold its 15.52 percent stake in the Hammermill Paper Company, a producer of papers based in Erie, Pa., and its 11.77 percent share in the Hayes-Albion Corporation, a metals-castings concern based in Jackson Mich.

headline: Patents; Portable Bar-Code Scanner
abstract: HELD instrument, regarded as important in the growing commercial practice of sorting consumer goods with bar-code laser scanners, was patented this week for its manufacturer, Symbol Technologies Inc. of Hauppauge, L.I. The device weighs only a pound and can be plugged into electronic cash registers.  Jerome Swartz, the principal inventor and the chief executive officer of the company, said it was the first truly portable, handheld, trigger-actuated laser scanner that reads the familiar black and white lines appearing on many consumer products sold today.

headline: ** Company Reports ** CYNEX MANUFACTURING CORP (O)
abstract: Year to Sept 30 1982 1981 Sales 2,588,817 2,124,167 Net inc 28,421 b25,824 b-Net loss.

headline: DAMAGE IN MOZAMBIQUE RAID LOOKS SURPRISINGLY LIGHT
abstract: In both scope and impact, South Africa's reprisal raid here Monday does not seem to equal the act it purported to avenge.   South Africa sent its warplanes into a suburb of the Mozambican capital to exact retribution for a car bombing in Pretoria last week that killed 18 people and wounded almost 200. The African National Congress, the most prominent nationalist movement opposed to the white minority Government in Pretoria, said Monday that it was responsible for the attack.   The congress is represented here in various ways, and South African statements soon after the raid laid great emphasis on assertions that the warplanes had struck installations used by the movement to plan guerrilla tactics and had also knocked out a Mozambican missile base.

headline: GUNSHOTS STILL PUNCTUATE ANGKOR'S FRAGILE GLORIES
abstract: After 13 years of war, neglect, invasion, anarchy and continuing guerrilla clashes, the glory of Angkor Wat is diminished but still intact.   More than four years after the Vietnamese Army swept across Cambodia in pursuit of the Pol Pot forces, however, neither Angkor Wat nor the 75 square miles of ancient temples, tombs and palaces that surround it can yet be described as perfectly safe.   On a recent Sunday four American visitors to the temple complex heard dozens of shots ringing out. Since some of the shooting came from south and west of the temple, areas teeming with Vietnamese and Cambodian soldiers, the Government guide was asked if such gunplay was normal, if bullets ever struck the temple, and why nobody intervened.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: There is an air of selfcongratulation among African leaders here who, finally, and after much division, have been able to convene the Organization of African Unity's twice-postponed 19th summit meeting. It is as if a notion central to the continent's self-image - that a collective African resolve is capable of overcoming individual disputes - has been rescued.   Yet the manner in which the gathering was finally assembled has left some critical questions unanswered and has posed a new hazard.  In the process of debate, compromise and pressure that led to the summit opening Wednesday night, the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, was further alienated from Africa's mainstream. That probably removes the restraints, if any, there had been on his behavior and raises the possibility of a renewal of Libyan adventurism, perhaps in Chad, Libya's neighbor to the south.

headline: Patents; Two New Rubik Puzzles
abstract: ERNO RUBIK, the Hungarian professor who invented the famous Rubik's Cube but never patented it in the United States, was awarded two patents here this week for other puzzles called spatial logical toys.   The two patents are assigned to Politoys Ipari Szovetkezet, a toy manufacturer in Budapest that also produces Rubik's Cubes.

headline: BILL LETS LIFE INSURERS USE FUTURES TO HEDGE
abstract: A little-noticed bill that Governor Cuomo is expected to sign soon would allow life insurance companies for the first time to hedge their investments and loans in the futures markets.   Because most states tend to follow New York's standards in insurance regulation, the bill has profound implications for the nation's securities, credit and futures markets. Life insurers are the biggest source of long-term credit and, with the pension funds they manage, a dominant force in the stock and bond markets.

headline: EGYPTIANS ARE DISAPPOINTED BY THE JORDANIAN-P.L.O. RIFT
abstract: While publicly saying that the current setback is only temporary, Egyptian officials are privately disappointed that King Hussein of Jordan has abandoned plans for a joint approach with the Palestine Liberation Organization aimed at talks with Israel.   Such an approach had been strongly encouraged in recent weeks by President Hosni Mubarak in order to generate momentum for peace talks before the United States, a pivotal negotiator in the Egyptian view, becomes embroiled in election-year politics.   Mr. Mubarak's key adviser, Osama el-Baz, told reporters that Egypt was prepared to offer new suggestions in an effort to bring the P.L.O. and the Jordanian Government together. It was necessary, he said, ''to preserve the peace momentum and contain a possible rift.''

headline: Cullinet Project With Anacomp
abstract: Anacomp Inc. and Cullinet Software said that they would jointly develop a new version of Anacomp's retail banking software, which is currently designed for banks with assets of $1 billion or more.

headline: B.P. Drops Oilfield Bid
abstract: The British Petroleum Company P.L.C. has decided not to exercise its right to match a bid by the Dorset Group for the British Gas Corporation's Wytch Farm oilfield, Energy Secretary Nigel Lawson told Parliament today.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE
abstract: Michael Jeffries, who has been in charge of investigating new business opportunities for Federated Department Stores, found a concept that he liked and decided to try it on his own.   Mr. Jeffries, who is 38, said yesterday that he would team up with Robert Mandel, 58, an executive who spent much of his career at Petrie Stores, to develop their own chain of women's apparel shops.   The partners plan to open four stores next year, the first in February. The concept at the yet-to-be-named store chain will be clothes for the affluent working woman, from 25 to 50 years old.

headline: Scali Head Reaffirms Link With Ogilvy
abstract: In response to queries yesterday, Marvin Sloves, chairman of Scali, McCabe, Sloves, a wholly owned subsidiary of Ogilvy & Mather International since 1977, said that while he had been negotiating for some time with the parent company to get some S.M.S. equity back in the hands of its executives he has no interest in being totally independent of the parent, and indeed has been assured by Ogilvy management that it plans a continuing ownership position.   As for the rumor that his agency may be acquired by a foreign agency, he said he was in frequent conversations with such agencies but only to seek possible overseas joint-venture arrangements as a way of achieving desired international growth.   The Scali shop was acquired for cash, not Ogilvy stock.

headline: First Union Corp.  Appoints President
abstract: Edward E. Crutchfield Jr., president and chief executive officer of the First Union Bank in Charlotte, N.C., has been named to the additional post of president of the First Union Corporation, the bank's holding company.   Mr. Crutchfield, 41 years old, has been president of the bank since 1973.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: SEXUAL REPRESSION IN THE LAND OF THE KAMA SUTRA
abstract: It was just an obscure, two-paragraph item in the papers a few days ago. One Satya Singh was convicted and sentenced to a year's ''rigorous imprisonment'' and a fine of more than $100 for ''outraging the modesty of a girl by kissing her.''   Mr. Singh's conviction for offending the sensibilities of a teenaged employee of his wife's factory was overturned by a higher court. But the incident said a lot about how sex is treated in urban, middle-class India.

headline: Chicago Dock
abstract: Shareholders of the Chicago Dock and Canal Trust approved a joint venture with the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States to develop a residential and commercial complex in Chicago projected to cost between $2 billion and $3 billion. The action completes a transaction announced last October.

headline: Homequity and Fantus Get New Presidents
abstract: Homequity Inc., a pioneer in the business of relocating corporate employees, has named John J. Gottsman as president.  Mr. Gottsman, 40, succeeds Robert D. Kunisch, 41, who moves to Homequity's parent, the PHH Group, as one of three executive vice presidents. Mr. Kunisch will be in charge of personnel-related services at PHH and Mr. Gottsman will report to him.   In other changes at PHH, James M. Keane, 44, was named president of a newly acquired unit, the Fantus Company, which specializes in site selection and plant relocation. Mr. Keane was formerly senior vice president of operations at Homequity.   Homequity moves about 20,000 families a year and contributes about half the $500 million sales volume of PHH, which is based in Hunt Valley, Md., and is traded on the New York Stock Exchange. PHH's other major business is leasing fleets of vehicles to corporations.  It has also recently entered the businees of leasing executive air fleets.

headline: Louisiana Land
abstract: The Louisiana Land and Exploration Company said it planned to distribute one unit of beneficial interest in the L.L.& E. Royalty Trust for each two common shares held, payable June 28 to holders of record on June 22. The company will convey to the trust net overriding royalty interests in nine productive oil and gas properties and a 3 percent royalty interest in about 400,000 acres of the company's unleased and undeveloped south Louisiana fee lands, it said. Dissident shareholders, who recently lost a proxy fight, said the company's plans for the trust did not go far enough.

headline: Pentagon Nominates Once-Criticized General
abstract: A general who received White House criticism and reassignment for saying that the Soviet Union had achieved ''strategic superiority'' over the United States and that this was producing a ''drift toward war'' has been nominated for another star, the Pentagon announced today.   It said Maj. Gen. Robert L. Schweitzer was nominated for promotion to lieutenant general and was being reassigned from his post as an assistant deputy chief of staff to chairman of the Inter-American Defense Board.

headline: No Headline
Louisiana Offering Draws Investors
abstract: A $99.85 million general obligation bond issue for the State of Louisiana was won yesterday in competitive bidding by Citibank and priced to yield 5.5 percent in 1984 and 9.25 percent in 2003. The issue was sold out on the first day, the underwriter reported.

headline: Platinum Cash Prices At Premium Over Gold
abstract: Platinum cash prices sold at a premium over gold yesterday for the first time since Sept. 11, 1981.
