This came a day after platinum futures moved to a premium over gold, after having sold at discounts of as much as $131 an ounce since 1981.   After the close yesterday, dealers quoted ''free'' cash platinum at $439.50 an ounce. That was $5 below the close of the active near July futures contract, which was up $5.30 on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

headline: Patents; Acting Head Serving At the Patent Office
abstract: Gerald J. Mossinghoff, who headed the Commerce Department's Patent and Trademark Office as commissioner since 1981, has now been made Acting Deputy Secretary of Commerce, succeeding Guy W. Fiske, who resigned. In the absence of Secretary Malcolm Baldrige, who is in China, Mr. Mossinghoff is also Acting Secretary of Commerce.  Donald J. Quigg, Deputy Commissioner of Patents and Trademarks, is serving as acting head of that office. Mr. Mossinghoff was deputy general counsel of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration until he became commissioner.

headline: The U.N. Today; May 3, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Special Committee on the Charter of the United Nations and on the Strengthening of the Role of the Or- ganization - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Meets at 10:30 A.M.   Working Group of Governmental Experts on the Implementation of Human Rights - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Economic Committee - 3 P.M.   Social Committee - 3 P.M.

headline: Guyana Expelling 2 In the U.S. Embassy
abstract: Guyana has ordered two United States Embassy officials out of the country for interfering in its domestic affairs, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.   An American Embassy spokesman denied the charges and said, ''As far as we are concerned the two officials to whom the charges have been referred have not engaged in any activities which are inconsistent with their diplomatic status in Guyana.''

headline: Iran Reports 37 Dead In Iraqi Missile Attack
abstract: Thirty-seven people were killed, 210 were wounded and 200 houses and shops were destroyed or damaged when three long-range Iraqi missiles struck a residential area in the Iranian city of Dizful Friday night, the Iranian press agency said today.

headline: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 20, 1983
abstract: The Economy   Senate Republicans, in a compromise, agreed to put off for at least four years tax withholding on income from interest and dividends. However, the White House was cool to the idea and said President Reagan, who opposes repeal, had not changed his position.  (Page A1.)   Officials said Mr. Reagan will continue to seek a budget compromise with Congress despite the advice of Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger. (A20.)

headline: 42 Die and 50 Are Injured In Istanbul Hotel Blaze
abstract: A fire gutted a hotel filled with foreign tourists today, killing 42 people and injuring at least 50, witnesses and officials said.   When the fire broke out, the officials said, many guests panicked and stampeded to the stairs or rushed to windows instead of seeking safety on the roof of the six-story Washington Hotel.

headline: THE WEALTH AND AURA OF MORGAN
abstract: A spotless, light beige carpet stretches like a sea of tranquillity across the executive floor of the Morgan Bank. The walls are paneled in genuine, not-too-highly-polished oak. The baseboards are of green marble. Huge oil portraits of Morgan's past chairmen peer across the chamber from gilt frames. An antique grandfather clock, with wood inlay, quietly ticks away the hours.   This perception of orderliness and this aura of perfection are the trademarks of the House of Morgan and of its two primary components - J.P. Morgan & Company, the holding company, and the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, the bank.   Morgan is so well run and so profitable that it is the paragon of the banking industry. Bankers Trust openly tries to emulate it, and even Walter B. Wriston, Citicorp's supremely self-confident chairman, often uses Morgan as a model of profitability and a yardstick by which to measure how well a bank is run. Last year, for example, Morgan - the nation's fifth-largest bank holding company with assets of $58.6 billion - earned 78 cents on each $100 of average assets, more than any other of the 15 largest bank holding companies.

headline: Postal Rivalry
abstract: To the Business Editor:    As Bernard Wunder notes (''Let the Postal Service Compete Fairly,'' April 17), providing daily home delivery to rural areas is expensive, and probably not justified on strictly economic grounds. But Mr.  Wunder fails to note that infrequent or unreliable service for highdensity areas or priority mail is even more inefficient.

headline: '84 Outlays Could Top $1 Billion at 2 Concerns
abstract: Both Procter & Gamble, the multi-brand packaged goods giant, and General Motors, the multiproduct automobile maker, each could exceed $1 billion in advertising spending in 1984, according Schonfeld & Associates, the Evanston, Ill., computer company whose annual Ads Forecasts does a pretty good job of being in the budget ballpark.   However, the company qualifies its breakthrough prediction.

headline: Initial Stock Offerings Set Record in Quarter
abstract: A record for equity financings was set in the first quarter by companies selling stock publicly for the first time, a tally by Abrahamsen & Company showed yesterday.   Initial public offerings of stock totaled about $2.18 billion and amounted to a fifth of all equity financings during the quarter.

headline: ** Company Reports ** KRM PETROLEUM CORP (O)
Hyatt to Seek Plan for Braniff
abstract: Jay A. Pritzker, the chairman of Hyatt International, will meet with a select group of Braniff International creditors here today and urge them to come up with a proposal to restart the airline, a source involved in the negotiations said yesterday.   The source said that Mr. Pritzker was annoyed with having bettered his offer several times only to have the secured creditors say that it was not good enough.

headline: Patents; Nuclear Power Technique
abstract: A METHOD and device for producing nuclear fusion, patented this week for the Army, may prove of much value to the power industry. The invention was made by Thomas G. Roberts, a research physicist at the Army missile laboratories in Huntsville, Ala.

headline: Doner Wins Sedgefield
abstract: W.B. Doner & Company in Baltimore, which for two years has been handling co-op advertising for Blue Bell's Wrangler Men's division, has now been assigned the regular advertising account of the Sedgefield Sportswear Company division, which makes branded jeans and ''casual bottoms'' for males of all ages and young girls and junior misses. Mathieu, Gerfen & Bresner of New York, one of the Bloom Companies, previously did the ads.

headline: Executive at Coachmen Adds President's Duties
abstract: Coachmen Industries, makers of recreational vehicles and other products, has named C. Raymond Johnson president and chief operating officer. Mr. Johnsosn, 36, will retain his postion as executive vice president of the recreational vehicles group.   Coachmen also named Philip G. Lux, 54, executive vice president of the parts and supply group, to the additional new post of vice chairman.   Thomas H. Corson, 55, who had been handling the responsibilities of president, will remain chairman and chief executive. Mr. Corson and two brothers founded the company in Middlebury, Ind., in 1964.

headline: REAGAN AND O'NEILL SPAR ON TAX BILL
abstract: On the eve of consideration by the House of Representatives of a Democratic bill to limit the July 1 reduction in income taxes, President Reagan and Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr.  traded angry accusations today over whose policies were hurting the middle class.   Mr. Reagan, speaking to the National Federation of Independent Business, said the Democrats were shedding ''an ocean of crocodile tears'' over Federal deficits and were seeking to impose a ''graveyard philosophy'' of higher taxes and spending.   The Democrats, he said, were practicing ''the politics of envy'' and were trying to pit one group against another with their proposal to place a ceiling on the tax cut so that families in higher tax brackets would benefit relatively less.   ''It takes a great leap of faith to trust the motivation and wisdom of the self-proclaimed champions of fairness who are now attacking the middle class,'' Mr. Reagan declared. ''The tax 'cap' is not a fairness bill. It's a jobs-destruction bill. It would cut off our nose to spite our face.''

headline: DURABLES ORDERS UP IN MARCH
abstract: Orders to factories for durable goods edged up three-tenths of 1 percent in March, the Commerce Department reported today. Increases for military hardware, machinery and household goods outweighed declines for the transportation industries and primary metals.   The new overall gain was the fourth in the past five months and marked a rebound from the revised 3.5 percent decline in February.

headline: FOR THE NEW ETHIOPIA, OLD TROUBLES GRIND ON
abstract: Nine years after the overthrow of Emperor Haile Selassie, political signboards here still proclaim, ''Revolutionary Motherland or Death.''   This nation of more than 40 million people in the Horn of Africa is a sprawl of mountain fastness, fertile plain and steaming seaboard coveted for its location on the Red Sea and its potential.   The Government of Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam has promised a dictatorship of the proletariat, but there is a residual, largely dispossessed middle class and a profound feeling for religion - Christian, Islamic or animist. An Eastern bloc diplomat said the Ethiopian people ''are not mentally prepared for socialist organization.''

headline: Oppenheimer Chooses Top Official of New Unit
abstract: Oppenheimer & Company, the investment firm, has set up a new subsidiary to expand its leveraged-buyout activities and has chosen a corporate executive, rather than a Wall Street man, to head it.   Stephen M. McGrath, 47, will be president of the new unit, to be called the Oppenheimer Strategic Investments Corporation.

headline: I.B.M. INTRODUCES COMPUTER TO REPLACE SYSTEM 34 MODEL
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation introduced a new medium-sized general purpose computer today as an eventual replacement for its existing System/34 model.   The new computer, called the System/36, will have 20 percent to 70 percent better performance than the System/34, which was introduced in 1977 and will now be phased out of production, I.B.M. said. The company made its announcement at the National Computer Conference, which opened here today.

headline: COMMODITIES
abstract: Of the two groups of stock index futures traders who have been selling the market short in recent weeks, those who counted on the blue chips to lead the decline have made large profits from those who thought the secondary issues would show the larger losses.   The traders with the profits had bought the Value Line futures and sold short the Standard & Poor's 500 futures. The S.& P. 500 consists mainly of blue chips, while the Value Line measures a much much broader range of stocks. The losers were those who sold the Value Line and bought the S.& P. 500.

headline: Conoco Capital
abstract: Conoco Inc. said it expects 1983 capital outlays and cash exploration spending to total a record $2.3 billion, up 9 percent from 1982. Conoco said petroleum spending will be increased 11 percent, to $2 billion.

headline: DISTILLER IN OFFER FOR LENOX
abstract: The Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation yesterday offered $87 a share in cash, or an indicated $392 million, to acquire Lenox Inc., a maker of china best known as the official supplier to the White House. Lenox's early reaction to the proposal was unfavorable.   Brown-Forman, the Louisville, Ky., distiller and marketer of Southern Comfort and Jack Daniel's whiskies, Bolla Italian wines and Martell cognacs, said its offer was not conditioned on any minimum number of shares being tendered. Lenox, which has 4.54 million shares outstanding, recently declared a 100 percent stock dividend, payable July 1 to holders of record on June 3.

headline: Tax Cut Limit Vote Due
abstract: The House Ways and Means Committee will meet Thursday to approve a $700 cap on the 10 percent individual tax cut that takes effect July 1, committee staff members said today. At a Democratic caucus, many members expressed their reluctance to support the proposal but said they would vote for it because it is the idea of House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr.

headline: TURKISH TRIAL SEEN BY JOURNALISTS AS WARNING
abstract: The trial of a 75-year-old publisher arrested for reprinting a 22-year-old editorial is being seen by many Turkish journalists as a warning that strict controls will be enforced by the military regime even as the country moves toward elections next fall.   The trial is also widely viewed as a test of the democratic intentions of the Turkish generals, whose new Constitution guarantees freedom of the press and expression.   Nadir Nadi, the highly respected publisher of the liberal Istanbul daily Cumhuriyet, is being tried by an Istanbul martial-law court for reprinting an editorial in defense of two independent cultural institutes.   The military court reconvenes Monday to hear the defense, and a verdict is considered possible then. An independent observer who has closely followed the case said any outcome other than an acquittal would be a serious blow to press freedom in this country.

headline: ** Company Reports ** WEIGH-TRONIX INC (O)
Need for Capital
abstract: To the Business Editor:    The implication of the article ''The Corporate Tax: Uneven, Unfair?'' (March 20) is that a corporate tax structured to encourage investment in productive equipment is undesirable. I find that implication disturbing.   If we as a nation are at all concerned about improving productivity and preserving some semblance of a competitive position in world markets, not to mention the national security aspects of maintaining healthy energy and heavy industries, we must insure that sufficient capital is available to replace and modernize key productive equipment. If this necessitates a more liberal depreciation treatment than for less vital investment, we should applaud rather than condemn our ability to be responsive to the need.

headline: British Columbia To Vote on May 5
abstract: Premier Bill Bennett today called a provincial general election for May 5, saying investment uncertainty could be cleared only by a provincial government with a ''strong and enduring mandate.''   Mr. Bennett said that while international traders have confidence in his eight-year-old Social Credit government, investment decisions were being withheld because of the uncertain political climate.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: The departure of Ariel Sharon from the post of Defense Minister appears to have changed the way the inner circle of the Israeli Government makes policy.   There has been more consultation among key ministers in the two months since Mr. Sharon resigned, and a calmer, more collegial atmosphere in most deliberations, according to well-placed officials.    Mr. Sharon remains in the Cabinet, but mainly as a gadfly, with little of the influence that once made him the second most powerful man in Israel.   At Cabinet meetings and public gatherings, he has adopted an increasingly critical line toward Government policies, arguing against the flexibility brought by his successor, Moshe Arens, in negotiations with Lebanon and relations with the United States.

headline: PORTUGAL USING ITS GOLD
abstract: Portugal has apparently been forced to dip into its large gold reserves to overcome short-term cash problems caused by delays in obtaining a $300 million loan, foreign bankers said today.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * American Financial Corp. and its chairman, Carl H. Lindner, said they had increased their stake in Fisher Foods Inc. to 17.9 percent of the common shares outstanding, through open market purchases.   * Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting firm, said it had developed a line of microcomputer software on accounting, tax and audit-related topics, for sale to other accounting firms; marketing is to begin in Florida, and reach national distribution later this year.

headline: POLAND'S 'PARALLEL ECONOMY' THRIVING
abstract: Coffee, shoes, stereo equipment, ball-point pens, books, punk-rock tapes, all the things that Poles cannot find in their stores are spread out, although perhaps not in profusion, in a large field on the edge of Warsaw each Saturday morning.   Tens of thousands of people swarm through the so-called Persian market each weekend. Similar markets have sprung elsewhere in the capital and in other cities.   The sprawling free market, where entrepreneurs with connections peddle the scarce goods, is only the most visible example of what is called here the second or parallel economy, the subterranean system by which Poles cope with the official economy. Failure of Official Economy   Part survival mechanism, part freebootery, the parallel economy has many aspects, ranging from simple networks of friends and favors to a current widespread speculation in, of all things, coffee-table books. Obviously there are no records, but its scope is vast.

headline: Volcker's Record
abstract: To the Business Editor: After reading Professor Thurow's article (''Why Volcker Should Be Let Go,'' June 5) it's difficult to determine if he considers himself an optimist or a pessimist, given current monetary policy. But one thing is indeed certain: Fed Chairman Volcker is a realist.

headline: Electronic Data's Iran Settlement
abstract: Millionaire H. Ross Perot said he and his company, the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, had settled all its claims against Iran for $16.5 million.   In May 1980, Electronic Data won a $19 million breach-of-contract judgement against Iran.

headline: Stake in Kerr Sold by Jacobs
abstract: Irwin L. Jacobs, a Minneapolis investor who has made a reputation by buying troubled companies and profiting from selling their assets, has ended his interest in the Kerr Glass Manufacturing Corporation.   A Securities and Exchange Commission filing in Washington indicated that a group headed by Mr. Jacobs had sold its 6.8 percent stake in the container maker, which is based in Los Angeles.

headline: Japan Studies Beef Quotas
abstract: Japan's top agriculture official said today that his nation must reach a domestic consensus about expanding its quotas on beef and orange imports before resuming talks with the United States.   Iwazo Kaneko, the Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, told Japanese reporters it could take two months for the ruling party and farm leaders to achieve such a consensus, the ministry said.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: The Soviet Union, with its daily fulminations against Secretary of State George P. Shultz's plan for the withdrawal of foreign troops from Lebanon, has again cast itself as a spoiler of the American peace initiative for the Middle East.   Ever since President Reagan offered his proposals for a settlement between Israel and the Palestinians in September, the Soviet Union has exerted influence on key figures, including Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, to shun the proposals.  Arabs have been told that the Reagan plan dooms the Palestinians to ''eternal wandering'' without a state of their own.   In recent weeks Moscow has been directing its polemics against the effort to get Israeli, Syrian and Palestinian forces out of Lebanon, saying the provision of an Israeli-monitored security zone in the south of Lebanon would turn that country into ''Israel's hireling'' and provide ''a stronghold for a fresh United States military presence in the Middle East.''

headline: Federated's Chief For Discount Chain
abstract: Federated Department Stores Inc., the nation's largest operator of department stores, announced yesterday that it would get into the growing industry of selling national brands at discount prices. It named a young executive from a competitor, May Department Stores Inc., to head a chain of stores that will be opened next year.   John H. Eyler Jr., 34 years old, who is currently president and chief executive of May's D&F division, with headquarters in Denver, will join Federated, which is based in Cincinnati, on May 9.

headline: Texas Gas Is Silent On Coastal's Offer
abstract: The Texas Gas Resources Corporation declined comment yesterday on a $45-a-share tender offer made for its stock by the Coastal Corporation, but analysts predicted it would fight the bid.   Coastal said Sunday night that it intended to purchase up to 10 million Texas Gas shares, which would give it a 52 percent interest in the company.

headline: ** Company Reports ** LINDBERG CORP (O)
abstract: Qtr to March 31 1983 1982 Sales 12,832,276 22,215,620 Net loss 993,235 b1,046,618 Share earns .20 b-Net income.

headline: TRANSCRIPT OF PRESIDENT REAGAN'S CONFERENCE WITH REPORTERS
abstract: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's statement yesterday in Washington on the confirmation of Kenneth L. Adelman as head of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, followed by an exchange with reporters, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT   I am deeply gratified by the United States Senate's confirmation today of Ambassador Kenneth Adelman to be director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency. It's my earnest hope that this positive step will mark the beginning of a new bipartisan consensus on the vital issue of nuclear arms reduction. I'm convinced that Kenneth Adelman will prove that the confidence which the Senate has expressed in him today is well-founded. Under his leadership we can look forward to a reinvigorated Arms Control and Disarmament Agency that will make an important contribution to our arms reduction efforts.   As we seek equitable and verifiable agreements with the Soviet Union to reduce the arsenals and the risks of war, we will need the advice and support of the Congress. I'm confident that with full consultation with Congress and the development of our arms reduction initiatives, the United States can continue to be a force for genuine peace and progress in the world. And if we're met with reciprocal seriousness of purpose from the Soviet Union, 1983 can be a year of historic importance in securing a more solid and stable peace through arms reductions. Helen?

headline: BULGARIAN SCOFFS AT TIMES ARTICLE
abstract: A Bulgarian spokesman, responding to an article published in The New York Times on March 23, has questioned whether a Bulgarian intelligence official mentioned in the report actually exists. The official was reported to have said that the Soviet secret police wanted Pope John Paul II killed to prevent Western subversion of Poland.   The Times article said a Bulgarian intelligence official named Dimiter Savov had told Iordan Mantarov, a Bulgarian who later defected in France, that the K.G.B., the Soviet intelligence and internal security agency, saw the election of the Polish Pope in 1978 as a threat to Soviet control over Poland.

headline: Caterpillar to Offer 5 Million Shares
abstract: The Caterpillar Tractor Company said that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of five million shares of common stock, through underwriters led by the Merrill Lynch White Weld Captial Markets Group.   The public offering would be the first such financing by the company; its stock closed at 45 5/8 yesterday. Between late 1981 and late 1982, Caterpillar was active in the debt markets, where it raised more than $850 million through sales of notes and debentures, including zero coupon and deep discount issues.

headline: Beltran Unit Faces Chapter 11 Filing
abstract: The Beltran Corporation said an involuntary petition for Chapter 11 reorganization under the Bankruptcy Act had been filed against its Acton Foodservices Corporation subsidiary in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the District of Massachusetts.

headline: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
abstract: Long-Term Rates

headline: Western Talks With Wien Parent
abstract: Western Airlines Inc. said that it had resumed discussions about a merger with Household International Inc., the parent company of Wien Air Alaska.

headline: Harvester-Ford
abstract: The Ford Motor Company said it was renegotiating an existing $500 million engine supplier contract with the International Harvester Company, seeking to double output of Harvester's light truck diesel engines starting next year. Harvester sources said that, when the final agreement was reached, the value of the accord would reach nearly $900 million. Harvester is Ford's only supplier of light truck diesel engines.

headline: CHRYSLER DROPS BOND AS TOO COSTLY
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation, discouraged by high interest rates from entering the bond market, reported yesterday that it had canceled a plan to sell $200 million in bonds to help repay $400 million of its federally guaranteed loans.   Instead, the auto maker said it would make the June 15 payment entirely from its cash reserve. That would leave the auto maker with $800 million in federally guaranteed loans outstanding. The $200 million issue would have been one of the largest offered by a major corporation.

headline: U.S. ENVOY SAYS SALVADOR KILLING LOOKS POLITICAL
abstract: The United States Ambassador to El Salvador said today that in ''all probability'' the slaying of the deputy commander of the United States Military Group in El Salvador was a ''political act.''   Western and Salvadoran sources differed on whether the killing here of the officer, Lieut. Comdr. Albert A. Schaufelberger 3d of the Navy, on Wednesday at 6:30 P.M. was the work of the left, the extreme right or some segments of the Salvadoran security forces who are unhappy with the level of United States involvement in El Salvador.   (A statement purporting to come from a Salvadoran leftist guerrilla group, the Popular Liberation Forces, and broadcast by a local radio station claimed responsibility for the killing, United Press International reported. An embassy spokesman said, ''We're looking into the communique,'' but officials noted that Salvadoran guerrillas have their own radio station and have rarely left communiques at other stations.)

headline: Pogo Tender Suit Counterclaim
abstract: Sedco Inc. and Northwest Industries jointly announced that they would file a counterclaim in the tender offer litigation begun on April 27 by the Pogo Producing Company in Houston.

headline: Around the World; Lebanon Starts Effort To Gain Arab Backing
abstract: The Lebanese Government began new efforts today to gain backing from Arab countries in trying to persuade Syria to withdraw its troops from Lebanon.   The Secretary General of the Arab League, Chedli Klibi of Tunisia, arrived here at the request of President Amin Gemayel, while Foreign Minister Elie Salem flew to Saudi Arabia to meet King Fahd.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: For all its historic significance and for all the smiles and handshakes of the negotiators, the signing of the Israeli-Lebanese withdrawal agreement seems to have been cause for little real rejoicing in either Israel or Lebanon.   Usually the signing of an agreement between two nations marks a clarification of their relations and the beginning of a new, clearly defined era. Today's signing ceremonies here and in Qiryat Shemona, an Israeli border town,ushered in a new era, but it is one dominated by a sense of uncertainty about the future in Lebanon, Israel and the Arab world.   This is not to take anything away from the accord itself, which both sides hailed today as a scrupulously fair compromise hammered out with the help of the United States. Ink on Paper   In theory, the agreement solves everything between Israel and Lebanon. But in reality - for the time being - it solves nothing.  Unless Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization agree to conclude similar withdrawal arrangements, the Israeli-Lebanese accord will remain nothing but ink on paper.

headline: U.S. Steel Defends Plan
abstract: The United States Steel Corporation might have to close its Fairless, Pa., plant as early as 1986 unless it makes a controversial deal to import British steel, David Roderick, the company chairman, said yesterday.   Earlier estimates that the Philadelphia-area mill could stay open until 1990 now appear ''optimistic,'' he said at the annual meeting of the American Iron and Steel Institute.

headline: Citibank Service
abstract: Citibank has introduced a new discount brokerage service at its metropolitan branches.

headline: ** Company Reports ** AGS COMPUTERS INC (O)
** Company Reports ** H & H OIL TOOL CO (O)
U.S. RAISES TARIFF FOR MOTORCYCLES
abstract: In an unusually strong protectionist action, President Reagan today ordered a tenfold increase in tariffs for imported heavyweight motorycles.   The impact of Mr. Reagan's action, which followed the unanimous recommendation of his trade advisers, is effectively limited to Japanese manufacturers, which dominate every sector of the American motorycycle market.   The action was exceptional for protecting a single American company, the Harley-Davidson Motor Company of Milwaukee, the sole surviving American maker of motorcycles.   The only comparable trade action by this Administration, the President's decision last May to impose quotas on sugar imports for the first time since 1974, was aimed at an entire industry.

headline: Anaheim Electric Yield at 9%
abstract: A $130.7 million issue of Aa/A+-rated Anaheim, Calif., electric revenue bonds was tentatively priced yesterday to yield 9 percent for bonds due in 2007, according to underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. Yields for shorter maturities ranged from 5 1/4 percent for bonds due in 1985 to 8.7 percent for those due in 1998.   Investment bankers noted that the Anaheim bonds attracted many California-based investors, who are willing to accept a slightly lower yield than what is available on other electric revenue bond issues outside the state. For California residents, income from local bonds is exempt from the state's income tax, while out-of-state bonds are subject to a levy as high as 11 percent.

headline: FRANCE BLOCKS JAPANESE BID FOR INFORMAL TIES TO NATO
abstract: Japan has tried to set up an informal consultation arrangement with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, but the move has been blocked by France, Japanese officials and foreign diplomats here report.   The attempt reportedly was made in January with United States support as a means of strengthening Japanese connections with the West on security matters. Officials pointed out that, while the United States was linked to Japan through the security treaty of 1960 and to its European allies through NATO, no ties on security matters existed between Japan and Western Europe.   In an attempt to bridge this gap, the sources said, Japan's Foreign Minister, Shintaro Abe, suggested during a trip to France, Britain and West Germany in January that an informal ''consultation mechanism'' be established between Tokyo and NATO.

headline: 23 REPORTED DEAD IN LEBANON BATTLE
abstract: Twenty-three people were reported killed and as many as 100 others kidnapped in outbreaks today between Druse and Christian factions in the Shuf Mountains south of Beirut.   The area, the scene of many exchanges in recent months between the two groups, is under the control of Israeli troops.  The Government-sponsored Voice of Lebanon radio said at least 14 Druse and 9 Christians were killed in shelling and gunfire in villages in the area.

headline: Head of Showa Venture At Diamond Shamrock
abstract: Allan J. Tomlinson, president and chief operating officer of the Diamond Shamrock Corporation, is stepping down to lead a Diamond Shamrock venture with Showa Denko of Japan.   Mr. Tomlinson, 50, will become chairman and chief executive of a company being formed with the big Japanese petrochemical concern.

headline: Kodak Recasts Unit's Name
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company has decided to change the six-day-old name of its camera-making unit, the U.S.  Equipment Division, figuring people might not want to buy USED cameras.

headline: Washington Watch; Cruise Ships, U.S. Style
abstract: A FLORIDA builder and financier, Robert L. Lambert, believes he has a new recipe for business success. First, buy two Cunard liners with help from investor syndicates. Next, hire as Washington counsel the son of the Speaker of the House. Then, persuade Congress to pass a private bill authorizing American-flag registration. And, finally, sign up droves of East Coast, Great Lakes and West Coast passengers for cruises between American ports such as New York and Charleston, S.C. Foreign-flag cruise ships are barred by law from these routes, which represent a new dimension to the cruise business, a growth industry.   Mr. Lambert, a resident of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., said in a Washington interview that his company, Cruise America Line Inc., has an option to buy the Cunard Countess and the Cunard Princess if Congress authorizes American registration of the foreign-built vessels. Each ship is 536 feet long and carries 938 passengers.

headline: 2 Use Bow and Arrow To Cross Berlin Wall
abstract: Two East Berliners used a bow and arrow to shoot a line across the Berlin Wall, then glided to the West on a pulley 35 feet above the ground while guards were not looking, the West Berlin newspaper BZ said today.   One of the men, a heating engineer identified only as Michael B., 23 years old, told the newspaper that he and a 24-year-old electrician friend hatched the plan on New Year's Eve.   Michael said he was recently released in an amnesty from a 20-month jail sentence following an earlier, unsuccessful escape attempt across the Hungarian-Austrian border.

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: Israeli military sources say their Defense Forces high command is increasingly concerned over the recent reinforcement of the Syrian Army and   Palestinian guerrilla forces in Lebanon.  The reinforcement, they say, includes the return of a Palestine Liberation Organization infantry brigade that the Israelis believed they destroyed last summer.   As a result, these sources and intelligence analysts in the United States and in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization say, the Israeli high command is faced with two major problems.

headline: FOES PAINT A RIGHTIST THATCHER FUTURE
abstract: The British general-election campaign has entered a new phase, with the opposition parties now warning the voters of the dangers of a landslide Tory victory by suggesting that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has a hidden radical agenda for a second term.   ''The time has come,'' said Dr. David Owen of the Social Democrats, ''to begin to draw the queen bee's sting.'' With little more than a week remaining until the balloting on June 9, the opposition Labor Party and the new Liberal-Social Democratic alliance hope to force Mrs. Thatcher and the Conservative Party onto the defensive. Until now, she has managed to project an air of quiet assurance, of business almost as usual, while they floundered in her wake. The public-opinion polls, appearing almost daily, continue to give her a lead that would produce a victory of dimensions not seen in Britain since Labor's sweep in 1945.

headline: U.N. Reports Progress In Talks on Afghanistan
abstract: Indirect negotiations between Pakistan and Afghanistan recessed today until June 16, and the United Nations mediator reported ''substantial progress'' toward an agreement that could open the way to withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan.   Foreign Ministers Sahabzada Yaqub Kahn of Pakistan and Mohammed Dost of Afghanistan ''agreed to suspend the discussions to enable the delegations to hold consultations in their capitals,'' a United Nations statement said.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * General Cigar and Tobacco Co. to Young & Rubicam/Chicago for its Silver Creek brand of smokeless tobacco.

headline: 20 ARE REPORTED KILLED IN INDIA AS SIKH PROTESTERS BATTLE POLICE
abstract: At least 20 people were reportedly killed today and 180 wounded in the northern Indian state of Punjab as policemen sought to clear thousands of demonstrating Sikh nationalists from the state's roads.   Hundreds were said to have been arrested during the demonstrations, which consisted of occupying the roads with the aim of blocking transportation. The demonstrations were organized by the Akali Dal party, a Sikh opposition political organization, to focus national attention on its demands for greater autonomy for Punjab, where most Sikhs live. Sikhs also want land from neighboring states merged into Punjab and water for irrigation.

headline: U.S. FEARS DISCORD WITH MAJOR ECONOMIC ALLIES AT ECONOMIC TALKS
abstract: Despite the Reagan Administration's efforts to assure a harmonious economic summit conference at Williamsburg, Va., over the Memorial Day weekend, aides are worried that the meeting may be marked by sharp disagreements.   In interviews today, officials at the White House and State Department said President Reagan hoped the conferees could ''agree to disagree'' amicably on matters such as the charge by France that American budget deficits and high interest rates are damaging the world economy.   They added that the seven heads of state who will attend the meeting, scheduled for May 28-30, had powerful incentives to avoid a divisive conference like the one last year in Versailles, France. The nations involved are the United States, Britain, France, West Germany, Italy, Canada and Japan.

headline: REFINERS' STOCKS GROW
abstract: Prices of copper futures, a key economic indicator, fell an average of one-half cent a pound yesterday as several bearish factors combined to make speculators convert their recent paper profits into cash.   One factor was a report by the Bureau of Mines showing that the nation's copper refiners had 285,000 metric tons of copper on hand Jan. 31. This compared with 268,000 on Dec. 31 and 160,000 on Jan.  31, 1982.

headline: A.T.& T. Satellite
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company formally asked permission of the Federal Communications Commission to launch the first in a series of new Telstar satellites on July 28, the launching date assigned by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The company plans to launch the second Telstar next year and a third in 1985. The Telstar series will augment and eventually replace the Comstar satellites that A.T.& T.  leases now from the Communications Satellite Corporation, or Comsat.

headline: Money Fund Assets Slump
abstract: After weeks of modest declines, assets of money market mutual funds fell a sharp $1.7 billion last week, to $166.9 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.   It was the funds' 29th drop in a row.

headline: Hawaii Bond Yield At Maximum 8.8%
abstract: The Hawaii Department of Transportation's $118.1 million issue of A/ AAA-rated airport and harbor revenue bonds was tentatively priced with a maximum yield of about 8.80 percent through underwriters led by Blyth Eastman Paine Webber Inc. Yields for shorter maturities ranged from 4.75 percent in 1984 to 8.5 percent in 1997.

headline: ** Company Reports ** MARSHALL & ILSLEY CORP (O)
abstract: Qtr to March 31 1983 1982 Net inc 7,452,000 5,279,000 Per share 1.65 1.21

headline: FALSE IMAGES AND POLITICAL BIAS
abstract: AGROWING number of economists and government officials today have e xpressed concern that America's industrial base is in serious d ecline, threatening economic recovery and a continuation of high u nemployment. They fear that the West will not survive if the United S tates forsakes the production of steel and becomes a nation of i nsurance companies and fast-food restaurants. An industrial policy f or the United States is being proposed to counteract this trend.   In fact, there is no reason to believe that the decline of our heavy industries is a cause for alarm. There is precious little evidence to demonstrate such decline in the first place.

headline: Market Place; Energy Issues' New Strength
abstract: ENERGY related issues, long out of favor with investors, surged ahead last week, while some recent strong groups gave ground in the stock market. This process provided another example of the group rotation that has helped to cushion stock prices from any jarring decline since the bull market began last August.   The scramble to purchase oil issues, spurred by recommendations at several brokerage firms, was clearly evident Thursday, the final session of a four-day week. This buying spree followed a proposal by the state-owned British National Oil Corporation for price cuts of 50 cents to 75 cents a barrel for North Sea oil.

headline: China Accuses Vietnamese Of Increasing Border Attacks
abstract: China accused Vietnam today of increasing incursions and provocations along their common border and warned the Hanoi Government it would suffer ''grave consequences'' if the incidents continued.   The Chinese also accused the Vietnamese of killing or wounding 14 Chinese in border attacks in March.  The protest, handed to the Vietnamese Embassy. said, ''The Chinese Government today warned the Vietnamese authorities that if they let the trend of armed provocations against China's border continue to develop, they must be held responsible for the grave consequences.''

headline: SALVADORAN PLAN FOR LAND CHANGES SUFFERS SETBACKS
abstract: El Salvador's land redistribution program has suffered significant setbacks in the last few months, according to the country's largest farmers' union and a preliminary study made for the A.F.L.-C.I.O.   The farmers' group, the Salvadoran Communal Union, with 40,000 members representing 100,000 small landholders and agricultural workers, warns that if the Government does not take action to reverse the decline, it will lose support in rural areas.   ''In the countryside, if you don't have beans and corn, you are lost,'' said Samuel Maldonado, a leader of the union. Peasants Being Evicted   ''The day that they see that they have lost their rights,'' he said, speaking of the farmers who had begun to benfit under the land program, ''they will decide to join the guerrillas. If you have 5,000 beneficiaries, and they lose out, they get frustrated, and that's 5,000 machine guns that will turn against the Government.''

headline: 400 Former Polish Internees Reported to Resettle in U.S.
abstract: The State Department said today that as many as 400 Poles interned after the crackdown on the Solidarity union had left Poland and had been resettled in the United States.   Alan D. Romberg, a spokesman for the department, said the United States had made no agreement with the Polish Government to accept them as refugees.

headline: Texas Housing
abstract: A $125 million issue of the Texas Housing Agency's 9 percent bonds due in 1995 was tentatively priced at 100 by a Goldman, Sachs & Company group. The bond proceeds will be deposited in certificates of deposit at local savings and loan associations, which will then extend below-market rate financing for the construction of multifamily housing projects. Because the backing of the C.D.'s by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation also applies to bondholders' investments of up to $100,000, the Texas Housing issue was rated AAA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

headline: Della Femina Given Rolls-Royce Promotion
abstract: The really big excitement at Della Femina, Travisano & Partners concerned a product with a slightly higher price tag than a package of Chip-A-Roos. Would you believe a Rolls-Royce?

headline: U.S. Carrier in Mediterranean
abstract: The aircraft carrier Coral Sea was due to enter the Mediterranean today, temporarily at least increasing United States naval air power within reach of the Middle East.

headline: Soviet Is Said to Free 5 Held for 13 Months
abstract: Five men who were arrested 13 months ago after publishing underground criticisms of the Soviet system have been released from jail without standing trial, associates of the five men reported today.   The associates said the men were freed last week under what was described as a ''partial amnesty,'' under which the men did not acknowledge any guilt and the prosecutor did not retract the accusations.

headline: Explosion Is Said to Kill Afghan Defense Official
abstract: A land mine planted by guerrillas in eastern Paktia province of Afghanistan killed a top Defense Ministry official and nine other people traveling in an air force van, rebel sources said today.   The Defense Ministry Secretary, Mohammad Shafiq Ahangar, was killed with his son when the mine blew up their van June 9 on a road in Khowst, in Paktia province bordering Pakistan, the sources said.

headline: Technology Unit Picks Texas Site
abstract: The city of Austin, Tex., has beaten 56 other municipal contestants in the competition to become home to a major new research enterprise headed by Bobby R. Inman, former Deputy Director of Central Intelligence, it was announced today.   The company, called the Microelectronics and Computer Technology Corporation, is a joint venture of a dozen large companies that have each pledged to spend a minimum of $50 million a year to develop high-technology products, such as supercomputers for the international market.   Austin was selected Monday from a group of four finalists that also included San Diego, Atlanta and the Raleigh-Durham-Chapel Hill research triangle of North Carolina. It was chosen, Admiral Inman said in a telephone interview, largely because of the commitment that state businessmen and others had shown to high-technology industry, particularly computers.

headline: Canadian National
abstract: Canadian National Railways will merge the administration of its money-losing trucking and express divisions and move from Quebec to Toronto, the state-owned transportation company said. Eventually, there will be a full integration of the two divisions, company officials said.

headline: Montero Vehicle Priced
abstract: Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America said today that its new Montero model, a four-wheel-drive utility vehicle, would be introduced this month at $9,229.

headline: Braniff Extension On Reorganization
abstract: A Federal bankruptcy judge gave Braniff International two more weeks to submit its long-awaited reorganization plan and the airline's chief executive said it would be filed by April 18.   Howard D. Putnam, chief executive officer of Braniff, said the extension was granted by United States Bankruptcy Judge John Flowers because of a crowded court docket.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Head 'Doing a Little Work'
abstract: David Packard, co-founder of the Hewlett-Packard Company, likes to keep his hand in. Yesterday, for example, he was in New York at a show of company computer products ''doing a little work,'' as he put it.   Mr. Packard and William R. Hewlett are no longer involved in the day-to-day operations of Hewlett-Packard, the Palo Alto, Calif., technology company they founded in 1939 with $595. Today, the company has sales of more than $4 billion. Mr. Hewlett is vice chairman and Mr. Packard chairman. John A. Young is the president and chief executive.

headline: ISRAEL'S MILITARY CHIEF RETIRES AND IS REPLACED BY HIS DEPUTY
abstract: Israel's Chief of Staff, Lieut. Gen. Rafael Eytan, retired from the army today, completing the changes in military leadership envisioned by the state commission that investigated the Beirut massacre. His replacement, former deputy chief of staff Moshe Levy, was installed in office and promoted from major general to lieutenant general.   The change is widely seen here as likely to bring a revision in the style of leadership. General Eytan was a tough-talking general with a penchant for delivering political statements. He was adored at the right of the political spectrum and disliked at the left, where many Israelis accused him of politicizing the army.

headline: Default in Taiwan
abstract: The Taiwanese Government has no plans to bail out the Great International Corporation, Taiwan's fifthlargest trading company, which has been defaulting on its debt payments, an official of the Economic Ministry said. Twenty-seven financial institutions, including six foreign banks, are owed more than $50 million by Great International and its affiliate, the We Sheng Group, which has been defaulting on payments since late last year. Local bankers said they were bracing for what could become Taiwan's largest commercial banking loss.

headline: Reagan to Meet Mexican
abstract: President Reagan will visit President Miguel de la Madrid of Mexico in a northern Mexican city in August, the White House announced today. Larry Speakes, the deputy White House press secretary, said a site for the meeting had not been chosen. Mr. Reagan first met with Mr. de la Madrid Oct. 8 in San Diego.

headline: FAST FOOD AND FLAMBOYANCE, TO GO
abstract: LEAVING his hillside estate at six o'clock one morning last week, Harold G. Fulmer 3d drove his stately Stutz Blackhawk the three miles to a McDonald's restaurant. He ordered scrambled eggs, alerted the manager to a straw that littered the parking lot and sat down to eat and talk with the manager about fishing. Then he walked back to the Stutz, settled his 6-foot 4-inch, 250-pound frame in the seat and headed to a 7:30 charity meeting. By 9, he was in his office, signing paychecks.   Here in the Lehigh Valley, people see Mr. Fulmer as something of a folk hero, a hefty native son who went from a $1-an-hour job flipping burgers to an empire he values at more than $80 million. His holdings, besides 140 antique and classic cars, include a chain of printing and office supply stores, commercial and residential property in Allentown, a hotel, a small airport and a radio station.  But most of all, they include McDonald's restaurants, because he owns a lot of them - 14 to be exact.

headline: AFFILIATED'S EARNINGS UP
abstract: Earnings for Affiliated Publications Inc., parent company of The Boston Globe and operator of 10 radio stations, rose 19.2 percent, to $3.1 million, or 39 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1983, compared with $2.6 million.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Totes Inc., Cincinnati, has named Fahlgren & Ferriss to handle two new product assignments, one of which is a new dress/casual sock called ''soft sole.''

headline: TIME SAYS IT NEGOTIATED TO BUY DIARY
abstract: Time magazine said yesterday that it had negotiated to buy the rights to the purported diaries of Adolf Hitler from Stern, the West German news magazine. But the deal came apart, a spokesman said, when the two parties were unable to overcome several major stumbling blocks, including the price to be paid for the rights.   ''We never came close to an agreement on the price,'' said Brian Brown, publicity manager for Time. ''We were unable to resolve the differences between Time and Stern's closing deadlines, and because of our inability to do that we would have been unable to insure that some other publication did not steal the property. And there was insufficient time for us to conduct our own investigation into the legitimacy of the documents.''

headline: NORTHWEST UTILITIES IN WARNING
abstract: Four private utilities that have invested $700 million in a nuclear plant being built by the Washington Public Power Supply System told the system that they would take drastic steps - including legal action - to prevent the power system from halting construction on the plant.   Craftsmen were laid off at the site at Elma, Wash., designated as Unit 3, last week and the utilities' executives say that if new financing cannot be secured to resume construction, they will sue the supply system for violating an ownership agreement.   The executives met in closed session Monday to discuss ways of keeping construction going. Their views were disclosed in interviews after the meeting.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * American Home Products Corp. named Robert G. Blount senior vice president-finance.   * Banco di Roma, Rome, has appointed Nicola Stock executive vice president, area manager for North America and head of the New York branch.

headline: SHULTZ URGES THE MEXICANS TO PROMISE PEACE
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, seeking to ease tensions with Mexico over United States policy in Central America, urged the Mexican Government today to promote peace in the region but warned that Nicaraguan arms supplies to guerrilla forces were creating turmoil there.   Mr. Shultz, who led an unusually senior-level delegation here, made it clear in a series of meetings at the Foreign Ministry that despite broad differences between Mexico and the United States over such issues as Central America and Mexican immigration, the Reagan Administration attached considerable importance to strengthening ties with the Mexican Government.   ''Both of our societies are restless, not satisfied with the status quo, we are dynamic nations,'' Mr. Shultz said at the opening of the United States-Mexico Binational Commission, which was established two years ago to improve economic and political links between the two nations. He added: ''Friendship does not mean conformity. Our relationship does not demand that.''

headline: Sears Raising Stake In Simpsons-Sears
abstract: The Hudson's Bay Company said today that it had agreed to sell 17,595,925 class B voting shares, or 20.2 percent, of Simpsons-Sears Ltd. to Sears, Roebuck & Company at $12 a share for a total price of $211.2 million (Canadian).   The acquisition, scheduled for July 1, would increase Sears, Roebuck's holding in Simpsons-Sears to 60.5 percent.

headline: Dow Hits A Record 1,237.28
abstract: A late rally enabled the stock market to post its fifth consecutive advance yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average climbing to a record 1,237.28, up 10.02 points.   Sparking the late surge was a report from the International Business Machines Corporation that its revenues and profits so far this year ''were even stronger'' than in 1982. At 3 P.M., the Dow average, which is made up of 30 leading issues, was up less than a point.   I.B.M., an institutional favorite, was heavily traded, rising 2 7/8 points, to a new high of 120 7/8.  Analysts said stock prices had been helped by growing speculation that President Reagan would reappoint Paul A. Volcker as chairman of the Federal Reserve. Mr. Volcker, whose term expires in August, has considerable support in the financial community.

headline: Sanyo's German Project
abstract: The Sanyo Electric Company said today that it was negotiating with an unidentified West German steel company to buy an idle factory for the assembly of videotape recorders early next year.

headline: Quake in Soviet Asia
abstract: A moderate earthquake rocked an unpopulated area of the Tadzhikistan region of the Soviet Union near the Afghan border today, the Soviet news agency Tass said. There were no reports of casualties or damage.

headline: ** Company Reports ** WESTERN DIGITAL CORP (O)
abstract: Qtr to March 31 1983 1982 Sales 13,457,000 8,114,000 Net inc b945,000 c3,349,000 Share earns .06 9mo sales 32,202,000 24,400,000 Net inc b601,000 c3,148,000 Share earns .04  b-After losses from discontinuedoperations of $2,000 for the quarterand $194,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss.

headline: Chock Full o'Nuts Selects a President
abstract: The Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation, which has been seeking a president, announced yesterday that it had found one. He is Gordon M. Garrett, who has been serving as vice president for marketing at the Eckerd Drug Company, a national drugstore chain.   Chock Full's founder, William Black, died in March at the age of 80. Dr. Leon Pordy, 63, the company's president, became chairman and chief executive.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS; RATE RISE LAID TO INVESTOR PSYCHOLOGY
abstract: Interest rates rose last week, not because the Federal Reserve tightened credit availability but because market participants sold securities in the belief that such tightening had occurred, according to analysts. They reached this conclusion after reviewing Fed data released Friday.  The thing that led them to decide that negative investor psychology was what pushed rates up was the report that banks ended the week with free reserves of $403 million on June 8, more than necessary to satisfy their required reserve positions at the Fed. Therefore, the Federal funds rate should have been lower, analysts said.

headline: ** Company Reports ** HUBBELL, HARVEY, INC (A)
Train Fell on Volga Boat, Local Resident Says
abstract: A resident of the Volga River city of Ulyanovsk, at the scene of Sunday's boat disaster, said today that a freight train had toppled onto the boat after the vessel crashed into a railroad bridge.   ''There is great chaos in the city,'' the Ulyanovsk resident said in a telephone call to a relative in Moscow.

headline: Baldwin-United Misses $5 Million Debt Payment
abstract: The Baldwin-United Corporation failed yesterday to make a promised $5 million payment to one of its bank creditors, raising the possibility that it would not be able to work out an agreement to reschedule more than $700 million in short-term debt.   ''We got word around five o'clock that we would not receive payment today,'' a spokesman for the First Tennessee National Corporation said. ''And no indication was given as to when we might get paid. In view of those facts, our lawyers are investigating legal alternatives.''

headline: U.S.-MEXICAN DISCORD IS OLD
abstract: Disagreements between the United States and Mexico over how to deal with Nicaragua go back almost 60 years.  In 1927, Under Secretary of State Robert E. Olds described Mexico's approach to problems in Central America as ''a direct challenge to the United States.''

headline: Production Of Cars Dips
abstract: Domestic auto makers are curtailing car production slightly this week compared with last week, an industry trade journal reported today.   Ward's Automotive Reports said the auto makers would build 2.9 percent fewer cars in the United States this week than they did last week, or 132,369 compared with 136,287.

headline: A KEY ARAFAT AIDE WOUNDED IN SYRIA
abstract: A senior aide to Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chief, was shot and wounded today in Syria, and a Palestinian official in Damascus accused guerrilla mutineers in the attack.   The shooting came as rival factions of the Palestine Liberation Organization clashed in Lebanon for a second day.  A spokesman in Damascus, quoted by Arab radio reports, said that Col. Izziddin Sharif, known by the guerrilla code name Abu Ziad, was shot in both legs during a dawn ambush outside a guerrilla camp 15 miles south of Damascus. His teen-age son was also wounded in the attack, the spokesman said.

headline: Japan Lacks Evidence In Soviet Spy Case
abstract: Japan said today that an official inquiry failed to back charges that a Soviet K.G.B. agent had recruited Japanese politicians and reporters and planted a mole in the Foreign Ministry, giving Moscow regular access to highly sensitive information.   The National Police Agency said it would not press charges against 11 of the Japanese named by the K.G.B. defector, Maj. Stanislav A.  Levchenko, as his contacts when he served in Japan in the guise of a Soviet reporter.

headline: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
abstract: Tax-Exempt Bonds*8.86 An index of yields for long-term A-rated general obligation bonds compiled weekly by The Bond Buyer.  Aa Utility Bonds*11.25 Salomon Brothers' estimate for new long-term issues.

headline: Coral Petroleum's Chapter 11 Filing
abstract: Coral Petroleum Inc. filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

headline: Bausch & Lomb
abstract: Bausch & Lomb Inc. announced that it had begun marketing its first gas-permeable hard contact lens in Canada and would apply soon for permission to sell it in the United States.

headline: The Talk of Port-au-Prince
abstract: For the thousands of people accustomed to eating, sleeping and peddling their wares along this capital's alleys and roads, Boulevard Jean Jacques Dessalines was once a choice spot.   The boulevard, which is Port-au-Prince's main street, runs past the busiest stores and the central market buildings, so the peddler who had his own little patch on its cluttered sidewalks regarded himself as being in the hub of things.   But the street life of Port-au-Prince and its unspoken, intricate rules have been disrupted as a result of Pope John Paul II's brief visit here in March. Because the Pope's motorcade was to pass along the boulevard, municipal workers trucked some 5,000 vendors, beggars and other street people out of town in the days before he arrived.

headline: FOE RELIES ON FOE IN SOUTHERN AFRICA
abstract: In the view of Mozambique and other black-ruled African nations in this region, white-ruled South Africa is a focus of evil, a government that preys on its neighbors' frailties.   But the relationship seems to be ambivalent, for the demon is also a kind of provider. A history of colonial dependence has left Mozambique heavily reliant on a neighbor whose policies of racial separation it abhors but whose military and economic strength cannot be ignored.   The electricity here, for instance, comes from South Africa, so that, should Pretoria wish it, this city and its faltering industries could be brought to a halt. Figures are not published, but it is generally acknowledged that South Africa is Mozambique's biggest commercial partner.

headline: Pope Begins Visit to Milan
abstract: Amid driving rain and heavy security, Pope John Paul II today began the first papal visit to Milan since Pope Martin V came here in 1418.

headline: U.S. Tells Visitor From Soviet Not to Speak With Reporters
abstract: Georgi A. Arbatov, a visiting Soviet official, has been asked by the State Department not to speak with reporters because American officials do not have equivalent access to the Soviet press.   Mr. Arbatov, who heads the Institute on the United States and Canada in Moscow, is on a 20-day trip.

headline: SHAMROCK IS STILL GOING ITS OWN WAY
abstract: As a troubled chemicals producer a decade ago, the Diamond Shamrock Corporation rewrote its strategic plan. By selling its chemicals businesses and investing in a variety of energy operations, Diamond Shamrock set out to become an integrated energy company.   That strategy may have culminated this week when the Dallas company made a hostile tender offer for the Natomas Company, a diversified energy concern with oil and gas reserves in the Far East.   In the past, the timing of Diamond Shamrock's acquisitions have often been greeted by Wall Street analysts with a mixture of surprise and consternation. And the Natomas bid is proving to be no exception - not that Diamond Shamrock seems to care.

headline: Businesses Plan Less Spending
abstract: American businesses are planning to spend $305.5 billion on expansion and modernization projects this year, down 3.1 percent from last year's recession-depressed level after adjusting for inflation, the Government reported today.   The decline before adjustment would have been 3.4 percent, the Commerce Department said.  Jerry Jasinowski, chief economist for the National Association of Manufacturers, said in a statement that the projected decline in real business investment spending this year would mark ''the first time that has happened at the beginning of an economic recovery.''

headline: Chevron Bond Yields Raised
abstract: A two-part $57.8 million pollution control revenue bond financing on behalf of Chevron U.S.A. Inc. was tentatively priced with a yield of 7.25 percent on bonds with a final maturity in 2001.

headline: HOUSE GETS A PLAN ON COVERT ACTIONS
abstract: Democratic members of the House Foreign Affairs Committee are considering a proposal to create a commission that would set guidelines for, and approve or disapprove, all covert intelligence activities by the United States Government.   Under the proposal, commission members would be appointed by the President and the leaders of the House and Senate.

headline: VOLCKER'S CURRENCY AID VIEW
abstract: Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said last night that he favored limited intervention in the foreign exchange markets when ''exchange rates seem clearly wrong.''   Mr. Volcker, in a speech to the Forex Association of America in New York, said, ''My conclusion is that, if we are not too ambitious, we can constructively do something to help stabilize exchange rates within the general framework of the floating system.''   The chairman's comments reflect those he made recently in Rome to a meeting of the Trilateral Commission. They appear to go further than Administration policy, which is opposed to any intervention except to counter disorderly markets caused by some major, unexpected event, such as the intervention when President Reagan shot in March 30, 1981.

headline: Playboy Raises
abstract: A ''very disappointing'' year has led Playboy Enterprises Inc. to put a cap on raises for some of its 1,700 employees during the next fiscal year, officials told employees in a memorandum.

headline: German Stock Rally
abstract: The 100-share index of the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung rose to a new high today of 310.73, surpassing the previous record set last Friday by 2.98 points. The Commerzbank index of 60 shares rose 9.4 points, to 931.4, the highest since June 22, 1961.

headline: Carling Chairman Quits
abstract: Canada's former energy minister, Alastair Gillespie, resigned yesterday as chairman of Carling O'Keefe Ltd., one of Canada's largest brewers. In a statement, he cited the adverse publicity caused by his involvement in a coal liquefaction project in Nova Scotia.

headline: REAGAN PROPOSES CURBING IMPORTS FROM NATIONS DEFYING SANCTIONS
abstract: President Reagan today asked Congress for authorization to restrict imports from countries that sell to Communist bloc nations in violation of an American trade sanction.   The proposed legislation, in the form of amendments to the Export Administration Act, would be the first to empower a President to restrict imports during trade disputes.   In the past the United States has penalized foreign companies violating American sanctions by putting them on a so-called ''denial list,'' an action that prevented them from purchasing American goods and services or from importing technology from their parent company.

headline: G.E. Sale Accord
abstract: The General Electric Company has signed a definitive agreement to sell two mining concerns to the Broken Hill Proprietary Company of Melbourne, Australia, for about $2.4 billion, the two companies said. G.E. said in January that it intended to sell Utah International Inc. and the Utah-Marcona Corporation. Directors of both G.E. and Broken Hill have approved the sales, which are expected to become final this fall. Under sale terms, G.E. will retain the Ladd Petroleum Corporation, a unit of Utah, as well as Utah's interest in the Pathfinder uranium mines in Wyoming, the Trapper steam coal mine in Colorado and some land development properties in the United States.

headline: JACOBS MAKES BID FOR BEKINS
abstract: Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis millionaire who earlier had tried to take over the Pabst Brewing Company and is currently negotiating to buy the Kaiser Steel Company, yesterday offered to buy the Bekins company, one of the nation's leading household movers.   The latest bid, the third to emerge for Bekins, called for Bekins shareholders to get $23 a share, or a total of $89.1 million.  Bekins, meanwhile, said that a board meeting on Tuesday to approve a $21-a-share offer from the Far West Financial Corporation, controlled by the Belzberg brothers of Canada, had been recessed so that the Jacobs offer and another one could be discussed.

headline: Patents; A Nut That Locks Itself to a Bolt
abstract: A nut that locks itself to a bolt was patented this week by Richard L. Reynolds, an engineer in Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J. The inventor, who was granted patent 4,383,787, says the device, trademarked Pac-Nut, has undergone development in the automotive industry and is scheduled to be used on 1984 Ford front-wheel-drive cars. He predicts it will eliminate any adjustment of nut tension in the axles.  Pac-Nuts are manufactured by the Peterson American Corporation in Southfield, Mich., and are expected to have many automotive and aerospace applications.

headline: Market Place; Bank Profits: Confusion
abstract: BANK holding companies will soon begin reporting 1983 first-quarter profits, and the process, according to Wall Street professionals, promises to create confusion among bank stock investors. The issue centers on a new rule adopted in March by the Securities and Exchange Commission.   In recent years, banks reported two income figures. One line represented operating earnings, or income before securities transactions. Known in the trade as ''IBST,'' this has traditionally been the critical figure in determining a bank's profitability. The second figure was derived after allowing for gains or losses in the bank's investment portfolio, consisting mainly of Government and municipal bonds.

headline: A DEBATE OVER EXTENDING RENT CONTROLS TO SMALL APARTMENT UNITS
abstract: Of New York City's 1.9 million rental apartments, about 23 percent are in small buildings with fewer than six units, according to city housing officials. And state officials said that of New York's total of 3.2 million rental units, 66 percent are in buildings of fewer than six units.   Some apartments in the smaller multifamily dwellings - those whose current residents have lived in them since June 30, 1971 - are covered by rent controls. The large majority, however, have never been regulated. (The 900,000 apartments in the city that are covered by rent stabilization are mostly in buildings of more than six units.)

headline: The U.N. Today; June 1, 1983; SECURITY COUNCIL
abstract: Meets at 10:30 A.M. on question of Namibia. GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Working Group on the Rights of Mi- grant Workers and Their Families - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Disarmament Commission - 10:30 A.M. and 5 P.M.

headline: Takeover by GTE Clears a Hurdle
abstract: The Justice Department said it had agreed in principle to allow the GTE Corporation to buy the Southern Pacific Communications Company.

headline: Iran Rebuffs Iraq On Sparing Civilians
abstract: Iran responded negatively today to a proposal by Iraq that the two countries agree to stop shelling each other's towns and villages. It said the suggestion constituted a confession that Iraq had been bombarding civilians.

headline: Dollar Bond Yields Are Up
abstract: Yields on fixed-interest dollar bonds rose between 1/4-point and 3/8-point in very quiet trading here today, dealers said.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues   * Consumers Power Co. filed for an offering of $50 million of first mortgage bonds due in 2013, through Morgan Stanley & Co.   * Credit National, Paris, said it would issue three billion francs of fixed-rate domestic bonds next week. The bonds will have a 14.80 percent coupon, and be priced at 99.76 to yield 14.86 percent.

headline: BOND SCHEDULE FOR WEEK IS HEAVY
abstract: It is going to be a very busy week for underwriters of both corporate and municipal bond issues.  More than $1 billion of corporate bonds are coming to market - the largest single week of offerings since the first week in May, when more than $2 billion in new debt rushed to market. Since then, those bonds have traded at discounts, and, unless the overall tone of the credit market improves, the issues this week face a similar trading pattern.

headline: Hyatt Reaffirms Intent To Abandon Braniff Bid
abstract: The Hyatt Corporation today reaffirmed that it has abandoned its efforts to revive Braniff International, a move that appeared to set the stage for a court showdown between the failed airline's secured and unsecured creditors.   ''We made an offer; we withdrew the offer,'' said Karen Rugen, a representative at Hyatt's Chicago headquarters. ''This is not a ploy'' to induce Braniff to accept Hyatt's bid, she said. Miss Rugen said the company will not make another offer to Braniff and is not interested in talking further with the grounded airline.

headline: A French Nuclear Test Reported in Pacific
abstract: France set off a 70-kiloton nuclear test explosion, much larger than any previous known French test, at Mururoa Atoll in the South Pacific, Foreign Minister Bill Hayden announced in Parliament today.

headline: Nippon Electric's Billion-Bit Chip
abstract: The Nippon Electric Company said it had developed a new magnetic memory concept that will make it possible to store one billion bits of information on a single chip.   A spokesman said a memory using the new concept would require no mechanically driven memory mechanism. Company officials said commercial production will begin in three or four years.

headline: I.R.S. CRACKS DOWN ON DONATIONS OF ART
abstract: For years America's museum collections have grown at the taxpayer's expense. That much the Government intended. But the Internal Revenue Service says art donors have abused the tax system - to the tune of millions of dollars - by claiming greater write-offs than they are entitled to.   So the I.R.S. tried to crack down. While its officials concede that the problem still remains, the agency, as well as some members of the art community, say policing efforts are paying off.

headline: Chinet Dinnerware Spot Delayed by Keyes-Fibre
abstract: Keyes-Fibre of Stamford, Conn., was all set to start advertising its Chinet disposable dinnerware on television in May but its media buying service could not get a good enough schedule at an acceptable price so the company is going to hold off at least until Labor Day.   That means we will all have to wait to see the commercial from Cadwell, Davis Partners/Advertising that positions the formedwoodpulp product against regular china.   Chinet comes in dinner, dessert plates, bowls and, the most popular, lunch plates, which has a suggested retail price on its 40-pack of $2.39.

headline: DWG-Rexham
abstract: The DWG Corporation, which is headed by Victor Posner, the financier, reported to the Securities and Exchange Commision that it had acquired 230,650 shares, of the Rexham Corporation.

headline: ON ICAHN
abstract: To the Business Editor:    Mr. Icahn, who wants to stop the oppression of shareholders, made no distinction between shareholders and shareraiders.  In times past, shareholders were owners who cared about a company -and they held their shares for a long-term investment. Today, the stockmarket is infested with shareraiders who care nothing about a company -and they trade their shares as fast as an electron can travel.

headline: JEWS AND BUSINESS
abstract: To the Business Editor: I find the article on ''Jews in the Corporate Establishment'' most disturbing, in particular the tasteless anecdote related by Laurence Tisch equating Judaism with a hunchback's hump.   The article brought home to me the magnitude of the task facing those of us who are dedicated to correcting the distorted notion of Judaism epitomized a century ago by Heinrich Heine's epigram: ''Judaism is not a religion, it is a misfortune.''

headline: ** Company Reports ** BUCKBEE-MEARS CO (O)
** Company Reports ** SEI CORP (O)
abstract: Qtr to March 31 1983 1982 Revenue 14,999,000 9,619,000 Net inc 1,164,000 798,000 Share earns .20 .15 The results for the latest quarter include the operations of TMI SystemsCorp., Lexington Mass., acquired inDecember 1982.

headline: FURTHER RATE DROPS EXPECTED
abstract: The modest decline in interest rates last week in the face of this week's heavy schedule of new Treasury issues is being seen as a strong sign that rates will head still lower in the future.   Although firm investor commitments to buy the new issues have been modest, securities dealers are so confident that demand will materialize that they have been willing to push prices higher in the last few trading sessions. Prices of Treasury notes have increased enough to reduce the yield of the upcoming three-year notes to 9.48 percent from 9.68 percent late Wednesday after the Treasury announced its borrowing plans.   The drop in yields has been smaller for longer dated issues, however; 10-year notes, for example, fell to 10.21 from 10.3 percent and the 10 3/8 percent bonds fell to 10.37 from 10.42 percent.

headline: Swiss Prices Up in April
abstract: Wholesale prices in Switzerland in April rose five-tenths of 1 percent from March and were up two-tenths of 1 percent from a year earlier, the federal Office of Industry, Trade and Labor said today. The year-to-year increase was up slightly from one-tenth of 1 percent in March.

headline: NO LAYOFFS, BUT . . .
abstract: To The Business Editor: I am one of more than 100 employees who were not ''laid off'' from Materials Research Corporation, but who lost their job anyway (''Lifetime Employment, U.S. Style,'' April 17). During the period that the company's sales fell to $60.1 million from $71.6 million, the official word was that no one would be laid off.

headline: E.E.C. Jobless Rate Off
abstract: Unemployment in the European Economic Community slipped to 10.4 percent in May from 10.7 percent in April, largely because of seasonal factors, Eurostat, the community's statistics agency, said today.

headline: Chinese Steel Output
abstract: Chinese steel production in 1982 rose 4.4 percent, to 37.16 million metric tons, compared with 1981, the State Statistical Bureau said in its annual report. Last May, China said it planned a 4 percent cut in steel output, to 34 million tons, in 1982.

headline: New President At Uniworld
abstract: Douglass L. Alligood, one of the better-known black advertising executives, has left his position as director of corporate advertising for the RCA Corporation to become president and chief operating officer of the Uniworld Group, specialists in advertising to the black community.   His beginnings in the ad game were with a black specialty agency, as a staff artist and account executive with Seymour, Leatherwood & Cleveland in Detroit.

headline: Exxon Lifts Price
abstract: The Exxon Company U.S.A. announced that it had increased its wholesale prices by 2 percent in New York State, effective yesterday, and said the increase reflected the cost of New York's new 2 percent gross receipts tax, which is applicable to the state's 18 largest oil companies. Exxon, a subsidiary of the Exxon Corporation, said the price increase applies to all petroleum products with the exception of fuel oil exempted by a residential use certificate. The new tax was signed into law on March 28, retroactive to Jan. 1, 1983.

headline: FM RADIO SERVICE IS EXPANDED
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission today approved new rules allowing FM radio stations to use their facilities to transmit data such as electronic mail and offer nationwide paging services, competing directly with phone companies and other communications concerns.   The rules will allow both commercial and noncommercial stations to provide the services, using the idle subchannels of their main signals. Public stations, which had sought the new authority as a way to bring relief to their beleaguered finances, expressed delight with today's announcement.

headline: PATHMARK AND ITS SUPERSTORES
abstract: NEXT FALL the largest supermarket ever built in Manhattan will open on the edge of Chinatown.
