At 42,600 square feet, it will be four times the size of the average D'Agostino's, Gristede's, A.& P. and Sloan's grocery stores that now dot the borough.   But Pathmark hopes that the newest of its ''Super Centers'' will do more than just dwarf the competition. It's looking for profits. And it has found that, in the food business, the bigger the store the bigger the profits - even in high-rent Manhattan.   ''Manhattan is a highly stored borough,'' said Leonard Lieberman, president of the Supermarkets General Corporation, which owns the Pathmark chain. ''But for superstores like the one we plan near Chinatown, it's an untapped market'' - a market that Pathmark has parlayed in such places as Hackensack, N.J., and Staten Island into profit margins that are the envy of the industry.

headline: No Piecemeal Conrail Sale
abstract: The United States Railway Association made the official determination today that Conrail is profitable, clearing the way for a sale of the 15,000-mile Northeast-Middle Western railroad in one piece to private enterprise.

headline: U.S. Rejects Lumber Charge
abstract: The Government has rejected a charge by the United States lumber industry that Canada has given its companies unfair subsidies to sell in the American market, Commerce Department officials said today.   The ruling reaffirms a preliminary decision of two months ago concerning $1.7 billion a year of imported softwood, fencing and shingles. This country's lumber industry, represented by the United States Coalition for Fair Canadian Lumber Imports, had asked for penalty duties against the Canadian products.

headline: JUDGE ORDERS NEW GAF PROXY VOTE
abstract: A Federal judge yesterday ordered a new vote in the bitter GAF Corporation proxy contest, thus upsetting the victory claimed only a month ago by Samuel J. Heyman, a dissident GAF shareholder.   That unofficial outcome, which resulted in Mr. Heyman's slate of 10 directors unseating GAF's current management, was challenged by the company on the ground that Mr. Heyman withheld damaging information from his proxy material that might have cast doubt on his fitness to serve as a director.   Mr. Heyman said he was ''shocked and surprised'' by the decision and would appeal it. In beginning the proxy fight earlier this year, he had charged that Jesse Werner, GAF's 66-year-old chairman, had mismanaged the company, selling off assets to stay in business despite poor profitability. He had called for the sale of GAF's two remaining major divisions, its chemical and roofing businesses.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: CRIME IN SICILY: A NEW EFFORT TO FIGHT IT
abstract: Ten magistrates went to Sicily recently for a week of inquiries to help the judicial branch draft recommendations for a more efficient campaign against organized crime.   Other magistrates, all representing the Supreme Council that governs Italy's judges and prosecutors, visited the southern regions of the mainland that, like Sicily, are the bases of crime ''families.''   During the magistrates' visit, which began the week of April 10, these events occurred in Sicily: Between 8:30 P.M. on April 12 and 1 P.M. on April 13, there were 12 homicides and three attempted homicides in which the intended victims were wounded. All of the acts of violence were attributed to the Mafia, the Sicilian ''family,'' which is now deeply divided. The victims were described by the police and judicial officials as participants in the warfare between opposing clans of crime.

headline: SWEDEN WARNS MOSCOW OVER SUBS AND TEMPORARILY RECALLS ITS ENVOY
abstract: Sweden protested today against ''the gross violations of Swedish territorial integrity of which the Soviet Navy has been guilty'' and threatened to sink any submarine that enters its waters without permission.   In an unusually strong series of actions for a neutral nation, the Swedish Government sent a stiff diplomatic note to Moscow, temporarily recalled its Ambassador there, Carl de Geer, and indicated that official visits between the two countries would be cut back sharply. Prime Minister Olof Palme said Soviet military activity off Sweden's coast should ''be roundly condemned by all.''   ''We are determined to be very firm but not hysterical,'' the Prime Minister said.

headline: Rebels Raid Colombia Village
abstract: Leftist guerrillas of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia ransacked the village of Aguada some 130 miles northeast of here, killing a policeman and wounding two more, the police said. They said the rebels had destroyed the town hall, the police station and the post office in grenade attacks before looting stores and then rounded up villagers to give them a two-hour lecture on Communist doctrines.

headline: Afghan Rebels Claim Success in Recent Battle
abstract: Guerrilla sources said today that rebels aided in their planning by Afghan army renegades had killed 90 Government soldiers and captured a military base in a province bordering the Soviet Union.   The report, which was carried by the Pakistan-based Afghan Islamic Press, could not be independently confirmed.

headline: Interpublic Earnings Drop 46.2% in Quarter
abstract: The Interpublic Group of Companies, with three agency networks operating worldwide, released its first-quarter results yesterday.

headline: A STUDY QUESTIONS GAINS BY ISRAELIS
abstract: The International Institute for Strategic Studies has concluded that Israel's gains through the invasion of Lebanon may prove to be less than at first expected.   The institute, which is based in London and is maintained by endowments from American, European and Asian countries, said, ''The Palestine Liberation Organization's will to continue the fight, the sympathy it has attracted from many nations and the growth of anti-Israel opinion in countries that hitherto have supported her are all likely to prove durable, and may turn out eventually to outweigh the short-term gain.''   The institute, in its ''Strategic Survey 1982-1983,'' said Israel's invasion of Lebanon, which ''can legitimately be called the sixth Arab-Israeli war,'' was not intended to secure the northern border against hostile forces, as the Israeli Government said. It said the action ''was intended to humiliate the P.L.O., destroy it as a military force and compel it to recognize that the only way to peace was through political compromise.''

headline: France Limiting Sports With South Africans
abstract: The French Government today ordered sports organizations to end all contacts with South Africa because of its apartheid policy.   The ban ends all possibility of a scheduled tour of South Africa this summer by France's national rugby team.

headline: 3,000 Mourn Victims Of Embassy Bombing
abstract: More than 3,000 mourners filled the Washington Cathedral today in a tribute to 17 Americans killed in the bombing last week of the United States Embassy in Beirut, Lebanon.

headline: THE NEW ACTIVISTS: BIG INVESTORS
abstract: FOR Citibank, it was an awkward situation. The bank's $20 billion t rust department, which held one million shares of Superior Oil for i ts clients, wanted to vote them against Superior's management in a p roxy battle. The hitch was that the oil company was also a customer o f the bank, so a vote against management in effect would be a vote a gainst one of the bank's own customers.   But Citibank decided to vote against management anyway, helping to circumvent antitakeover measures that Superior had adopted earlier in the year. Citibank officers felt that the measures were bad for its trust clients and ''undemocratic,'' said the bank's senior vice president and chief investment officer, Peter Vermilye.   The incident is one that is happening, with variations, more and more frequently on and off Wall Street. Institutional investors - which include trust departments, mutual funds, pension funds and independent investment management firms - increasingly are flexing muscles previously unused. They are voting against management and in some cases demanding a greater role in running companies. As one Wall Street investor put it: ''The power is there and power doesn't like a vacuum.''

headline: Reynolds to Raise Cigarette Prices
abstract: The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company said it would raise the price of its cigarettes $1.50 per 1,000 for all domestic brands, except the new Century brand.  Reynolds's announcement was closely followed by one by American Brands, which said it would match Reynolds's increase.

headline: Mankiewicz At Gray & Co.
abstract: Frank Mankiewicz, who resigned May 10 as the president of National Public Radio, has been named executive vice president of Gray & Company, a public relations company.   Mr. Mankiewicz, 59 years old, who had been president of Public Radio since 1977, will work with the government relations and public relations teams at Gray & Company, according to the company's chairman, Robert K. Gray.   Previously, Mr. Mankiewicz had worked for Senator George McGovern and the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy and was a newspaper columnist.

headline: PARLIAMENT IN ISRAEL DEFEATS PLAN TO PULL BACK IN LEBANON
abstract: The Israeli Parliament today rejected a Labor Party proposal for an early withdrawal of forces from Lebanon.   The vote against the proposal was 55 to 47.

headline: 6 Nuclear Plant Contractors Indicted
abstract: Six major electrical contractors were indicted today by a grand jury on Federal charges of conspiring to rig bids on four nuclear power plants being built by the Washington Public Power Supply System and one in Indiana.   A lawyer for the Washington system, which has halted construction on four of its five plants because of a lack of financing, said the case was being reviewed as a possible source of funds.   The contracts for the Washington plants were valued at more than $250 million. The Indiana contract, for a plant in Marble Hill being built by the Public Service Company, was valued at $160 million.

headline: NEC Marketing A Supercomputer
abstract: The NEC Corporation's managing director, Akira Koike, said the company had developed and begun marketing the world's fastest computer system, the supercomputer SX-2, capable of carrying out 1.3 billion calculations a second.   Mr. Koike told a news conference the system is suitable for scientific calculation and analysis of data in the aerospace, nuclear and meteorological technology fields. He said NEC, formerly the Nippon Electric Company, expects to sell about 30 units in the next four years. Mr. Koike added that world demand for such systems is likely to reach between 500 and 600 units in the next five years.

headline: 10 Killed in Java Accident
abstract: Ten people were killed and 43 others were severely injured today in a traffic accident in Java involving a military truck, two buses and a motorbike. A police spokesman said the driver of a truck with 38 soldiers aboard lost control while driving on a narrow road near Semarang, 225 miles east of Jakarta. The truck hit two buses and a motorbike before overturning.

headline: Markets Closed Monday
abstract: All American stock and commodity markets will be closed Monday in observance of Memorial Day. Banks and government offices will also be closed. The weekly Treasury bill auction is scheduled for Tuesday.

headline: U.S. PLANS TO SHIFT ARMS BID TO SOVIET IN GENEVA PARLEY
abstract: Bolstered by the political solidarity of the Williamsburg meeting, the Reagan Administration signaled its intention today to revise its proposal to the Soviet Union for cuts in strategic nuclear arms.   Officials said there was disagreement between the State Department and the Defense Department over the revisions in the United States position at the talks in Geneva on reducing strategic, or long-range, weapons.   President Reagan has scheduled a National Security Council meeting for Tuesday to resolve the issue.  Mr. Reagan met today for 40 minutes with Edward L. Rowny, the strategic arms negotiator, who later told reporters that the President had wanted ''to get my views on what changes he should make to my instructions.'' Desire for Accord Affirmed   Mr. Rowny, affirming Mr. Reagan's desire for an agreement, said ''the President instructed me to examine all Soviet proposals seriously and to be flexible in our responses wherever this would be consistent with our overall objectives.''

headline: DOW TOPS 1,200, ENDS DOWN 3.20
abstract: Stock prices fell yesterday after late selling by nervous investors.  The Dow Jones industrial average, which is made up of 30 prominent companies, closed down 3.20 points, to 1,188.27, after briefly setting a new high of 1,202.11 early in the day. Broader market averages also slipped.   At the close of trading, 851 stocks had declined and 833 advanced.  Volume on the New York Stock Exchange slipped to 106.2 million shares from 110.2 million on Wednesday, when the Dow soared 16.93 points, to a closing record of 1,191.47.

headline: CSX DOWN 26.1% IN QUARTER
abstract: The CSX Corporation, which owns one of the nation's largest railroads, yesterday reported first-quarter net income of $35.6 million, or 84 cents a share, down 26.1 percent from earnings of $48.2 million, or $1.16 a share, in the first quarter of last year.   Revenues declined by 12.4 percent, to $1.13 billion, from $1.29 billion in the 1982 quarter.  CSX officials said that the decline resulted mainly from a 20 percent decline in coal traffic in the quarter, compared with the first quarter last year. The fall in coal more than offset improved traffic in some of the general commodity groups.

headline: AMEX SETS MARK
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest fell 3.3 percent, or 5.1 million shares, in the month ended June 15, to 148.6 million shares. The high of 153.7 million shares was set last month. The short interest for the period a year earlier totaled 98.9 million shares.   In the latest period, the short interest on the American Stock Exchange rose to a record 18.3 million shares, up 3.5 million from a revised previous high of 14.8 million shares.   A short position can result from the sale of borrowed stock in the hope of buying the same issue at a later date and at a lower price to cover the sale.

headline: BOND AND NOTE PRICES GAIN
abstract: The Treasury announced yesterday that it will sell $15 billion of notes and bonds next week, divided into notes due in three and ten years, and 10 3/8 percent bonds due in 2012.   Although the size of the financing package was larger than anticipated, it did not destroy the optimism of many investors, economists and dealers who expect interest rates to decline later this year. Prices of Treasury notes and bonds fell slightly after the financing announcement, but still ended the day with gains ranging from an eighth of a point for notes due in three years to more than a quarter of a point for long-term bonds. 'Rates Are Headed Lower'   ''We still feel that rates are headed lower, if for no other reason than the economic recovery is not strong and inflation is not rising,'' said George Collins at T. Rowe Price Asociates.

headline: PATENTS; Implantable Heart Uses Two Hydraulic Pumps
abstract: The third in a series of patents on a totally implantable artificial heart, with a pair of hydraulically actuated blood pumps, was received this week by Foxcroft Associates of San Antonio, Tex., sponsors of the project.

headline: ** Company Reports ** FIRST ARKANSAS BANKSTOCK CORP (O)
abstract: Qtr to March 31 1983 1982 Op earn 1,248,850 1,103,761 Per share .63 .57 Net inc 1,259,276 b1,569,511 Per share .64 .81 b-Includes a securities loss of$31,451 and an extraordinary gainfrom early retirement of capital notesof $497,201.

headline: The U.N. Today; May 27, 1983
abstract: SECURITY COUNCIL   Meets on Namibia at 10:30 A.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL   Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Adams-Russell Co. said that it had sold its television station WYTV in Youngstown, Ohio, to the Youngstown Broadcasting Co. for $8.8 million.   * GAF Corp. said its GAF Broadcasting Co. unit had agreed to lease one of WNCN radio station's subcarriers to Market Information Inc. of Omaha, which will use the classical music's subcarrier to provide information on commodities throughout the New York metropolitan area.

headline: A Fluor Division Is Put Up for Sale
abstract: The Fluor Corporation said it had put its money-losing Distribution Services division up for sale. The division accounted for about 8 percent of Fluor's $7.33 billion in revenues during its latest fiscal year.

headline: AMENDED WITHHOLDING REPEAL GAINS
abstract: The Senate Finance Committee agreed today to repeal tax withholding on interest and dividends, but voted to attach to the repeal bill a package of unrelated measures, including President Reagan's Caribbean Basin Initiative and a trade reciprocity bill.   Senator Russell B. Long of Louisiana, the ranking Democrat on the committee, charged that today's action would so clutter the repeal bill passed by the House earlier this month that the Democrat-controlled House would not accept it, even if the Republican-dominated Senate passed the measure with all the elements proposed today.   Senator Long said that the committee's action would in effect derail the effort to repeal withholding.  He added, however, that he would work instead to have the Senate endorse the repeal bill passed earlier this month by the House, without amendments. That bill would repeal the existing law that requires financial institutions to withhold 10 percent of their customers' interest and dividend payments, starting July 1.

headline: ECONOMIC THEORIES FACE TEST
abstract: Scholars from 15 countries, contending that today's economic practices are not functioning for either capitalist or Communist countries, are preparing a sweeping and intensive inquiry into the theories undergirding those practices.    The review is to be undertaken by the International Federation of Institutes for Advanced Study, which was set up 11 years ago by the Nobel Foundation in Sweden and by the Rockefeller Foundation in this country. The broad outlines of the project were drawn up by the scholars at a five-day meeting, that ended today, at the Rockefeller estate, a wooded retreat of rolling hills and gardens.   The federation's study is to take three years, to cost $1 million in its initial stages, and to engage scholars in questioning policies regarding trade, technology, energy management, food production and distribution, national security issues and other elements bearing on the global economy.

headline: Antitrust Suit Against Bell
abstract: A Massachusetts telephone company filed a Federal antitrust lawsuit today charging the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and two of its affiliates with illegally dominating the market for phone equipment.   The plaintiff, the DASA Corporation of Andover, is seeking more than $150 million in damages from A.T.& T., the Western Electric Company and Bell Telephone Labs Inc.

headline: Key Solidarity Figure Arrested in Wroclaw
abstract: One of the top five fugitive leaders of the Solidarity union has been captured by the police, the official Polish press agency said today.   It said Jozef Pinior, a member of the movement's provisional coordinating commission, was arrested in the southwestern industrial city of Wroclaw.

headline: Brown-Forman Is Sued by Lenox
abstract: Lenox Inc. said is had filed a countersuit in Federal court in Newark against the Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation, charging a violation of Federal securities laws.   Lenox, a maker of china, seeks to prohibit Brown-Forman from proceeding with its $413 million tender offer for Lenox on the ground that the Kentucky distiller has made misleading statements.

headline: Addendum
abstract: * Cahners Publishing Company, Boston, the major United States publishing arm of Reed International, London, has acquired the assets of Fischer Medical Publications.

headline: Ford Unit to Offer $300 Million Notes
abstract: The Ford Motor Credit Company has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $300 million of floating rate notes. Interest on the notes will fluctuate according to changes in the London interbank offering rate for six-month deposits.

headline: Strike Halts Burials in Paris
abstract: Burials in the main cemeteries of Paris were suspended today as gravediggers and pallbearers staged a one-day strike over working conditions, city officials said. The officials said 110 of the 140 gravediggers employed by the city and 46 of the 96 pallbearers stopped work.

headline: Additional Shares Sought by A.M.C.
abstract: The American Motors Corporation said it will ask its shareholders this month to authorize the issuance of 40 million additional shares of common stock.

headline: TAKEOVER CONNOISSEURS BIDDING FOR SOTHEBY'S
abstract: Stephen Claar Swid is from the Bronx, and Marshall Stuart Cogan is from Brighton, Mass. They met on Wall Street and teamed up to become successful at turning companies around.   They have done well with General Felt, which makes carpet backing, and Knoll International, a manufacturer of contemporary furniture.  Now they want to add Sotheby Parke Bernet, the venerable British auction house.

headline: REBELS DEMAND P.L.O. END COMPROMISE AND CORRUPTION
abstract: Col. Saed Musa, the leader of the rebellion against Yasir Arafat, said today that his men would not give up their revolt until Mr. Arafat agreed to root out corruption in the Palestine Liberation Organization, reject all compromise peace plans and consent to share power with the dissident officers.   Colonel Musa, a 56-year-old onetime Jordanian Army officer who before his revolt was deputy chief of the P.L.O. Military Operations Room, met with a few reporters in a two-story house in Hammara, a village in the center of his tiny rebel domain along the Syrian border in the Bekaa, Lebanon's eastern valley.   The dissident Palestinian officer, who goes by the code name Abu Musa, made his points in Arabic articulately and with the confidence of a man who appeared comfortable in his role as a rebel leader. It was clear as Colonel Musa and the officers around him discussed the reasons for their insurrection that they had in effect mounted a ''coup d'etat'' against Mr. Arafat except that there was no state apparatus for them to seize. Instead, they have taken over a cluster of villages and P.L.O. positions in the last area in the Middle East where the Palestinian guerrillas can operate with a small measure of autonomy.

headline: REPORTS OF ANTI-SANDINIST AID WORRY SENATORS
abstract: Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., the majority leader, said today that many of his Senate colleagues were deeply worried about reports the Reagan Administration was actively supporting a guerrilla movement against the Government of Nicaragua.   Mr. Baker said he planned to discuss the reports with the bipartisan leadership of the intelligence committee in order ''to hear from them on a confidential basis about what's going on.'' The committee has scheduled a closed session on Nicaragua next Tuesday.

headline: 2 Soviet Fishermen Die
abstract: The police began an investigation today into the deaths from methyl alcohol poisoning of two Soviet fishermen aboard a Soviet trawler south of Singapore, officials said. Five other fishermen aboard the vessel were also taken ill. Two were treated and released, and the other three remained hospitalized in critical condition, the police said.

headline: Trafalgar Bid For P & O
abstract: Trafalgar House P.L.C. is prepared to spend up to $45 million to raise its stake in the Peninsular & Oriental Steam Navigation Company to 15 percent, Trafalgar's chairman, Nigel Broackes, said today.   Trafalgar, a real estate and construction company, earlier said it had bought 500,000 more deferred shares of the shipping concern yesterday, taking its holding to 5.25 percent in its bid for control.    The terms of the Trafalgar bid, described as derisory by the P & O board, consist of five Trafalgar ordinary shares for four P & O deferred shares - stock on which dividends are not payable until a certain date or until certain conditions have been met.

headline: Content Bill On Autos Advances
abstract: One of last year's most contentious pieces of legislation, an unsuccessful bill aimed at requiring both foreign and domestic auto makers to use a large percentage of American parts and labor in cars they sell in the United States, made its first advance today toward passage by the new Congress.   By a voice vote, a House subcommittee approved without dissent a domestic content bill virtually identical to the 1982 measure and sent it to the Energy and Commerce Committee.   The lack of debate, however, did not mean that opposition to the protectionist measure had diminished. Neither does support seem to have waned significantly because of the improved fortunes of the American auto industry. Republicans, while not voting against the measure today, warned that they would fight hard against it when the full committee takes it up, probably within the next few weeks.

headline: Salvador Rebels Report Big Battle With Army
abstract: The Salvadoran Army rushed reinforcements today to a northern province where guerrillas said they had killed 84 soldiers in a major battle that would lead to the military's ''total collapse.''   The battle took place Wednesday in Morazan Province, where rebels have held about a dozen villages since last fall.

headline: Market Place; How to Read Stock Ratings
abstract: LAST November, shortly after Greg A. Smith joined Prudential-Bache Securities as research director, the firm adopted a new rating system for stocks. ''Prior to that time,'' he recalled recently, ''the ratings simply consisted of Buy, Sell or Hold.''   Today, like some of its competitors, Prudential-Bache offers a far more elaborate set of opinions that, as one brokerage executive said, ''gives both the customer and the salesman something to hang on to.''    Research departments employ various grading systems for stocks.  Moreover, they often observe different periods of time in their recommendations. The result is a kind of Wall Street shorthand that summarizes the advice on a company.

headline: Marketer Will Lead Wharton Econometric
abstract: Bruce R. Lippke has been named president of Wharton Econometric Forecasting Associates, which started out as a nonprofit corporation owned by the University of Pennsylvania and is now owned by Compagnie Internationale de Services Informatique, a Paris computer company.   Mr. Lippke, 49, was hired by the new owners, who just bought the company from the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company. Ziff-Davis in turn had purchased Wharton from the University of Pennsylvania in 1980.

headline: Assailants in Istanbul Kill 2 And Wound 27 Near Bazaar
abstract: Terrorists detonated five bombs in front of the ancient Grand Bazaar today and fired into a crowd, killing at least two pedestrians and wounding 27 people, the police reported. One of the attackers was killed.

headline: BEIRUT EMBASSY BLAST PROMPTS U.N. SECURITY REVIEW
abstract: Jack W. Santarelli, the chief of the United Nations' security force, guards what may be the world's most vulnerable diplomatic complex.   ''It's wide open,'' he said in an interview. ''It wasn't built to meet the security threat we know today. It's a very attractive target for a terrorist or troublemakers.''

headline: South Africa Questions Wife of a U.S. Reporter
abstract: The wife of the South African correspondent of The Washington Post was taken to police station in Johannesburg for fingerprinting and interrogation. Sue Sparks, wife of the correspondent, Allister Sparks, appeared in Magistrate's Court in connection with a charge of trying to defeat the ends of justice.

headline: NATO AFFIRMS '83 MISSILE DEPLOYMENT
abstract: Defense ministers of Atlantic alliance countries today affirmed a pledge to begin deploying American medium-range missiles in Europe next December if an American-Soviet agreement on limiting such arms is not reached by then.   But the unity sought by the United States was marred when Greece refused to sign the pledge and Denmark added a reservation.  Denmark's Defense Minister, Hans Engell, said his Conservative-led Government supported deployment. But he noted that the Danish Parliament had adopted a resolution compelling the Government to press for postponement of deployment in the absence of progress at the American-Soviet talks in Geneva. The resolution was proposed by the opposition Social Democratic Party.

headline: ** Company Reports ** STRYKER CORP (O)
abstract: Qtr to March 31 1983 1982 Sales 17,743,000 14,321,000 Net inc 1,610,000 1,330,000 Share earns .33 .28 Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2stock split effective October 1982.

headline: Profits Scoreboard
abstract: Net Income   Percent

headline: ARGENTINES PRESS FALKLAND CLAIM
abstract: President Reynaldo Bignone said today that Argentina was continuing to fight for its claims to the Falkland Islands despite its defeat by Britain a year ago.   In a statement issued through his official spokesman, President Bignone also called on Britain to resume negotiations over sovereignty as suggested by a United Nations resolution.

headline: Advertising; Timex To Change TV Tactics
abstract: TO heighten the impact of its new television campaign at a time of intense competition, the Timex Corporation, a maker of moderately priced watches, will try a different media tactic. Its startling new 30-second network television commercials, in prime time, each made up of three vignettes, will be followed in the next station break in the top 50 spot TV markets by 10-second spots consisting of one of the single vignettes.   ''It's a way of increasing frequency,'' said Edward H. Meyer, president of Grey Advertising, the Timex agency.  What makes the commercials startling is the way the new line of Timex watches is used in them. ''They are treated as architecture, sculpture or landscape,'' said John Morrissey, vice president and creative group head.

headline: Norstar Bancorp
abstract: The Norstar Bancorp, a Rochester-based bank holding company, announced that it had increased its offer for all of the shares of the Security New York State Corporation that it does not already own.

headline: Advertising; Ally Wins Big Again In Awards
abstract: ALLY & Gargano once again scored the best at The One Show, the season's first important presentation of advertising awards, although it didn't quite overwhelm the event as it did last year.   The agency won five of the 30 gold awards that were handed out in all media categories as well as for collatoral material such as point-of-sale and brochures. The awards were presented Friday at the Pierre Hotel.   Four of the five of the Ally shop's awards (there were also three silvers) were in the television category, which is considered by the professionals as the really big time. Backer & Spielvogel, with three gold and two silver, was all TV with Miller Beer and Sony Betamax, but Doyle Dane Bernbach, with four and three, was all in print.  Ammirati & Puris won three of each with a real media mix - television, point of purchase, newspaper, outdoor, and trade magazines.

headline: GULF CLASHES IMPERIL OIL SPILL CLEANUP
abstract: Renewed fighting between Iraq and Iran presented new obstacles today to efforts by Persian Gulf countries to obtain a cease-fire so that an Iranian oil spill threatening their coastlines can be capped.   The Teheran radio announced that it had opened a new offensive in a southern area of the battle zone along an 18-mile front between the villages of Ayinieh and Zobaidat, about 50 miles west of the city of Dizful. The Iranians described the attack as major and said they had killed or wounded 3,000 Iraqi soldiers.   An Iraqi announcement disputed this claim, saying the Iranian offensive had been repulsed. Both sides reported that fighting continued in an area between Iraq's Misan Province and the Iranian provinces of Ilam and Khuzistan.

headline: Long-Term Interest Rates Up; 30-Year Bond Brings 10.29%
abstract: Long-term interest rates, which had declined steadily during the past week, rose slightly yesterday as investors and securities dealers faced nearly $1.5 billion of new corporate issues, as well as a $3.75 billion auction of new Treasury bonds.   The flood of new corporate issues caught many market participants by surprise, and was tied to the turnabout in the Treasury market.  The Treasury's outstanding 10 3/8 percent bonds, for example, rose about 3/8 point in the morning, and were traded at 101 3/8 before declining to 100 18/32, down 3/8 on the day, to yield about 10.31 percent.   ''The new corporate offerings meant that sales efforts were fragmented; I've never seen anything like it on the day of a Treasury bond auction,'' commented James M. Davin, a managing director at the First Boston Corporation.

headline: U.N. Official Confers On Afghan Fighting
abstract: The United Nations efforts to find a solution to the Afghan conflict were resumed here today when Under Secretary General Diego Cordovez met separately with the Foreign Ministers of Pakistan and Afghanistan.   The aim of the talks is to find a way to permit the withdrawal of the more than 100,000 Soviet troops in Afghanistan and the safe return home of the 3 million Afghan refugees in Pakistan and Iran.

headline: I.M.F. Appointment
abstract: The International Monetary Fund announced today that its managing director, Jacques de Larosiere, has been appointed to serve another five-year term.

headline: A Rate Ceiling To End Today
abstract: The process of bank deregulation will move forward one additional step today with the removal of ceilings on the amount of interest that banks and savings institutions may pay on 2 1/2-year certificates of deposit.   Based on interviews, however, it appeared yesterday that most banks were not excited about the latest move toward deregulation.

headline: Lightning Kills 8 in Austria
abstract: Lightning struck a group of hikers today, killing eight people and injuring nine, a police spokesman reported. The hikers were resting under two trees.

headline: ** Company Reports ** WHITAKER CABLE CORP (A)
SENATE SET TO RESUME TAX FIGHT
abstract: The Senate is expected later this week to tackle again the delicate issue of withholding on interest and dividends. But even if the Senate votes to repeal the tax measure - as is widely expected - Congressional leaders are predicting that victory may still be elusive, and that the question may not be resolved for several more months.   Senator Robert W. Kasten Jr., the Wisconsin Republican who is leading the battle for repeal in the Senate, plans to attach his repeal amendment to a trade reciprocity bill this week. His previous amendment for repeal held up the $4.6 billion jobs bill for several days last month. The trade bill itself is expected to win Senate approval. But there is no assurance that it will be acted upon by the House of Representatives.

headline: B.A.T. Profits Advance
abstract: B.A.T. Industries P.L.C. said today that it had 1982 pretax profits of 856 million, up from 684 million a year earlier, on turnover of 11.51 billion, up from 9.27 billion.  The pound is worth $1.51 in United States currency. B.A.T. said retailing turnover and trading profits in 1982 were helped by the acquisition of Marshall Field in the United States.

headline: BOND AND BILL FUTURES DECLINE ON RATE FEARS
abstract: Prices of Treasury bond and bill futures fell sharply yesterday as a report last Friday of another unexpected surge in the basic money supply renewed fears of a rebound in interest rates.   At the close of the Chicago futures markets, the spot June Treasury bond futures were down 1 7/32ds, at 77 17/ 32ds, while the September contract lost 1 5/32ds, at 77. The spot JuneTreasury bill futures fell 19 basis points, to 91.83, and the September contract plunged 25 basis points, to 91.62.

headline: AIDES URGE SHULTZ TO VISIT MOSCOW TO TEST ITS MOOD
abstract: Some State Department officials have been urging Secretary of State George P. Shultz to consider undertaking a diplomatic mission to Moscow this summer, according to high-ranking Administration officials.   The purpose of the trip, the officials said, would be to explore possibilities for easing negotiating deadlocks and to determine what lies behind Moscow's recently expressed interest in more normal relations,   But the prevalent thinking within the Administration regarding such a mission, several officials said, is considerably more cautious.  They said the notion of a Shultz mission to Moscow had not been broached to the Soviet Government because of disagreement within the Administration over the wisdom of such a mission. Mr. Shultz himself said Friday that so far there had not been enough progress on a wide range of Soviet-American issues to warrant any high-level meeting before the fall, when he is scheduled to talk with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko.   Specifically, some State Department officials are said to have proposed that Mr. Shultz seek discussions with Mr. Gromyko this summer to deal with arms issues and regional disputes and to explore whether Moscow will move toward agreements on such issues as cultural exchanges and opening of consulates in Kiev and New York.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Borden Inc. has elected R.J. Ventres an executive vice president and also president of its chemical division.   * Capital Air, Smyrna, Tenn., has elected George M. Kamats chairman, chief executive officer and chief operating officer.

headline: Wall St. Journal Editor
abstract: Dow Jones & Company said yesterday that Norman Pearlstine will become managing editor of The Wall Street Journal on Sept. 1. Mr.  Pearlstine, 40 years old, will succeed Laurence G. O'Donnell, 47, who will become an associate editor of The Journal and other Dow Jones publications, the company said. Mr. Pearlstine will be in charge of all day-to-day news gathering and reporting operations.  Currently editor and publisher of The Wall Street Journal/Europe, which began publication in January, he had previously been the national news editor for The Journal's United States edition. Before joining The Journal he was an executive editor at Forbes magazine.

headline: PORTABLE COMPUTER'S PROMISE
abstract: Manny A. Fernandez beamed with delight at the crowds gathered in his company's booth at the National Computer Conference here. For an unknown company that was not even listed in the exhibit guide, the Gavilan Computer Corporation was drawing crowds that would have done I.B.M. proud.   ''The world wants one,'' said Mr. Fernandez, president and chief executive of Gavilan, based in Campbell, Calif. He referred to the object of all the attention - a computer with a disk drive, printer, internal memory, a display screen and software just like most other computers have. Only this computer was small enough to be powered by batteries and to fit in a briefcase.

headline: REAGAN RIGHTS POLICY CALLED WEAK IN 4 LATIN NATIONS
abstract: Contacts have declined between United States embassies and opposition leaders in the military-run countries in the southern part of South America since President Reagan took office, according to American diplomats and opposition leaders in those countries.   In interviews over the last three months, the opposition political, church and human rights leaders in the four countries, Chile, Paraguay, Uruguay and Argentina, were virtually unanimous in saying they saw the decline in meetings, social invitations and sharing of information as a sign of a shift away from the human rights policies of the Carter Administration.   Adding to that impression was the lifting, soon after the Reagan Administration took office, of a number of trade and lending sanctions that had been imposed by President Jimmy Carter on the four countries because of political and human rights abuses. Shift to 'Silent Diplomacy'   United States embassy officials in each of the four countries countered that the United States remained committed to human rights in the region. The only change, the diplomats said, has been in a shift of tactics - from the Carter Administration's activism to the Reagan Administration's ''silent diplomacy.''

headline: World Bank Appeal
abstract: A.W. Clausen, president of the World Bank, appealed on Thursday for greater support for the International Development Association, a World Bank subsidiary that makes concessionary loans to the poorest nations. ''The recession has resulted in the most serious breakdown in the development of the third world in a generation,'' said Mr. Clausen, who has been holding talks here with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and other officials.

headline: London Stock Index Up
abstract: The Financial Times 30-share index ended 13.7 points higher today at a record 727.8, dealers said. The close of the index of 30 London Stock Exchange issues topped the previous high of 726.4 on June 14. Dealers said that electrical stocks showed particular strength.

headline: Mattel Direct Marketing Chooses N.W. Ayer
abstract: Last December, Mattel Inc. created Mattel Direct Marketing, and last week, the subsidiary chose N.W. Ayer and its subsidiary, Ayer Direct, as its agency.   The other agencies in the competetition, according to David Savage, the president of Mattel Direct, were Benton & Bowles Direct, Ogilvy & Mather Direct, Barry Blau & Partners and Krup-Taylor of Los Angeles.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Federal Reserve Wednesday, June 1, 1983 All data in millions of dollars

headline: SALVADOR PARTY CALLS CHARTER THREAT TO NEW LAND EFFORTS
abstract: El Salvador's Christian Democrats said today that two articles in a draft constitution would ''close the door'' on future land redistribution efforts and vowed to seek a revision.   ''These articles are extremely negative and signify a type of anxiousness to close the door to future reforms in the text of the new constitution, especially agrarian reforms,'' Dr. Jose Antonio Ehrlich, the assistant secretary general of the Christian Democrats, said at a news conference today.   The country's progress in its land redistribution program has been one of the main measures in the United States Congress of whether to approve new aid for El Salvador. Depending on how they are interpreted, Articles 104 and 105 of the new constitution could severely restrict the land redistribution program if the draft is approved in its present form by the Constituent Assembly.

headline: ON PATROL DOWN AMAZON: CHALLENGES FOR THE BOLD
abstract: The blast of the horn and the roiling water to stern meant that the naval river patrol ship Raposo Tavares, its 67 crew members and a pet monkey were off on another Amazon mission.   For those on board, the departure from Manaus and the breeze it lifted were welcome, because the deck had become so heated by the midday sun that it burned through shoe leather.   As the craft pulled out into the midstream currents of the muddy river, officers and seamen dropped below to change from their shore duty slacks and starched chemises to shorts, T-shirts and sandals, regulation tropical wear in the Brazilian Navy.   The cannon on the bow, the mortar emplacements at the base of the stack and the six machine guns ringing the ship were sheathed in gray canvas hoods. This was to be a peaceful operation, charting the constantly shifting river bed of the world's mightiest waterway and bringing medical assistance to some of the isolated communities along the route.

headline: Pan Am Fares
abstract: Pan American World Airways said it reduced air fares between the Caribbean and 10 cities in the United States by as much as 54 percent.

headline: U.N. Council Puts Off Session on Nicaragua
abstract: The Security Council put off its session on Nicaragua today until foreign ministers from four Latin American nations, trying to act as mediators, hold talks in Panama on Wednesday.   The four foreign ministers are Rodrigo Lloreda Caicedo of Colombia, Jose Alberto Zambrano Velasco of Venezuela, Bernardo Sepulveda of Mexico and Juan Jose Amado of Panama, The four, who are due to meet in Panama City, are trying to reconcile Nicaragua's insistence on direct but separate talks with the United States and Honduras and the view shared by Honduras and the United States that negotiations should include all five Central American nations - Costa Rica, El Salvador and Guatemala as well as Nicaragua and Honduras.

headline: Trade Publication Sold
abstract: The SFN Companies, Glenview, Ill., which is largely in textbook publishing, will acquire Broadcast Advertisers Reports on July 1 for $24 million, SFN announced yesterday. BAR, which is 29 years old, is well-known in the advertising business as the source of estimates of advertiser spending on the television networks and stations.

headline: TUESDAY, MAY 3, 1983; Companies
abstract: The American Motors Corporation and China are close to signing an agreement to jointly produce Jeeps in Peking. The accord, which would be the first joint venture by an American auto maker in China, calls for the production of 40,000 vehicles a year for sale throughout the Far East. (Page A1.)   A $2.05 million libel judgment against The Washington Post was thrown out by a Federal judge. U.S. District Court Judge Oliver Gasch, overturning a jury verdict returned last summer, ruled that the newspaper had not acted with malice in reporting that the president of Mobil Oil, William P. Tavoulareas, had used his influence and Mobil's money to ''set up his son'' in the shipping business. (A1.)

headline: Rolls Cuts Thousands From Car Prices
abstract: Citing increasing pressure against the weakened British pound, Rolls-Royce Motors Ltd. yesterday announced what may be the biggest price cut on any consumer product in history, slicing $18,000 from its least expensive model and making similar cuts on its full line of cars sold in the United States.   ''We decided to do this two weeks ago,'' said George Lewis, president of the publicly held company's North American subsidiary.  ''What had happened was that we had been driven out of our normal pricing position. Some people would joke about our normal position, but the exchange rate had broken our usual relationship with other high-line cars.''

headline: Goodyear Closing
abstract: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said it would close its Jackson tire plant by the end of this year, cutting 600 jobs. Goodyear said the plant, which produces biasply tires for the North American market, was being closed because of excessive production costs.

headline: Stokely-Van Camp
abstract: Esmark Inc. said that it would not participate as an investor in the acquisition of Stokely-Van Camp Inc. by the SVC Acquiring Corporation. SVC is a group led by William Stokely, Stokely-Van Camp's chairman, that is trying to take to company private. Stokely said, however, that Esmark does not plan on disposing of its stock position and intends to vote in favor of the proposed transaction.

headline: Train Crash in Egypt Kills 22
abstract: A speeding train slammed into the rear of a stationary train 30 miles south of here today, killing 22 people and injuring 46, the police said. It was the second Egyptian railway disaster in less than two weeks. On May 30, 12 people were killed and 40 were injured when a train heading for Cairo derailed and was struck by another train.

headline: LABORITE STRESSING ISSUES, NOT IMAGE
abstract: The television interviewer had reminded Michael Foot an hour before that this part of England, East Anglia, is covered with military installations, but the 69-year-old Labor Party leader was in no mood to tone down his message to suit the area.   ''I listen to the superpowers and they both speak the same language,'' he shouted. ''The Russians and the Americans, they both tell us they can make the world safer by piling their nuclear arms just a bit higher. Well, we don't believe they can.

headline: Bonn Says Citizen Who Died In East Germany Was Beaten
abstract: The Government said today that a West German who died during questioning at a border crossing point inside East Germany last Sunday had suffered several blows to the head.   A Government statement said a post-mortem showed the man died of a heart attack but ''several wounds to the head were still unexplained.''

headline: TOKYO STOCK INDEX AT RECORD HIGH
abstract: With foreign investors buying aggressively, prices on the Tokyo stock market today jumped to a record high of 8,798.62 points on the Dow Nikkei Index, up 86.89 for the day.   The previous high of 8,719.88 on the index of 225 stocks was set last May 9.  One reason for the surge, analysts said, was American economic statistics indicating that a stronger-than-expected recovery may be under way in the United States, which would stimulate growth worldwide.

headline: South African Is Said to Seek Asylum From Mozambicans
abstract: An officer of the South African military has asked for political asylum in Mozambique, the official Mozambique press agency reported today.   Quoting an official source, the agency said the man had surrendered to Mozambican border guards Saturday.  The report did not name the man and said no further details were immediately available.

headline: French Production Up
abstract: French industrial production in April rose a seasonally adjusted eight-tenths of 1 percent from March, the Government said Friday. In March, production had fallen at the same rate.

headline: FINANCE NEW ISSUES;
abstract: Salomon Brothers Inc. won the bidding to underwrite a $115 million issue of prior-lien revenue bonds for the City of Houston water system.   The issue includes $40 million in serial bonds with coupons of 10.50 percent and due in 1984.

headline: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 1, 1983; The Economy
abstract: The leading economic indicators rose 1.1 percent in April, their 10th consecutive monthly increase, the Commerce Department reported.  The gain was seen as further evidence that recovery continues to gain momentum. Indeed, private and Government experts now believe the recovery will be stronger than the Administration had forecast. (Page D1.)

headline: News Analysis
abstract: Two years into Socialism, the French have begun to discuss the idea that their economic difficulties are whittling away at the country's place in world affairs.   Heavy foreign borrowing, the fall of the franc, unrelentingly poor economic statistics, skirmishing in the streets and attacks from the left and right on the policies of President Francois Mitterrand - all create a picture of a France in trouble, of a country increasingly limited in its possibilities to influence global policy.    Two articles in French newspapers made the point this week while Mr. Mitterrand was stressing the role of the United States' budget deficit as a cause of the world recession. One, in Le Canard Enchaine, the unusually well-informed satirical weekly, told of the Finance Minister, Jacques Delors, reporting sadly to the Cabinet that many third world countries no longer supported French positions at an International Monetary Fund meeting. Another, a commentary in Le Monde, asked whether France's friends ''would be so cruel to remind it that to talk high and loud at the international table you've to put your own house in order.''

headline: Grandma Lee's
abstract: Grandma Lee's Inc., a Toronto-based restaurant and bakery chain, said it was negotiating with Farmer Brown's Restaurants Inc. of Columbus, Ohio, about the latter's possible cooperation with Grandma Lee's of America.

headline: VIETNAM RAID: NUMBERS IN DOUBT
abstract: The number of Cambodian civilians killed early last month when Vietnamese troops shelled their camp, reportedly herded some of them into bunkers and then threw grenades at them has been placed by Cambodian refugees at between 20 and 40.   On April 8, five days after more than 1,000 Vietnamese troops launched an attack against the camp at O Smach, Son Sann, the former Cambodian Prime Minister, charged that Vietnamese troops had killed at least 200 civilians by herding them into trenches, throwing hand grenades at them and later finishing them off with bayonets.   Statements by refugees who fled into Thailand early last month made it clear that the attacks on civilians had occurred, but the figures differed.

headline: DISTILLERS CO. TO GET NEW CHAIRMAN IN FALL
abstract: John M. Connell has been named chairman of the world's largest producer of Scotch whisky, the Distillers Company. He will take on the new job in September.   Few people expect any radical change in policy when Mr. Connell, who has been with the company since 1946, takes over from the retiring chairman, John R. Cater. But many believe he will try to increase the company's share of the Scotch market in Britain, where it has fallen to less than 25 percent from more than 60 percent 15 years ago.

headline: Relief Arrives in Tahiti After Hurricane Strikes
abstract: Food, batteries and chemicals for purifying water arrived over the weekend to help Tahitians cope with the devastation caused by Hurricane Veena, which killed one person, injured 26 and left 25,000 homeless.

headline: ** Company Reports ** PETROLEUM & RESOURCES CORP (N)
abstract: As of March 31 1983 1982 Assets 231,005,814 185,393,791 Per share 26.64 25.75 The latest per share figure is after acapital gain distribution of $1.87 paidin February and with 30 million statedvalue $1.575 convertible preferredstock outstanding.

headline: VATICAN ASSAILS ARGENTINA JUNTA OVER ITS REPORT ON WAR ON LEFTISTS
abstract: The Vatican, with unusual force, today criticized the Argentine military Government's statement last week that the thousands of people still missing after its campaign in the 1970's against leftist terrorists must now be considered dead.   At the same time, President Sandro Pertini of Italy resumed his attacks on the Argentine leadership.  The Vatican made its view public in a prominently displayed, unsigned statement on the front page of today's issue of the Vatican daily L'Osservatore Romano. The publication of what amounts to a formal protest underlines the gravity of the view Pope John Paul II takes of the Argentine Government's efforts to put behind it the most serious human rights violations committed on its behalf.

headline: Stocks Down for a Fourth Day
abstract: Stock prices dropped yesterday for the fourth consecutive session as investors' apprehension over the outlook for interest rates and corporate earnings again weakened the list.   The Dow Jones industrial average ended the session down 6.67 points, to 1,113.49, after being off 13.54 points at 1 P.M. Analysts said bargain hunting accounted for the late rally. In the last four sessions the Dow average tumbled almost 30 points.   The market's selloff was broadly based with declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbering stocks that advanced by almost a 2-to-1 ratio. Turnover on the Big Board amounted to 77.1 million shares, compared with 76.8 million shares the day before.

headline: India's Army Ordered To End Assam Outbreak
abstract: Indian Army troops were called out today to put down new outbreaks of violence in the northeastern state of Assam that left at least nine people dead and 5,000 homeless, officials said.   A bomb blast tore through a home in Assam's northeastern Lakhimpur district, killing a man and his wife and seriously wounding their child, officials said.

headline: INDUSTRIAL NATIONS SHOW LOW INFLATION
abstract: The rate of inflation in the non-Communist industrial world has fallen to its lowest level in 10 years, pushed down by a global recession that has left more than 30 million people unemployed, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development reported today.   Consumer prices in the 24 industrial member countries climbed by only two-tenths of 1 percent, on average, during February following a rise of five-tenths of 1 percent in January, the organization said in its latest monthly inflation survey.   As a result, the average inflation rate over the 12 months through February dropped to 5.7 percent, compared with 5.9 percent in the 12 months ended last January. These are the first inflation figures at an annual rate below 6 percent since February 1973, the organization said.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM GROMYKO SPEECH REVIEWING SOVIET UNION'S FOREIGN POLICY
abstract: Following are excerpts from a speech by Foreign Minister Andrei A.  Gromyko before the Supreme Soviet yesterday, as distributed in translation by Tass, the Soviet press agency.   The special importance of the Soviet-American accords in the field of strategic arms that were reached before the coming to power of the present Administration in the United States, should be stressed.  Operating to this day is the treaty on the limitation of antiballistic missile systems and the treaty on the limitation of strategic arms (SALT I). As to the SALT II treaty, which today is being heaped with abuse in Washington by its opponents, it also could have become a serious accomplishment both for the Soviet Union and for the United States, and for the whole world.   As before, the Soviet Union comes out for normalizing relations with the People's Republic of China on the basis of reciprocity, searching for possibilities of a gradual expansion of bilateral ties and contacts. We stand for continuing the Soviet-Chinese political consultations that have begun and would like them to lead to positive results. We are convinced that normalization and improvement of relations between them accords with the cardinal interests of the peoples of both countries.

headline: POLAND ASSERTS WALESA IS NO LONGER FIT FOR ANY ROLE IN PUBLIC LIFE
abstract: The Polish authorities today published their most vitriolic attack against Lech Walesa, saying he was no longer fit to play any role in public life.   The attack appeared in a front-page article in this morning's issue of the Government newspaper Rzeczpospolita. The article was distributed by the official press agency, P.A.P., and appeared in most other newspapers today.

headline: BRANIFF FILES PLAN WITH COURT
abstract: Braniff International left the door open yesterday for further negotiations to revive part of the airline while meeting a court deadline to submit a plan of reorganization.   The plan, which was filed in a bankruptcy court in Fort Worth, calls for liquidation of most of Braniff's assets, leaving only a small company that would provide ground services employing about 200 people and with sales of about $12 million a year.   However, the plan also states that the board of directors will continue until May 16 ''to develop and propose a flying operation'' using up to 31 of its Boeing 727-200 aircraft to be leased at market prices. Braniff can amend its reorganization plan as long as the changes are made within 60 days, and still allow time for the 50,000 Braniff creditors to vote on it.

headline: CUBA IS OPEN TO TALKS ON TIES WITH U.S.
abstract: Cuba is willing to open ''serious negotiations'' on re-establishing normal relations with the United States, but the Reagan Administration will have to take the first step, a Cuban Vice President, Dr. Carlos Rafael Rodriguez, says.   In an interview, Mr. Rodriguez said Cuba was willing to discuss such issues as Cuban emigration, radio jamming and diplomatic relations with the United States. At the same time, he said Cuba was increasing its military preparedness.

headline: MARCH TOOL ORDERS UP IN MONTH, BUT OFF FROM '82
abstract: New orders for machine tools -often taken as a barometer of the economy's health - fell sharply last month and for the first quarter of 1983, when compared with 1982 levels. But the March total was sharply improved from the month before and was the highest monthly total since June 1982.   ''Things cannot get much worse for our industry,'' said James A.  Gray, president of the National Machine Tool Builders' Association.  ''Orders, shipments and backlogs are all at distressingly low levels. In constant dollars, industry activity is at its lowest level in 50 years. The one ray of hope is that the decline seems to be leveling off.''

headline: Becker Creates 3-Member Office
abstract: A.G. Becker Paribas Inc., the New York securities firm, announced yesterday that it had created a three-member executive office headed by Herve M. Pinet, chairman and chief executive.   Mr. Pinet, 57 years old, arrived in mid-April from Compagnie Financiere de Paribas, the big nationalized French bank that owns slightly more than half of the New York firm. Employees hold the rest.

headline: MAJOR NATIONS BACK U.S. ON JOINT EFFORT TO FIGHT TRADE BARS
abstract: Major industrialized allies have accepted a United States initiative for a new approach to world trade protectionism, European monetary officials said today.   The plan would create a broad forum in which these countries could coordinate their trade and economic policies. The aim would be to insure that restrictive trade policies did not spark a third world debt crisis that could destroy hopes of a global economic recovery.   What is contemplated, these officials said, is expanding future meetings of an existing international body, the Group of 10. This group brings together the finance ministers of 10 big industrialized countries. Under the new plan, trade ministers would join future meetings.

headline: JAPAN'S RULING PARTY WINS BUT WITHOUT LANDSLIDE
abstract: Although Japan's long-governing conservatives strengthened their parliamentary majority in Sunday's upper-house election, final totals tonight showed them falling short of the landslide victory that many had forecast.   But officials of the winning Liberal Democratic Party said they were more than satisfied with the results and indicated that no major shifts in domestic or foreign policy were contemplated.   Under Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, Japan has been more conspicuous in supporting closer ties to the West and increasing military spending.   However, this has also brought criticism of Mr. Nakasone, and he has lately toned down his forcefully pro-military statements. This afternoon he suggested caution would continue to be the rule. ''We have to be careful to know the demand of the people,'' he said.

headline: I.M.F. Consumer Prices
abstract: The International Monetary Fund said today that consumer prices in the industrialized countries rose 5.5 percent in the first quarter, down from 6.3 percent in the previous quarter and 8.5 percent in the first quarter of 1982.

headline: FRIDAY, APRIL 8, 1983
abstract: International   World bank lending rules would be tightened in return for bigger U.S. contributions to the I.M.F. under a plan bank regulators will submit to Congress today. Among other things, officials said, banks would be barred from enhancing their current income through fees they get for rescheduling loans to developing countries. (Page D1.)   Trade and finance ministers of six other leading industrial nations were invited by Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan to talks in Paris. The purpose of the May meetings, he said, is to help prevent clashes between trade and monetary policies. (D14.)

headline: TWO AMERICAN JOURNALISTS KILLED AT BORDER, HONDURAN ARMY SAYS
abstract: Two American journalists were killed today in Honduras near the Nicaraguan border when their car was hit by a rocket-propelled grenade, according to the Honduran Army.   The two journalists were identified as Dial Torgerson of The Los Angeles Times and Richard Cross, a freelance photographer on assignment for U.S. News & World Report.   A third person in the car, Jose Herrero, their Honduran driver, was reported to have survived the attack. Within 30 Yards of Border   Honduran military officials said the car in which the journalists were driving was hit between 4 and 6 P.M. just outside the town of Cifuentes.  The officials said the attack took place at the edge of a hilly area where the road comes within 30 yards of the Nicaraguan border and is clearly visible from Nicaraguan territory.

headline: Technology; A Pay Phone Of Your Own
abstract: WITH all the deregulation in the telephone business, the pay telephone has remained one of the last monopolies of the local telephone company. Now, however, time is running out on that monopoly, too.   The Federal Communications Commission and several state regulatory agencies, prodded by small companies that want to sell coin telephones, are considering whether competition should be introduced into the sector.   Competition would allow restaurants, groceries and other businesses - and even consumers - to own pay phones and to keep the revenue, rather than giving most of it to the phone company. If that happens, there could eventually be a variety of pay phones of different shapes and sizes. Two pay phones on the same street might charge different rates for local calls.

headline: ** Company Reports ** WALBRO CORP (O)
abstract: Qtr to March 31 1983 1982 Sales 12,841,612 10,469,403 Net inc 422,669 b228,717 Share earns .54  b-Net loss.

headline: Travel Agents Going From In-House to Ogilvy
abstract: The American Society of Travel Agents, whose membership will be facing competitive pressures from outside their fold for the first time, has selected Ogilvy & Mather, New York, to do a $5 million image campaign.

headline: G.M. Denies Plan To End Chevette
abstract: The General Motors Corporation plans to start phasing out its Chevrolet Chevette in 1985 and has been studying what to do with its two Chevette plants in Georgia and Delaware, United Automobile Workers officials say. But Roger B.  Smith, G.M. chairman, repeatedly has denied any such plans and a G.M. spokesman, John Mueller, said he knew nothing about such a phase-out.

headline: Long Financial Times Strike
abstract: Tens of thousands of British business executives are wishing there was a bit more color in their lives these days - pink, to be exact. A three-week strike that shows no sign of ending has taken the strikingly colored Financial Times out of their lives.   ''Virtually every single person here in broking, banking and investment is used to getting their information from the F.T.,'' said Roger Nightingale, an equity markets specialist and economic forecaster for Hoare Govett Ltd. ''It's disrupting to have to look other places to find it.''

headline: Benihana at Romann
abstract: Benihana of Tokyo, the restaurant chain where the chefs are the show, will be getting into the frozen food business in October, when it introduces into the New York market Benihana Restaurant Classics, with a $1 million ad budget. It has just named Romann & Tannenholz Advertising for that assignment. Hume Smith Mickelberry Advertising is the agency for the restaurant chain.

headline: ** Company Reports ** INDUSTRIAL VALLEY BANK &TRUST CO (PHILADELPHIA, PA)
abstract: Qtr to March 31 1983 1982 Op earn 2,548,000 2,661,000 Per share .70 .73 Net inc b3,056,000 b2,874,000 Per share .88 .81 b-After extraordinary credits of$508,000 for the latest quarter and$213,000 for the year-earlier period.

headline: Market Place; When the Dow Faces a Test
abstract: AT 1 P.M. Friday some money managers skipped lunch to stare at their stock quotation machines with worried frowns. The Dow Jones industrial average had slipped to 1,114.07, and the word on Wall Street was that, if this indicator closed below 1,110, stock prices would tumble. No crash, certainly, but a pretty bad crack, maybe.   What's so magical about 1,110 on the Dow? Technical analysts point out that this figure marked ''the last reaction low'' after the average finished at a record high of 1,145.90 on March 24.

headline: North Sea Oilfield
abstract: Norsk Hydro has determined that the Oseberg oil and gas field in the North Sea is commercial and that production could begin in 1990, Torvild Aakvaag, the company's managing director, said today.

headline: Ford Shelves Plans For Portugal Plant
abstract: The Ford Motor Company said today that it had shelved plans for a $1 billion assembly plant in Portugal because of slow growth in car sales in Europe.   In a statement, the chairman for Europe of the company, E.J.  Blanche, said that because of the delay in economic recovery and subsequent slower growth rate in car sales it was not an appropriate time to build a car plant in Europe.

headline: BOOKS BARRED BY PRAGUE FIND NEW LIFE IN TORONTO
abstract: A noted Czech emigre novelist and his wife, also a writer, have set out to sustain Czech literature and redeem it from the political arbiters of culture in Prague, who have banned more than 200 writers.   The novelist, Josef Skvorecky, whose own books have been outlawed, and his wife, Zdena Salivarova, have gone into competition with Czechoslovakia's official publishing establishment by issuing 139 Czech books.   Some are by authors who fled or were banished after the Soviet military intervention in 1968 ended a brief period of liberalization; others are the works of writers still living in Czechoslovakia whose manuscripts have made their way here.

headline: NORTHWEST, SEDCO SEEK 51% OF POGO
abstract: Northwest Industries and Sedco Inc.  said today that they planned to make a tender offer at $25 a share for about 26 percent, or 6.25 million common shares, of the Pogo Producing Company.   Sedco now owns about 1.27 million Pogo shares and Northwest Industries has about 4.8 million Pogo shares, or a total of 25 percent of the company's outstanding stock.

headline: CHRYSLER TO REPAY LOAN EARLY
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation will repay $400 million of its $1.2 billion in Government-guaranteed loans by the end of next month, Lee A. Iacocca, Chrysler's chairman, said today.   Mr. Iacocca said the decision to repay the guaranteed loans, which saved the company from bankruptcy in 1980 and 1981, was both an effort to reduce the company's interest costs for the loans and a gesture to underscore its return to financial health.   Chrysler executives said the company would use cash on hand and marketable securities to make about half the $400 million repayment, and expected to sell medium-term bonds within the next two months to finance the remaining $200 million. They said Chrysler hoped to pay off all its Government-guaranteed debt by the end of 1985.

headline: ** Company Reports ** RAI RESEARCH (A)
abstract: Qtr to Feb 28 1983 1982 Sales 1,287,216 1,407,634 Net inc 110,033 175,338 Share earns .06 .09 9mo sales 4,346,862 4,195,331 Net inc 721,774 666,955 Share earns .37 .34 Share earnings reflect a 5 percentstock dividend paid Jan. 10, 1983.

headline: U.S. WORRIED OVER IRAN'S BAHAIS
abstract: Reports reaching the State Department and members of the Bahai faith in the United States reveal new persecution in Iran against the Bahais, including executions and the barring of tens of thousands of Bahai children from attending school.    ''It is serious, very serious because, bit by bit, the Bahai community is being destroyed,'' said Firuz Kazemzadeh, a Bahai of Iranian descent who is chairman of the Committee on Middle Eastern Studies at Yale. ''Thousands of Bahais will not be massacred tomorrow, but given time the community will be destroyed in small steps.''

headline: ** Company Reports ** GUARDIAN INDUSTRIES CORP (N)
New British Securities Rules
abstract: Stricter Government controls over licensed securities dealers will go into effect on June 1, the Trade Department said today.   Under new rules laid before Parliament today, the department said, a licensed dealer will be required to keep client money and investments separate from its own. A dealer will also have to tell clients of the insurance or other arrangements set up to protect them if the dealer fails, and disclose any material interest it may have in a transaction.

headline: Uniworld Group Gets A Burger King Account
abstract: Waiting but a day after the announcement of its new president, Douglass L. Alligood, the Uniworld Group, specialists in advertising to the black consumer market, now announces a new client - Burger King.   Up to now the Pillsbury subsidiary has not had any specific ethnic market advertising, unlike McDonald's, which uses Burrell Advertising in Chicago and Kentucky Fried Chicken, which has Mingo-Jones Advertising in New York. Burger King's regular agency continues to be J. Walter Thompson.

headline: Swedish Stock Delay
abstract: Sweden's stock exchange will suspend trading for six days from this Friday because of technical problems at the computerized Securities Registration Center, according to exchange officials.

headline: Daughter of Founder Is Suing Superior Oil
abstract: The feud between Williametta Keck Day and her brother, Howard B.  Keck, over the welfare of Superior Oil Company, the company their father founded in 1921, has reached Federal court.   Mrs. Day, who opposes the company's antitakeover posture and changes in the bylaws to allow her brother to continue on the board of directors, sued Superior Oil this week to postpone the annual meeting.   ''I have always felt a responsibility to all other owners of Superior stock who have placed their faith in my father's company,'' she said in a letter mailed to shareholders April 15. ''Those of you who know me also know that if I believe something is wrong, I won't keep quiet about it.''

headline: NEW CHOICE IN SALVADOR: A NEGOTIATOR
abstract: Gen. Carlos Eugenio Vides Casanova, the man likely to be El Salvador's next Minister of Defense, is known in Government circles as an excellent administrator who enjoys the role of mediator.   He was called on to replace Gen. Jose Guillermo Garcia, a military source said, because he is the one ranking member of the military who has the respect of the departmental commanders and is considered able to keep the military out of politics.   Since October 1979 General Vides Casanova has been head of the national guard, which had the reputation of being the worst of the three security forces for human rights abuses. ''He was called on to clean up the guard,'' said a political source, who added that although the force's reputation has not improved greatly it is no longer considered the worst.

headline: Bonds Oversubscribed For San Diego Utility
abstract: A $100 million offering of industrial revenue bonds, issued by the City of San Diego on behalf of the San Diego Gas and Electric Company, was oversubscribed by late yesterday.   The single maturity of June 1, 2018, was given a 10 1/8 percent coupon and tentatively priced at 99.25 by the Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group to yield 10.203 percent. Because of the heavy demand, however, the underwriters said they would probably lower the yield.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN FOOD REGULATION; HITTING A SNAG IN THE SALT WARS
abstract: When Arthur Hayes became commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration in April 1981, he jettisoned nearly all of the Carter Administration's ambitious mandatory labeling plans for a variety of food ingredients and began a vigorous public relations drive against one - sodium.  Now he says that an increasing number of manufacturers are going along with his voluntary program, which involves labeling all products with the amount of sodium they contain.  ''At last count, about 20 percent'' of processed food products carry sodium labeling, ''and we are confident that this figure will have increased to one-third by mid-1983,'' he said in mid-February.At the outset of the voluntary program in 1981, sodium labeling was at 13 percent, he said.

headline: French Aide to Visit Arabs
abstract: Defense Minister Charles Hernu of France is scheduled to arrive here Monday for two days of talks expected to focus on French arms sales to the United Arab Emirates.  Official sources said the two sides would discuss the possible sale of French Mirage 2000 jet fighters. The United Arab Emirates said last week that it was planning to expand its navy.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues   * Alaska Housing Finance Corp. will offer $75 million of stateassisted mortgage bonds series K due in 1993 through Salomon Brothers Inc.   * Consumers Power Co.'s $80 million issue of 12 1/2 percent firstmortgage bonds due in 2013 was priced at par through Morgan Stanley & Co.; the bonds are rated Baa-3 by Moody's Investors Service and BB+ by Standard & Poor's Corp.   * Manufacturers Hanover Overseas Capital Corp.'s $50 million issue of Eurodollar notes due in 1988 was priced at par, bearing 10.25 percent; a $100 million issue of notes due in 1990 was also priced at par, bearing 10.25 percent; both issues are unconditionally guaranteed by Manufacturers Hanover Corp.   * Ontario Hydro's $200 million issue of Euronotes due in 1990 was priced at par, bearing 10.25 percent, through Deutsche Bank.

headline: Your Money; Health Plans: A Rule Change
abstract: ONE of the lesser-known provisions of the 1982 tax law dramatically changes the way that medical insurance will be offered to workers between the ages of 65 and 70.   The change, which took effect at the beginning of this year, makes benefits from an employer's health insurance plan primary to Medicare, the Federal Government's insurance program for people over 65 years old. Previously, the benefits payable under an employer group health plan was secondary to Medicare benefits.   ''The employee may now end up with more coverage,'' said Janet E.  Shepherd, a partner of Hewitt Associates, a consulting and actuarial firm based in Lincolnshire, Ill., who has studied the new arrangement. ''In the past, you would have to wait to see what Medicare paid first.''

headline: NEW BOND RULE LIGHTENS SCHEDULE
abstract: Friday will see the virtual end of bearer bonds in the municipal market. Instead, state and local governments must offer all new issues in registered form, signaling what some say is the beginning of a computerized bond record-keeping system.   The new law means that no bond issues over one year in maturity can be issued in bearer form, an anonymous form of trading where the ''bearer'' is presumed to be the owner. This change was designed to help the Federal government keep better track of interest payments made to individuals. Few municipals carry less than one-year maturity.

headline: SUMMIT TEXT ON ARMS POLICY
abstract: Following is the text of a statement read by Secretary of State George P. Shultz today on behalf of the seven industrial nations meeting here:   As leaders of our seven countries, it is our first duty to defend the freedom and justice on which our democracies are based. To this end, we shall maintain sufficient military strength to deter any attack, to counter any threat and to insure the peace. Our arms will never be used except in response to aggression.

headline: CBS-CHINA TV PACT ANNOUNCED
abstract: CBS Inc. will provide 64 hours of programming and advertising to Chinese television annually, the company announced yesterday. The arrangement represents the first regular scheduling in China of commercial American network television shows, according to John Eger, general manager of CBS Broadcast International.   Starting in October, CBS programs will be shown in China at 8 P.M.  Friday, immediately after the evening news, and on alternate Sundays, after the English-language lesson. The Chinese are expected to buy travel and cultural programs, some basketball shows and documentaries.

headline: Advertising; Wendy's Plans New Campaigns
