abstract: YESTERDAY in Columbus, Ohio, Wendy's International began serving and advertising a breakfast menu. Its first.  Wendy's, based next door to Columbus in Dublin, hopes to help the gross sales of its individual units catch up a wee bit with those of McDonald's.   Since the size of both the national and local advertising budgets is based on a percentage of gross sales, the more you sell, the more you can advertise and sell more, if the product is any good.

headline: THE SEARCH FOR HERPES DRUGS
abstract: The United States pharmaceutical industry has mounted a huge effort to find treatments and possibly a cure for genital herpes, a venereal disease afflicting millions of Americans and spreading rapidly.   For pharmaceutical companies, the herpes epidemic presents the potential of a big new market. Analysts say that virtually every major drug manufacturer is focusing part of its research on vaccines, medications or diagnostic procedures to combat the disease.   While herpes is rarely life threatening to otherwise healthy adults, the problem is vast because of the number infected - as many as 20 million, or nearly one out of ten Americans, may have the disease - the psychological trauma the disease often creates, and the far more serious danger it poses when transmitted to newborn children or victims of cancer, heart disease or other ailments. Those who contract herpes can now expect to carry the virus for life, although not all carriers suffer recurrences.

headline: Spanish Bankruptcy
abstract: The Banco de los Pirineos, in temporary receivership since 1981, filed for bankruptcy before a Barcelona court, legal sources said today.

headline: INTEREST RATES SLIGHTLY LOWER
abstract: Interest rates fell slightly yesterday in quiet trading as dealers in Treasury securities waited for today's announcement of a large financing expected next week while dealers in tax-exempt securities digested a large supply of new issues.   Prices of Treasury issues declined slightly at the opening but recovered in the afternoon to close with modest gains of a quarter of a point or less. Dealers said that activity was confined to traders and other speculators.   The late-afternoon rise in prices of Treasury issues was based on relatively few trades and was linked to rumors that the Treasury borrowing in early May could be less than the $14.5 billion that is widely anticipated. Even if the early May financing is less than $14.5 billion, analysts said it would be of limited help in reducing interest rates because future Treasury borrowing needs will remain huge unless budget deficits are reduced.

headline: Addenda
abstract: * Jean Anderson & Associates, a newly formed research firm at 875 North Michigan Avenue in Chicago.   * Signature magazine increasing its circulation rate base 8.7 percent, to 750,000, from 690,000, and its advertising rates 16 percent, effective with the September issue.   * Golf Digest magazine increasing its advertising rates and circulation rate base 12.1 percent, to 1.15 million, from 1.02 million, effective with the September issue.

headline: TURKS ASK FOR HELP IN FIGHTING ARMENIAN ATTACKS
abstract: Turkey has called on Western governments for help in preventing attacks on Turkish diplomats by radical Armenian groups.   It said such attacks might increase as the anniversary of mass arrests and deportations of Armenians from Istanbul on April 24, 1915, approaches. Under the Ottomans, most Armenians were deported to Syrian desert areas and hundreds of thousands perished.   On Thursday the Armenian Patriarch of Istanbul appealed to Armenians around the world to fight against ''those Armenians who have made a black stain on the race.'' Patriarch Shnork Kaloustian and other Armenian religious and lay leaders took part in a march to the central Taksim Square, where they observed a minute's silence in memory of the 26 Turkish diplomats and aides killed by Armenian extremists in the past decade.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Tenneco Is Sued By Superior Oil
abstract: The Superior Oil Company said it had filed a suit charging Tenneco Inc. with breach of contract in five natural gas sales agreements. Superior said it had asked for a declaratory judgment that the ''take-or-pay'' obligation be binding on Tenneco.

headline: A CLOSE-UP LOOK AT THE FRAUD THAT RUINED O.P.M.
abstract: The study, two years in the making, is 600 pages long. It provides a rare glimpse into the workings of American industry, finance, investment banking, accounting and lawyering. And it finds fault with some of the nation's most prestigious business institutions.   The issue is what these institutions did - and did not do - to discover and disclose a $225 million fraud perpetrated over a decade by one of the nation's largest computer leasing companies.   The company was O.P.M. Leasing Services. Its principal crime: the use of forged and altered computer leases as collateral to obtain loans.

headline: Norstar Merger
abstract: The Security New York State Corporation and Norstar Bancorp signed a previously announced agreement to merge in a $105 million transaction.

headline: 8 Austrians Jailed In a Political Scandal
abstract: Two former opposition politicians were among eight men jailed today, four days before national parliamentary elections, in one of Austria's biggest corruption scandals.   The eight were convicted of siphoning off million of dollars in a housing cooperative scheme in Burgenland Province.  A court in Eisenstadt, 25 miles south of Vienna, sentenced Ernst Rauchwarter, a former Austrian People's Party member of the Burgenland parliament, to the maximum penalty of 10 years in jail.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: LEBANON, DESPITE SYRIAN REBUFF, SEEKS DIRECT TALKS ON WITHDRAWAL
abstract: Despite strong rebuffs from Syria, Lebanon is still trying to start direct negotiations with Damascus in an effort to overcome Syria's denunciation of the Lebanese-Israeli troop withdrawal agreement, which was signed Tuesday.   Reports here today indicated President Amin Gemayel had organized a delegation that was ready to go to Damascus. Neither its size nor the names of its members have been announced.   Philip C. Habib, the United States special envoy, who arrived here Wednesday night, had talks with Mr. Gemayel and other Lebanese leaders today. Mr. Habib, who had planned to go next to Damascus until he was told by Syria that he would not be received, then left Beirut. After a brief stopover in Cairo he left for Saudi Arabia.

headline: Advertising; Aiming TV At Upscale Audiences
abstract: ASMALL group of agency, media and creative types as well as b roadcasters braved the April snowflakes yesterday morning to get to t he Museum of Broadcasting and learn why they should advertise on t elevision to reach the so-called wellderly, mingles, roomies or c ouplets.   The first group is made up of well-off widows, renamed by the Television Bureau of Advertising. The remaining three are all names for working unmarried couples, also known as ''possl-q's'' or persons of the opposite sex sharing living quarters.

headline: Isuzu-G.M. Link
abstract: Isuzu Motors Ltd. said it had applied to the West German Government for approval to establish a joint venture with the General Motors Corporation to market Isuzu's trucks in Europe.  The officials said Isuzu and G.M. hope to establish a joint venture, with the Japanese partner investing its capital in Continental Vehicle Sales Company, which is a West German subsidiary of G.M.

headline: A COMEBACK TRY AT FOX
abstract: IN 1977, ''Star Wars'' came to the nation's screens, and the Force was with it. The Force was with ''The Empire Strikes Back,'' too, in 1980. And when ''Return of the Jedi'' opens this Wednesday at 800 movie theaters across the country, completing the trilogy that has accounted for nearly $1 billion in ticket sales so far, it will almost inevitably be the movie of the summer of '83. ''We expect it to be the biggest of the three,'' said Alan Hirschfield, the chairman and chief executive since mid-1981 of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation, ''Jedi's'' distributor.   And it had better be, for the Force has not been with Fox for years. Since 1979, when Mr. Hirschfield joined Fox from a consulting job at Warner Communications, the company has been engulfed in an almost unending wave of contention and change, from infighting in the executive suite and rapid turnover to the $700 million purchase of Fox itself in 1981 by the Denver oilman Marvin Davis.   Last November, Fox was cut out of a cable consortium when Columbia Pictures Industries spurned it in favor of a stronger partnership with Home Box Office and CBS. When Paramount, Warner Brothers and MCA, which owns Universal, formed their own alliance in January, Fox became one of two studios - the other is MGM/UA - that does not own a means of distributing movies by cable.

headline: LATE RALLY LIFTS DOW BY 9.23
abstract: The stock market, aided by a late rally, rose moderately yesterday in somewhat heavier trading. The best gainers were some of the technology and retail issues.   The Dow Jones industrial average, ahead less than a point at 3 P.M., closed with a gain of 9.23 points, to 1,211.44. In the general market, advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange outscored stocks that fell by nearly a 2-to-1 ratio.

headline: The U.N. Today; June 27, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Committee on Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee on Information - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Decolonization Subcommittee on Petitions, Information and Assistance - 10:30 A.M.   World Food Council - 10:30 A.M.  and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Commission on Transnational Cor- porations - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Creamer Get PPG's Pool-Cleaning Product
abstract: Creamer's Pittsburgh office has just been assigned PPG's Swimming Pool Chemicals division, which was previously at Ketchum Advertising, long-time agency for all of PPG Industries.   The pool-cleaning product involved is Pittchlor, which is competing in a market that is dominated by Olin's HTH, a calcium hypochlorite product. If PPG puts up a good fight against HTH with its $2.5 million budget, Pittchlor's budget might even reach $1 million.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS; GROWING CONCERN OVER RATES
abstract: "May is going to stand out in retrospect as the benchmark month - the month in which the whole psychology of the market changed," said Scott Winningham, economist at McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei, a research firm that specializes in fixed-income securities. Indeed, in early May interest rates were at their lowest levels this month, and analysts were predicting they were heading lower.  However, with each Friday in May came news that the basic money supply was growing at an increasingly faster rate. The market was also getting reports that the economy was blossoming beyond expectations. Those two trends killed the early hopes of a cut in the discount rate and sharpened the focus on Federal Reserve policy.

headline: ** Company Reports ** BEAR CREEK CORP (O)
FUNDS, BROKERS, ET AL.
abstract: Banks and savings and loans are the most popular places for I.R.A.'s, but many investors open I.R.A.'s with mutual funds, money market funds or stockbrokers.   Based on historical performance, the average common stock mutual fund can be expected over the long haul to outperform other easily available I.R.A. investment options.

headline: WIFE OF SAKHAROV SAYS HE'S IN PERIL
abstract: Yelena G. Bonner held a sidewalk news conference today to warn that her husband, Dr. Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and human rights campaigner, would die unless the Soviet authorities relented and allowed him to return to Moscow for urgent medical treatment.   A week after an official announcement that Dr. Sakharov would not be permitted to leave for the West, Miss Bonner said that she and her husband both had serious heart conditions that necessitated a return to the capital.   Dr. Sakharov is serving an indefinite term of internal exile under close secret police guard in Gorky, a city 250 miles to the east.  The meeting with the reporters was to have taken place in Miss Bonner's sixth-floor apartment in central Moscow, but the first arrivals found the apartment door barred by plainclothes agents, evidently from the K.G.B., the Soviet intelligence and internal-security agency. Joined by a uniformed policeman, they blocked the reporters' access, forcing the 60-year-old Miss Bonner to emerge and hold the session on the street.

headline: U.S. AIDE IN BOLIVIA ON BARBIE INQUIRY
abstract: An official from Washington has begun an investigation here into possible connections between a Nazi war criminal and members of United States intelligence agencies.   The official, Allan Ryan, from the Justice Department's office of special investigations, is interviewing former Bolivian Government members and others familiar with the activities of Klaus Barbie. Mr.  Barbie was expelled from Bolivia and returned to France in February to face trial on charges of ''crimes against humanity.''

headline: SYRIAN VOWS TO UNDERMINE LEBANON-ISRAEL ACCORD
abstract: A ranking Syrian official said today that if the provisional accord on troop withdrawal between Israel and Lebanon was signed Syria would leave its troops in Lebanon for the foreseeable future and would ''do all we can to foil the agreement.''    ''In the light of such an agreement, Syria cannot ever pull out of Lebanon at any point in the future,'' the official, an intimate of President of Hafez al-Assad, said in a lengthy interview. ''After Camp David, Syria prevented the expansion of the accord. This time, our troops stay where they are, regardless of what they think in Washington, and in time certain measures will be taken against Lebanon.''

headline: LEBANON FREES 4 WITNESSES HELD IN BOMBING
abstract: The Lebanese police said today that they had released four Lebanese witnesses who had been held in connection with Monday's bombing of the United States Embassy.   The police said two of the witnesses had testified that a lone terrorist, wearing a black leather jacket and driving a black pickup truck, had forced his way across a security barricade and into the embassy driveway and then perished in the explosion.   Foreign Minister Elie Salem said in an interview with NBC News on Wednesday that the four were being investigated, but that it was still too early to accuse anyone in the bombing.

headline: I.B.M. AGREES TO BUY 15% OF ROLM
abstract: In an apparent move to enter the data communications field more forcefully, the International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 15 percent of the Rolm Corporation, a telecommunications company based in Santa Clara, Calif., for $228 million in cash.   I.B.M. said it would cooperate with Rolm on various projects, perhaps including joint ventures outside the United States.  Analysts said yesterday that the move was important to I.B.M.'s efforts to compete with American Bell, a subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, and other companies entering the rapidly merging fields of computing and telecommunications. ''I.B.M.  is trying to take a position in those companies which are crucial to its competitive position,'' said Harry Kohli, a vice president and telecommunications analyst at Sutro & Company in San Francisco.   While I.B.M. dominates computer manufacturing, it is only one of a number of companies developing systems for the transmission of voice and computer data. Thus far, its efforts in this area of computer telecommunications have been largely experimental.

headline: SANDINIST REBEL IS REPORTED BACK IN NICARAGUA
abstract: Close aides of Eden Pastora Gomez, the former Sandinist commander, said here today that he had entered Nicarcgua secretly. He is organizing his supporters for a challenge to the Sandinist Government, they said.   They said that Mr. Pastora, a revolutionary hero known as Commander Zero, slipped into Nicaragua late last month, although they refused to disclose his exact whereabouts. They said they had been in radio contact with him in Nicaragua in recent days.

headline: ASKS BETTER TIES
abstract: Yuri V. Andropov said today that the Soviet Union had a ''sincere and fervent desire'' to restore normal relations with the United States and was ''ready and interested in seeking joint initiatives'' to that end.   At a meeting with W. Averell Harriman, a former American envoy here, Mr. Andropov blamed the Reagan Administration for a situation that, as he put it, ''cannot but give rise to alarm.''   The Soviet leader appealed for a return to peaceful coexistence.  ''In view of the overall strategic situation and the growing number of explosive problems around the world, the U.S.S.R. and the United States cannot allow themselves to be drawn toward military competition,'' he said.

headline: People
abstract: * Richard B. Hamilton Jr. promoted to senior vice president at Benton & Bowles.

headline: Paradyne Cites Testimonial
abstract: The Paradyne Corporation, accused of violating Federal securities laws in obtaining a $100 million Government contract, denied the charges today and offered evidence to show that the Social Security Administraion was satisfied with the company's equipment.   At a meeting of stockholders in Largo, Fla., Paradyne distributed a statement by the Social Security Administration, which said the agency was ''satisfied with the overall performance of the Paradyne 8400 terminal systems that are currently being installed'' in Social Security field offices.

headline: Advertising; Country Living's New Shop
abstract: LANSDOWNE ADVERTISING has won the Country Living magazine account because, as far as the publisher is concerned, it has shown it can communicate the magazine's success to the rest of Madison Avenue in an advertising campaign.   And that is what Ronald A. Galotti, 33-year-old publisher, wants, because he knows that along the Street of Concepts, it is that old top-of-mind awareness of ''a hot book'' that is vital when final selections are being made for a magazine advertising schedule.   The theme for the campaign is: ''Country Living. The Texture of America Today.'' It will appear as the headline over the first ad, which will be illustrated by a colorful graph showing the magazine's rate base growth from 400,000 in 1981 to 800,000, which is scheduled to replace 750,000 in July. It and the rest of the campaign will appear in most of the advertising trade press, as well as several newspapers.

headline: THURSDAY, APRIL 21, 1983
abstract: The Economy   The gross national product grew at an annual rate of 3.1 percent in the first quarter, the largest quarterly rise in two years, the Commerce Department reported. It said prices rose at an annual rate of 3.2 percent in the period, down from 4.9 percent in the fourth quarter. According to economists, the increase in the G.N.P., spurred by a sharp rise in housing construction, is the surest sign to date that recovery is moving ahead. Still, the rise was smaller than some had predicted, indicating that the recovery might be modest. (Page A1.)   The Supreme Court ruled that states may ban nuclear power plants so long as they are motivated by doubts about their economics rather than their safety. The decision, upholding a California moratorium on future construction of nuclear plants, was a sharp setback for both the troubled nuclear industry and the Federal Government. It does not apply to projects already under way. (A1.)

headline: Rise Forecast In Car Output
abstract: United States car production during this model year is likely to be 9.5 percent above the level of a year ago, the first gain since the 1979 model year, according to an auto trade journal.   Ward's Automotive Reports said today that domestic auto makers should build 5.65 million cars during the 1983 model run, ending in August.

headline: DOW FALLS BY 3.01, TO 1,239.18
abstract: Stock prices responded yesterday with much less enthusiasm than many financial experts had expected to the weekend reappointment of Paul A. Volcker as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.   Analysts said that the reappointment was welcome, but apparently had already been reflected in the sharp run-up in prices last week as rumors of the nomination gained strength.   The Dow Jones industrial average, up about 5 points in the first hour of trading and about 2 points at noon, slipped to the minus side at about 12:45 P.M. and continued to slide, closing at 1,239.18, off 3.01 points.   Volume for the day fell to 84.3 million, from 93.6 million on Friday.  ''The market celebrated the Volcker appointment last week, and today reappraised the fast pace of business growth, which usually signals a rise in inflation'' said Robert H. Stovall, first vice president of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ''U.S. personal income increased 1.2 percent in May, the biggest jump since July 1981, and that partly explains the lift in housing starts and retail sales and foreshadows inflationary pressures down the road.''

headline: I.B.M. Settles Lin Data Suit
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation, which charged that Yeong S. Lin and his company, the Lin Data Corporation, had used I.B.M. trade secrets, has reached an out-of-court settlement with the former I.B.M employee.   In agreeing that the litigation will be suspended, I.B.M. said yesterday that Mr. Lin had pledged not to disclose or use I.B.M.  trade secrets and had agreed to pay an undisclosed sum to I.B.M. An independent monitor will be appointed to make sure the agreement is fulfilled, I.B.M said. It also said that the defendants had agreed to ''an entry of judgment against them'' if the agreement were violated.

headline: TEXAS GENERAL INC. FILES FOR PROTECTION
abstract: Texas General Resources Inc., a holding company for a group of small energy companies based here, and two of its subsidiaries - International Drilling Services Inc. and Texas General Resources International N.V. - have filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.   The company said today that it had failed to reach an agreement to restructure about $45 million of secured debt with Marine Midland Bank of New York, its principal lender.

headline: Seafirst Dissidents Limit Vote Goal
abstract: Opponents of the merger between the Seafirst Corporation and the BankAmerica Corporation say they probably do not have the shareholder votes to stop it outright at a meeting scheduled for Tuesday, but they may have enough support to force BankAmerica to take another look at the proposal.

headline: FRENCH STOREKEEPERS ADD PROTESTS TO PARIS STUDENT DEMONSTRATIONS
abstract: The police here skirmished with students and shopkeepers today after separate anti-Government demonstrations brought 10,000 shopkeepers into the streets.   On Thursday, 13 students were reported hurt in clashes with the police in Toulouse, Lyons and Montpellier.  Organizers of today's student protest called off the march before the 7,000 marchers reached their destination, the Place de la Bastille. But small groups of young people, many of them wearing helmets or masks, broke away and hurled rocks and metal sign stanchions at the police. Witnesses said a few students threw firebombs.

headline: MITTERRAND SEEKS PARLEY TO REVAMP MONETARY SYSTEM
abstract: President Francois Mitterrand of France called today for a conference ''at the highest level'' that would attempt to reorganize the world monetary system.   ''The time has really come to think in terms of a new Bretton Woods,'' Mr. Mitterrand told some 100 finance, trade and foreign ministers attending a two-day meeting of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development here. ''Outside this proposition, there will be no salvation.''   Mr. Mitterrand was referring to the landmark meeting of wartime leaders in Bretton Woods, N.H., in 1944 that fixed exchange rates among major currencies. The cornerstone of the system was an American guarantee to convert dollars into gold at $35 an ounce.

headline: ** Company Reports ** LACLEDE STEEL CO (O)
abstract: Qtr to March 31 1983 1982 Sales 46,041,000 53,991,000 Net inc b1,367,000 c3,170,000 Share earns .62  b-Including a credit of $1,111,000from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Net loss.

headline: Control Data
abstract: The Control Data Corporation's Control Data Ltd. subsidiary said it had acquired 40 percent of Systime P.L.C., the largest shareholding in the company, following completion of Systime's financial restructuring.

headline: FOCUS ON FEDERAL FUNDS RATE
abstract: The credit markets have been on edge recently because of fears that the Federal Reserve might have decided to tighten credit and thereby cause interest rates to rise. The most closely watched interest rate of all is the rate for overnight loans between banks, known as the Federal funds rate.   Wall Street economists say they are not sure if the Fed has tightened its policy. But an increase in the Federal funds rate could be a sign that the Fed has made an adjustment.

headline: VW'S LOSS FOR YEAR AT $122 MILLION
abstract: Volkswagenwerk A.G., West Germany's biggest auto maker, reported today that it lost $122.4 million last year, mostly as a result of a big loss at the Volkswagen American subsidiary.   The parent company's loss compared with a profit of $55.5 million the year before. It was Volkswagen's largest loss since 1974, a recession year.

headline: WORLD BANKING GUIDELINES
abstract: New guidelines aimed at tightening supervision of international banking were released today by the West German Bundesbank.   The revisions to a 1974 code were agreed to by 11 major Western countries. The changes were prompted by the collapse last year of Banco Ambrosiano, one of Italy's largest commercial banks, and by the refusal of Banca d'Italia, Italy's central bank, to accept responsibility for about $400 million in liabilities incurred by Ambrosiano's Luxembourg unit, Ambrosiano Holdings S.A.   West German central bank officials said today that the revisions, although not legally binding, shifted responsibility for overseeing subsidiaries of foreign banks largely onto supervisory authorities in the countries where the bank subsidiaries operate.

headline: Leaving Wells for Bates
abstract: After 10 years as a creative team at Wells, Rich, Greene, near the dignified old Plaza Hotel, Thomas W. Heck, art director, and Nancy Vaughn, copywriter, are moving to Ted Bates Advertising/New York, in the midst of bustling, rowdy Times Square. They will be executive creative directors, reporting to Michael L. Becker, vice chairman and chief creative officer.

headline: Vandals Demolish the Grave Of Hans Christian Andersen
abstract: Vandals have destroyed the grave of Hans Christian Andersen, the author of fairy tales, a cemetery spokesman said today.   The six-foot sandstone monument in the Assistens cemetery in central Copenhagen, which included a life-size bust of the author, was smashed to pieces, apparently by heavy hammers.   Ten other graves were also vandalized.

headline: Schenley President Given Additional Posts
abstract: Howard S. Feldman, president of Schenley Industries, has been named to the additional posts of chairman and chief executive, the company said yesterday.   Mr. Feldman, 64, replaces Meshulam Riklis, 59, who is chairman and chief executive of Schenley's parent, the Rapid-American Corporation.

headline: Japan Loans To China
abstract: Japan has made $1 billion in loans to China under a five-year agreement signed in 1979, the New China News Agency said today.   It quoted a senior Chinese Foreign Trade Ministry official as saying China had already used up $432 million of the loans by the end of March.

headline: Golden West Air Ends Operations
abstract: Golden West Airlines, California's largest commuter airline, said it had ceased operations, making it the third California commuter airline to go out of business since August.   Analysts said the company was hurt by the competition spawned by airline deregulation, which brought a proliferation of new carriers.

headline: British Banks Cut Rate
abstract: Britain's major banks, responding to concerns of the new Government, cut their base interest rate by half a percentage point today, to 9 1/2 percent.

headline: Peking Finds Security Lax in Plane Hijacking
abstract: Shen Tu, director general of China's national airline, said today that inadequate airport security had allowed six hijackers to bring two handguns aboard the first plane ever to be hijacked out of China. He demanded that they be returned from South Korea to face trial.

headline: The Talk of Addis Ababa
abstract: Three Ethiopian men were walking the other day past the complex of buildings that houses some of this country's revolutionary institutions and whose security precautions include a metal fence severing what used to be the main approach to a cathedral.   As the men came abreast the place of worship, they stopped, removed their caps and bowed in brief reverence, gazing past the armed revolutionary guards and the hammer and sickle emblems of the new order toward an older emblem - the ornate cross of the Ethiopian Orthodox Union Church.   ''That sort of thing happens all the time,'' said a longtime resident of Addis Ababa, who, like most people here, offered to talk only in return for anonymity and thus protection from a stern regime. ''Religion was here a long time before Marxism.''   That much is apparent on Sunday mornings, when many of the 1.5 million people who inhabit this capital of high-rise buildings interwoven with shanties forgo food and drink to present themselves before the priests who officiate at ritual-laden services throughout the city. A missionary worker said church attendance in the last couple of years had blossomed, a kind of relief and quest for renewal after the darkest days of the revolution.

headline: GULF NATIONS FAIL TO AGREE ON HALTING OIL SPILL
abstract: The eight Persian Gulf nations failed again today to agree on how to fight an Iranian oil slick that is expected to reach Bahrain within 24 hours.   Dr. Abdul-Rahman al-Awadi, executive director of the Regional Organization for the Protection of the Marine Environment, said at a news conference here that the delegates could not even agree on a final statement at their session today.   It was the third time this month the group has met to try to work out a truce in the Iran-Iraq war to allow the capping of wells in the offshore Iranian oilfield of Noruz. Dr. Awadi attributed the failure to agree to ''political and military'' considerations. He said consultations would continue, but he did not set a date for another meeting.

headline: West Bank Demonstrations Leave 3 Palestinians Injured
abstract: An Israeli Army spokesman said today that three Palestinians were injured in Nablus during demonstrations in the occupied West Bank.

headline: 11.12 GAIN PUTS DOW AT 1,219.52
abstract: The stock market resumed its upsurge yesterday in active trading, with the Dow Jones industrial average finishing at another new high.  The Dow average, which is made up of 30 leading stocks, rose 11.12 points, to 1,219.52, after losing 1.06 points on Wednesday, mainly because of profit taking. Yesterday was the eighth time in the last 12 trading days that the indicator had closed at a record level.   The Dow, a key market barometer, has soared 106 points in the last three weeks. A high of 1,209.46 was reached on Tuesday. Since the bull market began in mid-August, the Dow has advanced about 440 points, reflecting expectations of an economic recovery and lower interest rates.

headline: Court Delays Braniff Action
abstract: Braniff International has been granted two more weeks to submit its reorganization plan to United States Bankruptcy Judge John Flowers.   Judge Flowers extended the deadline from next Monday to April 18, court documents show. After that date, Braniff will no longer have the exclusive right to file a reorganization plan and its creditors may submit a plan of their own for the airline, which filed for bankruptcy protection from its creditors on May 13, 1982, after shutting down the preceding evening.

headline: Nicaragua's Air Force Said to Bomb Indians
abstract: Nicaraguan Air Force planes bombed at least one Indian village in an attack on rebels inside Nicaragua, forcing about 1,000 peasants to flee into Honduras in panic, refugees and a United Nations official said today.   The official, Dwight Harriman, director of a United Nations-run relief camp in Mocoron, said, ''We could have 10,000 people here soon.''   Miskito Indians at the camp said their village, Santa Clara, 250 miles northeast of Managua, was bombed on on March 28.

headline: Nigerian Debt Talks Hit Snags
abstract: Efforts to agree on a package to reschedule a portion of Nigeria's short-term debt burden bogged down today in a meeting here of European lenders.   ''There's a will to get something together, but people don't want to be bulldozed,'' said a bank spokesman who asked not be identified.  The purpose of the meeting was to bring the banks up to date on a plan that American banking sources said Monday had been tentatively approved in a meeting of American banks in New York at the Bankers Trust Company. That plan was said to involve the rescheduling of $1.5 billion of Nigeria's debt, with an agreement that payments be suspended from June 1 to next Jan.1.

headline: A.M.C.'s Rate Program
abstract: The American Motors Corporation today announced that it would extend purchase incentive programs on two jeep models and its popular Renault Alliance until June 30.   American Motors had been offering 11.9 percent rates on loans for auto purchases under a program that expired Tuesday.

headline: AM General Order
abstract: The AM General Corporation, a subsidiary of the American Motors Corporation, was awarded a $38 million contract to build 6,400 postal vehicles for the Federal Government, the company announced. AM General is the leading supplier of vehicles to the United States Postal Service. A.M.C. is trying to sell AM General to get needed cash for auto development programs.

headline: CONTINUING DECLINE SEEN FOR RATES
abstract: The credit markets set aside fears of higher interest rates last week and readily absorbed $2.4 billion of new corporate and foreign offerings at the same time as the Treasury sold $15 billion of new notes and bonds, a record combination of financing for one week.   ''The week of Treasury refundings is often a time when realities get sorted out and investors take a hard look at just what they expect for interest rates,'' said William Gibson, chief economist at the Republic Bank of Dallas. ''Everyone gets worried about the heavy supply ahead of time'' he said, but it very often happens that the weeks of heaviest supply are the weeks of greatest investor buying.''    The success of the corporate and Government financings was widely attributed to a belief that short-term rates would soon decline as money supply growth subsides from the rapid pace of the first quarter. Low inflation continues to put downward pressure on longterm yields.

headline: Syria Sponsoring Talks On Rift Within P.L.O.
abstract: Syria has started talks to try to prevent dissent within Yasir Arafat's mainstream Fatah group from tearing apart the Palestine Liberation Organization, Palestinian officials said today.   The discussions began at the Foreign Ministry in Damascus late Monday night under the auspices of Syria's ruling Baath Party.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: Taxing the Elderly Rich   Should the elderly pay more taxes? Congress recently moved to tax Social Security benefits of retired people whose incomes exceed a certain level. But maybe it should go further, suggests Allen D.  Manvel, a retired division chief of the Census Bureau.   In a recent article in Tax Notes, he said that all people 65 and older are eligible for an extra $1,000 personal ex emption and that 12 million people claimed such exemptions in 1980, at an estimated cost to the Treasury of $2.4 billion.   The basic problem with the exemption, Mr. Manvel says, is that it is available to all elderly, not just those in need. A recent analysis by the Congressional Budget Office, for example, showed that of all the 1980 tax returns filed with adjusted gross income greater than $1 million, more than one-third claimed the $1,000 exemption.

headline: K.G.B. SUPPRESSING A DISSIDENT GROUP
abstract: Since the middle of last week a Leningrad courtroom has been the scene of a treason trial that appears to represent the most determined effort yet to suppress the so-called Solzhenitsyn Fund, a semiclandestine group that has aided thousands of Soviet political prisoners and their families over the last decade.   A 32-year-old former journalist, Valery Repin, has spent hours in the dock confessing that his work as Leningrad manager of the fund made him a ''thoughtless pawn'' of the Central Intelligence Agency and its efforts to obtain ''military-political'' secrets.   His wife, testifying for the prosecution, has corroborated his confession and pleaded for the court's mercy. More than two dozen of the couple's friends and associates, most of them beneficiaries or workers of the fund, have affirmed their role in the purported treachery.

headline: The Talk of Soweto
abstract: Those who disparage David Thebehali, the canny and affable ''Mayor'' of South Africa's largest black settlement, like to point out that he gained his position with only 97 votes in a widely boycotted election five years ago. Disputing that tally with a wounded expression, Mr. Thebehali insists he was actually the choice of 295 of Soweto's inhabitants - none of whom, including himself, have an unambiguous claim to citizenship under the country's laws.   Since Soweto has a population of at least 1.2 million, Mr.  Thebehali's mandate can hardly be regarded as overwhelming, even by his own generous estimate. But it was a start, and he has been building on it ever since, using the limited powers conferred on him as the indirectly elected chairman of the Soweto Community Council to do favors for potential voters.   Since 1978, he says, he has met personally with 78,000 Soweto inhabitants to help them out of snags with the white bureaucracy, ease their housing problems or even counsel them on their marriages.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * Albany Savings Bank, Albany, has elected Gilbert O. Robert chairman and chief executive officer.   * Continental Group, Stamford, Conn., has appointed Richard D.  Hofmann chief planning officer.

headline: ** Company Reports ** PHILADELPHIA ELECTRIC CO (N)
F.C.C. Upholds MCI Award
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission has upheld a nearly $1 million damage award that the MCI Communications Corporation won in 1981 against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.   MCI will receive only about $89,000 of the award, however, because the agency also concluded that MCI owes a Bell subsidiary, Pacific Telephone and Telegraph, $843,000 to settle overdue bills.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
abstract: The Phillips Petroleum Company took advantage of rising bond prices and a dearth of new high-grade corporate issues yesterday to sell $250 million of 11 1/4 percent debentures due in 2013.   Underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company offered the Aa3-rated debentures at a price of 100 to yield 11.25 percent to maturity.

headline: Margeotes Accounts
abstract: Margeotes/Fertitta & Weiss has picked up two new accounts worth about $2.5 million in billings.

headline: THRIFT UNITS: CAUTIOUS RIVALS
abstract: Last November, when thrift institutions were granted new powers allowing them to make commercial loans, some analysts predicted that a price war would break out with their traditional rivals, the small commercial banks.   Six months later the commercial banks, which strenuously opposed allowing thrift institutions to do commercial lending, have little to worry about. Despite clamoring for the additional powers, most savings and loan associations and mutual savings banks are moving gingerly into the riskier - and potentially much more profitable - arena of commercial banking.   Under the Depository Institutions Act of 1982, federally chartered savings and loan associations can invest up to 5 percent of their total assets in commercial loans this year, while mutual savings banks can invest 5.5 percent of their assets. Next year the ratio will rise to 10 percent for both kinds of institutions.

headline: LEVESQUE SAYS PARTY NEEDS TO SPUR QUEBEC SEPARATISM
abstract: Premier Rene Levesque said today that his party would have to stoke up what he described as a ''dormant'' separatist consciousness in Quebec to pave the way for an election within two years that will clearly be run on the issue of independence.   In a two-hour interview in Hull, just across the river from Ottawa, Mr. Levesque said his Parti Quebecois, aware of its low rating in public opinion polls, was gearing up for a campaign he hopes will result in a mandate to proclaim independence.   ''Our position is that if we get anything that looks like 50 percent of the vote, which automatically would mean that we won 60 percent of the French-speaking vote, that's a mandate,'' he said.  ''If we get it we go ahead by all legitimate means.''

headline: NEW BOMB BLAST IN SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: A bomb blew up under a parked car here during lunch hour today, causing damage but no casualties.   There was no immediate claim of responsiblity for the blast, which came six days after a car bomb killed 18 people and wounded 217 in Pretoria, South Africa's administrative capital.

headline: NEW TRADE AGENCY OUTLINED
abstract: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige today gave the first details of the Administration's plans for what he called a ''lean and mean'' cabinet-level Department of Trade.   The Commerce Department chief, who helped work out the reorganization with its principal White House champion, Edwin Meese 3d, Presidential counselor, said he hoped Congress would approve it by the end of this year. He conceded, however, that such quick action was not certain.

headline: Arab Windshields Smashed
abstract: Dozens of Arab-owned cars parked near the Jewish township of Qiryat Arba in the Israeli-occupied West Bank were damaged overnight, the Israel radio reported today. The police said they had received 33 complaints from Arab residents whose car windshields were smashed. Qiryat Arba, built near thePalestinian town of Hebron, has been a frequent site of clashes between Jews and Arabs.

headline: MONEY FUNDS FIGHTING BACK
abstract: When banks were permitted to offer their own money market accounts in December, the nation's mutual funds warned that the extraordinarily high introductory rates offered by most banks to draw depositors away from the funds would not last forever.   They were right. In fact, the high rates barely survived a few months. By one reckoning last week, the average rate offered on federally insured bank money market accounts nationwide, 8.13 percent, topped the average rate for mutual funds by only a quarter of a percentage point.

headline: Poland Bars Amnesty For the Pope's Visit
abstract: The Government stressed today that it would not grant the Roman Catholic Church's request that political prisoners be granted amnesty before the visit of Pope John Paul II next month.   ''The authorities attach the possibility of amnesty to the assurance of an indispensible state of internal stabilization in the country,'' the Communist Party newspaper Trybuna Ludu said, echoing recent statements by Jerzy Urban, the Government spokesman.

headline: SNAG SEEN ON BRITISH STEEL PLAN
abstract: As the United States Steel Corporation and the British Steel Corporation continued their work on a plan to ship Scottish steel production to a Pennsylvania mill, a British Steel spokesman indicated yesterday that his company was seeking to free the Scottish plant from Government subsidies.   The spokesman, Philip Wolfinden, the head of information services for the British company, said that his company's Ravenscraig plant in Scotland might be set up as a separate unsubsidized plant within the subsidized British Steel Corporation or be spun off as a separate non-Government company.   Removing the subsidies would solve a major problem in the steelmakers' plan. Under American law, imports are liable to limitations if they are from subsidized producers and therefore can be sold below production costs. Indeed, the American steel industry has relied on that law in recent years to win protection from steel imports, which have taken a growing share of the domestic market.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues   * Canadian Pacific Securities Corp. is raising $60 million (Canadian) in a 11 7/8 percent seven-year Eurobond issue offered at par through underwriters led by Orion Roal Bank.   * Citicorp's weekly auction of $125 million of 91-day commercial paper drew an average rate of 8.656 percent, down from 8.696 percent last week; $1.08 billion in bids were submitted, at rates ranging from 8.645 percent to 8.670 percent.   * Dansk Olie O.G. Naturgas began issuing $100 million of A1-rated commercial paper in the United States through Goldman, Sachs.

headline: S.E.C. SAYS FINANCIAL CORP. WILL LOWER '82 PROFIT REPORT
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that the Financial Corporation of America had agreed to reduce its previously reported 1982 profits 26 percent, to $27.2 million, from $36.7 million.   Financial, headed by Charles W. Knapp, is the parent of the State Savings and Loan Association, whose aggressive lending practices have made it one of the nation's largest thrift institutions, with 30 offices in California.   Financial and its independent auditor, Arthur Andersen & Company, have been involved in an accounting practice dispute with the S.E.C.  over the way the company recorded sales of foreclosed property and delinquent mortgage loans. Review of Proxy Materials   The S.E.C. questioned Financial's accounting practices during a review of proxy materials that the company submitted regarding its proposed acquisition of First Charter Financial Corporation of Beverly Hills, a combination that would have more than $17 billion in assets. First Charter's shareholders are scheduled to vote on the transaction May 24.

headline: Belize Leader Sees Reagan
abstract: Prime Minister George Price of Belize paid a 75-minute visit today to President Reagan at the White House.  The two men discussed insurgency in Central America, the economic development needs of the region and Belize's territorial dispute with Guatemala.

headline: DEAL SEEN ON POWER BOND DEBT
abstract: Government and utility officials in the Northwest have reached ''substantial agreement in principle'' on a plan to avoid default on the $7 billion debt for two abandoned nuclear power projects, according to the Governor of Washington.   After an 11-hour meeting Tuesday night, Gov. John Spellman said that the participants would take the ''possible solution'' back to the groups they represent. Another meeting will be held Friday, he said.

headline: TWO SIDES APPROVE THE FINAL WORDING OF LEBANESE PACT
abstract: Israeli and Lebanese negotiators completed work today on the text of their security agreement, a spokesman for the Israeli Foreign Ministry announced. He said the accord was ready to sign.   The accord lays the basis for a withdrawal of Israeli soldiers from Lebanon, provided Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization also withdraw their forces from the country. Israel has also demanded, before withdrawal, a return of Israelis held prisoner and an accounting of all those missing in action.

headline: MORGAN'S NET INCOME CLIMBS 37%
abstract: J.P. Morgan & Company, the nation's fifth-largest bank holding company, reported yesterday that its first-quarter net income rose to $117.8 million, an increase of 37 percent over the $86 million earned in the first quarter of 1982. On a per-share basis, net income rose to $2.76, from $2.09. The company's primary subsidiary is the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, the nation's fifth-largest bank.   The surge in earnings occurred despite a quadrupling of the provision for loan losses, to $70 million, from $17 million in the period a year earlier. In addition, Morgan said that problem loans almost doubled to $700 million, or 2.1 percent of total loans, from $386 million, or 1.8 percent of the total, in the comparable period of 1982.

headline: Seoul Opposition Leader Ends a Hunger Strike
abstract: Kim Young Sam, a former opposition leader, said today that he had ended a hunger strike he began 23 days ago, but that he would press his struggle for democratic political changes.   Mr. Kim, once rated a presidential contender, said in a statement that he had given up the fast because of pleas from supporters, family members and others.

headline: Killings in Peru Put at 866
abstract: Peru's Interior Minister has told the country's Senate that 866 people have died in guerrilla violence in the central Andes since the end of 1980, local newspapers reported today. In a confidential report to a defense committee on Thursday, the minister, Luis Percovich, said also that 2,400 suspected members of the Shining Path guerrilla group had been arrested, the newspapers said.

headline: Money Market Fund Assets Off $1.7 Billion
abstract: Money market fund assets fell $1.7 billion for the week ended Wednesday, to $171.6 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. The drop during the previous week was $1.9 billion.

headline: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 8, 1983; Markets
abstract: Stock prices plunged as concern spread that the Federal Reserve may soon tighten monetary policy, pushing up interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 19.33 points, to 1,194.91. Over all, declines outnumbered advances by 1,044 to 588. The decline was the Dow's largest since May 2, when it fell 21.87 points. (Page D1.)   Short- and long-term interest rates rose as many traders interpreted the Fed's failure to add funds to the banking system as a sign that it has tightened credit availability. Experts said the credit markets' bearish tone was intensified by a rumor - subsequently denied - that Paul A. Volcker had resigned as chairman of the Fed. (D9.)

headline: Clarifying Rules
abstract: To the Business Editor: Thomas C. Hayes states (''Good Buys in the Thrift Business,'' May 8) that state-chartered Florida S.& L.'s have considerable advantages relative to federally chartered S.& L.'s in Florida because, in part, the state-chartered institutions are permitted to invest as much as half of their total assets outside of mortgages, whereas Federal thrifts are subject to a 5 percent ceiling on such investments.   Mr. Hayes is in error in this belief.

headline: Investing; UNCERTAIN TIMES FOR PHONE STOCKS
abstract: MCI COMMUNICATIONS, Ma Bell's chief competitor in the long-distance telephone market, has a problem. Despite a continued exceptional earnings performance so far this year, prices for MCI shares have underperformed the highly volatile but exceedingly popular telecommunications group.   Increasingly, MCI may not find itself alone.  Worries about the impact of the scheduled divestiture of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in seven months, plus late delivery of new products in an industry whose lifeblood is technological change, have rocked one of the stock market's longstanding rules: Prices of the telecommunications issues always move in tandem. The industry, in short, is in the throes of a shakeout that could last for several years.

headline: Baldrige View on Volcker
abstract: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said today that Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, has done a good job, but that replacing him would not have an adverse impact on the financial markets.   Mr. Volcker's four-year term as chairman ends in August and speculation is growing on his chances for reappointment.

headline: CURRENCT INTEREST RATES
abstract: Tax-Exempt Bonds

headline: IT'S NECESSARY FOR SHORT-TERM GROWTH
abstract: AFOOLISH consistency, Emerson told us, is the hobgoblin of little m inds. But we are wary of politicians who would have us do one thing t oday and the opposite tomorrow.  This aversion to inconsistency may help explain why those who would raise taxes in the future to close the Federal deficit are having a hard time persuading people that the tax cut scheduled for July should be permitted to take effect. Despite appearances, however, tax cuts now and tax increases in the future are both necessary for dealing with two distinct problems, unemployment and long-term economic growth.

headline: Grand Met Raises Profit
abstract: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. said today that its earnings more than doubled in the six months ended March 31 from the same period a year earlier.

headline: Japan to Explain Trade Aims
abstract: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan said today that he would send a public relations mission to the United States and Western Europe soon to promote imports and, at the same time, combat bitterness over Japan's large trade surplus. The Finance Ministry estimates that the surplus in the year ending next March will be more than $14 billion, compared with just over $9 billion in the last fiscal year.

headline: S.E.C. Panel Asks Curb On 'Golden Parachutes'
abstract: A special panel named by the Securities and Exchange Commission recommended yesterday that stockholders be consulted when a company makes provisions for lucrative severance payments, or ''golden parachutes,'' for its executives.   The panel also recommended a rule that would prevent anyone from buying more than 15 percent of a company's stock, unless the additional stock was bought directly from the company or through a public tender offer, or from someone that had held it for more than two years.   The idea, the panel said, would be to insure that after a partial takeover, the remaining stockholders receive a good price for their stock. Some critics contend that it is inequitable that a buyer in the open market can gain control of a company without making a tender offer to all shareholders.

headline: Insider Reports
abstract: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued Wednesday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE   AMERICAN BROADCASTING COMPANIES INC.

headline: Excerpts from speech, page A16.
abstract: Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, offered today to reduce nuclear medium-range forces in Europe to the present NATO levels in numbers of warheads as well as in numbers of missiles and planes.   His proposal, which left many details unclear, would still seek to include French and British nuclear forces within the arsenal of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and would bar the United States from deploying missiles in Europe as planned by the Atlantic alliance later this year.   (The United States welcomed Soviet willingness to negotiate ceilings in warheads as well as in medium-range missiles and planes, but it insisted that it could not count British and French forces as part of the NATO arsenal. Page A16.)

headline: Conrail Assets
abstract: Canadian Pacific Ltd. and the Canadian National Railway Company said they had agreed with the Consolidated Rail Corporation to buy certain Conrail assets in Canada. The assets include Conrail's leases of the Canada Southern Railway Company and the Detroit River Tunnel. They will also acquire 72 percent of Canada Southern's shares and all the Detroit River Tunnel shares from Conrail.

headline: Montedison To Expand
abstract: Montedison S.p.A., it was learned yesterday, will announce it has made a major move to expand its health sciences operations in the United States through the formation of Erbamont N.V., which includes all of the health-sciences and pharmaceuticals operations of the Milan-based Montedison.   Erbamont is one of the world's largest producers of anticancer chemotherapeutic drugs including Adriamycin, which is the largest selling anticancer drug in the United States and Western Europe.

headline: U.S. ASSAILED IN FRANCE OVER STRENGTH OF DOLLAR
abstract: After the American dollar climbed today to a new high in relation to the French franc, for the third day in a row, Finance Minister Jacques Delors directed a bitter attack at the Reagan Administration. He accused it of dashing hopes for a general economic recovery in Europe this year.   The Finance Minister, answering questions in Parliament, said the dollar's strength would force up the cost of imported oil and other commodities paid for in dollars, aggravating inflation and obliging countries to raise their interest rates and hold back their growth.  He demanded that the United States take immediate action to push the dollar down, either by cutting interest rates or by intervening in the currency markets.

headline: REISCHAUSER IN A BOSTON HOSPITAL
abstract: Edwin O. Reischauer, former United States Ambassador to Japan and a noted Asia scholar, was taken from Tokyo to a hospital here Wednesday. He was reported in stable condition today with gastritis, an inflammation of the stomach lining.

headline: Freddie Mac Sets Offering
abstract: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation will announce today the offering of $1 billion of guaranteed mortgage certificates that will be priced and sold by an underwriting syndicate led by the First Boston Corporation and Salomon Brothers.   ''The offering will be the largest ever of a mortgage-related security,'' Edward S. Atwater, vice president of First Boston, said yesterday.

headline: MOSCOW PREDICTS A MISSILE IMPASSE
abstract: The Soviet Communist party newspaper Pravda has rejected the possibility of combining American proposals with aspects of Yuri V. Andropov's latest offer to produce an accord on reducing medium-range nuclear weapons in Europe.   In an editorial prepared for publication in Friday's issue, Pravda noted that President Reagan had pledged to give serious study to the offer Mr. Andropov put forward last week. The paper said this appeared to mean that the United States would like to ''adapt'' the central aspect of the Soviet proposal, a readiness to use warheads as well as the number of missile launchers as the basic accounting units, to the existing American offer.   ''A negative answer can be given to this question right away,'' Pravda said.  It said that the Soviet and American offers at the Geneva talks on reductions of medium-range nuclear weapons in Europe were incompatible.

headline: FRENCH CALL ARCHIVIST A SOVIET SPY
abstract: French police officials said today that they had arrested a man for of passing industrial secrets to the Soviet Union.  The police said the man, Patrick Guerrier, 25 years old, an archivist for a company that officials would not identify, had photocopied documents and passed them to officials of the Soviet Embassy whom the police identified as agents of the K.G.B., the Soviet intelligence agency.

headline: Market Place; Wall Street's Success Story
abstract: WHEN the stock market closed Friday, it appeared as if Hollywood had written the script. All the major market indicators finished at record highs, once again defying forecasts that prices were poised for a tumble after climbing so high so fast.   The Dow Jones industrial average advanced 46.63 points for the week, to 1,171.34. It has registered seven daily gains in a row for the first time since the spring of 1981.

headline: ** Company Reports ** INTERNATIONAL BUSINESSMACHINES CORP (N)
abstract: Qtr to March 31 1983 1982 Gr inc 8,287,000,000 7,006,000,000 Net inc 976,000,000 789,000,000 Share earns 1.62 1.33 Gross income figures include salesof $3,970,000,000 and $2,747,000,000 forthe latest and year-ago first quarters,respectively, rental income of$2,579,000,000 and $2,847,000,000 for thelatest and year-ago first quarters andservice income of $1,738,000,000 and$1,472,000,000 for the latest and year-ago first quarters.

headline: ITALIAN GLOOMY OVER MIDEAST PEACE PROSPECTS
abstract: Italy's Foreign Minister, returning from a tour of the Middle East, has painted a gloomy picture of the outlook for peace in both the Arab-Israeli conflict and in the war between Iran and Iraq.   Foreign Minister Emilio Colombo, discussing his trip to Syria, Iraq and Kuwait, said in an interview Friday night that criticism of the American role in the Middle East negotiations was strongest in Damascus, where he met with President Hafez al-Assad and Foreign Minister Abdel Halim Khaddam.   Mr. Colombo said he found little hope for immediate peace prospects in either the Middle East or in the war between Iraq and Iran.  Mr. Colombo plans to meet Secretary of State George P. Shultz in Paris Monday, together with the Foreign Ministers of Britain and France, who also contribute to the multinational peacekeeping force in Lebanon.

headline: U.S. and Soviet Argue Blame For Prolonging Madrid Talks
abstract: The Soviet Union and the United States accused each other again today of prolonging the Conference on European Security and Cooperation, which has been in virtual stalemate for over 30 months, delegates said.   Yuri V. Dubinin of the Soviet Union said the conference could fail if the United States refused to change its positions.

headline: On Icahn
abstract: To the Business Editor:    Carl Icahn neglects to mention (''Stop the Oppression of Shareholders,'' May 22) how he amassed millions of dollars from his corporate raids.

headline: SATURDAY, JUNE 4, 1983; The Economy
abstract: New-car sales by the Big Three auto makers rose 17.7 percent during the final selling days of May. This brought the industry's annual selling rate for the month to seven million vehicles, the highest in nearly two years. Analysts welcomed the increase as a ''breakthrough'' to a ''new plateau,'' indicating that full recovery might be under way. Chrysler's sales were up 38.9 percent in the period, while Ford's rose 22.2 percent and G.M.'s 12.5 percent. (Page 29.)   The jobless rate fell in May to 10 percent from 10.1 percent, its third consecutive monthly decline, the Labor Department reported. The seasonally adjusted rate and the total number of unemployed - 11,192,000 -remained near their highest levels since 1940. But the total number of employed rose sharply, to 101,226,000, adding up to a gain of more than 800,000 jobs since December. Officials saw the new figures as evidence of further improvement in the nation's labor market. (1.) The jobless rate in New York City also declined. (8.)

headline: Some New Issues May Be Postponed
abstract: Given the rise in interest rates last week and the stubbornly high rate of money supply growth, underwriters of corporate and tax-free bonds scheduled for this week may postpone issues if market conditions do not improve.   Problems in selling new issues were emphasized last week when lack of investor interest prompted Goldman, Sachs & Company to raise the yield on the New York State Power Authority bonds and the First Boston Corporation to withdraw its $109 million Ohio Building Authority refunding issue.   Despite the heavy calendar for this week, one analyst predicted: ''Some of the deals will be taken out of the market. I don't know how many will actually come to market.''

headline: Thrift Unit Merger Plan
abstract: Federal regulators today urged that the nation's savings and loan associations be allowed to merge across state lines, if such actions are acceptable to the states involved.   The proposal, by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, is now subject to public comment for two months, after which the board could formally approve the change.

headline: LOSS SEEN BY TEXAS INSTRUMENTS
abstract: Texas Instruments Inc., citing a sudden and sharp drop in the sale of home computer software to retailers, has announced that it expects to report a ''major loss'' in the second quarter, possibly as much as $100 million.   The company, in a statement issued late Friday night, also said that, ''in contrast to earlier assessments, it now appears that 1983 will be a significantly poorer year for the company than 1982.''   The Dallas-based company, a leading producer of semiconductor products and a major factor in other segments of the electronics business, had been expected to benefit in 1983 from the economic recovery, gains in the sale of electronics to the Government and the burgeoning home computer business. In early 1983, some analysts were predicting profits as high as $12 a share for the year, compared with 1982 earnings of $6.10 a share.

headline: SALVADOR REBELS ISOLATE BORDER AREA
abstract: A series of bridge bombings and coordinated attacks by Salvadoran guerrillas along the Honduran border constituted one of the most destructive rebel strikes in months, according to officials and residents of the area.   Military analysts speculated that one of the assaults Friday, on Santa Rosa de Lima, the key town in northern La Union province, was part of a campaign to take enough territory so the rebel forces in La Union and neighboring Morazan province could unite, dominating the entire northeast corner of El Salvador.   If they could do so, the region would become their largest contiguous zone of free movement in the country.  Residents of the area that was attacked, which included the Salvadoran border post of El Amatillo as well as nearby Santa Rosa de Lima, said the total destruction of five of six border bridges could lead to a virtual collapse of trade between Honduras and El Salvador and the consequent decline of Santa Rosa de Lima, which has been a thriving commercial center.

headline: Miles Shifts Vitamins To Tatham-Laird
abstract: Miles Laboratories Inc., Elkhart, Ind., announced yesterday that it had shifted all of its adult vitamin advertising from J. Walter Thompson/ U.S.A., New York, to Tatham-Laird & Kudner, Chicago.

headline: Fasting Seoul Dissident Is Removed to Hospital
abstract: The opposition leader Kim Young-sam, who began a hunger strike a week ago demanding a democratic form of government in South Korea, was forcibly removed from his home today and taken to a hospital.   His wife said about 20 plainclothes policemen entered the house and demanded that the 55-year-old Mr. Kim go to a hospital.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Nutritional Management Inc., Boston, to Barnum Communications Inc.  ADVERTISING

headline: Withholding Plan by Dole
abstract: Senator Bob Dole, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said yesterday that he would try to salvage a law that would withhold taxes from interest and dividend income.   In a news conference in Manhattan, the Republican from Kansas conceded that the withholding law, scheduled to take effect July 1, would be repealed, possibly as early as this week.

headline: ** Company Reports ** CRANE CO (N)
abstract: Qtr to March 31 1983 1982 Sales 222,642,000 316,756,000 Net loss b7,120,000 c5,651,000 Share earns .55 b-Including a tax credit of $6,872,000 and a pretax gain of $14,882,000 on the sale of 800,000 common shares of Atlantic Richfield Co. c-Net income including a tax credit of $3,571,000. Year-ago results have been adjusted for a stock dividend paid in February 1983.

headline: Iran Denies Any Involvement In Bombing of U.S. Embassy
abstract: Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati of Iran was quoted as saying today that Iran was not involved in any way in the bombing that wrecked the United States Embassy in Beirut.   ''We deny any involvement and we think this allegation is another propaganda plot against us,'' the official Islamic Republic News Agency quoted Mr. Velayati as saying in a newspaper interview.   Reports from Beirut said that after the bombing Monday, an anonymous caller telephoned a French news agency and took responsibility for the blast in the name of the Islamic Jihad Organization, which is believed to be an underground group associated with Moslem Shiite fundamentalists in Lebanon to support the Iranian leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

headline: Addendum
abstract: * Modern Maturity magazine increasing its circulation rate base 4.9 percent, to 8.5 million, from 8.1 million, effective June 1.

headline: BOSS KETTERING AND INVENTIONS
abstract: Boss Kettering, by Stuart W. Leslie. Columbia University Press, New York. 382 pages, $19.95.   Patent Pending: Today's Inventors & Their Inventions, by Richard L. Gausewitz. Devin-Adair Publishers, Old Greenwich, Conn. 240 pages, $14.95.   A Handbook for Inventors by Calvin D. MacCracken. Charles Scribner's Sons, New York. 211 pages, $14.95. CHARLES KETTERING was politically naive, a woeful administrator and h is speeches were often little more than repeated exhortations to w ork hard. Yet the onetime Ohio farm boy received honorary doctorate d egrees from almost 40 universities, his serialized biography a ppeared in The Saturday Evening Post and he made the cover of Time m agazine. Long before his death in 1958, Kettering, who set up and f or many years directed the General Motors Research Corporation, was w idely recognized as the greatest America inventor and engineer sinceT homas Edison.

headline: Market Place; Some Groups Show Strength
abstract: THE Wall Street adage, ''It's not a stock market but a market of stocks,'' was borne out last week. While the Dow Jones industrial average remained virtually unchanged at 1,241.69, off 0.50 point, some stocks were kicking up their heels.   Automotive issues, strong for the second week in a row, moved ahead 6.9 percent to rank as the top-performing group, according to a computer analysis by Laszlo Birinyi of Salomon Brothers. Helping to fuel this advance was a report that new-car sales for the Big Three automobile manufacturers in the June 11-20 period soared 73 percent above the year-earlier level.

headline: POLL FINDS DOUBT OVER RESPONSES TO SOVIET THREAT
abstract: The American people tend to accept President Reagan's description of a Soviet threat but reject his strategy for meeting it, according the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.   By about 3 to 2, those interviewed saw the Soviet Union as a growing threat as well as an immediate danger. But by an even bigger margin, 2 to 1, the respondents felt that the American arms buildup would result only in a further buildup of Soviet arms and not in serious negotiations.   The public's approach to preventing nuclear war and reducing nuclear arms - by a margin of 64 percent to 25 percent, according to the poll - was to seek a mutual freeze on nuclear weapons with the Soviet Union rather than a military buildup by the United States.

headline: World Food Output Falling
abstract: World food production will fall this year after bumper grain crops last year, according to the director general of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, Edouard Saouma of Lebanon.

headline: G.M. Chairman Sees Big Profit
abstract: The chairman of the General Motors Corporation said that he anticipates the corporation will report a profit of more than $2 billion in 1983.   ''I am hopeful that we will earn a profit sufficient to share with our hourly rate employees,'' Roger B. Smith told the annual stockholders meeting.

headline: INCOME SHOWS BIG MARCH RISE
abstract: Americans' personal income rose sixtenths of 1 percent in March, the biggest gain since last fall, the Commerce Department reported today.   Economists welcomed the report as a signal that consumers would be increasing their recently sluggish spending, a rise that is crucial to the economic recovery.   In fact, personal consumption spending did increase by four-tenths of 1 percent in March after declining slightly in February, the department said. Income had risen only one-tenth of 1 percent in February.

headline: Flexi-Van Sues Former Chairman
abstract: The Flexi-Van Corporation, an international transportation-leasing company, said it had filed suit against its former chairman, David H. Murdock, and other shareholders, charging them with violations of securities law in what it called ''an unlawful plan'' to take control of the company.   Flexi-Van directors ousted Mr. Murdock as chairman last week, and said he would not be nominated for re-election to the board. Mr.  Murdock controls more than 20 percent of the company's stock.

headline: SALES OF NEW HOMES OFF 4%
abstract: Sales of new single-family houses in April fell 4 percent from the month before, the Government reported today, but the rate was still substantially higher than last year.   Prices rose to a record median level of $74,900, almost $2,000 higher than in March.

headline: LATIN WOES HURTING MIAMI
abstract: Economic downturns in Latin American countries are causing serious financial trouble for many businesses here.  Latin tourist traffic to southern Florida, once a reliable hedge against domestic recessions, is in a slump and it is unclear when an upturn may occur. Foreign investment in real estate in the area has dropped and is expected to decline further. Two international banking agencies have announced plans to close as financial transactions have diminished; others have reduced staff and hours.   Some believe the alarm is exaggerated. ''The general concern is that Florida is going down the drain with Latin America,'' said Peter Genero, chief of the Latin American Trade Office of Florida's Department of Commerce. ''There are ups and downs and things like that, but it's not catastrophic.''

headline: New Kronenbourg Ad: 'Better, Not Bitter'
abstract: Kronenbourg beer, with advertising by Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver, was available only in New York in the beginning of 1981, in New York and Boston in the beginning of 1982, and now, after an explosion in distribution, is in 24 states.   And for the first time the imported French brew is getting magazine advertising and it will be in Playboy, Penthouse and Omni, with other ads in college newspapers.   For the first two years the introductory advertising was on TV and radio with the theme ''Europeans Like Heineken but Love Kronenbourg'' The new one, Kronenbourg, better, not bitter,'' will be heard and seen on regional TV in the Northeast and on radio in New York, Boston, Chicago, San Francisco and Philadelphia.

headline: BANK ASSET RULE EXPECTED FROM FED
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board is expected to propose today that the nation's biggest banks be required to maintain their primary capital at 5 percent or more of their total assets. The proposal would come against a backdrop of increasing concern within Congress about the stability of both the nation's and the international banking system.   A bank's primary capital represents money that either belongs to shareholders or which must be converted into shareholder money. This capital represents a cushion between potential losses, on one hand, and money that belongs to depositors and other creditors, on the other.

headline: Patents; Strobe for Coronary Disease
abstract: THE Cardiac Strobe, as it is trademarked, was patented this week by Robert E. Wernikoff, a scientist at the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, who describes it as effective in the detection of coronary artery disease, a major cause of death in the United States.   Patent 4,382,184 is assigned to Cardiac Imaging, which is associated with the Cambridge Research and Development Group in Westport, Conn.

headline: 1,500 Vietnamese Troops Begin Leaving Cambodia
abstract: About 1,500 Vietnamese troops accompanied by tanks and artillery today left Phnom Penh, the Cambodian capital, for home.

headline: People
abstract: * William M. Lane has been elected an executive vice president of J. Walter Thompson USA.

headline: Federal Reserve; Wednesday, June 15, 1983
abstract: All data in millions of dollars

headline: Soviet Weighing Case Of U.S.-Soviet Couple
abstract: Soviet emigration authorities were reconsidering the application to emigrate of a Soviet man married to an American lawyer today. The re-examination came after a protest on the couple's behalf in a major hotel.

headline: On Air Fares
abstract: To the Business Editor:    Professor Paul W. MacAvoy, who is dedicated to ''deregulating'' transportation industries, would have an interesting time as a mayor responsible for the public transportation system of a large city. In ''A Plan That Won't Endure Competition'' (April 3), he attacks any attempt to set a ''standard fare level'' based on mileage because this keeps fares above costs on high-density routes. Every traveler's fare, he argues, should reflect the cost of service for that traveler.

headline: DOW GAINS 1.45
abstract: Stock prices advanced broadly yesterday as small and institutional investors alike stepped up their buying and sent volume over the 100 million mark. In the overall market, advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange outscored declining stocks by 1,010 to 675.   Analysts noted that investors apparently are convinced that the nine-month rally still has some way to go before the long-awaited correction.

headline: Guatemala Dismisses General Who Urged General Elections
abstract: The army's senior general was discharged today for having urged the military government to hold elections.

headline: U.S. FISCAL POLICY WATCHED
abstract: When Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, testifies before the House Banking Committee tomorrow, he is likely to repeat often-made statements that monetary policy alone cannot guide the economy to a sustained noninflationary recovery. Rather, the Government's decisions on spending and taxation - its fiscal policy - must also be directed to the same goals.   In the present environment, Mr. Volcker is expected to say that smaller Federal budget deficits are necessary. The need to reduce deficits and Treasury borrowings will be most acute, he could say, in coming years when the competition for loans among consumers, businesses and the Treasury is expected to heat up and put upward pressure on interest rates.

headline: Raymond International
abstract: Raymond International stockholders, at the annual meeting yesterday, approved amendments to the company charter requiring approval of 80 percent of shareholders for certain business transactions. The engineering and construction concern has been negotiating with Kelso & Company, an investment banking firm that specializes in leveraged buyouts. Raymond, which has six million shares outstanding, has been considering a plan by which its management and employees would buy out the company for $25 a share, or $150 million.

headline: STERN DOCTOR, STERN REMEDY
abstract: April 3, 1982, was perhaps the darkest day in the political life of Margaret Thatcher.  A national opinion poll published a week before reported that the British public thought she would go down as the worst Prime Minister in history. Her monetarist policies were being blamed for an unemployment rate that had almost doubled in the three years since she took office. Her constant declarations that she would halt the decline of Britain and get it back on the road to health and prosperity fell on many ears as the sound of someone trying to drown out criticism with strong but hollow words.
