Speculation About Departure   And on that Saturday in April, during an emergency meeting of the House of Commons to debate her Government's failure to recognize the threat that led to the taking of the Falkland Islands by Argentina, the lobbies of Parliment buzzed with the prospect of the Prime Minister's departure in disgrace.   In less than 75 days all that changed. The British task force that retook the Falklands also recaptured for Mrs. Thatcher a confidence that she came perilously close to losing early that spring. Now, in a surprising recovery, her Government was swept back into office today.

headline: Northwest, Sedco Extend Pogo Offer
abstract: Northwest Industries and Sedco Inc., the two companies seeking to acquire control of Pogo Producing Inc., the Houston-based energy company, said they had extended their tender offer to buy Pogo shares at $25 through midnight next Tuesday.

headline: Article 170918 -- No Title
abstract: The European Economic Community today authorized a $3.7 billion loan to France to help it with a severe balance-of-payments problem.   Finance ministers from the 10 Common Market countries authorized the loan at a brief meeting.

headline: Burglars Use Paris Sewers
abstract: Burglars entered the Malleret Company, a jewelry manufacturer, through the sewer system and stole $550,000 worth of gold jewelry, the police said today.

headline: Chrysler Debt Ratings Are Raised by S.& P.
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation's and the Chrysler Financial Corporation's senior debt ratings were raised to B from CCC by S.& P. yesterday.   While this upgrades the bond rating, it still ranks it as a speculative issue because the company ''continues to operate with a high degree of financial risk,'' according to the rating service. S.& P. said that ''questions remain about the company's long-term ability to remain competitive in the world   However, the rating was increased, S& P. said, because ''the company's recapitalization plan strengthns its balance sheet by reducing debt levels and replacing most of its preferred equity with common equity.'' S.& P. also cited Chrysler's plans to repay early $400 million of its $1.2 billion of Government guaranteed loans due in 1990 as a reason for the rating change.

headline: 8 YEARS OF TALK ON ECONOMICS
abstract: The ninth economic summit conference is being convened in Williamsburg, Va., this weekend in an atmosphere strikingly different from that in which the previous eight sessions were held.   For the first time since the meetings began in 1975, inflation is not viewed as a significant problem. And the price of energy, rather than rising, has been falling.   The deep recession of the past two years lingers, but there are hopeful signs that economic growth is reviving, at least in the United States, West Germany, Britain and Japan.   There is even basic agreement among the seven participants about the need to provide assistance to the developing countries, especially heavily indebted third-world nations.

headline: BRANIFF URGES CREDITORS TO APPROVE HYATT PLAN
abstract: Executives of Braniff International are pushing to persuade secured creditors to go along with a $70 million proposal by the Hyatt Corporation to restart part of the airline.   The secured creditors are expected to be the major obstacle to the proposal. In a meeting last Tuesday with Jay Pritzker, Hyatt's chairman, they questioned the viability of a $70 million plan that he presented. Sources from the creditors said the $70 million Hyatt proposal that Braniff approved Thursday did not differ much from a plan outlined to the steering committee of the secured creditors.

headline: Economic Scene; If the Japanese Shifted to Coal
abstract: TOKYO THE Japanese economy, while still the pacesetter among the major industrialized nations, is boxed in. The roads to future growth seem blocked. Restraints in various guises already curb the flow of more than half of its exports. Because the Government is worried about large budget deficits, fiscal austerity is the order of the day.   With the yen weak and ever-present complaints from trading partners, stimulating the economy by reducing interest rates is difficult since it would soften the yen further, making Japanese exports cheaper in foreign markets.

headline: ** Company Reports ** JOY MANUFACTURING CO (N)
Royal Plans to Sell Its Banks in Florida
abstract: Royal Trustco Ltd. of Canada said today that it would sell its Florida banking operations to Florida National Banks of Jacksonville for $80 million.   Toronto-based Royal Trustco, the seventh-largest financial institution in Canada, owns 35 offices in seven Florida counties with combined assets of $902 million.

headline: Kurdish Rebels Report They Killed 70 Iraqis
abstract: Kurdish rebels in northern Iraq fought off a large-scale assault on their base area at Shene on Friday, killing 70 Iraqi soldiers and shooting down a helicopter gunship, a spokesman for the rebels said in London tonight.   A statement issued by the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan said the Kurds had wiped out an Iraqi commando unit that landed by helicopter on the summit of Manende Mountain, which overlooks the Qala Diza area. No rebels were killed in the battle, the statement said.

headline: IN PAKISTAN, AN AFGHAN PEEPHOLE
abstract: For centuries, travelers on their way to India from Afghanistan, Persia and points beyond have stopped in this rough-cut frontier outpost lying astride ancient routes of trade and conquest that snake through the Khyber Pass, 25 miles west of here on the Afghan border. And for centuries they have gravitated to the street of the storytellers in the Old City's main bazaar to swap tales, both true and fanciful, about faraway places and events.   Today Peshawar has become a different sort of information exchange. The traders and travelers still come from beyond the Khyber Pass, but these days they are overwhelmingly outnumbered by another group of tale-tellers, the thousands of Afghan refugees, defectors, exiles, rebel political leaders and guerrilla commanders who have flooded across the border and into town in the three and a half years since Soviet troops entered Afghanistan.

headline: Volcker Plan to Curb Bank Mergers
abstract: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve, citing ''dangers to the financial system,'' has sent to Congress a proposal for legislation to slow the blending of banks and other types of businesses.   The recommendations, which expand on comments Mr. Volcker made to the Senate Banking Committee in April, are spelled out in a letter to the committee's chairman, Jake Garn, Republican of Utah.

headline: A.M.C. Contracts
abstract: A subsidiary of the American Motors Corporation received three Army contracts totaling $308.2 milllion, the Defense Department said. The contracts, for five-ton trucks, were given to A.M.C.'s AM General Corporation unit.

headline: Salvador Prelate Asks Punishment for Killers
abstract: Archbishop Arturo Rivera Damas demanded today that the murderers of thousands of Salvadorans killed in the nation's civil strife be brought to justice.   In an outspoken homily, the Archbishop said 114 people were killed in last week's violence and 30,000 had died in the four-year civil war, in which Governnment forces, backed by the United States, are fighting leftist guerrillas.   ''Curiously, in the cases of North American citizens, elements belonging to the security forces have been detained, while in the cases of thousands of assassinated Salvadorans, very rarely has justice been done,'' Archbishop Rivera Damas said. ''Where are the perpetrators of these crimes?''

headline: Lima Rocked by Explosions
abstract: At least 10 explosions rocked Lima Friday night and two homemade bombs were defused close to the presidential palace, the police said.

headline: SWISS PONDER FUTURE STATUS OF 8 RUSSIANS
abstract: Eight Soviet soldiers captured by Afghan guerrillas are serving two years of internment in the relatively pleasant surroundings of a minimum-security detention center in the foothills of the Alps.   The question of what to do with the Soviet soldiers when the two years are up has already touched off a dispute.  In Switzerland, political passions run high over such things as how many trees can be cut down to build a highway or how much force is justifiable in evicting illegal squatters from tenements.   The prisoners - seven privates and a sergeant - came here in May 1982 under a program arranged by the International Committee of the Red Cross. The program is based loosely on an article of the 1949 Geneva Convention that allows internment of prisoners of war in a neutral country if the two warring countries agree.

headline: RAYMOND IN TALKS ON A BUYOUT PLAN
abstract: Raymond International Inc., a big international construction and engineering company based in Houston, said yesterday that it was considering a leveraged buyout by its management and employees.   Raymond has some 6 million shares outstanding.

headline: PERU'S LEADER UNHURT IN SHOOTING
abstract: A guard accidentally fired his submachine gun into a crowd around President Fernando Belaunde Terry in the port city of Callao today, wounding three people, the Government said.  President Belaunde was unhurt.   The President's office and the police said there had not been an attempt to assassinate Mr. Belaunde. Some news accounts and witnesses said a woman dressed in black had called the President an assassin and shouted to the crowd, ''Kill him!''

headline: PRETORIA SLOWS TRAFFIC TO LESOTHO IN A RETALIATORY MOVE OVER REBELS
abstract: By slowing down traffic at its main border post with landlocked Lesotho, South Africa showed today that its arsenal of retaliatory measures against neighboring nations that harbor personnel of the underground African National Congress includes economic as well as military weapons.   A spokesman for the South African police said the border post at the end of a narrow railway bridge over the Caledon River that is impoverished Lesotho's main link to the outside world would close four hours early this evening on account of ''manpower problems.''   A diplomat in Maseru, the Lesotho capital, which lies on the other side of the river, said rumors were sweeping the town that South Africa planned to close the border entirely for the weekend.   The slowdown appears to have started Thursday afternoon, even before a relatively powerful bomb exploded under a car in Bloemfontein, a South African city that is 80 miles from Maseru. No one was injured in the blast, but it was the first explosion in a downtown urban area since last Friday's car-bomb explosion in Pretoria that killed 18 people and wounded 188.

headline: European Talks Delayed
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany said today that a meeting of the Common Market planned in Stuttgart for June 6 and 7 had been postponed until after the British elections on June 9. He said it would now be held June 17 to 19.  Speaking to reporters after talks with President Francois Mitterrand, Mr. Kohl said he had made the decision after consulting with other Western European leaders.

headline: THE TURMOIL AT AMERICAN BELL
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's new subsidiary, American Bell, is in a state of turmoil after only five months of operation. Developments today and Monday point to a scramble within American Bell to reduce costs and to eliminate troubling organizational problems that could retard its movement into new businesses.   Today, A.T.& .T announced the resignation of Archie J. McGill, president of American Bell's Advanced Information Systems division, which sells equipment and computer services to business customers.  The resignation followed by a day a reorganization involving the other division of American Bell, the consumer products unit.

headline: HIGH-TECH STOCKS: A REAL PUZZLER
abstract: Right before your eyes,'' says a Prudential-Bache ad on hightechnology stocks, ''our industrial society has been changing to an information society.''   So in the stock market, it would seem obvious to be in the technology group. But are the stocks a good investment? Some opinion on Wall Street is that the group has ridden the bull market too far and too fast.   Barton M. Biggs, chief investment strategist for Morgan Stanley & Company, wrote recently of a ''science technology craze,'' adding that ''there are a few incipient signs of a world class bubble in the blowing.'' In his view, ''Investors should know that they are buying stocks, not companies. Companies keep growing but the stocks can get overpriced.''

headline: Market Place; Investors' Fear Of Labor Party
abstract: WITH just two and a half weeks left before Britain's June 9 general election, the City of London - the country's financial community - is growing steadily more confident that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and the Conservative Party will stay in power. Prices on the London Stock Exchange have risen, the pound has been strong and bond prices have been steady for the last week as jitters about a possible Labor Party victory have receded.   Polls show support for the Labor Party edging upward but largely at the expense of the alliance of the Liberal Party and the Social Democratic Party. The Conservative margin over Labor remains 7 percent or more.

headline: U.S. AND CANADIANS TO REVIEW RELATIONS
abstract: When Allan J. MacEachen, Canada's Foreign Minister, begins two days of talks with Secretary of State George P.  Shultz in Washington on Monday, the mood will be much balmier than when the two leaders first agreed seven months ago to hold quarterly reviews of the relationship between the two countries.   ''There's no doubt about it, it has been basically a success story,'' said Paul H. Robinson Jr., the United States Ambassador to Canada, who cited recent easing of Canadian restrictions on foreign investments and new arrangements on East Coast fishing as proof that ''the relationship has demonstrably improved since George Shultz took over.'' Nowhere to Go   An official of Canada's Ministry of External Affairs who is directly involved in the day-to-day administration of relations concurred with Mr. Robinson's assessment. But he noted that three years ago the relationship was probably at its lowest point since the War of 1812, and that it had nowhere to go but up.

headline: CHINA TO LET SEOUL TRY HIJACKERS IN RETURN FOR JET AND PASSENGERS
abstract: China agreed today to let South Korea try six hijackers who seized a Chinese passenger plane last week and forced it to fly to South Korea, an official announcement said.   In a four-point agreement, the two countries also agreed on the return of the jetliner, its passengers and crew, the announcement said.   The six hijackers, five men and a woman, seized the Chinese staterun airline's British-made Trident jet Thursday on a domestic flight from Shenyang in Manchuria to Shanghai. They shot and wounded two crew members and demanded to be flown to Taiwan, according to officials here. But the pilot flew over North Korean air space and was forced to land at a United States military base north of Seoul.

headline: CABLE CATALYST: JANE DEKNATEL THE IN-HOUSE MOVIE MAKER AT HBO
abstract: JANE DEKNATEL is under siege, Hollywood-style. Her modest Century City office in central Los A ngeles is bombarded by scripts and movie ideas from producers and w ould-be producers. She ''takes'' endless meetings, interrupting themf or telephone calls from the other coast, Europe and Australia.   The reason for Mrs. Deknatel's popularity is that she has some $85 million to spend next year on a new category of entertainment: the made-for-pay-TV movie.   Mrs. Deknatel is the 40-year-old vice president of made-for-pay motion pictures at Home Box Office, which, with 12 million subscribers, is the largest single cable channel and the most aggressive new force in entertainment. Established in 1981, HBO Premiere Films, as the new venture is called, has already underwritten a handful of movies.

headline: Holiday Closings
abstract: Stock markets were closed for Ascension Day yesterday in Zurich, Brussels, Frankfurt, Amsterdam, Johannesburg and Paris. Tables for those exchanges do not appear in today's paper.

headline: Chock Full Shareholders
abstract: J. Patrick Lannan, a 77-year-old former top executive of the ITT Corporation, was named yesterday as a member of a new Chock Full o'Nuts shareholders' committee that said it represents 875,100 shares, or 17.5 percent of the company's stock. A previous committee was headed by Jerry Finkelstein, 67, a New York businessman.

headline: U.S. REPORT SAID TO ACCUSE SOVIET ON ARMS TREATY
abstract: An interagency task force is close to sending President Reagan a report that finds the Soviet Union guilty of violating the 1979 strategic arms limitation treaty with recent missile tests, White House officials said Friday.   Should the President and his National Security Council endorse the findings, officials said the interagency group had prepared several American responses, ranging from private diplomatic protests to the Soviet Union, having the President present the charges and evidence publicly, or even declaring that the Reagan Administration no longer feels bound to observe the treaty.   Some officials said President Reagan may make a speech or issue a statement on purported Soviet treaty violations, making a missile test on Feb. 8 the centerpiece. But it would deal as well with American suspicions that Moscow has also violated treaties imposing limits on underground nuclear testing and possibly even the antiballistic missile treaty of 1972.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: Until the car-bomb explosion Friday in the heart of Pretoria, the occasional death of a bystander from underground violence nearly always seemed to result from miscalculation.   But the Pretoria blast, which killed 17 people and wounded 188 outside air force headquarters there, introduced a form of violence that has been to some extent grimly expected and often theorized about but never before experienced in South Africa.   An unofficial tabulation of acts of sabotage attributed in recent years to the underground military arm of the African National Congress, which seems to have tacitly accepted responsibility for the Pretoria bombing, puts the latest explosion in stunning perspective.  It appears to have been the 88th known sabotage attack since the start of 1981 and it did more damage than all the previous 87 together.

headline: ** Company Reports ** FIDELCOR INC (O)
abstract: Qtr to March 31 1983 1982 Op earn 19,572,000 6,340,000 Per share 3.78 1.24 Net inc b20,247,000 6,340,000 Per share 3.91 1.24 b-Includes an extraordinary creditof $675,000 and a one-time gain of $11.1million on the sale of the FidelityBuilding Corp.

headline: PAINE AIDE POSED AS LAWYER
abstract: Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis Inc. has been fined $1,000 and cited for contempt of court because the vice president in charge of the firm's litigation department - a law school graduate who failed the bar examination in 1969 and never took it again - falsely held himself out as a lawyer.   At a pretrial deposition in a lawsuit involving a claim against the firm brought by a former Paine, Webber employee in California, the Paine, Webber vice president, Timothy E. Longworth, testified under oath that he was a member of the bar. The testimony is reported in next week's issue of The National Law Journal,   United States District Judge Edward Rafeedie of Los Angeles, who heard the case, imposed the fine and the contempt citation last month, and also ordered Paine, Webber to notify its corporate and outside counsel in all pending litigation begun since 1979 that Mr.  Longworth was not a lawyer.

headline: Japan Deports Chinese After U.S. Bars Asylum
abstract: Japan has deported a Chinese interpreter because the United States rejected her plea for political asylum, Japanese newspapers reported today.   Japan never accepts defectors, but the Government usually allows them to be received by a third country.

headline: GREEK BID TO COMMON MARKET
abstract: Two years after Greece became the European Economic Community's 10th member, the Socialist Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou is asking the community's partners for huge sums of money as an incentive not to quit the organization, despite Mr.  Papandreou's campaign promise to pull out.   In response, the executive commission of the Brussels-based Common Market has already suggested giving Greece an extra $1.6 billion in special aid to strengthen its economy over the next five years. And other member states are likely to accede to the demands for more money as well.   In part, the strategy of Mr. Papandreou's Government is a reflection of the far-reaching poverty in Greece, where the annual average income is just $4,000 a person, the lowest in the Common Market. But it is also an effort by Mr. Papandreou and his followers, analysts say, to wriggle out of one of their more radical commitments without losing political face.

headline: WHITE HOUSE CRITICIZES SENATE'S 1984 BUDGET
abstract: The White House today criticized as ''off target'' the Senate's newly passed bipartisan budget for 1984, which calls for tax increases President Reagan considers too high.   At the same time, the Senate's chief tax writer, Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, predicted that Congress would refuse to vote taxes as high as those recommended by the Senate.   Adopted shortly before midnight Thursday by a vote of 50 to 49, the budget calls for tax increases of $9 billion in the fiscal year 1984, $13 billion in 1985 and $51 billion in 1986. It also proposes $849.7 billion in spending and a deficit of $178.6 billion for 1984.

headline: I.M.F. View On Economy
abstract: The International Monetary Fund has issued its most optimistic economic forecast in recent years, but said that huge budget deficits in the United States threatened recovery in that country and elsewhere.   The fund, in its annual world economic outlook released Tuesday, said the budget deficits, expected to reach about $200 billion this year and continue to be high in subsequent years, were among the most critical issues confronting the world's economy.

headline: Rhone-Poulenc Outlay
abstract: Rhone-Poulenc S.A., the Government-owned chemical maker, plans to spend 500 million francs, or the equivalent of about $67 million, to make an advanced polyester film used in the video cassette industry, a spokesman said Friday. The outlay, which represents almost a quarter of the company's investment budget for 1983, will be used to modernize a plant at Saint-Maurice-de-Beynost and to increase film production to 24,000 tons a year from 14,000.  The film, terphane, is also used in packing and graphic arts.

headline: D'Arcy Aide to Handle Business Development
abstract: Hal Bay, chairman and chief executive of D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius, announced yesterday that, just as he promised he would, he is moving the first international executive into New York headquarters to strengthen that office.   The person is Alan Pilkington, chairman of D'Arcy Australasia and the Far East, who is moving from Sydney to New York, where, in addition to attending to his old duties, he will also direct strategic business development. D'Arcy, by the way, is beginning its four-day worldwide management conference at the Plaza Hotel on Monday.

headline: COMPUTER MAKER'S FAST START
abstract: In many respects the Compaq Computer Corporation, an 18-month-old company based in Houston, is a symbol of the personal computer industry of the 1980's.   Like many new computer companies, it was started by a small group of defectors from a larger manufacturer, Texas Instruments. On the strength of a prototype and an idea, the company's founders quickly assembled $30 million in venture capital. And, as often happens, their former employer has taken them to court, charging them with raiding the company and infringing its patents.

headline: SOVIET SAID TO REJECT NEW OFFER ON NATO MISSILES
abstract: A senior official of the Reagan Administration said today that the Soviet Union had rejected what he portrayed as new and flexible interim proposals by the United States at the Geneva talks to limit medium-range missiles in Europe.   The official, who is involved in the talks, said that since the latest Geneva session resumed on May 17 the Reagan Administration had authorized its chief negotiator, Paul H. Nitze, to explore Soviet willingness to accept parity in medium-range warheads at a level between zero and 450.   The maximum figure is lower than the 572 Pershing 2 and cruise missiles that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization plans to start deploying in Western Europe at the end of the year if agreement is not reached in Geneva. The official said the American proposals above the zero level included a mixture of Pershing 2's, which will be deployed only in West Germany, and cruise missiles.

headline: LEADER OF TEXTRON UNIT NAMED WATERBURY CHIEF
abstract: An expert in the field of industrial fasteners has been named president and chief executive of the Waterbury Companies, a leading manufacturer of buttons based in Waterbury, Conn.   The executive, Michael J. Tragakiss, joined Waterbury last week after 10 years at Textron Inc., the conglomerate based in Providence, R.I. Mr. Tragakiss, 50 years old, replaces L.P. Sperry Jr., who will remain as chairman of Waterbury until he retires.   In its nearly 175 years of existence, the company's button group has become one of the largest such companies in the nation. In a telephone interview, however, Mr. Tragakiss said he plans to expand the company's business into gift buttons and mail orders, as well as overseas.

headline: SWEDES RANKLED BY TAXES
abstract: The more that Swedes think about their Government's latest efforts to prop up their welfare state by raising taxes, the less they like it.   They went along with December's increase of two percentage points in the value added tax, making a total charge of 23.46 percent on most of the things consumers buy. They also grudgingly accepted large increases in inheritance taxes, a rise in payroll taxes paid by employers, special taxes on video equipment and a proposed cut in tax concessions for stockholders.   But their irritation boiled over with a new law intended to help the Social Democratic administration collect income taxes from a vast army of part-time workers. These are Swedes who do repair and service work on a barter basis or for cash. This ''gray'' area of the economy has provided savings for consumers and extra income - none of it reported - for the moonlighting workers.

headline: SPENDING IN GILDED STYLE
abstract: ANTHONY V. MILONE got an expensive new suit when he became vice p resident of a new medical products company in Tuckahoe, N.Y., last y ear. He also got an American Express Gold Card.   ''We're a small company,'' he said. ''But it pays to make the client think you're doing better than you really are. If your shoes are shiny, and you dress well, it can help. And if at the end of a luncheon you pull out a Gold Card, that's one more thing. People want to be associated with success.''   Jean Meger, a businesswoman in Anaheim, Calif., takes that strategy a step further. She places her Gold Card or her Visa Preferred card discreetly on the table before she orders at a restaurant, and leaves it there during the meal. ''You get better service,'' she said. ''And if you want to impress someone, it's a nice flash.''

headline: ** Company Reports ** FRASER INC
abstract: Qtr to March 31 1983 1982 Sales 97,000,000 102,700,000 Net inc b1,681,000 143,000 Share earns .19 .02 b-Including a gain of $900,000 on thesale of investments.

headline: PAYMENTS DEFICIT NARROWS
abstract: A big drop in oil imports helped narrow the deficit in the United States balance of payments to $3.05 billion in the first quarter, the Commerce Department said today.   But Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said he expects a deficit of more than $20 billion for all of 1983.  The report said the three-month deficit in the broadest measure of foreign trade - the current account of payments for merchandise, services and financial investments - was less than half the record $6.6 billion posted in the final quarter of 1982. Today's report revised earlier Commerce Department estimates showing deficits of $6.1 billion for the fourth quarter and $8.1 billion for all of last year.

headline: TOP OFFICERS SHIFT AT CORNING GLASS
abstract: The Corning Glass Works yesterday announced a major realignment of its management and a shift of the posts of chairman and chief executive officer from one Houghton brother to another.   The Houghton family founded the company at Corning, N.Y., 132 years ago.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand
abstract: Ingersoll-Rand, which manufactures air compressors and other industrial machinery, will close its foundry for a week, laying off 135 employees, because of slumping orders, company officials said.

headline: Law Aids Seafirst
abstract: Gov. John Spellman signed legislation today that allows banks from out of state to buy Washington banks.  The new law would facilitate plans by the BankAmerica Corporation to buy the Seafirst Corporation for $400 million.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Chrysler Offers New Rebate Plan
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation announced that it would offer rebates ranging up to $750 and the lowest car financing rate in the auto industry, 8.7 percent, starting this weekend.

headline: ARA to Buy Solon For $100 Million
abstract: Solon Automated Services Inc. and ARA Services Inc. announced an agreement for ARA to acquire Solon for $100 million in cash and notes.

headline: 3 TEXANS END BID FOR BUTCHER UNIT
abstract: Three Texas investors have withdrawn their offer to buy C.H. Butcher Jr.'s troubled Southern Industrial Banking Corporation, their lawyer said today. Jack Bailey, a Nashville attorney representing the Texans, said the offer was withdrawn because it had not been accepted by a Monday deadline they had set.

headline: Bulgaria Asserts Turk Has Not Left Country
abstract: A Turk wanted in connection with the assassination attempt on Pope John Paul II is in Bulgaria under police surveillance and has not left the country as was reported in Italy, the Bulgarian press agency said today.   ''Bekir Celenk is under control of the respective Bulgarian authorities and is to be available to the investigation agencies,'' the agency said in a report from Sofia, the Bulgarian capital.

headline: 2 P.L.O. FACTIONS CLASH IN LEBANON IN HEAVY FIGHTING
abstract: Heavy fighting broke out today for the first time between Palestinian guerrilla factions in eastern Lebanon.  The violence grows out of a continuing rebellion by some Palestine Liberation Organization units whose members are opposed to Yasir Arafat's leadership. Mr. Arafat himself was out of the country at the time, having left for a visit to Rumania Friday after a daylong vister, he flew to Algeria for a two-hour meeting with President Chadli Benjedid, United Press International reported.)   Lebanese police officials said 7 people were killed and 18 wounded when rival factions within Al Fatah, the main guerrilla group, battled each other with artillery, rockets and heavy machine-gun fire a few miles west of the ancient town of Baalbek. Area Blocked Off by Syrians   The officials said the clashes lasted 90 minutes, after which the intensity of the fighting eased. Syrian troops, who control the Bekaa region, a valley where about 6,000 Palestinian guerrillas are entrenched, blocked off roads leading to the scene of the violence but did not intervene, the officials said.

headline: ARAFAT LOYALISTS RETREAT IN BEKAA UNDER PRESSURE FROM REBEL FORCES
abstract: Guerrillas loyal to Yasir Arafat are retreating northward from the central Bekaa under pressure from rebels opposed to the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization.   Mr. Arafat's supporters, who are being cut off from all ammunition and supplies by Syrian troops in the valley, have virtually disappeared from Shtaura, a strategic junction town on the Beirut-Damascus highway in the heart of the Bekaa.   A week ago reporters driving through Shtaura found several buildings bristling with teen-age Arafat loyalists brandishing their Kalashinovs and bedecked with bandoleers.  Red graffiti painted on the walls of their outposts said, ''With Arafat until Death.'' Today only the graffiti remained.

headline: GAF Session Ends
abstract: The annual meeting of GAF shareholders in New York reconvened for a short time yesterday and was adjourned until May 23, pending a count in the proxy battle for control of the company. The meeting had previously been adjourned until April 28. GAF has asked for more time to determine whether a dissident shareholder, Samuel Heyman, has title to his GAF shares.

headline: ISLAM, AFTER PERSECUTIONS, REBOUNDS IN CHINA
abstract: From a slender minaret of the Id Kah Mosque, a loudspeaker summoned the faithful to evening prayer.  A street vendor removed his cloth shoes, knelt on a piece of cardboard under a poplar tree and pressed his forehead to the ground in the southwestward direction of Mecca. Inside the rambling mosque in this heavily Moslem city in western China, a row of other worshipers facing the whitewashed wall took up the affirmation of God's greatness - ''Allah akhbar!''   Daily prayer, one of the five pillars of the Moslem faith, goes on today in the world's most populous atheistic country. After harsh but ultimately unsuccessful persecution by Maoist radicals, the authorities have allowed Islam to flourish and become China's most active religion. 13 Million Moslems   Statistics from last year's nationwide census indicated that China has about 13 million ethnic Moslems, more than the combined populations of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates.  Unofficial estimates put the number closer to 20 million.

headline: Reagan Selects an Envoy
abstract: President Reagan announced today that he would nominate Robert Keating, a consultant to the general counsel's office at the Navy Department, to be Ambassador to Madagascar and the Comoro Islands.

headline: CHILEAN UNION CHIEF FREED AS GENERAL STRIKE NEARS
abstract: A magistrate has ordered the release on bail of the leader of Chile's truck owners, whose union is one of those that has called a general strike against the military Government for Thursday.   The truck owner's lawyer, Hernan de la Maza, said Adolfo Quinteros Soto, who was detained Tuesday, was charged with breaking internal security laws but released on $10 bail after being questioned for more than three hours.

headline: Turkish President Warns Voting Could Be Delayed
abstract: Turkey's military President, apparently trying to discourage activities by former political leaders, warned today that elections scheduled for next November might be delayed.
